children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: On the 20th of August, 1672, the city of the Hague, always so lively, so neat, and so trim that one might believe every day to be Sunday, with its shady park, with its tall trees, spreading over its Gothic houses, with its canals like large mirrors, in which its steeples and its almost Eastern cupolas are reflected,the city of the Hague, the capital of the Seven United Provinces, was swelling in all its arteries with a black and red stream of hurried, panting, and restless citizens, who, with their knives in their girdles, muskets on their shoulders, or sticks in their hands, were pushing on to the Buytenhof, a terrible prison, the grated windows of which are still shown, where, on the charge of attempted murder preferred against him by the surgeon Tyckelaer, Cornelius de Witt, the brother of the Grand Pensionary of Holland was confined.
children.prevalue: On the 20th of August 1672 the city of the Hague always so lively so neat and so trim that one might believe every day to be Sunday with its shady park with its tall trees spreading over its Gothic houses with its canals like large mirrors in which its steeples and its almost Eastern cupolas are reflected the city of the Hague the capital of the Seven United Provinces was swelling in all its arteries with a black and red stream of hurried panting and restless citizens who with their knives in their girdles muskets on their shoulders or sticks in their hands were pushing on to the Buytenhof a terrible prison the grated windows of which are still shown where on the charge of attempted murder preferred against him by the surgeon Tyckelaer Cornelius de Witt the brother of the Grand Pensionary of Holland was confined

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: If the history of that time, and especially that of the year in the middle of which our narrative commences, were not indissolubly connected with the two names just mentioned, the few explanatory pages which we are about to add might appear quite supererogatory; but we will, from the very first, apprise the readerour old friend, to whom we are wont on the first page to promise amusement, and with whom we always try to keep our word as well as is in our powerthat this explanation is as indispensable to the right understanding of our story as to that of the great event itself on which it is based.
children.prevalue: If the history of that time and especially that of the year in the middle of which our narrative commences were not indissolubly connected with the two names just mentioned the few explanatory pages which we are about to add might appear quite supererogatory but we will from the very first apprise the readerour old friend to whom we are wont on the first page to promise amusement and with whom we always try to keep our word as well as is in our powerthat this explanation is as indispensable to the right understanding of our story as to that of the great event itself on which it is based

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Cornelius de Witt, Ruart de Pulten, that is to say, warden of the dikes, exburgomaster of Dort, his native town, and member of the Assembly of the States of Holland, was fortynine years of age, when the Dutch people, tired of the Republic such as John de Witt, the Grand Pensionary of Holland, understood it, at once conceived a most violent affection for the Stadtholderate, which had been abolished for ever in Holland by the Perpetual Edict forced by John de Witt upon the United Provinces.
children.prevalue: Cornelius de Witt Ruart de Pulten that is to say warden of the dikes exburgomaster of Dort his native town and member of the Assembly of the States of Holland was fortynine years of age when the Dutch people tired of the Republic such as John de Witt the Grand Pensionary of Holland understood it at once conceived a most violent affection for the Stadtholderate which had been abolished for ever in Holland by the Perpetual Edict forced by John de Witt upon the United Provinces

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: As it rarely happens that public opinion, in its whimsical flights, does not identify a principle with a man, thus the people saw the personification of the Republic in the two stern figures of the brothers De Witt, those Romans of Holland, spurning to pander to the fancies of the mob, and wedding themselves with unbending fidelity to liberty without licentiousness, and prosperity without the waste of superfluity; on the other hand, the Stadtholderate recalled to the popular mind the grave and thoughtful image of the young Prince William of Orange.
children.prevalue: As it rarely happens that public opinion in its whimsical flights does not identify a principle with a man thus the people saw the personification of the Republic in the two stern figures of the brothers De Witt those Romans of Holland spurning to pander to the fancies of the mob and wedding themselves with unbending fidelity to liberty without licentiousness and prosperity without the waste of superfluity on the other hand the Stadtholderate recalled to the popular mind the grave and thoughtful image of the young Prince William of Orange

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The brothers De Witt humoured Louis XIV., whose moral influence was felt by the whole of Europe, and the pressure of whose material power Holland had been made to feel in that marvellous campaign on the Rhine, which, in the space of three months, had laid the power of the United Provinces prostrate.
children.prevalue: The brothers De Witt humoured Louis XIV whose moral influence was felt by the whole of Europe and the pressure of whose material power Holland had been made to feel in that marvellous campaign on the Rhine which in the space of three months had laid the power of the United Provinces prostrate

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Louis XIV. had long been the enemy of the Dutch, who insulted or ridiculed him to their hearts' content, although it must be said that they generally used French refugees for the mouthpiece of their spite. Their national pride held him up as the Mithridates of the Republic. The brothers De Witt, therefore, had to strive against a double difficulty,against the force of national antipathy, and, besides, against the feeling of weariness which is natural to all vanquished people, when they hope that a new chief will be able to save them from ruin and shame.
children.prevalue: Louis XIV had long been the enemy of the Dutch who insulted or ridiculed him to their hearts content although it must be said that they generally used French refugees for the mouthpiece of their spite Their national pride held him up as the Mithridates of the Republic The brothers De Witt therefore had to strive against a double difficulty against the force of national antipathy and besides against the feeling of weariness which is natural to all vanquished people when they hope that a new chief will be able to save them from ruin and shame

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: This new chief, quite ready to appear on the political stage, and to measure himself against Louis XIV., however gigantic the fortunes of the Grand Monarch loomed in the future, was William, Prince of Orange, son of William II., and grandson, by his mother Henrietta Stuart, of Charles I. of England. We have mentioned him before as the person by whom the people expected to see the office of Stadtholder restored.
children.prevalue: This new chief quite ready to appear on the political stage and to measure himself against Louis XIV however gigantic the fortunes of the Grand Monarch loomed in the future was William Prince of Orange son of William II and grandson by his mother Henrietta Stuart of Charles I of England We have mentioned him before as the person by whom the people expected to see the office of Stadtholder restored

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: This young man was, in 1672, twentytwo years of age. John de Witt, who was his tutor, had brought him up with the view of making him a good citizen. Loving his country better than he did his disciple, the master had, by the Perpetual Edict, extinguished the hope which the young Prince might have entertained of one day becoming Stadtholder. But God laughs at the presumption of man, who wants to raise and prostrate the powers on earth without consulting the King above; and the fickleness and caprice of the Dutch combined with the terror inspired by Louis XIV., in repealing the Perpetual Edict, and reestablishing the office of Stadtholder in favour of William of Orange, for whom the hand of Providence had traced out ulterior destinies on the hidden map of the future.
children.prevalue: This young man was in 1672 twentytwo years of age John de Witt who was his tutor had brought him up with the view of making him a good citizen Loving his country better than he did his disciple the master had by the Perpetual Edict extinguished the hope which the young Prince might have entertained of one day becoming Stadtholder But God laughs at the presumption of man who wants to raise and prostrate the powers on earth without consulting the King above and the fickleness and caprice of the Dutch combined with the terror inspired by Louis XIV in repealing the Perpetual Edict and reestablishing the office of Stadtholder in favour of William of Orange for whom the hand of Providence had traced out ulterior destinies on the hidden map of the future

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The Grand Pensionary bowed before the will of his fellow citizens; Cornelius de Witt, however, was more obstinate, and notwithstanding all the threats of death from the Orangist rabble, who besieged him in his house at Dort, he stoutly refused to sign the act by which the office of Stadtholder was restored. Moved by the tears and entreaties of his wife, he at last complied, only adding to his signature the two letters V. C. (Vi Coactus), notifying thereby that he only yielded to force.
children.prevalue: The Grand Pensionary bowed before the will of his fellow citizens Cornelius de Witt however was more obstinate and notwithstanding all the threats of death from the Orangist rabble who besieged him in his house at Dort he stoutly refused to sign the act by which the office of Stadtholder was restored Moved by the tears and entreaties of his wife he at last complied only adding to his signature the two letters V C Vi Coactus notifying thereby that he only yielded to force

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: It was a real miracle that on that day he escaped from the doom intended for him.
children.prevalue: It was a real miracle that on that day he escaped from the doom intended for him

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: John de Witt derived no advantage from his ready compliance with the wishes of his fellow citizens. Only a few days after, an attempt was made to stab him, in which he was severely although not mortally wounded.
children.prevalue: John de Witt derived no advantage from his ready compliance with the wishes of his fellow citizens Only a few days after an attempt was made to stab him in which he was severely although not mortally wounded

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: This by no means suited the views of the Orange faction. The life of the two brothers being a constant obstacle to their plans, they changed their tactics, and tried to obtain by calumny what they had not been able to effect by the aid of the poniard.
children.prevalue: This by no means suited the views of the Orange faction The life of the two brothers being a constant obstacle to their plans they changed their tactics and tried to obtain by calumny what they had not been able to effect by the aid of the poniard

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: How rarely does it happen that, in the right moment, a great man is found to head the execution of vast and noble designs; and for that reason, when such a providential concurrence of circumstances does occur, history is prompt to record the name of the chosen one, and to hold him up to the admiration of posterity. But when Satan interposes in human affairs to cast a shadow upon some happy existence, or to overthrow a kingdom, it seldom happens that he does not find at his side some miserable tool, in whose ear he has but to whisper a word to set him at once about his task.
children.prevalue: How rarely does it happen that in the right moment a great man is found to head the execution of vast and noble designs and for that reason when such a providential concurrence of circumstances does occur history is prompt to record the name of the chosen one and to hold him up to the admiration of posterity But when Satan interposes in human affairs to cast a shadow upon some happy existence or to overthrow a kingdom it seldom happens that he does not find at his side some miserable tool in whose ear he has but to whisper a word to set him at once about his task

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The wretched tool who was at hand to be the agent of this dastardly plot was one Tyckelaer whom we have already mentioned, a surgeon by profession.
children.prevalue: The wretched tool who was at hand to be the agent of this dastardly plot was one Tyckelaer whom we have already mentioned a surgeon by profession

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: He lodged an information against Cornelius de Witt, setting forth that the wardenwho, as he had shown by the letters added to his signature, was fuming at the repeal of the Perpetual Edicthad, from hatred against William of Orange, hired an assassin to deliver the new Republic of its new Stadtholder; and he, Tyckelaer was the person thus chosen; but that, horrified at the bare idea of the act which he was asked to perpetrate, he had preferred rather to reveal the crime than to commit it.
children.prevalue: He lodged an information against Cornelius de Witt setting forth that the wardenwho as he had shown by the letters added to his signature was fuming at the repeal of the Perpetual Edicthad from hatred against William of Orange hired an assassin to deliver the new Republic of its new Stadtholder and he Tyckelaer was the person thus chosen but that horrified at the bare idea of the act which he was asked to perpetrate he had preferred rather to reveal the crime than to commit it

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: This disclosure was, indeed, well calculated to call forth a furious outbreak among the Orange faction. The Attorney General caused, on the 16th of August, 1672, Cornelius de Witt to be arrested; and the noble brother of John de Witt had, like the vilest criminal, to undergo, in one of the apartments of the town prison, the preparatory degrees of torture, by means of which his judges expected to force from him the confession of his alleged plot against William of Orange.
children.prevalue: This disclosure was indeed well calculated to call forth a furious outbreak among the Orange faction The Attorney General caused on the 16th of August 1672 Cornelius de Witt to be arrested and the noble brother of John de Witt had like the vilest criminal to undergo in one of the apartments of the town prison the preparatory degrees of torture by means of which his judges expected to force from him the confession of his alleged plot against William of Orange

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: But Cornelius was not only possessed of a great mind, but also of a great heart. He belonged to that race of martyrs who, indissolubly wedded to their political convictions as their ancestors were to their faith, are able to smile on pain: while being stretched on the rack, he recited with a firm voice, and scanning the lines according to measure, the first strophe of the Justum ac tenacem of Horace, and, making no confession, tired not only the strength, but even the fanaticism, of his executioners.
children.prevalue: But Cornelius was not only possessed of a great mind but also of a great heart He belonged to that race of martyrs who indissolubly wedded to their political convictions as their ancestors were to their faith are able to smile on pain while being stretched on the rack he recited with a firm voice and scanning the lines according to measure the first strophe of the Justum ac tenacem of Horace and making no confession tired not only the strength but even the fanaticism of his executioners

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: The judges, notwithstanding, acquitted Tyckelaer from every charge; at the same time sentencing Cornelius to be deposed from all his offices and dignities; to pay all the costs of the trial; and to be banished from the soil of the Republic for ever.
children.prevalue: The judges notwithstanding acquitted Tyckelaer from every charge at the same time sentencing Cornelius to be deposed from all his offices and dignities to pay all the costs of the trial and to be banished from the soil of the Republic for ever

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: This judgment against not only an innocent, but also a great man, was indeed some gratification to the passions of the people, to whose interests Cornelius de Witt had always devoted himself: but, as we shall soon see, it was not enough.
children.prevalue: This judgment against not only an innocent but also a great man was indeed some gratification to the passions of the people to whose interests Cornelius de Witt had always devoted himself but as we shall soon see it was not enough

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The Athenians, who indeed have left behind them a pretty tolerable reputation for ingratitude, have in this respect to yield precedence to the Dutch. They, at least in the case of Aristides, contented themselves with banishing him.
children.prevalue: The Athenians who indeed have left behind them a pretty tolerable reputation for ingratitude have in this respect to yield precedence to the Dutch They at least in the case of Aristides contented themselves with banishing him

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: John de Witt, at the first intimation of the charge brought against his brother, had resigned his office of Grand Pensionary. He too received a noble recompense for his devotedness to the best interests of his country, taking with him into the retirement of private life the hatred of a host of enemies, and the fresh scars of wounds inflicted by assassins, only too often the sole guerdon obtained by honest people, who are guilty of having worked for their country, and of having forgotten their own private interests.
children.prevalue: John de Witt at the first intimation of the charge brought against his brother had resigned his office of Grand Pensionary He too received a noble recompense for his devotedness to the best interests of his country taking with him into the retirement of private life the hatred of a host of enemies and the fresh scars of wounds inflicted by assassins only too often the sole guerdon obtained by honest people who are guilty of having worked for their country and of having forgotten their own private interests

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: In the meanwhile William of Orange urged on the course of events by every means in his power, eagerly waiting for the time when the people, by whom he was idolised, should have made of the bodies of the brothers the two steps over which he might ascend to the chair of Stadtholder.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile William of Orange urged on the course of events by every means in his power eagerly waiting for the time when the people by whom he was idolised should have made of the bodies of the brothers the two steps over which he might ascend to the chair of Stadtholder

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Thus, then, on the 20th of August, 1672, as we have already stated in the beginning of this chapter, the whole town was crowding towards the Buytenhof, to witness the departure of Cornelius de Witt from prison, as he was going to exile; and to see what traces the torture of the rack had left on the noble frame of the man who knew his Horace so well.
children.prevalue: Thus then on the 20th of August 1672 as we have already stated in the beginning of this chapter the whole town was crowding towards the Buytenhof to witness the departure of Cornelius de Witt from prison as he was going to exile and to see what traces the torture of the rack had left on the noble frame of the man who knew his Horace so well

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Yet all this multitude was not crowding to the Buytenhof with the innocent view of merely feasting their eyes with the spectacle; there were many who went there to play an active part in it, and to take upon themselves an office which they conceived had been badly filled,that of the executioner.
children.prevalue: Yet all this multitude was not crowding to the Buytenhof with the innocent view of merely feasting their eyes with the spectacle there were many who went there to play an active part in it and to take upon themselves an office which they conceived had been badly filled that of the executioner

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: There were, indeed, others with less hostile intentions. All that they cared for was the spectacle, always so attractive to the mob, whose instinctive pride is flattered by it,the sight of greatness hurled down into the dust.
children.prevalue: There were indeed others with less hostile intentions All that they cared for was the spectacle always so attractive to the mob whose instinctive pride is flattered by it the sight of greatness hurled down into the dust

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Has not, they would say, this Cornelius de Witt been locked up and broken by the rack? Shall we not see him pale, streaming with blood, covered with shame? And was not this a sweet triumph for the burghers of the Hague, whose envy even beat that of the common rabble; a triumph in which every honest citizen and townsman might be expected to share?
children.prevalue: Has not they would say this Cornelius de Witt been locked up and broken by the rack Shall we not see him pale streaming with blood covered with shame And was not this a sweet triumph for the burghers of the Hague whose envy even beat that of the common rabble a triumph in which every honest citizen and townsman might be expected to share

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Moreover, hinted the Orange agitators interspersed through the crowd, whom they hoped to manage like a sharpedged and at the same time crushing instrument,moreover, will there not, from the Buytenhof to the gate of the town, a nice little opportunity present itself to throw some handfuls of dirt, or a few stones, at this Cornelius de Witt, who not only conferred the dignity of Stadtholder on the Prince of Orange merely vi coactus, but who also intended to have him assassinated?
children.prevalue: Moreover hinted the Orange agitators interspersed through the crowd whom they hoped to manage like a sharpedged and at the same time crushing instrument moreover will there not from the Buytenhof to the gate of the town a nice little opportunity present itself to throw some handfuls of dirt or a few stones at this Cornelius de Witt who not only conferred the dignity of Stadtholder on the Prince of Orange merely vi coactus but who also intended to have him assassinated

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Besides which, the fierce enemies of France chimed in, if the work were done well and bravely at the Hague, Cornelius would certainly not be allowed to go into exile, where he will renew his intrigues with France, and live with his big scoundrel of a brother, John, on the gold of the Marquis de Louvois.
children.prevalue: Besides which the fierce enemies of France chimed in if the work were done well and bravely at the Hague Cornelius would certainly not be allowed to go into exile where he will renew his intrigues with France and live with his big scoundrel of a brother John on the gold of the Marquis de Louvois

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Being in such a temper, people generally will run rather than walk; which was the reason why the inhabitants of the Hague were hurrying so fast towards the Buytenhof.
children.prevalue: Being in such a temper people generally will run rather than walk which was the reason why the inhabitants of the Hague were hurrying so fast towards the Buytenhof

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Honest Tyckelaer, with a heart full of spite and malice, and with no particular plan settled in his mind, was one of the foremost, being paraded about by the Orange party like a hero of probity, national honour, and Christian charity.
children.prevalue: Honest Tyckelaer with a heart full of spite and malice and with no particular plan settled in his mind was one of the foremost being paraded about by the Orange party like a hero of probity national honour and Christian charity

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: This daring miscreant detailed, with all the embellishments and flourishes suggested by his base mind and his ruffianly imagination, the attempts which he pretended Cornelius de Witt had made to corrupt him; the sums of money which were promised, and all the diabolical stratagems planned beforehand to smooth for him, Tyckelaer, all the difficulties in the path of murder.
children.prevalue: This daring miscreant detailed with all the embellishments and flourishes suggested by his base mind and his ruffianly imagination the attempts which he pretended Cornelius de Witt had made to corrupt him the sums of money which were promised and all the diabolical stratagems planned beforehand to smooth for him Tyckelaer all the difficulties in the path of murder

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: And every phase of his speech, eagerly listened to by the populace, called forth enthusiastic cheers for the Prince of Orange, and groans and imprecations of blind fury against the brothers De Witt.
children.prevalue: And every phase of his speech eagerly listened to by the populace called forth enthusiastic cheers for the Prince of Orange and groans and imprecations of blind fury against the brothers De Witt

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: The mob even began to vent its rage by inveighing against the iniquitous judges, who had allowed such a detestable criminal as the villain Cornelius to get off so cheaply.
children.prevalue: The mob even began to vent its rage by inveighing against the iniquitous judges who had allowed such a detestable criminal as the villain Cornelius to get off so cheaply

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Some of the agitators whispered, He will be off, he will escape from us!
children.prevalue: Some of the agitators whispered He will be off he will escape from us

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Others replied, A vessel is waiting for him at Schevening, a French craft. Tyckelaer has seen her.
children.prevalue: Others replied A vessel is waiting for him at Schevening a French craft Tyckelaer has seen her

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Honest Tyckelaer! Hurrah for Tyckelaer! the mob cried in chorus.
children.prevalue: Honest Tyckelaer Hurrah for Tyckelaer the mob cried in chorus

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: And let us not forget, a voice exclaimed from the crowd, that at the same time with Cornelius his brother John, who is as rascally a traitor as himself, will likewise make his escape.
children.prevalue: And let us not forget a voice exclaimed from the crowd that at the same time with Cornelius his brother John who is as rascally a traitor as himself will likewise make his escape

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: And the two rogues will in France make merry with our money, with the money for our vessels, our arsenals, and our dockyards, which they have sold to Louis XIV.
children.prevalue: And the two rogues will in France make merry with our money with the money for our vessels our arsenals and our dockyards which they have sold to Louis XIV

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Well, then, don't let us allow them to depart! advised one of the patriots who had gained the start of the others.
children.prevalue: Well then don t let us allow them to depart advised one of the patriots who had gained the start of the others

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Forward to the prison, to the prison! echoed the crowd.
children.prevalue: Forward to the prison to the prison echoed the crowd

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Amid these cries, the citizens ran along faster and faster, cocking their muskets, brandishing their hatchets, and looking death and defiance in all directions.
children.prevalue: Amid these cries the citizens ran along faster and faster cocking their muskets brandishing their hatchets and looking death and defiance in all directions

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: No violence, however, had as yet been committed; and the file of horsemen who were guarding the approaches of the Buytenhof remained cool, unmoved, silent, much more threatening in their impassibility than all this crowd of burghers, with their cries, their agitation, and their threats. The men on their horses, indeed, stood like so many statues, under the eye of their chief, Count Tilly, the captain of the mounted troops of the Hague, who had his sword drawn, but held it with its point downwards, in a line with the straps of his stirrup.
children.prevalue: No violence however had as yet been committed and the file of horsemen who were guarding the approaches of the Buytenhof remained cool unmoved silent much more threatening in their impassibility than all this crowd of burghers with their cries their agitation and their threats The men on their horses indeed stood like so many statues under the eye of their chief Count Tilly the captain of the mounted troops of the Hague who had his sword drawn but held it with its point downwards in a line with the straps of his stirrup

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: This troop, the only defence of the prison, overawed by its firm attitude not only the disorderly riotous mass of the populace, but also the detachment of the burgher guard, which, being placed opposite the Buytenhof to support the soldiers in keeping order, gave to the rioters the example of seditious cries, shouting,
children.prevalue: This troop the only defence of the prison overawed by its firm attitude not only the disorderly riotous mass of the populace but also the detachment of the burgher guard which being placed opposite the Buytenhof to support the soldiers in keeping order gave to the rioters the example of seditious cries shouting

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Hurrah for Orange! Down with the traitors!
children.prevalue: Hurrah for Orange Down with the traitors

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: The presence of Tilly and his horsemen, indeed, exercised a salutary check on these civic warriors; but by degrees they waxed more and more angry by their own shouts, and as they were not able to understand how any one could have courage without showing it by cries, they attributed the silence of the dragoons to pusillanimity, and advanced one step towards the prison, with all the turbulent mob following in their wake.
children.prevalue: The presence of Tilly and his horsemen indeed exercised a salutary check on these civic warriors but by degrees they waxed more and more angry by their own shouts and as they were not able to understand how any one could have courage without showing it by cries they attributed the silence of the dragoons to pusillanimity and advanced one step towards the prison with all the turbulent mob following in their wake

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: In this moment, Count Tilly rode forth towards them singlehanded, merely lifting his sword and contracting his brow whilst he addressed them:
children.prevalue: In this moment Count Tilly rode forth towards them singlehanded merely lifting his sword and contracting his brow whilst he addressed them

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Well, gentlemen of the burgher guard, what are you advancing for, and what do you wish?
children.prevalue: Well gentlemen of the burgher guard what are you advancing for and what do you wish

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The burghers shook their muskets, repeating their cry,
children.prevalue: The burghers shook their muskets repeating their cry

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Hurrah for Orange! Death to the traitors!
children.prevalue: Hurrah for Orange Death to the traitors

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: 'Hurrah for Orange!' all well and good! replied Tilly, although I certainly am more partial to happy faces than to gloomy ones. 'Death to the traitors!' as much of it as you like, as long as you show your wishes only by cries. But, as to putting them to death in good earnest, I am here to prevent that, and I shall prevent it.
children.prevalue: Hurrah for Orange all well and good replied Tilly although I certainly am more partial to happy faces than to gloomy ones Death to the traitors as much of it as you like as long as you show your wishes only by cries But as to putting them to death in good earnest I am here to prevent that and I shall prevent it

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Then, turning round to his men, he gave the word of command,
children.prevalue: Then turning round to his men he gave the word of command

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Soldiers, ready!
children.prevalue: Soldiers ready

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: The troopers obeyed orders with a precision which immediately caused the burgher guard and the people to fall back, in a degree of confusion which excited the smile of the cavalry officer.
children.prevalue: The troopers obeyed orders with a precision which immediately caused the burgher guard and the people to fall back in a degree of confusion which excited the smile of the cavalry officer

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Holloa! he exclaimed, with that bantering tone which is peculiar to men of his profession; be easy, gentlemen, my soldiers will not fire a shot; but, on the other hand, you will not advance by one step towards the prison.
children.prevalue: Holloa he exclaimed with that bantering tone which is peculiar to men of his profession be easy gentlemen my soldiers will not fire a shot but on the other hand you will not advance by one step towards the prison

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: And do you know, sir, that we have muskets? roared the commandant of the burghers.
children.prevalue: And do you know sir that we have muskets roared the commandant of the burghers

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: I must know it, by Jove, you have made them glitter enough before my eyes; but I beg you to observe also that we on our side have pistols, that the pistol carries admirably to a distance of fifty yards, and that you are only twentyfive from us.
children.prevalue: I must know it by Jove you have made them glitter enough before my eyes but I beg you to observe also that we on our side have pistols that the pistol carries admirably to a distance of fifty yards and that you are only twentyfive from us

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Death to the traitors! cried the exasperated burghers.
children.prevalue: Death to the traitors cried the exasperated burghers

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Go along with you, growled the officer, you always cry the same thing over again. It is very tiresome.
children.prevalue: Go along with you growled the officer you always cry the same thing over again It is very tiresome

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: With this, he took his post at the head of his troops, whilst the tumult grew fiercer and fiercer about the Buytenhof.
children.prevalue: With this he took his post at the head of his troops whilst the tumult grew fiercer and fiercer about the Buytenhof

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: And yet the fuming crowd did not know that, at that very moment when they were tracking the scent of one of their victims, the other, as if hurrying to meet his fate, passed, at a distance of not more than a hundred yards, behind the groups of people and the dragoons, to betake himself to the Buytenhof.
children.prevalue: And yet the fuming crowd did not know that at that very moment when they were tracking the scent of one of their victims the other as if hurrying to meet his fate passed at a distance of not more than a hundred yards behind the groups of people and the dragoons to betake himself to the Buytenhof

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: John de Witt, indeed, had alighted from his coach with his servant, and quietly walked across the courtyard of the prison.
children.prevalue: John de Witt indeed had alighted from his coach with his servant and quietly walked across the courtyard of the prison

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Mentioning his name to the turnkey, who however knew him, he said,
children.prevalue: Mentioning his name to the turnkey who however knew him he said

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Good morning, Gryphus; I am coming to take away my brother, who, as you know, is condemned to exile, and to carry him out of the town.
children.prevalue: Good morning Gryphus I am coming to take away my brother who as you know is condemned to exile and to carry him out of the town

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Whereupon the jailer, a sort of bear, trained to lock and unlock the gates of the prison, had greeted him and admitted him into the building, the doors of which were immediately closed again.
children.prevalue: Whereupon the jailer a sort of bear trained to lock and unlock the gates of the prison had greeted him and admitted him into the building the doors of which were immediately closed again

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Ten yards farther on, John de Witt met a lovely young girl, of about seventeen or eighteen, dressed in the national costume of the Frisian women, who, with pretty demureness, dropped a curtesy to him. Chucking her under the chin, he said to her,
children.prevalue: Ten yards farther on John de Witt met a lovely young girl of about seventeen or eighteen dressed in the national costume of the Frisian women who with pretty demureness dropped a curtesy to him Chucking her under the chin he said to her

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Good morning, my good and fair Rosa; how is my brother?
children.prevalue: Good morning my good and fair Rosa how is my brother

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Oh, Mynheer John! the young girl replied, I am not afraid of the harm which has been done to him. That's all over now.
children.prevalue: Oh Mynheer John the young girl replied I am not afraid of the harm which has been done to him That s all over now

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: But what is it you are afraid of?
children.prevalue: But what is it you are afraid of

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: I am afraid of the harm which they are going to do to him.
children.prevalue: I am afraid of the harm which they are going to do to him

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Oh, yes, said De Witt, you mean to speak of the people down below, don't you?
children.prevalue: Oh yes said De Witt you mean to speak of the people down below don t you

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Do you hear them?
children.prevalue: Do you hear them

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: They are indeed in a state of great excitement; but when they see us perhaps they will grow calmer, as we have never done them anything but good.
children.prevalue: They are indeed in a state of great excitement but when they see us perhaps they will grow calmer as we have never done them anything but good

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: That's unfortunately no reason, except for the contrary, muttered the girl, as, on an imperative sign from her father, she withdrew.
children.prevalue: That s unfortunately no reason except for the contrary muttered the girl as on an imperative sign from her father she withdrew

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Indeed, child, what you say is only too true.
children.prevalue: Indeed child what you say is only too true

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Then, in pursuing his way, he said to himself,
children.prevalue: Then in pursuing his way he said to himself

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Here is a damsel who very likely does not know how to read, who consequently has never read anything, and yet with one word she has just told the whole history of the world.
children.prevalue: Here is a damsel who very likely does not know how to read who consequently has never read anything and yet with one word she has just told the whole history of the world

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: And with the same calm mien, but more melancholy than he had been on entering the prison, the Grand Pensionary proceeded towards the cell of his brother.
children.prevalue: And with the same calm mien but more melancholy than he had been on entering the prison the Grand Pensionary proceeded towards the cell of his brother

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: As the fair Rosa, with foreboding doubt, had foretold, so it happened. Whilst John de Witt was climbing the narrow winding stairs which led to the prison of his brother Cornelius, the burghers did their best to have the troop of Tilly, which was in their way, removed.
children.prevalue: As the fair Rosa with foreboding doubt had foretold so it happened Whilst John de Witt was climbing the narrow winding stairs which led to the prison of his brother Cornelius the burghers did their best to have the troop of Tilly which was in their way removed

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Seeing this disposition, King Mob, who fully appreciated the laudable intentions of his own beloved militia, shouted most lustily,
children.prevalue: Seeing this disposition King Mob who fully appreciated the laudable intentions of his own beloved militia shouted most lustily

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Hurrah for the burghers!
children.prevalue: Hurrah for the burghers

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: As to Count Tilly, who was as prudent as he was firm, he began to parley with the burghers, under the protection of the cocked pistols of his dragoons, explaining to the valiant townsmen, that his order from the States commanded him to guard the prison and its approaches with three companies.
children.prevalue: As to Count Tilly who was as prudent as he was firm he began to parley with the burghers under the protection of the cocked pistols of his dragoons explaining to the valiant townsmen that his order from the States commanded him to guard the prison and its approaches with three companies

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Wherefore such an order? Why guard the prison? cried the Orangists.
children.prevalue: Wherefore such an order Why guard the prison cried the Orangists

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Stop, replied the Count, there you at once ask me more than I can tell you. I was told, 'Guard the prison,' and I guard it. You, gentlemen, who are almost military men yourselves, you are aware that an order must never be gainsaid.
children.prevalue: Stop replied the Count there you at once ask me more than I can tell you I was told Guard the prison and I guard it You gentlemen who are almost military men yourselves you are aware that an order must never be gainsaid

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: But this order has been given to you that the traitors may be enabled to leave the town.
children.prevalue: But this order has been given to you that the traitors may be enabled to leave the town

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Very possibly, as the traitors are condemned to exile, replied Tilly.
children.prevalue: Very possibly as the traitors are condemned to exile replied Tilly

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: But who has given this order?
children.prevalue: But who has given this order

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: The States, to be sure!
children.prevalue: The States to be sure

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The States are traitors.
children.prevalue: The States are traitors

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: I don't know anything about that!
children.prevalue: I don t know anything about that

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: And you are a traitor yourself!
children.prevalue: And you are a traitor yourself

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I?
children.prevalue: I

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Yes, you.
children.prevalue: Yes you

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Well, as to that, let us understand each other gentlemen. Whom should I betray? The States? Why, I cannot betray them, whilst, being in their pay, I faithfully obey their orders.
children.prevalue: Well as to that let us understand each other gentlemen Whom should I betray The States Why I cannot betray them whilst being in their pay I faithfully obey their orders

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: As the Count was so indisputably in the right that it was impossible to argue against him, the mob answered only by redoubled clamour and horrible threats, to which the Count opposed the most perfect urbanity.
children.prevalue: As the Count was so indisputably in the right that it was impossible to argue against him the mob answered only by redoubled clamour and horrible threats to which the Count opposed the most perfect urbanity

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Gentlemen, he said, uncock your muskets, one of them may go off by accident; and if the shot chanced to wound one of my men, we should knock over a couple of hundreds of yours, for which we should, indeed, be very sorry, but you even more so; especially as such a thing is neither contemplated by you nor by myself.
children.prevalue: Gentlemen he said uncock your muskets one of them may go off by accident and if the shot chanced to wound one of my men we should knock over a couple of hundreds of yours for which we should indeed be very sorry but you even more so especially as such a thing is neither contemplated by you nor by myself

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: If you did that, cried the burghers, we should have a pop at you, too.
children.prevalue: If you did that cried the burghers we should have a pop at you too

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Of course you would; but suppose you killed every man Jack of us, those whom we should have killed would not, for all that, be less dead.
children.prevalue: Of course you would but suppose you killed every man Jack of us those whom we should have killed would not for all that be less dead

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Then leave the place to us, and you will perform the part of a good citizen.
children.prevalue: Then leave the place to us and you will perform the part of a good citizen

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: First of all, said the Count, I am not a citizen, but an officer, which is a very different thing; and secondly, I am not a Hollander, but a Frenchman, which is more different still. I have to do with no one but the States, by whom I am paid; let me see an order from them to leave the place to you, and I shall only be too glad to wheel off in an instant, as I am confoundedly bored here.
children.prevalue: First of all said the Count I am not a citizen but an officer which is a very different thing and secondly I am not a Hollander but a Frenchman which is more different still I have to do with no one but the States by whom I am paid let me see an order from them to leave the place to you and I shall only be too glad to wheel off in an instant as I am confoundedly bored here

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Yes, yes! cried a hundred voices; the din of which was immediately swelled by five hundred others; let us march to the Townhall; let us go and see the deputies! Come along! come along!
children.prevalue: Yes yes cried a hundred voices the din of which was immediately swelled by five hundred others let us march to the Townhall let us go and see the deputies Come along come along

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: That's it, Tilly muttered between his teeth, as he saw the most violent among the crowd turning away; go and ask for a meanness at the Townhall, and you will see whether they will grant it; go, my fine fellows, go!
children.prevalue: That s it Tilly muttered between his teeth as he saw the most violent among the crowd turning away go and ask for a meanness at the Townhall and you will see whether they will grant it go my fine fellows go

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The worthy officer relied on the honour of the magistrates, who, on their side, relied on his honour as a soldier.
children.prevalue: The worthy officer relied on the honour of the magistrates who on their side relied on his honour as a soldier

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: I say, Captain, the first lieutenant whispered into the ear of the Count, I hope the deputies will give these madmen a flat refusal; but, after all, it would do no harm if they would send us some reinforcement.
children.prevalue: I say Captain the first lieutenant whispered into the ear of the Count I hope the deputies will give these madmen a flat refusal but after all it would do no harm if they would send us some reinforcement

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: In the meanwhile, John de Witt, whom we left climbing the stairs, after the conversation with the jailer Gryphus and his daughter Rosa, had reached the door of the cell, where on a mattress his brother Cornelius was resting, after having undergone the preparatory degrees of the torture. The sentence of banishment having been pronounced, there was no occasion for inflicting the torture extraordinary.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile John de Witt whom we left climbing the stairs after the conversation with the jailer Gryphus and his daughter Rosa had reached the door of the cell where on a mattress his brother Cornelius was resting after having undergone the preparatory degrees of the torture The sentence of banishment having been pronounced there was no occasion for inflicting the torture extraordinary

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Cornelius was stretched on his couch, with broken wrists and crushed fingers. He had not confessed a crime of which he was not guilty; and now, after three days of agony, he once more breathed freely, on being informed that the judges, from whom he had expected death, were only condemning him to exile.
children.prevalue: Cornelius was stretched on his couch with broken wrists and crushed fingers He had not confessed a crime of which he was not guilty and now after three days of agony he once more breathed freely on being informed that the judges from whom he had expected death were only condemning him to exile

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Endowed with an iron frame and a stout heart, how would he have disappointed his enemies if they could only have seen, in the dark cell of the Buytenhof, his pale face lit up by the smile of the martyr, who forgets the dross of this earth after having obtained a glimpse of the bright glory of heaven.
children.prevalue: Endowed with an iron frame and a stout heart how would he have disappointed his enemies if they could only have seen in the dark cell of the Buytenhof his pale face lit up by the smile of the martyr who forgets the dross of this earth after having obtained a glimpse of the bright glory of heaven

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: The warden, indeed, had already recovered his full strength, much more owing to the force of his own strong will than to actual aid; and he was calculating how long the formalities of the law would still detain him in prison.
children.prevalue: The warden indeed had already recovered his full strength much more owing to the force of his own strong will than to actual aid and he was calculating how long the formalities of the law would still detain him in prison

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: This was just at the very moment when the mingled shouts of the burgher guard and of the mob were raging against the two brothers, and threatening Captain Tilly, who served as a rampart to them. This noise, which roared outside of the walls of the prison, as the surf dashing against the rocks, now reached the ears of the prisoner.
children.prevalue: This was just at the very moment when the mingled shouts of the burgher guard and of the mob were raging against the two brothers and threatening Captain Tilly who served as a rampart to them This noise which roared outside of the walls of the prison as the surf dashing against the rocks now reached the ears of the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: But, threatening as it sounded, Cornelius appeared not to deem it worth his while to inquire after its cause; nor did he get up to look out of the narrow grated window, which gave access to the light and to the noise of the world without.
children.prevalue: But threatening as it sounded Cornelius appeared not to deem it worth his while to inquire after its cause nor did he get up to look out of the narrow grated window which gave access to the light and to the noise of the world without

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: He was so absorbed in his neverceasing pain that it had almost become a habit with him. He felt with such delight the bonds which connected his immortal being with his perishable frame gradually loosening, that it seemed to him as if his spirit, freed from the trammels of the body, were hovering above it, like the expiring flame which rises from the halfextinguished embers.
children.prevalue: He was so absorbed in his neverceasing pain that it had almost become a habit with him He felt with such delight the bonds which connected his immortal being with his perishable frame gradually loosening that it seemed to him as if his spirit freed from the trammels of the body were hovering above it like the expiring flame which rises from the halfextinguished embers

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: He also thought of his brother; and whilst the latter was thus vividly present to his mind the door opened, and John entered, hurrying to the bedside of the prisoner, who stretched out his broken limbs and his hands tied up in bandages towards that glorious brother, whom he now excelled, not in services rendered to the country, but in the hatred which the Dutch bore him.
children.prevalue: He also thought of his brother and whilst the latter was thus vividly present to his mind the door opened and John entered hurrying to the bedside of the prisoner who stretched out his broken limbs and his hands tied up in bandages towards that glorious brother whom he now excelled not in services rendered to the country but in the hatred which the Dutch bore him

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: John tenderly kissed his brother on the forehead, and put his sore hands gently back on the mattress.
children.prevalue: John tenderly kissed his brother on the forehead and put his sore hands gently back on the mattress

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Cornelius, my poor brother, you are suffering great pain, are you not?
children.prevalue: Cornelius my poor brother you are suffering great pain are you not

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I am suffering no longer, since I see you, my brother.
children.prevalue: I am suffering no longer since I see you my brother

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Oh, my poor dear Cornelius! I feel most wretched to see you in such a state.
children.prevalue: Oh my poor dear Cornelius I feel most wretched to see you in such a state

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: And, indeed, I have thought more of you than of myself; and whilst they were torturing me, I never thought of uttering a complaint, except once, to say, 'Poor brother!' But now that you are here, let us forget all. You are coming to take me away, are you not?
children.prevalue: And indeed I have thought more of you than of myself and whilst they were torturing me I never thought of uttering a complaint except once to say Poor brother But now that you are here let us forget all You are coming to take me away are you not

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I am.
children.prevalue: I am

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I am quite healed; help me to get up, and you shall see how I can walk.
children.prevalue: I am quite healed help me to get up and you shall see how I can walk

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: You will not have to walk far, as I have my coach near the pond, behind Tilly's dragoons.
children.prevalue: You will not have to walk far as I have my coach near the pond behind Tilly s dragoons

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Tilly's dragoons! What are they near the pond for?
children.prevalue: Tilly s dragoons What are they near the pond for

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Well, said the Grand Pensionary with a melancholy smile which was habitual to him, the gentlemen at the Townhall expect that the people at the Hague would like to see you depart, and there is some apprehension of a tumult.
children.prevalue: Well said the Grand Pensionary with a melancholy smile which was habitual to him the gentlemen at the Townhall expect that the people at the Hague would like to see you depart and there is some apprehension of a tumult

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Of a tumult? replied Cornelius, fixing his eyes on his perplexed brother; a tumult?
children.prevalue: Of a tumult replied Cornelius fixing his eyes on his perplexed brother a tumult

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Yes, Cornelius.
children.prevalue: Yes Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Oh! that's what I heard just now, said the prisoner, as if speaking to himself. Then, turning to his brother, he continued,
children.prevalue: Oh that s what I heard just now said the prisoner as if speaking to himself Then turning to his brother he continued

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Are there many persons down before the prison.
children.prevalue: Are there many persons down before the prison

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Yes, my brother, there are.
children.prevalue: Yes my brother there are

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: But then, to come here to me
children.prevalue: But then to come here to me

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: How is it that they have allowed you to pass?
children.prevalue: How is it that they have allowed you to pass

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: You know well that we are not very popular, Cornelius, said the Grand Pensionary, with gloomy bitterness. I have made my way through all sorts of bystreets and alleys.
children.prevalue: You know well that we are not very popular Cornelius said the Grand Pensionary with gloomy bitterness I have made my way through all sorts of bystreets and alleys

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: You hid yourself, John?
children.prevalue: You hid yourself John

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: I wished to reach you without loss of time, and I did what people will do in politics, or on the sea when the wind is against them,I tacked.
children.prevalue: I wished to reach you without loss of time and I did what people will do in politics or on the sea when the wind is against them I tacked

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: At this moment the noise in the square below was heard to roar with increasing fury. Tilly was parleying with the burghers.
children.prevalue: At this moment the noise in the square below was heard to roar with increasing fury Tilly was parleying with the burghers

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Well, well, said Cornelius, you are a very skilful pilot, John; but I doubt whether you will as safely guide your brother out of the Buytenhof in the midst of this gale, and through the raging surf of popular hatred, as you did the fleet of Van Tromp past the shoals of the Scheldt to Antwerp.
children.prevalue: Well well said Cornelius you are a very skilful pilot John but I doubt whether you will as safely guide your brother out of the Buytenhof in the midst of this gale and through the raging surf of popular hatred as you did the fleet of Van Tromp past the shoals of the Scheldt to Antwerp

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: With the help of God, Cornelius, we'll at least try, answered John; but, first of all, a word with you.
children.prevalue: With the help of God Cornelius we ll at least try answered John but first of all a word with you

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Speak!
children.prevalue: Speak

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: The shouts began anew.
children.prevalue: The shouts began anew

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Hark, hark! continued Cornelius, how angry those people are! Is it against you, or against me?
children.prevalue: Hark hark continued Cornelius how angry those people are Is it against you or against me

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I should say it is against us both, Cornelius. I told you, my dear brother, that the Orange party, while assailing us with their absurd calumnies, have also made it a reproach against us that we have negotiated with France.
children.prevalue: I should say it is against us both Cornelius I told you my dear brother that the Orange party while assailing us with their absurd calumnies have also made it a reproach against us that we have negotiated with France

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: What blockheads they are!
children.prevalue: What blockheads they are

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: But, indeed, they reproach us with it.
children.prevalue: But indeed they reproach us with it

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: And yet, if these negotiations had been successful, they would have prevented the defeats of Rees, Orsay, Wesel, and Rheinberg; the Rhine would not have been crossed, and Holland might still consider herself invincible in the midst of her marshes and canals.
children.prevalue: And yet if these negotiations had been successful they would have prevented the defeats of Rees Orsay Wesel and Rheinberg the Rhine would not have been crossed and Holland might still consider herself invincible in the midst of her marshes and canals

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: All this is quite true, my dear Cornelius, but still more certain it is, that if at this moment our correspondence with the Marquis de Louvois were discovered, skilful pilot as I am, I should not be able to save the frail barque which is to carry the brothers De Witt and their fortunes out of Holland. That correspondence, which might prove to honest people how dearly I love my country, and what sacrifices I have offered to make for its liberty and glory, would be ruin to us if it fell into the hands of the Orange party. I hope you have burned the letters before you left Dort to join me at the Hague.
children.prevalue: All this is quite true my dear Cornelius but still more certain it is that if at this moment our correspondence with the Marquis de Louvois were discovered skilful pilot as I am I should not be able to save the frail barque which is to carry the brothers De Witt and their fortunes out of Holland That correspondence which might prove to honest people how dearly I love my country and what sacrifices I have offered to make for its liberty and glory would be ruin to us if it fell into the hands of the Orange party I hope you have burned the letters before you left Dort to join me at the Hague

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: My dear brother, Cornelius answered, your correspondence with M. de Louvois affords ample proof of your having been of late the greatest, most generous, and most able citizen of the Seven United Provinces. I rejoice in the glory of my country; and particularly do I rejoice in your glory, John. I have taken good care not to burn that correspondence.
children.prevalue: My dear brother Cornelius answered your correspondence with M de Louvois affords ample proof of your having been of late the greatest most generous and most able citizen of the Seven United Provinces I rejoice in the glory of my country and particularly do I rejoice in your glory John I have taken good care not to burn that correspondence

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Then we are lost, as far as this life is concerned, quietly said the Grand Pensionary, approaching the window.
children.prevalue: Then we are lost as far as this life is concerned quietly said the Grand Pensionary approaching the window

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: No, on the contrary, John, we shall at the same time save our lives and regain our popularity.
children.prevalue: No on the contrary John we shall at the same time save our lives and regain our popularity

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: But what have you done with these letters?
children.prevalue: But what have you done with these letters

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: I have intrusted them to the care of Cornelius van Baerle, my godson, whom you know, and who lives at Dort.
children.prevalue: I have intrusted them to the care of Cornelius van Baerle my godson whom you know and who lives at Dort

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Poor honest Van Baerle! who knows so much, and yet thinks of nothing but of flowers and of God who made them. You have intrusted him with this fatal secret; it will be his ruin, poor soul!
children.prevalue: Poor honest Van Baerle who knows so much and yet thinks of nothing but of flowers and of God who made them You have intrusted him with this fatal secret it will be his ruin poor soul

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: His ruin?
children.prevalue: His ruin

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Yes, for he will either be strong or he will be weak. If he is strong, he will, when he hears of what has happened to us, boast of our acquaintance; if he is weak, he will be afraid on account of his connection with us: if he is strong, he will betray the secret by his boldness; if he is weak, he will allow it to be forced from him. In either case he is lost, and so are we. Let us, therefore, fly, fly, as long as there is still time.
children.prevalue: Yes for he will either be strong or he will be weak If he is strong he will when he hears of what has happened to us boast of our acquaintance if he is weak he will be afraid on account of his connection with us if he is strong he will betray the secret by his boldness if he is weak he will allow it to be forced from him In either case he is lost and so are we Let us therefore fly fly as long as there is still time

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Cornelius de Witt, raising himself on his couch, and grasping the hand of his brother, who shuddered at the touch of his linen bandages, replied,
children.prevalue: Cornelius de Witt raising himself on his couch and grasping the hand of his brother who shuddered at the touch of his linen bandages replied

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Do not I know my godson? have not I been enabled to read every thought in Van Baerle's mind, and every sentiment in his heart? You ask whether he is strong or weak. He is neither the one nor the other; but that is not now the question. The principal point is, that he is sure not to divulge the secret, for the very good reason that he does not know it himself.
children.prevalue: Do not I know my godson have not I been enabled to read every thought in Van Baerle s mind and every sentiment in his heart You ask whether he is strong or weak He is neither the one nor the other but that is not now the question The principal point is that he is sure not to divulge the secret for the very good reason that he does not know it himself

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: John turned round in surprise.
children.prevalue: John turned round in surprise

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: You must know, my dear brother, that I have been trained in the school of that distinguished politician John de Witt; and I repeat to you, that Van Baerle is not aware of the nature and importance of the deposit which I have intrusted to him.
children.prevalue: You must know my dear brother that I have been trained in the school of that distinguished politician John de Witt and I repeat to you that Van Baerle is not aware of the nature and importance of the deposit which I have intrusted to him

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Quick then, cried John, as there is still time, let us convey to him directions to burn the parcel.
children.prevalue: Quick then cried John as there is still time let us convey to him directions to burn the parcel

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Through whom?
children.prevalue: Through whom

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Through my servant Craeke, who was to have accompanied us on horseback, and who has entered the prison with me, to assist you downstairs.
children.prevalue: Through my servant Craeke who was to have accompanied us on horseback and who has entered the prison with me to assist you downstairs

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Consider well before having those precious documents burnt, John!
children.prevalue: Consider well before having those precious documents burnt John

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: I consider, above all things, that the brothers De Witt must necessarily save their lives, to be able to save their character. If we are dead, who will defend us? Who will have fully understood our intentions?
children.prevalue: I consider above all things that the brothers De Witt must necessarily save their lives to be able to save their character If we are dead who will defend us Who will have fully understood our intentions

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: You expect, then, that they would kill us if those papers were found?
children.prevalue: You expect then that they would kill us if those papers were found

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: John, without answering, pointed with his hand to the square, whence, at that very moment, fierce shouts and savage yells made themselves heard.
children.prevalue: John without answering pointed with his hand to the square whence at that very moment fierce shouts and savage yells made themselves heard

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Yes, yes, said Cornelius, I hear these shouts very plainly, but what is their meaning?
children.prevalue: Yes yes said Cornelius I hear these shouts very plainly but what is their meaning

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: John opened the window.
children.prevalue: John opened the window

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Death to the traitors! howled the populace.
children.prevalue: Death to the traitors howled the populace

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Do you hear now, Cornelius?
children.prevalue: Do you hear now Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: To the traitors! that means us! said the prisoner, raising his eyes to heaven and shrugging his shoulders.
children.prevalue: To the traitors that means us said the prisoner raising his eyes to heaven and shrugging his shoulders

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Yes, it means us, repeated John.
children.prevalue: Yes it means us repeated John

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Where is Craeke?
children.prevalue: Where is Craeke

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: At the door of your cell, I suppose.
children.prevalue: At the door of your cell I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Let him enter then.
children.prevalue: Let him enter then

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: John opened the door; the faithful servant was waiting on the threshold.
children.prevalue: John opened the door the faithful servant was waiting on the threshold

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Come in, Craeke, and mind well what my brother will tell you.
children.prevalue: Come in Craeke and mind well what my brother will tell you

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: No, John; it will not suffice to send a verbal message; unfortunately, I shall be obliged to write.
children.prevalue: No John it will not suffice to send a verbal message unfortunately I shall be obliged to write

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: And why that?
children.prevalue: And why that

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Because Van Baerle will neither give up the parcel nor burn it without a special command to do so.
children.prevalue: Because Van Baerle will neither give up the parcel nor burn it without a special command to do so

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: But will you be able to write, poor old fellow? John asked, with a look on the scorched and bruised hands of the unfortunate sufferer.
children.prevalue: But will you be able to write poor old fellow John asked with a look on the scorched and bruised hands of the unfortunate sufferer

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: If I had pen and ink you would soon see, said Cornelius.
children.prevalue: If I had pen and ink you would soon see said Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Here is a pencil, at any rate.
children.prevalue: Here is a pencil at any rate

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Have you any paper? for they have left me nothing.
children.prevalue: Have you any paper for they have left me nothing

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Here, take this Bible, and tear out the flyleaf.
children.prevalue: Here take this Bible and tear out the flyleaf

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Very well, that will do.
children.prevalue: Very well that will do

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: But your writing will be illegible.
children.prevalue: But your writing will be illegible

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Just leave me alone for that, said Cornelius. The executioners have indeed pinched me badly enough, but my hand will not tremble once in tracing the few lines which are requisite.
children.prevalue: Just leave me alone for that said Cornelius The executioners have indeed pinched me badly enough but my hand will not tremble once in tracing the few lines which are requisite

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: And really Cornelius took the pencil and began to write, when through the white linen bandages drops of blood oozed out which the pressure of the fingers against the pencil squeezed from the raw flesh.
children.prevalue: And really Cornelius took the pencil and began to write when through the white linen bandages drops of blood oozed out which the pressure of the fingers against the pencil squeezed from the raw flesh

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: A cold sweat stood on the brow of the Grand Pensionary.
children.prevalue: A cold sweat stood on the brow of the Grand Pensionary

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Cornelius wrote:
children.prevalue: Cornelius wrote

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: My dear Godson,
children.prevalue: My dear Godson

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Burn the parcel which I have intrusted to you. Burn it without looking at it, and without opening it, so that its contents may for ever remain unknown to yourself. Secrets of this description are death to those with whom they are deposited. Burn it, and you will have saved John and Cornelius de Witt.
children.prevalue: Burn the parcel which I have intrusted to you Burn it without looking at it and without opening it so that its contents may for ever remain unknown to yourself Secrets of this description are death to those with whom they are deposited Burn it and you will have saved John and Cornelius de Witt

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Farewell, and love me.
children.prevalue: Farewell and love me

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Cornelius de Witt
children.prevalue: Cornelius de Witt

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: August 20th, 1672.
children.prevalue: August 20th 1672

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: John, with tears in his eyes, wiped off a drop of the noble blood which had soiled the leaf, and, after having handed the despatch to Craeke with a last direction, returned to Cornelius, who seemed overcome by intense pain, and near fainting.
children.prevalue: John with tears in his eyes wiped off a drop of the noble blood which had soiled the leaf and after having handed the despatch to Craeke with a last direction returned to Cornelius who seemed overcome by intense pain and near fainting

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Now, said he, when honest Craeke sounds his coxswain's whistle, it will be a signal of his being clear of the crowd, and of his having reached the other side of the pond. And then it will be our turn to depart.
children.prevalue: Now said he when honest Craeke sounds his coxswain s whistle it will be a signal of his being clear of the crowd and of his having reached the other side of the pond And then it will be our turn to depart

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Five minutes had not elapsed, before a long and shrill whistle was heard through the din and noise of the square of the Buytenhof.
children.prevalue: Five minutes had not elapsed before a long and shrill whistle was heard through the din and noise of the square of the Buytenhof

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: John gratefully raised his eyes to heaven.
children.prevalue: John gratefully raised his eyes to heaven

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: And now, said he, let us off, Cornelius.
children.prevalue: And now said he let us off Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Whilst the clamour of the crowd in the square of Buytenhof, which grew more and more menacing against the two brothers, determined John de Witt to hasten the departure of his brother Cornelius, a deputation of burghers had gone to the Townhall to demand the withdrawal of Tilly's horse.
children.prevalue: Whilst the clamour of the crowd in the square of Buytenhof which grew more and more menacing against the two brothers determined John de Witt to hasten the departure of his brother Cornelius a deputation of burghers had gone to the Townhall to demand the withdrawal of Tilly s horse

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: It was not far from the Buytenhof to Hoogstraet (High Street); and a stranger, who since the beginning of this scene had watched all its incidents with intense interest, was seen to wend his way with, or rather in the wake of, the others towards the Townhall, to hear as soon as possible the current news of the hour.
