children.prevalue: It was not far from the Buytenhof to Hoogstraet High Street and a stranger who since the beginning of this scene had watched all its incidents with intense interest was seen to wend his way with or rather in the wake of the others towards the Townhall to hear as soon as possible the current news of the hour

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: This stranger was a very young man, of scarcely twentytwo or three, with nothing about him that bespoke any great energy. He evidently had his good reasons for not making himself known, as he hid his face in a handkerchief of fine Frisian linen, with which he incessantly wiped his brow or his burning lips.
children.prevalue: This stranger was a very young man of scarcely twentytwo or three with nothing about him that bespoke any great energy He evidently had his good reasons for not making himself known as he hid his face in a handkerchief of fine Frisian linen with which he incessantly wiped his brow or his burning lips

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: With an eye keen as that of a bird of prey,with a long aquiline nose, a finely cut mouth, which he generally kept open, or rather which was gaping like the edges of a wound,this man would have presented to Lavater, if Lavater had lived at that time, a subject for physiognomical observations which at the first blush would not have been very favourable to the person in question.
children.prevalue: With an eye keen as that of a bird of prey with a long aquiline nose a finely cut mouth which he generally kept open or rather which was gaping like the edges of a wound this man would have presented to Lavater if Lavater had lived at that time a subject for physiognomical observations which at the first blush would not have been very favourable to the person in question

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: What difference is there between the figure of the conqueror and that of the pirate? said the ancients. The difference only between the eagle and the vulture,serenity or restlessness.
children.prevalue: What difference is there between the figure of the conqueror and that of the pirate said the ancients The difference only between the eagle and the vulture serenity or restlessness

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: And indeed the sallow physiognomy, the thin and sickly body, and the prowling ways of the stranger, were the very type of a suspecting master, or an unquiet thief; and a police officer would certainly have decided in favour of the latter supposition, on account of the great care which the mysterious person evidently took to hide himself.
children.prevalue: And indeed the sallow physiognomy the thin and sickly body and the prowling ways of the stranger were the very type of a suspecting master or an unquiet thief and a police officer would certainly have decided in favour of the latter supposition on account of the great care which the mysterious person evidently took to hide himself

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: He was plainly dressed, and apparently unarmed; his arm was lean but wiry, and his hands dry, but of an aristocratic whiteness and delicacy, and he leaned on the shoulder of an officer, who, with his hand on his sword, had watched the scenes in the Buytenhof with eager curiosity, very natural in a military man, until his companion drew him away with him.
children.prevalue: He was plainly dressed and apparently unarmed his arm was lean but wiry and his hands dry but of an aristocratic whiteness and delicacy and he leaned on the shoulder of an officer who with his hand on his sword had watched the scenes in the Buytenhof with eager curiosity very natural in a military man until his companion drew him away with him

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: On arriving at the square of the Hoogstraet, the man with the sallow face pushed the other behind an open shutter, from which corner he himself began to survey the balcony of the Townhall.
children.prevalue: On arriving at the square of the Hoogstraet the man with the sallow face pushed the other behind an open shutter from which corner he himself began to survey the balcony of the Townhall

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: At the savage yells of the mob, the window of the Townhall opened, and a man came forth to address the people.
children.prevalue: At the savage yells of the mob the window of the Townhall opened and a man came forth to address the people

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Who is that on the balcony? asked the young man, glancing at the orator.
children.prevalue: Who is that on the balcony asked the young man glancing at the orator

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: It is the Deputy Bowelt, replied the officer.
children.prevalue: It is the Deputy Bowelt replied the officer

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: What sort of a man is he? Do you know anything of him?
children.prevalue: What sort of a man is he Do you know anything of him

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: An honest man; at least I believe so, Monseigneur.
children.prevalue: An honest man at least I believe so Monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Hearing this character given of Bowelt, the young man showed signs of such a strange disappointment and evident dissatisfaction that the officer could not but remark it, and therefore added,
children.prevalue: Hearing this character given of Bowelt the young man showed signs of such a strange disappointment and evident dissatisfaction that the officer could not but remark it and therefore added

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: At least people say so, Monseigneur. I cannot say anything about it myself, as I have no personal acquaintance with Mynheer Bowelt.
children.prevalue: At least people say so Monseigneur I cannot say anything about it myself as I have no personal acquaintance with Mynheer Bowelt

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: An honest man, repeated he who was addressed as Monseigneur; do you mean to say that he is an honest man (brave homme), or a brave one (homme brave)?
children.prevalue: An honest man repeated he who was addressed as Monseigneur do you mean to say that he is an honest man brave homme or a brave one homme brave

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Ah, Monseigneur must excuse me; I would not presume to draw such a fine distinction in the case of a man whom, I assure your Highness once more, I know only by sight.
children.prevalue: Ah Monseigneur must excuse me I would not presume to draw such a fine distinction in the case of a man whom I assure your Highness once more I know only by sight

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: If this Bowelt is an honest man, his Highness continued, he will give to the demand of these furibund petitioners a very queer reception.
children.prevalue: If this Bowelt is an honest man his Highness continued he will give to the demand of these furibund petitioners a very queer reception

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The nervous quiver of his hand, which moved on the shoulder of his companion as the fingers of a player on the keys of a harpsichord, betrayed his burning impatience, so ill concealed at certain times, and particularly at that moment, under the icy and sombre expression of his face.
children.prevalue: The nervous quiver of his hand which moved on the shoulder of his companion as the fingers of a player on the keys of a harpsichord betrayed his burning impatience so ill concealed at certain times and particularly at that moment under the icy and sombre expression of his face

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The chief of the deputation of the burghers was then heard addressing an interpellation to Mynheer Bowelt, whom he requested to let them know where the other deputies, his colleagues, were.
children.prevalue: The chief of the deputation of the burghers was then heard addressing an interpellation to Mynheer Bowelt whom he requested to let them know where the other deputies his colleagues were

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Gentlemen, Bowelt repeated for the second time, I assure you that in this moment I am here alone with Mynheer d'Asperen, and I cannot take any resolution on my own responsibility.
children.prevalue: Gentlemen Bowelt repeated for the second time I assure you that in this moment I am here alone with Mynheer d Asperen and I cannot take any resolution on my own responsibility

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The order! we want the order! cried several thousand voices.
children.prevalue: The order we want the order cried several thousand voices

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Mynheer Bowelt wished to speak, but his words were not heard, and he was only seen moving his arms in all sorts of gestures, which plainly showed that he felt his position to be desperate. When, at last, he saw that he could not make himself heard, he turned round towards the open window, and called Mynheer d'Asperen.
children.prevalue: Mynheer Bowelt wished to speak but his words were not heard and he was only seen moving his arms in all sorts of gestures which plainly showed that he felt his position to be desperate When at last he saw that he could not make himself heard he turned round towards the open window and called Mynheer d Asperen

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The latter gentleman now made his appearance on the balcony, where he was saluted with shouts even more energetic than those with which, ten minutes before, his colleague had been received.
children.prevalue: The latter gentleman now made his appearance on the balcony where he was saluted with shouts even more energetic than those with which ten minutes before his colleague had been received

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: This did not prevent him from undertaking the difficult task of haranguing the mob; but the mob preferred forcing the guard of the Stateswhich, however, offered no resistance to the sovereign peopleto listening to the speech of Mynheer d'Asperen.
children.prevalue: This did not prevent him from undertaking the difficult task of haranguing the mob but the mob preferred forcing the guard of the Stateswhich however offered no resistance to the sovereign peopleto listening to the speech of Mynheer d Asperen

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Now, then, the young man coolly remarked, whilst the crowd was rushing into the principal gate of the Townhall, it seems the question will be discussed indoors, Captain. Come along, and let us hear the debate.
children.prevalue: Now then the young man coolly remarked whilst the crowd was rushing into the principal gate of the Townhall it seems the question will be discussed indoors Captain Come along and let us hear the debate

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Oh, Monseigneur! Monseigneur! take care!
children.prevalue: Oh Monseigneur Monseigneur take care

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Of what?
children.prevalue: Of what

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Among these deputies there are many who have had dealings with you, and it would be sufficient, that one of them should recognize your Highness.
children.prevalue: Among these deputies there are many who have had dealings with you and it would be sufficient that one of them should recognize your Highness

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Yes, that I might be charged with having been the instigator of all this work, indeed, you are right, said the young man, blushing for a moment from regret of having betrayed so much eagerness. From this place we shall see them return with or without the order for the withdrawal of the dragoons, then we may judge which is greater, Mynheer Bowelt's honesty or his courage.
children.prevalue: Yes that I might be charged with having been the instigator of all this work indeed you are right said the young man blushing for a moment from regret of having betrayed so much eagerness From this place we shall see them return with or without the order for the withdrawal of the dragoons then we may judge which is greater Mynheer Bowelt s honesty or his courage

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: But, replied the officer, looking with astonishment at the personage whom he addressed as Monseigneur, but your Highness surely does not suppose for one instant that the deputies will order Tilly's horse to quit their post?
children.prevalue: But replied the officer looking with astonishment at the personage whom he addressed as Monseigneur but your Highness surely does not suppose for one instant that the deputies will order Tilly s horse to quit their post

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Why not? the young man quietly retorted.
children.prevalue: Why not the young man quietly retorted

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Because doing so would simply be signing the death warrant of Cornelius and John de Witt.
children.prevalue: Because doing so would simply be signing the death warrant of Cornelius and John de Witt

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: We shall see, his Highness replied, with the most perfect coolness; God alone knows what is going on within the hearts of men.
children.prevalue: We shall see his Highness replied with the most perfect coolness God alone knows what is going on within the hearts of men

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: The officer looked askance at the impassible figure of his companion, and grew pale: he was an honest man as well as a brave one.
children.prevalue: The officer looked askance at the impassible figure of his companion and grew pale he was an honest man as well as a brave one

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: From the spot where they stood, his Highness and his attendant heard the tumult and the heavy tramp of the crowd on the staircase of the Townhall. The noise thereupon sounded through the windows of the hall, on the balcony of which Mynheers Bowelt and D'Asperen had presented themselves. These two gentlemen had retired into the building, very likely from fear of being forced over the balustrade by the pressure of the crowd.
children.prevalue: From the spot where they stood his Highness and his attendant heard the tumult and the heavy tramp of the crowd on the staircase of the Townhall The noise thereupon sounded through the windows of the hall on the balcony of which Mynheers Bowelt and D Asperen had presented themselves These two gentlemen had retired into the building very likely from fear of being forced over the balustrade by the pressure of the crowd

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: After this, fluctuating shadows in tumultuous confusion were seen flitting to and fro across the windows: the council hall was filling.
children.prevalue: After this fluctuating shadows in tumultuous confusion were seen flitting to and fro across the windows the council hall was filling

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Suddenly the noise subsided, and as suddenly again it rose with redoubled intensity, and at last reached such a pitch that the old building shook to the very roof.
children.prevalue: Suddenly the noise subsided and as suddenly again it rose with redoubled intensity and at last reached such a pitch that the old building shook to the very roof

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: At length, the living stream poured back through the galleries and stairs to the arched gateway, from which it was seen issuing like waters from a spout.
children.prevalue: At length the living stream poured back through the galleries and stairs to the arched gateway from which it was seen issuing like waters from a spout

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: At the head of the first group, man was flying rather than running, his face hideously distorted with satanic glee: this man was the surgeon Tyckelaer.
children.prevalue: At the head of the first group man was flying rather than running his face hideously distorted with satanic glee this man was the surgeon Tyckelaer

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: We have it! we have it! he cried, brandishing a paper in the air.
children.prevalue: We have it we have it he cried brandishing a paper in the air

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: They have got the order! muttered the officer in amazement.
children.prevalue: They have got the order muttered the officer in amazement

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Well, then, his Highness quietly remarked, now I know what to believe with regard to Mynheer Bowelt's honesty and courage: he has neither the one nor the other.
children.prevalue: Well then his Highness quietly remarked now I know what to believe with regard to Mynheer Bowelt s honesty and courage he has neither the one nor the other

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Then, looking with a steady glance after the crowd which was rushing along before him, he continued,
children.prevalue: Then looking with a steady glance after the crowd which was rushing along before him he continued

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Let us now go to the Buytenhof, Captain; I expect we shall see a very strange sight there.
children.prevalue: Let us now go to the Buytenhof Captain I expect we shall see a very strange sight there

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: The officer bowed, and, without making any reply, followed in the steps of his master.
children.prevalue: The officer bowed and without making any reply followed in the steps of his master

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: There was an immense crowd in the square and about the neighbourhood of the prison. But the dragoons of Tilly still kept it in check with the same success and with the same firmness.
children.prevalue: There was an immense crowd in the square and about the neighbourhood of the prison But the dragoons of Tilly still kept it in check with the same success and with the same firmness

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: It was not long before the Count heard the increasing din of the approaching multitude, the first ranks of which rushed on with the rapidity of a cataract.
children.prevalue: It was not long before the Count heard the increasing din of the approaching multitude the first ranks of which rushed on with the rapidity of a cataract

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: At the same time he observed the paper, which was waving above the surface of clenched fists and glittering arms.
children.prevalue: At the same time he observed the paper which was waving above the surface of clenched fists and glittering arms

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Halloa! he said, rising in his stirrups, and touching his lieutenant with the knob of his sword; I really believe those rascals have got the order.
children.prevalue: Halloa he said rising in his stirrups and touching his lieutenant with the knob of his sword I really believe those rascals have got the order

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Dastardly ruffians they are, cried the lieutenant.
children.prevalue: Dastardly ruffians they are cried the lieutenant

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: It was indeed the order, which the burgher guard received with a roar of triumph. They immediately sallied forth, with lowered arms and fierce shouts, to meet Count Tilly's dragoons.
children.prevalue: It was indeed the order which the burgher guard received with a roar of triumph They immediately sallied forth with lowered arms and fierce shouts to meet Count Tilly s dragoons

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: But the Count was not the man to allow them to approach within an inconvenient distance.
children.prevalue: But the Count was not the man to allow them to approach within an inconvenient distance

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Stop! he cried, stop, and keep off from my horse, or I shall give the word of command to advance.
children.prevalue: Stop he cried stop and keep off from my horse or I shall give the word of command to advance

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Here is the order! a hundred insolent voices answered at once.
children.prevalue: Here is the order a hundred insolent voices answered at once

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: He took it in amazement, cast a rapid glance on it, and said quite aloud,
children.prevalue: He took it in amazement cast a rapid glance on it and said quite aloud

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Those who have signed this order are the real murderers of Cornelius de Witt. I would rather have my two hands cut off than have written one single letter of this infamous order.
children.prevalue: Those who have signed this order are the real murderers of Cornelius de Witt I would rather have my two hands cut off than have written one single letter of this infamous order

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: And, pushing back with the hilt of his sword the man who wanted to take it from him, he added,
children.prevalue: And pushing back with the hilt of his sword the man who wanted to take it from him he added

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Wait a minute, papers like this are of importance, and are to be kept.
children.prevalue: Wait a minute papers like this are of importance and are to be kept

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Saying this, he folded up the document, and carefully put it in the pocket of his coat.
children.prevalue: Saying this he folded up the document and carefully put it in the pocket of his coat

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Then, turning round towards his troop, he gave the word of command,
children.prevalue: Then turning round towards his troop he gave the word of command

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Tilly's dragoons, wheel to the right!
children.prevalue: Tilly s dragoons wheel to the right

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: After this, he added, in an undertone, yet loud enough for his words to be not altogether lost to those about him,
children.prevalue: After this he added in an undertone yet loud enough for his words to be not altogether lost to those about him

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: And now, ye butchers, do your work!
children.prevalue: And now ye butchers do your work

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: A savage yell, in which all the keen hatred and ferocious triumph rife in the precincts of the prison simultaneously burst forth, and accompanied the departure of the dragoons, as they were quietly filing off.
children.prevalue: A savage yell in which all the keen hatred and ferocious triumph rife in the precincts of the prison simultaneously burst forth and accompanied the departure of the dragoons as they were quietly filing off

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: The Count tarried behind, facing to the last the infuriated populace, which advanced at the same rate as the Count retired.
children.prevalue: The Count tarried behind facing to the last the infuriated populace which advanced at the same rate as the Count retired

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: John de Witt, therefore, had by no means exaggerated the danger, when, assisting his brother in getting up, he hurried his departure. Cornelius, leaning on the arm of the ExGrand Pensionary, descended the stairs which led to the courtyard. At the bottom of the staircase he found little Rosa, trembling all over.
children.prevalue: John de Witt therefore had by no means exaggerated the danger when assisting his brother in getting up he hurried his departure Cornelius leaning on the arm of the ExGrand Pensionary descended the stairs which led to the courtyard At the bottom of the staircase he found little Rosa trembling all over

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Oh, Mynheer John, she said, what a misfortune!
children.prevalue: Oh Mynheer John she said what a misfortune

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: What is it, my child? asked De Witt.
children.prevalue: What is it my child asked De Witt

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: They say that they are gone to the Townhall to fetch the order for Tilly's horse to withdraw.
children.prevalue: They say that they are gone to the Townhall to fetch the order for Tilly s horse to withdraw

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: You do not say so! replied John. Indeed, my dear child, if the dragoons are off, we shall be in a very sad plight.
children.prevalue: You do not say so replied John Indeed my dear child if the dragoons are off we shall be in a very sad plight

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: I have some advice to give you, Rosa said, trembling even more violently than before.
children.prevalue: I have some advice to give you Rosa said trembling even more violently than before

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Well, let us hear what you have to say, my child. Why should not God speak by your mouth?
children.prevalue: Well let us hear what you have to say my child Why should not God speak by your mouth

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Now, then, Mynheer John, if I were in your place, I should not go out through the main street.
children.prevalue: Now then Mynheer John if I were in your place I should not go out through the main street

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: And why so, as the dragoons of Tilly are still at their post?
children.prevalue: And why so as the dragoons of Tilly are still at their post

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Yes, but their order, as long as it is not revoked, enjoins them to stop before the prison.
children.prevalue: Yes but their order as long as it is not revoked enjoins them to stop before the prison

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Undoubtedly.
children.prevalue: Undoubtedly

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Have you got an order for them to accompany you out of the town?
children.prevalue: Have you got an order for them to accompany you out of the town

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: We have not?
children.prevalue: We have not

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Well, then, in the very moment when you have passed the ranks of the dragoons you will fall into the hands of the people.
children.prevalue: Well then in the very moment when you have passed the ranks of the dragoons you will fall into the hands of the people

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: But the burgher guard?
children.prevalue: But the burgher guard

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Alas! the burgher guard are the most enraged of all.
children.prevalue: Alas the burgher guard are the most enraged of all

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: What are we to do, then?
children.prevalue: What are we to do then

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: If I were in your place, Mynheer John, the young girl timidly continued, I should leave by the postern, which leads into a deserted bylane, whilst all the people are waiting in the High Street to see you come out by the principal entrance. From there I should try to reach the gate by which you intend to leave the town.
children.prevalue: If I were in your place Mynheer John the young girl timidly continued I should leave by the postern which leads into a deserted bylane whilst all the people are waiting in the High Street to see you come out by the principal entrance From there I should try to reach the gate by which you intend to leave the town

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: But my brother is not able to walk, said John.
children.prevalue: But my brother is not able to walk said John

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: I shall try, Cornelius said, with an expression of most sublime fortitude.
children.prevalue: I shall try Cornelius said with an expression of most sublime fortitude

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: But have you not got your carriage? asked the girl.
children.prevalue: But have you not got your carriage asked the girl

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: The carriage is down near the great entrance.
children.prevalue: The carriage is down near the great entrance

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Not so, she replied. I considered your coachman to be a faithful man, and I told him to wait for you at the postern.
children.prevalue: Not so she replied I considered your coachman to be a faithful man and I told him to wait for you at the postern

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: The two brothers looked first at each other, and then at Rosa, with a glance full of the most tender gratitude.
children.prevalue: The two brothers looked first at each other and then at Rosa with a glance full of the most tender gratitude

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: The question is now, said the Grand Pensionary, whether Gryphus will open this door for us.
children.prevalue: The question is now said the Grand Pensionary whether Gryphus will open this door for us

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Indeed, he will do no such thing, said Rosa.
children.prevalue: Indeed he will do no such thing said Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Well, and how then?
children.prevalue: Well and how then

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: I have foreseen his refusal, and just now whilst he was talking from the window of the porter's lodge with a dragoon, I took away the key from his bunch.
children.prevalue: I have foreseen his refusal and just now whilst he was talking from the window of the porter s lodge with a dragoon I took away the key from his bunch

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: And you have got it?
children.prevalue: And you have got it

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Here it is, Mynheer John.
children.prevalue: Here it is Mynheer John

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: My child, said Cornelius, I have nothing to give you in exchange for the service you are rendering us but the Bible which you will find in my room; it is the last gift of an honest man; I hope it will bring you good luck.
children.prevalue: My child said Cornelius I have nothing to give you in exchange for the service you are rendering us but the Bible which you will find in my room it is the last gift of an honest man I hope it will bring you good luck

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: I thank you, Master Cornelius, it shall never leave me, replied Rosa.
children.prevalue: I thank you Master Cornelius it shall never leave me replied Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: And then, with a sigh, she said to herself, What a pity that I do not know how to read!
children.prevalue: And then with a sigh she said to herself What a pity that I do not know how to read

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: The shouts and cries are growing louder and louder, said John; there is not a moment to be lost.
children.prevalue: The shouts and cries are growing louder and louder said John there is not a moment to be lost

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Come along, gentlemen, said the girl, who now led the two brothers through an inner lobby to the back of the prison. Guided by her, they descended a staircase of about a dozen steps; traversed a small courtyard, which was surrounded by castellated walls; and, the arched door having been opened for them by Rosa, they emerged into a lonely street where their carriage was ready to receive them.
children.prevalue: Come along gentlemen said the girl who now led the two brothers through an inner lobby to the back of the prison Guided by her they descended a staircase of about a dozen steps traversed a small courtyard which was surrounded by castellated walls and the arched door having been opened for them by Rosa they emerged into a lonely street where their carriage was ready to receive them

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Quick, quick, my masters! do you hear them? cried the coachman, in a deadly fright.
children.prevalue: Quick quick my masters do you hear them cried the coachman in a deadly fright

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Yet, after having made Cornelius get into the carriage first, the Grand Pensionary turned round towards the girl, to whom he said,
children.prevalue: Yet after having made Cornelius get into the carriage first the Grand Pensionary turned round towards the girl to whom he said

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Goodbye, my child! words could never express our gratitude. God will reward you for having saved the lives of two men.
children.prevalue: Goodbye my child words could never express our gratitude God will reward you for having saved the lives of two men

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Rosa took the hand which John de Witt proffered to her, and kissed it with every show of respect.
children.prevalue: Rosa took the hand which John de Witt proffered to her and kissed it with every show of respect

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Go! for Heaven's sake, go! she said; it seems they are going to force the gate.
children.prevalue: Go for Heaven s sake go she said it seems they are going to force the gate

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: John de Witt hastily got in, sat himself down by the side of his brother, and, fastening the apron of the carriage, called out to the coachman,
children.prevalue: John de Witt hastily got in sat himself down by the side of his brother and fastening the apron of the carriage called out to the coachman

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: To the TolHek!
children.prevalue: To the TolHek

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: The TolHek was the iron gate leading to the harbor of Schevening, in which a small vessel was waiting for the two brothers.
children.prevalue: The TolHek was the iron gate leading to the harbor of Schevening in which a small vessel was waiting for the two brothers

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: The carriage drove off with the fugitives at the full speed of a pair of spirited Flemish horses. Rosa followed them with her eyes until they turned the corner of the street, upon which, closing the door after her, she went back and threw the key into a cell.
children.prevalue: The carriage drove off with the fugitives at the full speed of a pair of spirited Flemish horses Rosa followed them with her eyes until they turned the corner of the street upon which closing the door after her she went back and threw the key into a cell

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: The noise which had made Rosa suppose that the people were forcing the prison door was indeed owing to the mob battering against it after the square had been left by the military.
children.prevalue: The noise which had made Rosa suppose that the people were forcing the prison door was indeed owing to the mob battering against it after the square had been left by the military

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Solid as the gate was, and although Gryphus, to do him justice, stoutly enough refused to open it, yet evidently it could not resist much longer, and the jailer, growing very pale, put to himself the question whether it would not be better to open the door than to allow it to be forced, when he felt some one gently pulling his coat.
children.prevalue: Solid as the gate was and although Gryphus to do him justice stoutly enough refused to open it yet evidently it could not resist much longer and the jailer growing very pale put to himself the question whether it would not be better to open the door than to allow it to be forced when he felt some one gently pulling his coat

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: He turned round and saw Rosa.
children.prevalue: He turned round and saw Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Do you hear these madmen? he said.
children.prevalue: Do you hear these madmen he said

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: I hear them so well, my father, that in your place
children.prevalue: I hear them so well my father that in your place

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: You would open the door?
children.prevalue: You would open the door

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: No, I should allow it to be forced.
children.prevalue: No I should allow it to be forced

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: But they will kill me!
children.prevalue: But they will kill me

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Yes, if they see you.
children.prevalue: Yes if they see you

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: How shall they not see me?
children.prevalue: How shall they not see me

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Hide yourself.
children.prevalue: Hide yourself

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: Where?
children.prevalue: Where

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: In the secret dungeon.
children.prevalue: In the secret dungeon

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: But you, my child?
children.prevalue: But you my child

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: I shall get into it with you. We shall lock the door and when they have left the prison, we shall again come forth from our hiding place.
children.prevalue: I shall get into it with you We shall lock the door and when they have left the prison we shall again come forth from our hiding place

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: Zounds, you are right, there! cried Gryphus; it's surprising how much sense there is in such a little head!
children.prevalue: Zounds you are right there cried Gryphus it s surprising how much sense there is in such a little head

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: Then, as the gate began to give way amidst the triumphant shouts of the mob, she opened a little trapdoor, and said,
children.prevalue: Then as the gate began to give way amidst the triumphant shouts of the mob she opened a little trapdoor and said

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Come along, come along, father.
children.prevalue: Come along come along father

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: But our prisoners?
children.prevalue: But our prisoners

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: God will watch over them, and I shall watch over you.
children.prevalue: God will watch over them and I shall watch over you

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Gryphus followed his daughter, and the trapdoor closed over his head, just as the broken gate gave admittance to the populace.
children.prevalue: Gryphus followed his daughter and the trapdoor closed over his head just as the broken gate gave admittance to the populace

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: The dungeon where Rosa had induced her father to hide himself, and where for the present we must leave the two, offered to them a perfectly safe retreat, being known only to those in power, who used to place there important prisoners of state, to guard against a rescue or a revolt.
children.prevalue: The dungeon where Rosa had induced her father to hide himself and where for the present we must leave the two offered to them a perfectly safe retreat being known only to those in power who used to place there important prisoners of state to guard against a rescue or a revolt

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: The people rushed into the prison, with the cry
children.prevalue: The people rushed into the prison with the cry

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: Death to the traitors! To the gallows with Cornelius de Witt! Death! death!
children.prevalue: Death to the traitors To the gallows with Cornelius de Witt Death death

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The young man with his hat slouched over his eyes, still leaning on the arm of the officer, and still wiping from time to time his brow with his handkerchief, was watching in a corner of the Buytenhof, in the shade of the overhanging weatherboard of a closed shop, the doings of the infuriated mob, a spectacle which seemed to draw near its catastrophe.
children.prevalue: The young man with his hat slouched over his eyes still leaning on the arm of the officer and still wiping from time to time his brow with his handkerchief was watching in a corner of the Buytenhof in the shade of the overhanging weatherboard of a closed shop the doings of the infuriated mob a spectacle which seemed to draw near its catastrophe

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Indeed, said he to the officer, indeed, I think you were right, Van Deken; the order which the deputies have signed is truly the deathwarrant of Master Cornelius. Do you hear these people? They certainly bear a sad grudge to the two De Witts.
children.prevalue: Indeed said he to the officer indeed I think you were right Van Deken the order which the deputies have signed is truly the deathwarrant of Master Cornelius Do you hear these people They certainly bear a sad grudge to the two De Witts

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: In truth, replied the officer, I never heard such shouts.
children.prevalue: In truth replied the officer I never heard such shouts

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: They seem to have found out the cell of the man. Look, look! is not that the window of the cell where Cornelius was locked up?
children.prevalue: They seem to have found out the cell of the man Look look is not that the window of the cell where Cornelius was locked up

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: A man had seized with both hands and was shaking the iron bars of the window in the room which Cornelius had left only ten minutes before.
children.prevalue: A man had seized with both hands and was shaking the iron bars of the window in the room which Cornelius had left only ten minutes before

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Halloa, halloa! the man called out, he is gone.
children.prevalue: Halloa halloa the man called out he is gone

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: How is that? gone? asked those of the mob who had not been able to get into the prison, crowded as it was with the mass of intruders.
children.prevalue: How is that gone asked those of the mob who had not been able to get into the prison crowded as it was with the mass of intruders

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Gone, gone, repeated the man in a rage, the bird has flown.
children.prevalue: Gone gone repeated the man in a rage the bird has flown

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: What does this man say? asked his Highness, growing quite pale.
children.prevalue: What does this man say asked his Highness growing quite pale

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Oh, Monseigneur, he says a thing which would be very fortunate if it should turn out true!
children.prevalue: Oh Monseigneur he says a thing which would be very fortunate if it should turn out true

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Certainly it would be fortunate if it were true, said the young man; unfortunately it cannot be true.
children.prevalue: Certainly it would be fortunate if it were true said the young man unfortunately it cannot be true

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: However, look! said the officer.
children.prevalue: However look said the officer

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: And indeed, some more faces, furious and contorted with rage, showed themselves at the windows, crying,
children.prevalue: And indeed some more faces furious and contorted with rage showed themselves at the windows crying

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Escaped, gone, they have helped them off!
children.prevalue: Escaped gone they have helped them off

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: And the people in the street repeated, with fearful imprecations,
children.prevalue: And the people in the street repeated with fearful imprecations

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Escaped gone! After them, and catch them!
children.prevalue: Escaped gone After them and catch them

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Monseigneur, it seems that Mynheer Cornelius has really escaped, said the officer.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur it seems that Mynheer Cornelius has really escaped said the officer

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Yes, from prison, perhaps, but not from the town; you will see, Van Deken, that the poor fellow will find the gate closed against him which he hoped to find open.
children.prevalue: Yes from prison perhaps but not from the town you will see Van Deken that the poor fellow will find the gate closed against him which he hoped to find open

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Has an order been given to close the town gates, Monseigneur?
children.prevalue: Has an order been given to close the town gates Monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: No,at least I do not think so; who could have given such an order?
children.prevalue: No at least I do not think so who could have given such an order

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Indeed, but what makes your Highness suppose?
children.prevalue: Indeed but what makes your Highness suppose

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: There are fatalities, Monseigneur replied, in an offhand manner; and the greatest men have sometimes fallen victims to such fatalities.
children.prevalue: There are fatalities Monseigneur replied in an offhand manner and the greatest men have sometimes fallen victims to such fatalities

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: At these words the officer felt his blood run cold, as somehow or other he was convinced that the prisoner was lost.
children.prevalue: At these words the officer felt his blood run cold as somehow or other he was convinced that the prisoner was lost

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: At this moment the roar of the multitude broke forth like thunder, for it was now quite certain that Cornelius de Witt was no longer in the prison.
children.prevalue: At this moment the roar of the multitude broke forth like thunder for it was now quite certain that Cornelius de Witt was no longer in the prison

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Cornelius and John, after driving along the pond, had taken the main street, which leads to the TolHek, giving directions to the coachman to slacken his pace, in order not to excite any suspicion.
children.prevalue: Cornelius and John after driving along the pond had taken the main street which leads to the TolHek giving directions to the coachman to slacken his pace in order not to excite any suspicion

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: But when, on having proceeded halfway down that street, the man felt that he had left the prison and death behind, and before him there was life and liberty, he neglected every precaution, and set his horses off at a gallop.
children.prevalue: But when on having proceeded halfway down that street the man felt that he had left the prison and death behind and before him there was life and liberty he neglected every precaution and set his horses off at a gallop

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: All at once he stopped.
children.prevalue: All at once he stopped

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: What is the matter? asked John, putting his head out of the coach window.
children.prevalue: What is the matter asked John putting his head out of the coach window

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Oh, my masters! cried the coachman, it is
children.prevalue: Oh my masters cried the coachman it is

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Terror choked the voice of the honest fellow.
children.prevalue: Terror choked the voice of the honest fellow

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Well, say what you have to say! urged the Grand Pensionary.
children.prevalue: Well say what you have to say urged the Grand Pensionary

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The gate is closed, that's what it is.
children.prevalue: The gate is closed that s what it is

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: How is this? It is not usual to close the gate by day.
children.prevalue: How is this It is not usual to close the gate by day

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Just look!
children.prevalue: Just look

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: John de Witt leaned out of the window, and indeed saw that the man was right.
children.prevalue: John de Witt leaned out of the window and indeed saw that the man was right

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Never mind, but drive on, said John, I have with me the order for the commutation of the punishment, the gatekeeper will let us through.
children.prevalue: Never mind but drive on said John I have with me the order for the commutation of the punishment the gatekeeper will let us through

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The carriage moved along, but it was evident that the driver was no longer urging his horses with the same degree of confidence.
children.prevalue: The carriage moved along but it was evident that the driver was no longer urging his horses with the same degree of confidence

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Moreover, as John de Witt put his head out of the carriage window, he was seen and recognized by a brewer, who, being behind his companions, was just shutting his door in all haste to join them at the Buytenhof. He uttered a cry of surprise, and ran after two other men before him, whom he overtook about a hundred yards farther on, and told them what he had seen. The three men then stopped, looking after the carriage, being however not yet quite sure as to whom it contained.
children.prevalue: Moreover as John de Witt put his head out of the carriage window he was seen and recognized by a brewer who being behind his companions was just shutting his door in all haste to join them at the Buytenhof He uttered a cry of surprise and ran after two other men before him whom he overtook about a hundred yards farther on and told them what he had seen The three men then stopped looking after the carriage being however not yet quite sure as to whom it contained

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The carriage in the meanwhile arrived at the TolHek.
children.prevalue: The carriage in the meanwhile arrived at the TolHek

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Open! cried the coachman.
children.prevalue: Open cried the coachman

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Open! echoed the gatekeeper, from the threshold of his lodge; it's all very well to say 'Open!' but what am I to do it with?
children.prevalue: Open echoed the gatekeeper from the threshold of his lodge it s all very well to say Open but what am I to do it with

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: With the key, to be sure! said the coachman.
children.prevalue: With the key to be sure said the coachman

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: With the key! Oh, yes! but if you have not got it?
children.prevalue: With the key Oh yes but if you have not got it

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: How is that? Have not you got the key? asked the coachman.
children.prevalue: How is that Have not you got the key asked the coachman

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: No, I haven't.
children.prevalue: No I haven t

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: What has become of it?
children.prevalue: What has become of it

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Well, they have taken it from me.
children.prevalue: Well they have taken it from me

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Who?
children.prevalue: Who

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Some one, I dare say, who had a mind that no one should leave the town.
children.prevalue: Some one I dare say who had a mind that no one should leave the town

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: My good man, said the Grand Pensionary, putting out his head from the window, and risking all for gaining all; my good man, it is for me, John de Witt, and for my brother Cornelius, who I am taking away into exile.
children.prevalue: My good man said the Grand Pensionary putting out his head from the window and risking all for gaining all my good man it is for me John de Witt and for my brother Cornelius who I am taking away into exile

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Oh, Mynheer de Witt! I am indeed very much grieved, said the gatekeeper, rushing towards the carriage; but, upon my sacred word, the key has been taken from me.
children.prevalue: Oh Mynheer de Witt I am indeed very much grieved said the gatekeeper rushing towards the carriage but upon my sacred word the key has been taken from me

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: When?
children.prevalue: When

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: This morning.
children.prevalue: This morning

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: By whom?
children.prevalue: By whom

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: By a pale and thin young man, of about twentytwo.
children.prevalue: By a pale and thin young man of about twentytwo

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: And wherefore did you give it up to him?
children.prevalue: And wherefore did you give it up to him

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Because he showed me an order, signed and sealed.
children.prevalue: Because he showed me an order signed and sealed

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: By whom?
children.prevalue: By whom

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: By the gentlemen of the Townhall.
children.prevalue: By the gentlemen of the Townhall

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Well, then, said Cornelius calmly, our doom seems to be fixed.
children.prevalue: Well then said Cornelius calmly our doom seems to be fixed

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Do you know whether the same precaution has been taken at the other gates?
children.prevalue: Do you know whether the same precaution has been taken at the other gates

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I do not.
children.prevalue: I do not

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Now then, said John to the coachman, God commands man to do all that is in his power to preserve his life; go, and drive to another gate.
children.prevalue: Now then said John to the coachman God commands man to do all that is in his power to preserve his life go and drive to another gate

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: And whilst the servant was turning round the vehicle the Grand Pensionary said to the gatekeeper,
children.prevalue: And whilst the servant was turning round the vehicle the Grand Pensionary said to the gatekeeper

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Take our thanks for your good intentions; the will must count for the deed; you had the will to save us, and that, in the eyes of the Lord, is as if you had succeeded in doing so.
children.prevalue: Take our thanks for your good intentions the will must count for the deed you had the will to save us and that in the eyes of the Lord is as if you had succeeded in doing so

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Alas! said the gatekeeper, do you see down there?
children.prevalue: Alas said the gatekeeper do you see down there

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Drive at a gallop through that group, John called out to the coachman, and take the street on the left; it is our only chance.
children.prevalue: Drive at a gallop through that group John called out to the coachman and take the street on the left it is our only chance

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: The group which John alluded to had, for its nucleus, those three men whom we left looking after the carriage, and who, in the meanwhile, had been joined by seven or eight others.
children.prevalue: The group which John alluded to had for its nucleus those three men whom we left looking after the carriage and who in the meanwhile had been joined by seven or eight others

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: These newcomers evidently meant mischief with regard to the carriage.
children.prevalue: These newcomers evidently meant mischief with regard to the carriage

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: When they saw the horses galloping down upon them, they placed themselves across the street, brandishing cudgels in their hands, and calling out,
children.prevalue: When they saw the horses galloping down upon them they placed themselves across the street brandishing cudgels in their hands and calling out

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Stop! stop!
children.prevalue: Stop stop

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: The coachman, on his side, lashed his horses into increased speed, until the coach and the men encountered.
children.prevalue: The coachman on his side lashed his horses into increased speed until the coach and the men encountered

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: The brothers De Witt, enclosed within the body of the carriage, were not able to see anything; but they felt a severe shock, occasioned by the rearing of the horses. The whole vehicle for a moment shook and stopped; but immediately after, passing over something round and elastic, which seemed to be the body of a prostrate man set off again amidst a volley of the fiercest oaths.
children.prevalue: The brothers De Witt enclosed within the body of the carriage were not able to see anything but they felt a severe shock occasioned by the rearing of the horses The whole vehicle for a moment shook and stopped but immediately after passing over something round and elastic which seemed to be the body of a prostrate man set off again amidst a volley of the fiercest oaths

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Alas! said Cornelius, I am afraid we have hurt some one.
children.prevalue: Alas said Cornelius I am afraid we have hurt some one

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Gallop! gallop! called John.
children.prevalue: Gallop gallop called John

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: But, notwithstanding this order, the coachman suddenly came to a stop.
children.prevalue: But notwithstanding this order the coachman suddenly came to a stop

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Now, then, what is the matter again? asked John.
children.prevalue: Now then what is the matter again asked John

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Look there! said the coachman.
children.prevalue: Look there said the coachman

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: John looked. The whole mass of the populace from the Buytenhof appeared at the extremity of the street along which the carriage was to proceed, and its stream moved roaring and rapid, as if lashed on by a hurricane.
children.prevalue: John looked The whole mass of the populace from the Buytenhof appeared at the extremity of the street along which the carriage was to proceed and its stream moved roaring and rapid as if lashed on by a hurricane

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Stop and get off, said John to the coachman; it is useless to go any farther; we are lost!
children.prevalue: Stop and get off said John to the coachman it is useless to go any farther we are lost

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Here they are! here they are! five hundred voices were crying at the same time.
children.prevalue: Here they are here they are five hundred voices were crying at the same time

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Yes, here they are, the traitors, the murderers, the assassins! answered the men who were running after the carriage to the people who were coming to meet it. The former carried in their arms the bruised body of one of their companions, who, trying to seize the reins of the horses, had been trodden down by them.
children.prevalue: Yes here they are the traitors the murderers the assassins answered the men who were running after the carriage to the people who were coming to meet it The former carried in their arms the bruised body of one of their companions who trying to seize the reins of the horses had been trodden down by them

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: This was the object over which the two brothers had felt their carriage pass.
children.prevalue: This was the object over which the two brothers had felt their carriage pass

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: The coachman stopped, but, however strongly his master urged him, he refused to get off and save himself.
children.prevalue: The coachman stopped but however strongly his master urged him he refused to get off and save himself

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: In an instant the carriage was hemmed in between those who followed and those who met it. It rose above the mass of moving heads like a floating island. But in another instant it came to a dead stop. A blacksmith had with his hammer struck down one of the horses, which fell in the traces.
children.prevalue: In an instant the carriage was hemmed in between those who followed and those who met it It rose above the mass of moving heads like a floating island But in another instant it came to a dead stop A blacksmith had with his hammer struck down one of the horses which fell in the traces

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: At this moment, the shutter of a window opened, and disclosed the sallow face and the dark eyes of the young man, who with intense interest watched the scene which was preparing. Behind him appeared the head of the officer, almost as pale as himself.
children.prevalue: At this moment the shutter of a window opened and disclosed the sallow face and the dark eyes of the young man who with intense interest watched the scene which was preparing Behind him appeared the head of the officer almost as pale as himself

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Good heavens, Monseigneur, what is going on there? whispered the officer.
children.prevalue: Good heavens Monseigneur what is going on there whispered the officer

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Something very terrible, to a certainty, replied the other.
children.prevalue: Something very terrible to a certainty replied the other

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Don't you see, Monseigneur, they are dragging the Grand Pensionary from the carriage, they strike him, they tear him to pieces!
children.prevalue: Don t you see Monseigneur they are dragging the Grand Pensionary from the carriage they strike him they tear him to pieces

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Indeed, these people must certainly be prompted by a most violent indignation, said the young man, with the same impassible tone which he had preserved all along.
children.prevalue: Indeed these people must certainly be prompted by a most violent indignation said the young man with the same impassible tone which he had preserved all along

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: And here is Cornelius, whom they now likewise drag out of the carriage,Cornelius, who is already quite broken and mangled by the torture. Only look, look!
children.prevalue: And here is Cornelius whom they now likewise drag out of the carriage Cornelius who is already quite broken and mangled by the torture Only look look

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Indeed, it is Cornelius, and no mistake.
children.prevalue: Indeed it is Cornelius and no mistake

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: The officer uttered a feeble cry, and turned his head away; the brother of the Grand Pensionary, before having set foot on the ground, whilst still on the bottom step of the carriage, was struck down with an iron bar which broke his skull. He rose once more, but immediately fell again.
children.prevalue: The officer uttered a feeble cry and turned his head away the brother of the Grand Pensionary before having set foot on the ground whilst still on the bottom step of the carriage was struck down with an iron bar which broke his skull He rose once more but immediately fell again

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Some fellows then seized him by the feet, and dragged him into the crowd, into the middle of which one might have followed his bloody track, and he was soon closed in among the savage yells of malignant exultation.
children.prevalue: Some fellows then seized him by the feet and dragged him into the crowd into the middle of which one might have followed his bloody track and he was soon closed in among the savage yells of malignant exultation

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: The young mana thing which would have been thought impossiblegrew even paler than before, and his eyes were for a moment veiled behind the lids.
children.prevalue: The young mana thing which would have been thought impossiblegrew even paler than before and his eyes were for a moment veiled behind the lids

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: The officer saw this sign of compassion, and, wishing to avail himself of this softened tone of his feelings, continued,
children.prevalue: The officer saw this sign of compassion and wishing to avail himself of this softened tone of his feelings continued

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Come, come, Monseigneur, for here they are also going to murder the Grand Pensionary.
children.prevalue: Come come Monseigneur for here they are also going to murder the Grand Pensionary

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: But the young man had already opened his eyes again.
children.prevalue: But the young man had already opened his eyes again

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: To be sure, he said. These people are really implacable. It does no one good to offend them.
children.prevalue: To be sure he said These people are really implacable It does no one good to offend them

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Monseigneur, said the officer, may not one save this poor man, who has been your Highness's instructor? If there be any means, name it, and if I should perish in the attempt
children.prevalue: Monseigneur said the officer may not one save this poor man who has been your Highness s instructor If there be any means name it and if I should perish in the attempt

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: William of Orangefor he it wasknit his brows in a very forbidding manner, restrained the glance of gloomy malice which glistened in his halfclosed eye, and answered,
children.prevalue: William of Orangefor he it wasknit his brows in a very forbidding manner restrained the glance of gloomy malice which glistened in his halfclosed eye and answered

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Captain Van Deken, I request you to go and look after my troops, that they may be armed for any emergency.
children.prevalue: Captain Van Deken I request you to go and look after my troops that they may be armed for any emergency

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: But am I to leave your Highness here, alone, in the presence of all these murderers?
children.prevalue: But am I to leave your Highness here alone in the presence of all these murderers

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Go, and don't you trouble yourself about me more than I do myself, the Prince gruffly replied.
children.prevalue: Go and don t you trouble yourself about me more than I do myself the Prince gruffly replied

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: The officer started off with a speed which was much less owing to his sense of military obedience than to his pleasure at being relieved from the necessity of witnessing the shocking spectacle of the murder of the other brother.
children.prevalue: The officer started off with a speed which was much less owing to his sense of military obedience than to his pleasure at being relieved from the necessity of witnessing the shocking spectacle of the murder of the other brother

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: He had scarcely left the room, when Johnwho, with an almost superhuman effort, had reached the stone steps of a house nearly opposite that where his former pupil concealed himselfbegan to stagger under the blows which were inflicted on him from all sides, calling out,
children.prevalue: He had scarcely left the room when Johnwho with an almost superhuman effort had reached the stone steps of a house nearly opposite that where his former pupil concealed himselfbegan to stagger under the blows which were inflicted on him from all sides calling out

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: My brother! where is my brother?
children.prevalue: My brother where is my brother

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: One of the ruffians knocked off his hat with a blow of his clenched fist.
children.prevalue: One of the ruffians knocked off his hat with a blow of his clenched fist

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Another showed to him his bloody hands; for this fellow had ripped open Cornelius and disembowelled him, and was now hastening to the spot in order not to lose the opportunity of serving the Grand Pensionary in the same manner, whilst they were dragging the dead body of Cornelius to the gibbet.
children.prevalue: Another showed to him his bloody hands for this fellow had ripped open Cornelius and disembowelled him and was now hastening to the spot in order not to lose the opportunity of serving the Grand Pensionary in the same manner whilst they were dragging the dead body of Cornelius to the gibbet

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: John uttered a cry of agony and grief, and put one of his hands before his eyes.
children.prevalue: John uttered a cry of agony and grief and put one of his hands before his eyes

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Oh, you close your eyes, do you? said one of the soldiers of the burgher guard; well, I shall open them for you.
children.prevalue: Oh you close your eyes do you said one of the soldiers of the burgher guard well I shall open them for you

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: And saying this he stabbed him with his pike in the face, and the blood spurted forth.
children.prevalue: And saying this he stabbed him with his pike in the face and the blood spurted forth

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: My brother! cried John de Witt, trying to see through the stream of blood which blinded him, what had become of Cornelius; my brother, my brother!
children.prevalue: My brother cried John de Witt trying to see through the stream of blood which blinded him what had become of Cornelius my brother my brother

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Go and run after him! bellowed another murderer, putting his musket to his temples and pulling the trigger.
children.prevalue: Go and run after him bellowed another murderer putting his musket to his temples and pulling the trigger

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: But the gun did not go off.
children.prevalue: But the gun did not go off

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: The fellow then turned his musket round, and, taking it by the barrel with both hands, struck John de Witt down with the buttend. John staggered and fell down at his feet, but, raising himself with a last effort, he once more called out,
children.prevalue: The fellow then turned his musket round and taking it by the barrel with both hands struck John de Witt down with the buttend John staggered and fell down at his feet but raising himself with a last effort he once more called out

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: My brother! with a voice so full of anguish that the young man opposite closed the shutter.
children.prevalue: My brother with a voice so full of anguish that the young man opposite closed the shutter

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: There remained little more to see; a third murderer fired a pistol with the muzzle to his face; and this time the shot took effect, blowing out his brains. John de Witt fell to rise no more.
children.prevalue: There remained little more to see a third murderer fired a pistol with the muzzle to his face and this time the shot took effect blowing out his brains John de Witt fell to rise no more

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: On this, every one of the miscreants, emboldened by his fall, wanted to fire his gun at him, or strike him with blows of the sledgehammer, or stab him with a knife or swords, every one wanted to draw a drop of blood from the fallen hero, and tear off a shred from his garments.
children.prevalue: On this every one of the miscreants emboldened by his fall wanted to fire his gun at him or strike him with blows of the sledgehammer or stab him with a knife or swords every one wanted to draw a drop of blood from the fallen hero and tear off a shred from his garments

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: And after having mangled, and torn, and completely stripped the two brothers, the mob dragged their naked and bloody bodies to an extemporised gibbet, where amateur executioners hung them up by the feet.
children.prevalue: And after having mangled and torn and completely stripped the two brothers the mob dragged their naked and bloody bodies to an extemporised gibbet where amateur executioners hung them up by the feet

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Then came the most dastardly scoundrels of all, who not having dared to strike the living flesh, cut the dead in pieces, and then went about the town selling small slices of the bodies of John and Cornelius at ten sous a piece.
children.prevalue: Then came the most dastardly scoundrels of all who not having dared to strike the living flesh cut the dead in pieces and then went about the town selling small slices of the bodies of John and Cornelius at ten sous a piece

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: We cannot take upon ourselves to say whether, through the almost imperceptible chink of the shutter, the young man witnessed the conclusion of this shocking scene; but at the very moment when they were hanging the two martyrs on the gibbet he passed through the terrible mob, which was too much absorbed in the task, so grateful to its taste, to take any notice of him, and thus he reached unobserved the TolHek, which was still closed.
children.prevalue: We cannot take upon ourselves to say whether through the almost imperceptible chink of the shutter the young man witnessed the conclusion of this shocking scene but at the very moment when they were hanging the two martyrs on the gibbet he passed through the terrible mob which was too much absorbed in the task so grateful to its taste to take any notice of him and thus he reached unobserved the TolHek which was still closed

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: Ah! sir, said the gatekeeper, do you bring me the key?
children.prevalue: Ah sir said the gatekeeper do you bring me the key

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: Yes, my man, here it is.
children.prevalue: Yes my man here it is

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: It is most unfortunate that you did not bring me that key only one quarter of an hour sooner, said the gatekeeper, with a sigh.
children.prevalue: It is most unfortunate that you did not bring me that key only one quarter of an hour sooner said the gatekeeper with a sigh

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: And why that? asked the other.
children.prevalue: And why that asked the other

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: Because I might have opened the gate to Mynheers de Witt; whereas, finding the gate locked, they were obliged to retrace their steps.
children.prevalue: Because I might have opened the gate to Mynheers de Witt whereas finding the gate locked they were obliged to retrace their steps

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Gate! gate! cried a voice which seemed to be that of a man in a hurry.
children.prevalue: Gate gate cried a voice which seemed to be that of a man in a hurry

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: The Prince, turning round, observed Captain Van Deken.
children.prevalue: The Prince turning round observed Captain Van Deken

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: Is that you, Captain? he said. You are not yet out of the Hague? This is executing my orders very slowly.
children.prevalue: Is that you Captain he said You are not yet out of the Hague This is executing my orders very slowly

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Monseigneur, replied the Captain, this is the third gate at which I have presented myself; the other two were closed.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur replied the Captain this is the third gate at which I have presented myself the other two were closed

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: Well, this good man will open this one for you; do it, my friend.
children.prevalue: Well this good man will open this one for you do it my friend

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: The last words were addressed to the gatekeeper, who stood quite thunderstruck on hearing Captain Van Deken addressing by the title of Monseigneur this pale young man, to whom he himself had spoken in such a familiar way.
children.prevalue: The last words were addressed to the gatekeeper who stood quite thunderstruck on hearing Captain Van Deken addressing by the title of Monseigneur this pale young man to whom he himself had spoken in such a familiar way

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: As it were to make up for his fault, he hastened to open the gate, which swung creaking on its hinges.
children.prevalue: As it were to make up for his fault he hastened to open the gate which swung creaking on its hinges

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: Will Monseigneur avail himself of my horse? asked the Captain.
children.prevalue: Will Monseigneur avail himself of my horse asked the Captain

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: I thank you, Captain, I shall use my own steed, which is waiting for me close at hand.
children.prevalue: I thank you Captain I shall use my own steed which is waiting for me close at hand

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: And taking from his pocket a golden whistle, such as was generally used at that time for summoning the servants, he sounded it with a shrill and prolonged call, on which an equerry on horseback speedily made his appearance, leading another horse by the bridle.
children.prevalue: And taking from his pocket a golden whistle such as was generally used at that time for summoning the servants he sounded it with a shrill and prolonged call on which an equerry on horseback speedily made his appearance leading another horse by the bridle

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: William, without touching the stirrup, vaulted into the saddle of the led horse, and, setting his spurs into its flanks, started off for the Leyden road. Having reached it, he turned round and beckoned to the Captain who was far behind, to ride by his side.
children.prevalue: William without touching the stirrup vaulted into the saddle of the led horse and setting his spurs into its flanks started off for the Leyden road Having reached it he turned round and beckoned to the Captain who was far behind to ride by his side

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: Do you know, he then said, without stopping, that those rascals have killed John de Witt as well as his brother?
children.prevalue: Do you know he then said without stopping that those rascals have killed John de Witt as well as his brother

children.name: Paragraph_140
