The deposit intrusted to Van Baerle, and carefully locked up by him, was nothing more nor less than John de Witt's correspondence with the Marquis de Louvois, the war minister of the King of France; only the godfather forbore giving to his godson the least intimation concerning the political importance of the secret, merely desiring him not to deliver the parcel to any one but to himself, or to whomsoever he should send to claim it in his name.
children.prevalue: Boxtel had not been mistaken in his supposition The deposit intrusted to Van Baerle and carefully locked up by him was nothing more nor less than John de Witt s correspondence with the Marquis de Louvois the war minister of the King of France only the godfather forbore giving to his godson the least intimation concerning the political importance of the secret merely desiring him not to deliver the parcel to any one but to himself or to whomsoever he should send to claim it in his name

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: And Van Baerle, as we have seen, locked it up with his most precious bulbs, to think no more of it, after his godfather had left him; very unlike Boxtel, who looked upon this parcel as a clever pilot does on the distant and scarcely perceptible cloud which is increasing on its way and which is fraught with a storm.
children.prevalue: And Van Baerle as we have seen locked it up with his most precious bulbs to think no more of it after his godfather had left him very unlike Boxtel who looked upon this parcel as a clever pilot does on the distant and scarcely perceptible cloud which is increasing on its way and which is fraught with a storm

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Little dreaming of the jealous hatred of his neighbour, Van Baerle had proceeded step by step towards gaining the prize offered by the Horticultural Society of Haarlem. He had progressed from hazelnut shade to that of roasted coffee, and on the very day when the frightful events took place at the Hague which we have related in the preceding chapters, we find him, about one o'clock in the day, gathering from the border the young suckers raised from tulips of the colour of roasted coffee; and which, being expected to flower for the first time in the spring of 1675, would undoubtedly produce the large black tulip required by the Haarlem Society.
children.prevalue: Little dreaming of the jealous hatred of his neighbour Van Baerle had proceeded step by step towards gaining the prize offered by the Horticultural Society of Haarlem He had progressed from hazelnut shade to that of roasted coffee and on the very day when the frightful events took place at the Hague which we have related in the preceding chapters we find him about one o clock in the day gathering from the border the young suckers raised from tulips of the colour of roasted coffee and which being expected to flower for the first time in the spring of 1675 would undoubtedly produce the large black tulip required by the Haarlem Society

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: On the 20th of August, 1672, at one o'clock, Cornelius was therefore in his dryroom, with his feet resting on the footbar of the table, and his elbows on the cover, looking with intense delight on three suckers which he had just detached from the mother bulb, pure, perfect, and entire, and from which was to grow that wonderful produce of horticulture which would render the name of Cornelius van Baerle for ever illustrious.
children.prevalue: On the 20th of August 1672 at one o clock Cornelius was therefore in his dryroom with his feet resting on the footbar of the table and his elbows on the cover looking with intense delight on three suckers which he had just detached from the mother bulb pure perfect and entire and from which was to grow that wonderful produce of horticulture which would render the name of Cornelius van Baerle for ever illustrious

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I shall find the black tulip, said Cornelius to himself, whilst detaching the suckers. I shall obtain the hundred thousand guilders offered by the Society. I shall distribute them among the poor of Dort; and thus the hatred which every rich man has to encounter in times of civil wars will be soothed down, and I shall be able, without fearing any harm either from Republicans or Orangists, to keep as heretofore my borders in splendid condition. I need no more be afraid lest on the day of a riot the shopkeepers of the town and the sailors of the port should come and tear out my bulbs, to boil them as onions for their families, as they have sometimes quietly threatened when they happened to remember my having paid two or three hundred guilders for one bulb. It is therefore settled I shall give the hundred thousand guilders of the Haarlem prize tothe poor. And yet
children.prevalue: I shall find the black tulip said Cornelius to himself whilst detaching the suckers I shall obtain the hundred thousand guilders offered by the Society I shall distribute them among the poor of Dort and thus the hatred which every rich man has to encounter in times of civil wars will be soothed down and I shall be able without fearing any harm either from Republicans or Orangists to keep as heretofore my borders in splendid condition I need no more be afraid lest on the day of a riot the shopkeepers of the town and the sailors of the port should come and tear out my bulbs to boil them as onions for their families as they have sometimes quietly threatened when they happened to remember my having paid two or three hundred guilders for one bulb It is therefore settled I shall give the hundred thousand guilders of the Haarlem prize tothe poor And yet

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Here Cornelius stopped and heaved a sigh. And yet, he continued, it would have been so very delightful to spend the hundred thousand guilders on the enlargement of my tulipbed or even on a journey to the East, the country of beautiful flowers. But, alas! these are no thoughts for the present times, when muskets, standards, proclamations, and beating of drums are the order of the day.
children.prevalue: Here Cornelius stopped and heaved a sigh And yet he continued it would have been so very delightful to spend the hundred thousand guilders on the enlargement of my tulipbed or even on a journey to the East the country of beautiful flowers But alas these are no thoughts for the present times when muskets standards proclamations and beating of drums are the order of the day

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Van Baerle raised his eyes to heaven and sighed again. Then turning his glance towards his bulbs,objects of much greater importance to him than all those muskets, standards, drums, and proclamations, which he conceived only to be fit to disturb the minds of honest people,he said:
children.prevalue: Van Baerle raised his eyes to heaven and sighed again Then turning his glance towards his bulbs objects of much greater importance to him than all those muskets standards drums and proclamations which he conceived only to be fit to disturb the minds of honest people he said

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: These are, indeed, beautiful bulbs; how smooth they are, how well formed; there is that air of melancholy about them which promises to produce a flower of the colour of ebony. On their skin you cannot even distinguish the circulating veins with the naked eye. Certainly, certainly, not a light spot will disfigure the tulip which I have called into existence. And by what name shall we call this offspring of my sleepless nights, of my labour and my thought? Tulipa nigra Barlaensis?
children.prevalue: These are indeed beautiful bulbs how smooth they are how well formed there is that air of melancholy about them which promises to produce a flower of the colour of ebony On their skin you cannot even distinguish the circulating veins with the naked eye Certainly certainly not a light spot will disfigure the tulip which I have called into existence And by what name shall we call this offspring of my sleepless nights of my labour and my thought Tulipa nigra Barlaensis

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Yes Barlaensis: a fine name. All the tulipfanciersthat is to say, all the intelligent people of Europewill feel a thrill of excitement when the rumour spreads to the four quarters of the globe: The grand black tulip is found! 'How is it called?' the fanciers will ask.'Tulipa nigra Barlaensis!''Why Barlaensis?''After its grower, Van Baerle,' will be the answer.'And who is this Van Baerle?''It is the same who has already produced five new tulips: the Jane, the John de Witt, the Cornelius de Witt, etc.' Well, that is what I call my ambition. It will cause tears to no one. And people will talk of my Tulipa nigra Barlaensis when perhaps my godfather, this sublime politician, is only known from the tulip to which I have given his name.
children.prevalue: Yes Barlaensis a fine name All the tulipfanciersthat is to say all the intelligent people of Europewill feel a thrill of excitement when the rumour spreads to the four quarters of the globe The grand black tulip is found How is it called the fanciers will ask Tulipa nigra Barlaensis Why Barlaensis After its grower Van Baerle will be the answer And who is this Van Baerle It is the same who has already produced five new tulips the Jane the John de Witt the Cornelius de Witt etc Well that is what I call my ambition It will cause tears to no one And people will talk of my Tulipa nigra Barlaensis when perhaps my godfather this sublime politician is only known from the tulip to which I have given his name

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Oh! these darling bulbs!
children.prevalue: Oh these darling bulbs

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: When my tulip has flowered, Baerle continued in his soliloquy, and when tranquillity is restored in Holland, I shall give to the poor only fifty thousand guilders, which, after all, is a goodly sum for a man who is under no obligation whatever. Then, with the remaining fifty thousand guilders, I shall make experiments. With them I shall succeed in imparting scent to the tulip. Ah! if I succeed in giving it the odour of the rose or the carnation, or, what would be still better, a completely new scent; if I restored to this queen of flowers its natural distinctive perfume, which she has lost in passing from her Eastern to her European throne, and which she must have in the Indian peninsula at Goa, Bombay, and Madras, and especially in that island which in olden times, as is asserted, was the terrestrial paradise, and which is called Ceylon,oh, what glory! I must say, I would then rather be Cornelius van Baerle than Alexander, Caesar, or Maximilian.
children.prevalue: When my tulip has flowered Baerle continued in his soliloquy and when tranquillity is restored in Holland I shall give to the poor only fifty thousand guilders which after all is a goodly sum for a man who is under no obligation whatever Then with the remaining fifty thousand guilders I shall make experiments With them I shall succeed in imparting scent to the tulip Ah if I succeed in giving it the odour of the rose or the carnation or what would be still better a completely new scent if I restored to this queen of flowers its natural distinctive perfume which she has lost in passing from her Eastern to her European throne and which she must have in the Indian peninsula at Goa Bombay and Madras and especially in that island which in olden times as is asserted was the terrestrial paradise and which is called Ceylon oh what glory I must say I would then rather be Cornelius van Baerle than Alexander Caesar or Maximilian

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Oh the admirable bulbs!
children.prevalue: Oh the admirable bulbs

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Thus Cornelius indulged in the delights of contemplation, and was carried away by the sweetest dreams.
children.prevalue: Thus Cornelius indulged in the delights of contemplation and was carried away by the sweetest dreams

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Suddenly the bell of his cabinet was rung much more violently than usual.
children.prevalue: Suddenly the bell of his cabinet was rung much more violently than usual

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Cornelius, startled, laid his hands on his bulbs, and turned round.
children.prevalue: Cornelius startled laid his hands on his bulbs and turned round

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Who is here? he asked.
children.prevalue: Who is here he asked

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Sir, answered the servant, it is a messenger from the Hague.
children.prevalue: Sir answered the servant it is a messenger from the Hague

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: A messenger from the Hague! What does he want?
children.prevalue: A messenger from the Hague What does he want

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Sir, it is Craeke.
children.prevalue: Sir it is Craeke

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Craeke! the confidential servant of Mynheer John de Witt? Good, let him wait.
children.prevalue: Craeke the confidential servant of Mynheer John de Witt Good let him wait

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: I cannot wait, said a voice in the lobby.
children.prevalue: I cannot wait said a voice in the lobby

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: And at the same time forcing his way in, Craeke rushed into the dryroom.
children.prevalue: And at the same time forcing his way in Craeke rushed into the dryroom

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: This abrupt entrance was such an infringement on the established rules of the household of Cornelius van Baerle, that the latter, at the sight of Craeke, almost convulsively moved his hand which covered the bulbs, so that two of them fell on the floor, one of them rolling under a small table, and the other into the fireplace.
children.prevalue: This abrupt entrance was such an infringement on the established rules of the household of Cornelius van Baerle that the latter at the sight of Craeke almost convulsively moved his hand which covered the bulbs so that two of them fell on the floor one of them rolling under a small table and the other into the fireplace

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Zounds! said Cornelius, eagerly picking up his precious bulbs, what's the matter?
children.prevalue: Zounds said Cornelius eagerly picking up his precious bulbs what s the matter

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The matter, sir! said Craeke, laying a paper on the large table, on which the third bulb was lying,the matter is, that you are requested to read this paper without losing one moment.
children.prevalue: The matter sir said Craeke laying a paper on the large table on which the third bulb was lying the matter is that you are requested to read this paper without losing one moment

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: And Craeke, who thought he had remarked in the streets of Dort symptoms of a tumult similar to that which he had witnessed before his departure from the Hague, ran off without even looking behind him.
children.prevalue: And Craeke who thought he had remarked in the streets of Dort symptoms of a tumult similar to that which he had witnessed before his departure from the Hague ran off without even looking behind him

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: All right! all right! my dear Craeke, said Cornelius, stretching his arm under the table for the bulb; your paper shall be read, indeed it shall.
children.prevalue: All right all right my dear Craeke said Cornelius stretching his arm under the table for the bulb your paper shall be read indeed it shall

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Then, examining the bulb which he held in the hollow of his hand, he said: Well, here is one of them uninjured. That confounded Craeke! thus to rush into my dryroom; let us now look after the other.
children.prevalue: Then examining the bulb which he held in the hollow of his hand he said Well here is one of them uninjured That confounded Craeke thus to rush into my dryroom let us now look after the other

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: And without laying down the bulb which he already held, Baerle went to the fireplace, knelt down and stirred with the tip of his finger the ashes, which fortunately were quite cold.
children.prevalue: And without laying down the bulb which he already held Baerle went to the fireplace knelt down and stirred with the tip of his finger the ashes which fortunately were quite cold

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: He at once felt the other bulb.
children.prevalue: He at once felt the other bulb

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Well, here it is, he said; and, looking at it with almost fatherly affection, he exclaimed, Uninjured as the first!
children.prevalue: Well here it is he said and looking at it with almost fatherly affection he exclaimed Uninjured as the first

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: At this very instant, and whilst Cornelius, still on his knees, was examining his pets, the door of the dryroom was so violently shaken, and opened in such a brusque manner, that Cornelius felt rising in his cheeks and his ears the glow of that evil counsellor which is called wrath.
children.prevalue: At this very instant and whilst Cornelius still on his knees was examining his pets the door of the dryroom was so violently shaken and opened in such a brusque manner that Cornelius felt rising in his cheeks and his ears the glow of that evil counsellor which is called wrath

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Now, what is it again, he demanded; are people going mad here?
children.prevalue: Now what is it again he demanded are people going mad here

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Oh, sir! sir! cried the servant, rushing into the dryroom with a much paler face and with a much more frightened mien than Craeke had shown.
children.prevalue: Oh sir sir cried the servant rushing into the dryroom with a much paler face and with a much more frightened mien than Craeke had shown

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Well! asked Cornelius, foreboding some mischief from the double breach of the strict rule of his house.
children.prevalue: Well asked Cornelius foreboding some mischief from the double breach of the strict rule of his house

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Oh, sir, fly! fly quick! cried the servant.
children.prevalue: Oh sir fly fly quick cried the servant

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Fly! and what for?
children.prevalue: Fly and what for

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Sir, the house is full of the guards of the States.
children.prevalue: Sir the house is full of the guards of the States

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: What do they want?
children.prevalue: What do they want

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: They want you.
children.prevalue: They want you

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: What for?
children.prevalue: What for

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: To arrest you.
children.prevalue: To arrest you

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Arrest me? arrest me, do you say?
children.prevalue: Arrest me arrest me do you say

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Yes, sir, and they are headed by a magistrate.
children.prevalue: Yes sir and they are headed by a magistrate

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: What's the meaning of all this? said Van Baerle, grasping in his hands the two bulbs, and directing his terrified glance towards the staircase.
children.prevalue: What s the meaning of all this said Van Baerle grasping in his hands the two bulbs and directing his terrified glance towards the staircase

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: They are coming up! they are coming up! cried the servant.
children.prevalue: They are coming up they are coming up cried the servant

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Oh, my dear child, my worthy master! cried the old housekeeper, who now likewise made her appearance in the dryroom, take your gold, your jewelry, and fly, fly!
children.prevalue: Oh my dear child my worthy master cried the old housekeeper who now likewise made her appearance in the dryroom take your gold your jewelry and fly fly

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: But how shall I make my escape, nurse? said Van Baerle.
children.prevalue: But how shall I make my escape nurse said Van Baerle

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Jump out of the window.
children.prevalue: Jump out of the window

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Twentyfive feet from the ground!
children.prevalue: Twentyfive feet from the ground

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: But you will fall on six feet of soft soil!
children.prevalue: But you will fall on six feet of soft soil

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Yes, but I should fall on my tulips.
children.prevalue: Yes but I should fall on my tulips

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Never mind, jump out.
children.prevalue: Never mind jump out

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Cornelius took the third bulb, approached the window and opened it, but seeing what havoc he would necessarily cause in his borders, and, more than this, what a height he would have to jump, he called out, Never! and fell back a step.
children.prevalue: Cornelius took the third bulb approached the window and opened it but seeing what havoc he would necessarily cause in his borders and more than this what a height he would have to jump he called out Never and fell back a step

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: At this moment they saw across the banister of the staircase the points of the halberds of the soldiers rising.
children.prevalue: At this moment they saw across the banister of the staircase the points of the halberds of the soldiers rising

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: The housekeeper raised her hands to heaven.
children.prevalue: The housekeeper raised her hands to heaven

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: As to Cornelius van Baerle, it must be stated to his honour, not as a man, but as a tulipfancier, his only thought was for his inestimable bulbs.
children.prevalue: As to Cornelius van Baerle it must be stated to his honour not as a man but as a tulipfancier his only thought was for his inestimable bulbs

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Looking about for a paper in which to wrap them up, he noticed the flyleaf from the Bible, which Craeke had laid upon the table, took it without in his confusion remembering whence it came, folded in it the three bulbs, secreted them in his bosom, and waited.
children.prevalue: Looking about for a paper in which to wrap them up he noticed the flyleaf from the Bible which Craeke had laid upon the table took it without in his confusion remembering whence it came folded in it the three bulbs secreted them in his bosom and waited

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: At this very moment the soldiers, preceded by a magistrate, entered the room.
children.prevalue: At this very moment the soldiers preceded by a magistrate entered the room

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Are you Dr. Cornelius van Baerle? demanded the magistrate (who, although knowing the young man very well, put his question according to the forms of justice, which gave his proceedings a much more dignified air).
children.prevalue: Are you Dr Cornelius van Baerle demanded the magistrate who although knowing the young man very well put his question according to the forms of justice which gave his proceedings a much more dignified air

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: I am that person, Master van Spennen, answered Cornelius, politely, to his judge, and you know it very well.
children.prevalue: I am that person Master van Spennen answered Cornelius politely to his judge and you know it very well

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Then give up to us the seditious papers which you secrete in your house.
children.prevalue: Then give up to us the seditious papers which you secrete in your house

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: The seditious papers! repeated Cornelius, quite dumfounded at the imputation.
children.prevalue: The seditious papers repeated Cornelius quite dumfounded at the imputation

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Now don't look astonished, if you please.
children.prevalue: Now don t look astonished if you please

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: I vow to you, Master van Spennen, Cornelius replied, that I am completely at a loss to understand what you want.
children.prevalue: I vow to you Master van Spennen Cornelius replied that I am completely at a loss to understand what you want

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Then I shall put you in the way, Doctor, said the judge; give up to us the papers which the traitor Cornelius de Witt deposited with you in the month of January last.
children.prevalue: Then I shall put you in the way Doctor said the judge give up to us the papers which the traitor Cornelius de Witt deposited with you in the month of January last

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: A sudden light came into the mind of Cornelius.
children.prevalue: A sudden light came into the mind of Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Halloa! said Van Spennen, you begin now to remember, don't you?
children.prevalue: Halloa said Van Spennen you begin now to remember don t you

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Indeed I do, but you spoke of seditious papers, and I have none of that sort.
children.prevalue: Indeed I do but you spoke of seditious papers and I have none of that sort

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: You deny it then?
children.prevalue: You deny it then

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Certainly I do.
children.prevalue: Certainly I do

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: The magistrate turned round and took a rapid survey of the whole cabinet.
children.prevalue: The magistrate turned round and took a rapid survey of the whole cabinet

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Where is the apartment you call your dryroom? he asked.
children.prevalue: Where is the apartment you call your dryroom he asked

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: The very same where you now are, Master van Spennen.
children.prevalue: The very same where you now are Master van Spennen

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: The magistrate cast a glance at a small note at the top of his papers.
children.prevalue: The magistrate cast a glance at a small note at the top of his papers

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: All right, he said, like a man who is sure of his ground.
children.prevalue: All right he said like a man who is sure of his ground

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Then, turning round towards Cornelius, he continued, Will you give up those papers to me?
children.prevalue: Then turning round towards Cornelius he continued Will you give up those papers to me

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: But I cannot, Master van Spennen; those papers do not belong to me; they have been deposited with me as a trust, and a trust is sacred.
children.prevalue: But I cannot Master van Spennen those papers do not belong to me they have been deposited with me as a trust and a trust is sacred

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Dr. Cornelius, said the judge, in the name of the States, I order you to open this drawer, and to give up to me the papers which it contains.
children.prevalue: Dr Cornelius said the judge in the name of the States I order you to open this drawer and to give up to me the papers which it contains

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Saying this, the judge pointed with his finger to the third drawer of the press, near the fireplace.
children.prevalue: Saying this the judge pointed with his finger to the third drawer of the press near the fireplace

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: In this very drawer, indeed the papers deposited by the Warden of the Dikes with his godson were lying; a proof that the police had received very exact information.
children.prevalue: In this very drawer indeed the papers deposited by the Warden of the Dikes with his godson were lying a proof that the police had received very exact information

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Ah! you will not, said Van Spennen, when he saw Cornelius standing immovable and bewildered, then I shall open the drawer myself.
children.prevalue: Ah you will not said Van Spennen when he saw Cornelius standing immovable and bewildered then I shall open the drawer myself

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: And, pulling out the drawer to its full length, the magistrate at first alighted on about twenty bulbs, carefully arranged and ticketed, and then on the paper parcel, which had remained in exactly the same state as it was when delivered by the unfortunate Cornelius de Witt to his godson.
children.prevalue: And pulling out the drawer to its full length the magistrate at first alighted on about twenty bulbs carefully arranged and ticketed and then on the paper parcel which had remained in exactly the same state as it was when delivered by the unfortunate Cornelius de Witt to his godson

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: The magistrate broke the seals, tore off the envelope, cast an eager glance on the first leaves which met his eye and then exclaimed, in a terrible voice,
children.prevalue: The magistrate broke the seals tore off the envelope cast an eager glance on the first leaves which met his eye and then exclaimed in a terrible voice

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Well, justice has been rightly informed after all!
children.prevalue: Well justice has been rightly informed after all

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: How, said Cornelius, how is this?
children.prevalue: How said Cornelius how is this

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Don't pretend to be ignorant, Mynheer van Baerle, answered the magistrate. Follow me.
children.prevalue: Don t pretend to be ignorant Mynheer van Baerle answered the magistrate Follow me

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: How's that! follow you? cried the Doctor.
children.prevalue: How s that follow you cried the Doctor

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Yes, sir, for in the name of the States I arrest you.
children.prevalue: Yes sir for in the name of the States I arrest you

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Arrests were not as yet made in the name of William of Orange; he had not been Stadtholder long enough for that.
children.prevalue: Arrests were not as yet made in the name of William of Orange he had not been Stadtholder long enough for that

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Arrest me! cried Cornelius; but what have I done?
children.prevalue: Arrest me cried Cornelius but what have I done

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: That's no affair of mine, Doctor; you will explain all that before your judges.
children.prevalue: That s no affair of mine Doctor you will explain all that before your judges

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Where?
children.prevalue: Where

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: At the Hague.
children.prevalue: At the Hague

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Cornelius, in mute stupefaction, embraced his old nurse, who was in a swoon; shook hands with his servants, who were bathed in tears, and followed the magistrate, who put him in a coach as a prisoner of state and had him driven at full gallop to the Hague.
children.prevalue: Cornelius in mute stupefaction embraced his old nurse who was in a swoon shook hands with his servants who were bathed in tears and followed the magistrate who put him in a coach as a prisoner of state and had him driven at full gallop to the Hague

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The incident just related was, as the reader has guessed before this, the diabolical work of Mynheer Isaac Boxtel.
children.prevalue: The incident just related was as the reader has guessed before this the diabolical work of Mynheer Isaac Boxtel

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: It will be remembered that, with the help of his telescope, not even the least detail of the private meeting between Cornelius de Witt and Van Baerle had escaped him. He had, indeed, heard nothing, but he had seen everything, and had rightly concluded that the papers intrusted by the Warden to the Doctor must have been of great importance, as he saw Van Baerle so carefully secreting the parcel in the drawer where he used to keep his most precious bulbs.
children.prevalue: It will be remembered that with the help of his telescope not even the least detail of the private meeting between Cornelius de Witt and Van Baerle had escaped him He had indeed heard nothing but he had seen everything and had rightly concluded that the papers intrusted by the Warden to the Doctor must have been of great importance as he saw Van Baerle so carefully secreting the parcel in the drawer where he used to keep his most precious bulbs

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The upshot of all this was that when Boxtel, who watched the course of political events much more attentively than his neighbour Cornelius was used to do, heard the news of the brothers De Witt being arrested on a charge of high treason against the States, he thought within his heart that very likely he needed only to say one word, and the godson would be arrested as well as the godfather.
children.prevalue: The upshot of all this was that when Boxtel who watched the course of political events much more attentively than his neighbour Cornelius was used to do heard the news of the brothers De Witt being arrested on a charge of high treason against the States he thought within his heart that very likely he needed only to say one word and the godson would be arrested as well as the godfather

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Yet, full of happiness as was Boxtel's heart at the chance, he at first shrank with horror from the idea of informing against a man whom this information might lead to the scaffold.
children.prevalue: Yet full of happiness as was Boxtel s heart at the chance he at first shrank with horror from the idea of informing against a man whom this information might lead to the scaffold

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: But there is this terrible thing in evil thoughts, that evil minds soon grow familiar with them.
children.prevalue: But there is this terrible thing in evil thoughts that evil minds soon grow familiar with them

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Besides this, Mynheer Isaac Boxtel encouraged himself with the following sophism:
children.prevalue: Besides this Mynheer Isaac Boxtel encouraged himself with the following sophism

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Cornelius de Witt is a bad citizen, as he is charged with high treason, and arrested.
children.prevalue: Cornelius de Witt is a bad citizen as he is charged with high treason and arrested

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: I, on the contrary, am a good citizen, as I am not charged with anything in the world, as I am as free as the air of heaven.
children.prevalue: I on the contrary am a good citizen as I am not charged with anything in the world as I am as free as the air of heaven

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: If, therefore, Cornelius de Witt is a bad citizen,of which there can be no doubt, as he is charged with high treason, and arrested,his accomplice, Cornelius van Baerle, is no less a bad citizen than himself.
children.prevalue: If therefore Cornelius de Witt is a bad citizen of which there can be no doubt as he is charged with high treason and arrested his accomplice Cornelius van Baerle is no less a bad citizen than himself

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: And, as I am a good citizen, and as it is the duty of every good citizen to inform against the bad ones, it is my duty to inform against Cornelius van Baerle.
children.prevalue: And as I am a good citizen and as it is the duty of every good citizen to inform against the bad ones it is my duty to inform against Cornelius van Baerle

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Specious as this mode of reasoning might sound, it would not perhaps have taken so complete a hold of Boxtel, nor would he perhaps have yielded to the mere desire of vengeance which was gnawing at his heart, had not the demon of envy been joined with that of cupidity.
children.prevalue: Specious as this mode of reasoning might sound it would not perhaps have taken so complete a hold of Boxtel nor would he perhaps have yielded to the mere desire of vengeance which was gnawing at his heart had not the demon of envy been joined with that of cupidity

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Boxtel was quite aware of the progress which Van Baerle had made towards producing the grand black tulip.
children.prevalue: Boxtel was quite aware of the progress which Van Baerle had made towards producing the grand black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Dr. Cornelius, notwithstanding all his modesty, had not been able to hide from his most intimate friends that he was all but certain to win, in the year of grace 1673, the prize of a hundred thousand guilders offered by the Horticultural Society of Haarlem.
children.prevalue: Dr Cornelius notwithstanding all his modesty had not been able to hide from his most intimate friends that he was all but certain to win in the year of grace 1673 the prize of a hundred thousand guilders offered by the Horticultural Society of Haarlem

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: It was just this certainty of Cornelius van Baerle that caused the fever which raged in the heart of Isaac Boxtel.
children.prevalue: It was just this certainty of Cornelius van Baerle that caused the fever which raged in the heart of Isaac Boxtel

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: If Cornelius should be arrested there would necessarily be a great upset in his house, and during the night after his arrest no one would think of keeping watch over the tulips in his garden.
children.prevalue: If Cornelius should be arrested there would necessarily be a great upset in his house and during the night after his arrest no one would think of keeping watch over the tulips in his garden

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Now in that night Boxtel would climb over the wall and, as he knew the position of the bulb which was to produce the grand black tulip, he would filch it; and instead of flowering for Cornelius, it would flower for him, Isaac; he also, instead of Van Baerle, would have the prize of a hundred thousand guilders, not to speak of the sublime honour of calling the new flower Tulipa nigra Boxtellensis,a result which would satisfy not only his vengeance, but also his cupidity and his ambition.
children.prevalue: Now in that night Boxtel would climb over the wall and as he knew the position of the bulb which was to produce the grand black tulip he would filch it and instead of flowering for Cornelius it would flower for him Isaac he also instead of Van Baerle would have the prize of a hundred thousand guilders not to speak of the sublime honour of calling the new flower Tulipa nigra Boxtellensis a result which would satisfy not only his vengeance but also his cupidity and his ambition

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Awake, he thought of nothing but the grand black tulip; asleep, he dreamed of it.
children.prevalue: Awake he thought of nothing but the grand black tulip asleep he dreamed of it

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: At last, on the 19th of August, about two o'clock in the afternoon, the temptation grew so strong, that Mynheer Isaac was no longer able to resist it.
children.prevalue: At last on the 19th of August about two o clock in the afternoon the temptation grew so strong that Mynheer Isaac was no longer able to resist it

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Accordingly, he wrote an anonymous information, the minute exactness of which made up for its want of authenticity, and posted his letter.
children.prevalue: Accordingly he wrote an anonymous information the minute exactness of which made up for its want of authenticity and posted his letter

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Never did a venomous paper, slipped into the jaws of the bronze lions at Venice, produce a more prompt and terrible effect.
children.prevalue: Never did a venomous paper slipped into the jaws of the bronze lions at Venice produce a more prompt and terrible effect

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: On the same evening the letter reached the principal magistrate, who without a moment's delay convoked his colleagues early for the next morning. On the following morning, therefore, they assembled, and decided on Van Baerle's arrest, placing the order for its execution in the hands of Master van Spennen, who, as we have seen, performed his duty like a true Hollander, and who arrested the Doctor at the very hour when the Orange party at the Hague were roasting the bleeding shreds of flesh torn from the corpses of Cornelius and John de Witt.
children.prevalue: On the same evening the letter reached the principal magistrate who without a moment s delay convoked his colleagues early for the next morning On the following morning therefore they assembled and decided on Van Baerle s arrest placing the order for its execution in the hands of Master van Spennen who as we have seen performed his duty like a true Hollander and who arrested the Doctor at the very hour when the Orange party at the Hague were roasting the bleeding shreds of flesh torn from the corpses of Cornelius and John de Witt

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: But, whether from a feeling of shame or from craven weakness, Isaac Boxtel did not venture that day to point his telescope either at the garden, or at the laboratory, or at the dryroom.
children.prevalue: But whether from a feeling of shame or from craven weakness Isaac Boxtel did not venture that day to point his telescope either at the garden or at the laboratory or at the dryroom

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: He knew too well what was about to happen in the house of the poor doctor to feel any desire to look into it. He did not even get up when his only servantwho envied the lot of the servants of Cornelius just as bitterly as Boxtel did that of their masterentered his bedroom. He said to the man,
children.prevalue: He knew too well what was about to happen in the house of the poor doctor to feel any desire to look into it He did not even get up when his only servantwho envied the lot of the servants of Cornelius just as bitterly as Boxtel did that of their masterentered his bedroom He said to the man

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: I shall not get up today, I am ill.
children.prevalue: I shall not get up today I am ill

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: About nine o'clock he heard a great noise in the street which made him tremble, at this moment he was paler than a real invalid, and shook more violently than a man in the height of fever.
children.prevalue: About nine o clock he heard a great noise in the street which made him tremble at this moment he was paler than a real invalid and shook more violently than a man in the height of fever

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: His servant entered the room; Boxtel hid himself under the counterpane.
children.prevalue: His servant entered the room Boxtel hid himself under the counterpane

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Oh, sir! cried the servant, not without some inkling that, whilst deploring the mishap which had befallen Van Baerle, he was announcing agreeable news to his master,oh, sir! you do not know, then, what is happening at this moment?
children.prevalue: Oh sir cried the servant not without some inkling that whilst deploring the mishap which had befallen Van Baerle he was announcing agreeable news to his master oh sir you do not know then what is happening at this moment

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: How can I know it? answered Boxtel, with an almost unintelligible voice.
children.prevalue: How can I know it answered Boxtel with an almost unintelligible voice

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Well, Mynheer Boxtel, at this moment your neighbour Cornelius van Baerle is arrested for high treason.
children.prevalue: Well Mynheer Boxtel at this moment your neighbour Cornelius van Baerle is arrested for high treason

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Nonsense! Boxtel muttered, with a faltering voice; the thing is impossible.
children.prevalue: Nonsense Boxtel muttered with a faltering voice the thing is impossible

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Faith, sir, at any rate that's what people say; and, besides, I have seen Judge van Spennen with the archers entering the house.
children.prevalue: Faith sir at any rate that s what people say and besides I have seen Judge van Spennen with the archers entering the house

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Well, if you have seen it with your own eyes, that's a different case altogether.
children.prevalue: Well if you have seen it with your own eyes that s a different case altogether

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: At all events, said the servant, I shall go and inquire once more. Be you quiet, sir, I shall let you know all about it.
children.prevalue: At all events said the servant I shall go and inquire once more Be you quiet sir I shall let you know all about it

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Boxtel contented himself with signifying his approval of the zeal of his servant by dumb show.
children.prevalue: Boxtel contented himself with signifying his approval of the zeal of his servant by dumb show

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: The man went out, and returned in half an hour.
children.prevalue: The man went out and returned in half an hour

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Oh, sir, all that I told you is indeed quite true.
children.prevalue: Oh sir all that I told you is indeed quite true

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: How so?
children.prevalue: How so

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Mynheer van Baerle is arrested, and has been put into a carriage, and they are driving him to the Hague.
children.prevalue: Mynheer van Baerle is arrested and has been put into a carriage and they are driving him to the Hague

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: To the Hague!
children.prevalue: To the Hague

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Yes, to the Hague, and if what people say is true, it won't do him much good.
children.prevalue: Yes to the Hague and if what people say is true it won t do him much good

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: And what do they say? Boxtel asked.
children.prevalue: And what do they say Boxtel asked

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Faith, sir, they saybut it is not quite surethat by this hour the burghers must be murdering Mynheer Cornelius and Mynheer John de Witt.
children.prevalue: Faith sir they saybut it is not quite surethat by this hour the burghers must be murdering Mynheer Cornelius and Mynheer John de Witt

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Oh, muttered, or rather growled Boxtel, closing his eyes from the dreadful picture which presented itself to his imagination.
children.prevalue: Oh muttered or rather growled Boxtel closing his eyes from the dreadful picture which presented itself to his imagination

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Why, to be sure, said the servant to himself, whilst leaving the room, Mynheer Isaac Boxtel must be very sick not to have jumped from his bed on hearing such good news.
children.prevalue: Why to be sure said the servant to himself whilst leaving the room Mynheer Isaac Boxtel must be very sick not to have jumped from his bed on hearing such good news

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: And, in reality, Isaac Boxtel was very sick, like a man who has murdered another.
children.prevalue: And in reality Isaac Boxtel was very sick like a man who has murdered another

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: But he had murdered his man with a double object; the first was attained, the second was still to be attained.
children.prevalue: But he had murdered his man with a double object the first was attained the second was still to be attained

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Night closed in. It was the night which Boxtel had looked forward to.
children.prevalue: Night closed in It was the night which Boxtel had looked forward to

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: As soon as it was dark he got up.
children.prevalue: As soon as it was dark he got up

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: He then climbed into his sycamore.
children.prevalue: He then climbed into his sycamore

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: He had calculated correctly; no one thought of keeping watch over the garden; the house and the servants were all in the utmost confusion.
children.prevalue: He had calculated correctly no one thought of keeping watch over the garden the house and the servants were all in the utmost confusion

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: He heard the clock striketen, eleven, twelve.
children.prevalue: He heard the clock striketen eleven twelve

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: At midnight, with a beating heart, trembling hands, and a livid countenance, he descended from the tree, took a ladder, leaned it against the wall, mounted it to the last step but one, and listened.
children.prevalue: At midnight with a beating heart trembling hands and a livid countenance he descended from the tree took a ladder leaned it against the wall mounted it to the last step but one and listened

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: All was perfectly quiet, not a sound broke the silence of the night; one solitary light, that of the housekeeper, was burning in the house.
children.prevalue: All was perfectly quiet not a sound broke the silence of the night one solitary light that of the housekeeper was burning in the house

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: This silence and this darkness emboldened Boxtel; he got astride the wall, stopped for an instant, and, after having ascertained that there was nothing to fear, he put his ladder from his own garden into that of Cornelius, and descended.
children.prevalue: This silence and this darkness emboldened Boxtel he got astride the wall stopped for an instant and after having ascertained that there was nothing to fear he put his ladder from his own garden into that of Cornelius and descended

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Then, knowing to an inch where the bulbs which were to produce the black tulip were planted, he ran towards the spot, following, however, the gravelled walks in order not to be betrayed by his footprints, and, on arriving at the precise spot, he proceeded, with the eagerness of a tiger, to plunge his hand into the soft ground.
children.prevalue: Then knowing to an inch where the bulbs which were to produce the black tulip were planted he ran towards the spot following however the gravelled walks in order not to be betrayed by his footprints and on arriving at the precise spot he proceeded with the eagerness of a tiger to plunge his hand into the soft ground

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: He found nothing, and thought he was mistaken.
children.prevalue: He found nothing and thought he was mistaken

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: In the meanwhile, the cold sweat stood on his brow.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile the cold sweat stood on his brow

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: He felt about close by it,nothing.
children.prevalue: He felt about close by it nothing

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: He felt about on the right, and on the left,nothing.
children.prevalue: He felt about on the right and on the left nothing

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: He felt about in front and at the back,nothing.
children.prevalue: He felt about in front and at the back nothing

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: He was nearly mad, when at last he satisfied himself that on that very morning the earth had been disturbed.
children.prevalue: He was nearly mad when at last he satisfied himself that on that very morning the earth had been disturbed

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: In fact, whilst Boxtel was lying in bed, Cornelius had gone down to his garden, had taken up the mother bulb, and, as we have seen, divided it into three.
children.prevalue: In fact whilst Boxtel was lying in bed Cornelius had gone down to his garden had taken up the mother bulb and as we have seen divided it into three

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Boxtel could not bring himself to leave the place. He dug up with his hands more than ten square feet of ground.
children.prevalue: Boxtel could not bring himself to leave the place He dug up with his hands more than ten square feet of ground

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: At last no doubt remained of his misfortune. Mad with rage, he returned to his ladder, mounted the wall, drew up the ladder, flung it into his own garden, and jumped after it.
children.prevalue: At last no doubt remained of his misfortune Mad with rage he returned to his ladder mounted the wall drew up the ladder flung it into his own garden and jumped after it

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: All at once, a last ray of hope presented itself to his mind: the seedling bulbs might be in the dryroom; it was therefore only requisite to make his entry there as he had done into the garden.
children.prevalue: All at once a last ray of hope presented itself to his mind the seedling bulbs might be in the dryroom it was therefore only requisite to make his entry there as he had done into the garden

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: There he would find them, and, moreover, it was not at all difficult, as the sashes of the dryroom might be raised like those of a greenhouse. Cornelius had opened them on that morning, and no one had thought of closing them again.
children.prevalue: There he would find them and moreover it was not at all difficult as the sashes of the dryroom might be raised like those of a greenhouse Cornelius had opened them on that morning and no one had thought of closing them again

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Everything, therefore, depended upon whether he could procure a ladder of sufficient length,one of twentyfive feet instead of ten.
children.prevalue: Everything therefore depended upon whether he could procure a ladder of sufficient length one of twentyfive feet instead of ten

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Boxtel had noticed in the street where he lived a house which was being repaired, and against which a very tall ladder was placed.
children.prevalue: Boxtel had noticed in the street where he lived a house which was being repaired and against which a very tall ladder was placed

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: This ladder would do admirably, unless the workmen had taken it away.
children.prevalue: This ladder would do admirably unless the workmen had taken it away

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: He ran to the house: the ladder was there. Boxtel took it, carried it with great exertion to his garden, and with even greater difficulty raised it against the wall of Van Baerle's house, where it just reached to the window.
children.prevalue: He ran to the house the ladder was there Boxtel took it carried it with great exertion to his garden and with even greater difficulty raised it against the wall of Van Baerle s house where it just reached to the window

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Boxtel put a lighted dark lantern into his pocket, mounted the ladder, and slipped into the dryroom.
children.prevalue: Boxtel put a lighted dark lantern into his pocket mounted the ladder and slipped into the dryroom

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: On reaching this sanctuary of the florist he stopped, supporting himself against the table; his legs failed him, his heart beat as if it would choke him. Here it was even worse than in the garden; there Boxtel was only a trespasser, here he was a thief.
children.prevalue: On reaching this sanctuary of the florist he stopped supporting himself against the table his legs failed him his heart beat as if it would choke him Here it was even worse than in the garden there Boxtel was only a trespasser here he was a thief

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: However, he took courage again: he had not gone so far to turn back with empty hands.
children.prevalue: However he took courage again he had not gone so far to turn back with empty hands

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: But in vain did he search the whole room, open and shut all the drawers, even that privileged one where the parcel which had been so fatal to Cornelius had been deposited; he found ticketed, as in a botanical garden, the Jane, the John de Witt, the hazelnut, and the roastedcoffee coloured tulip; but of the black tulip, or rather the seedling bulbs within which it was still sleeping, not a trace was found.
children.prevalue: But in vain did he search the whole room open and shut all the drawers even that privileged one where the parcel which had been so fatal to Cornelius had been deposited he found ticketed as in a botanical garden the Jane the John de Witt the hazelnut and the roastedcoffee coloured tulip but of the black tulip or rather the seedling bulbs within which it was still sleeping not a trace was found

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: And yet, on looking over the register of seeds and bulbs, which Van Baerle kept in duplicate, if possible even with greater exactitude and care than the first commercial houses of Amsterdam their ledgers, Boxtel read these lines:
children.prevalue: And yet on looking over the register of seeds and bulbs which Van Baerle kept in duplicate if possible even with greater exactitude and care than the first commercial houses of Amsterdam their ledgers Boxtel read these lines

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Today, 20th of August, 1672, I have taken up the mother bulb of the grand black tulip, which I have divided into three perfect suckers.
children.prevalue: Today 20th of August 1672 I have taken up the mother bulb of the grand black tulip which I have divided into three perfect suckers

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Oh these bulbs, these bulbs! howled Boxtel, turning over everything in the dryroom, where could he have concealed them?
children.prevalue: Oh these bulbs these bulbs howled Boxtel turning over everything in the dryroom where could he have concealed them

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Then, suddenly striking his forehead in his frenzy, he called out, Oh wretch that I am! Oh thrice fool Boxtel! Would any one be separated from his bulbs? Would any one leave them at Dort, when one goes to the Hague? Could one live far from one's bulbs, when they enclose the grand black tulip? He had time to get hold of them, the scoundrel, he has them about him, he has taken them to the Hague!
children.prevalue: Then suddenly striking his forehead in his frenzy he called out Oh wretch that I am Oh thrice fool Boxtel Would any one be separated from his bulbs Would any one leave them at Dort when one goes to the Hague Could one live far from one s bulbs when they enclose the grand black tulip He had time to get hold of them the scoundrel he has them about him he has taken them to the Hague

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: It was like a flash of lightning which showed to Boxtel the abyss of a uselessly committed crime.
children.prevalue: It was like a flash of lightning which showed to Boxtel the abyss of a uselessly committed crime

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Boxtel sank quite paralyzed on that very table, and on that very spot where, some hours before, the unfortunate Van Baerle had so leisurely, and with such intense delight, contemplated his darling bulbs.
children.prevalue: Boxtel sank quite paralyzed on that very table and on that very spot where some hours before the unfortunate Van Baerle had so leisurely and with such intense delight contemplated his darling bulbs

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Well, then, after all, said the envious Boxtel,raising his livid face from his hands in which it had been buriedif he has them, he can keep them only as long as he lives, and
children.prevalue: Well then after all said the envious Boxtel raising his livid face from his hands in which it had been buriedif he has them he can keep them only as long as he lives and

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: The rest of this detestable thought was expressed by a hideous smile.
children.prevalue: The rest of this detestable thought was expressed by a hideous smile

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: The bulbs are at the Hague, he said, therefore, I can no longer live at Dort: away, then, for them, to the Hague! to the Hague!
children.prevalue: The bulbs are at the Hague he said therefore I can no longer live at Dort away then for them to the Hague to the Hague

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: And Boxtel, without taking any notice of the treasures about him, so entirely were his thoughts absorbed by another inestimable treasure, let himself out by the window, glided down the ladder, carried it back to the place whence he had taken it, and, like a beast of prey, returned growling to his house.
children.prevalue: And Boxtel without taking any notice of the treasures about him so entirely were his thoughts absorbed by another inestimable treasure let himself out by the window glided down the ladder carried it back to the place whence he had taken it and like a beast of prey returned growling to his house

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: It was about midnight when poor Van Baerle was locked up in the prison of the Buytenhof.
children.prevalue: It was about midnight when poor Van Baerle was locked up in the prison of the Buytenhof

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: What Rosa foresaw had come to pass. On finding the cell of Cornelius de Witt empty, the wrath of the people ran very high, and had Gryphus fallen into the hands of those madmen he would certainly have had to pay with his life for the prisoner.
children.prevalue: What Rosa foresaw had come to pass On finding the cell of Cornelius de Witt empty the wrath of the people ran very high and had Gryphus fallen into the hands of those madmen he would certainly have had to pay with his life for the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: But this fury had vented itself most fully on the two brothers when they were overtaken by the murderers, thanks to the precaution which Williamthe man of precautionshad taken in having the gates of the city closed.
children.prevalue: But this fury had vented itself most fully on the two brothers when they were overtaken by the murderers thanks to the precaution which Williamthe man of precautionshad taken in having the gates of the city closed

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: A momentary lull had therefore set in whilst the prison was empty, and Rosa availed herself of this favourable moment to come forth from her hiding place, which she also induced her father to leave.
children.prevalue: A momentary lull had therefore set in whilst the prison was empty and Rosa availed herself of this favourable moment to come forth from her hiding place which she also induced her father to leave

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The prison was therefore completely deserted. Why should people remain in the jail whilst murder was going on at the TolHek?
children.prevalue: The prison was therefore completely deserted Why should people remain in the jail whilst murder was going on at the TolHek

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Gryphus came forth trembling behind the courageous Rosa. They went to close the great gate, at least as well as it would close, considering that it was half demolished. It was easy to see that a hurricane of mighty fury had vented itself upon it.
children.prevalue: Gryphus came forth trembling behind the courageous Rosa They went to close the great gate at least as well as it would close considering that it was half demolished It was easy to see that a hurricane of mighty fury had vented itself upon it

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: About four o'clock a return of the noise was heard, but of no threatening character to Gryphus and his daughter. The people were only dragging in the two corpses, which they came back to gibbet at the usual place of execution.
children.prevalue: About four o clock a return of the noise was heard but of no threatening character to Gryphus and his daughter The people were only dragging in the two corpses which they came back to gibbet at the usual place of execution

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Rosa hid herself this time also, but only that she might not see the ghastly spectacle.
children.prevalue: Rosa hid herself this time also but only that she might not see the ghastly spectacle

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: At midnight, people again knocked at the gate of the jail, or rather at the barricade which served in its stead: it was Cornelius van Baerle whom they were bringing.
children.prevalue: At midnight people again knocked at the gate of the jail or rather at the barricade which served in its stead it was Cornelius van Baerle whom they were bringing

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: When the jailer received this new inmate, and saw from the warrant the name and station of his prisoner, he muttered with his turnkey smile,
children.prevalue: When the jailer received this new inmate and saw from the warrant the name and station of his prisoner he muttered with his turnkey smile

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Godson of Cornelius de Witt! Well, young man, we have the family cell here, and we will give it to you.
children.prevalue: Godson of Cornelius de Witt Well young man we have the family cell here and we will give it to you

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: And quite enchanted with his joke, the ferocious Orangeman took his cresset and his keys to conduct Cornelius to the cell, which on that very morning Cornelius de Witt had left to go into exile, or what in revolutionary times is meant instead by those sublime philosophers who lay it down as an axiom of high policy, It is the dead only who do not return.
children.prevalue: And quite enchanted with his joke the ferocious Orangeman took his cresset and his keys to conduct Cornelius to the cell which on that very morning Cornelius de Witt had left to go into exile or what in revolutionary times is meant instead by those sublime philosophers who lay it down as an axiom of high policy It is the dead only who do not return

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: On the way which the despairing florist had to traverse to reach that cell he heard nothing but the barking of a dog, and saw nothing but the face of a young girl.
children.prevalue: On the way which the despairing florist had to traverse to reach that cell he heard nothing but the barking of a dog and saw nothing but the face of a young girl

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The dog rushed forth from a niche in the wall, shaking his heavy chain, and sniffing all round Cornelius in order so much the better to recognise him in case he should be ordered to pounce upon him.
children.prevalue: The dog rushed forth from a niche in the wall shaking his heavy chain and sniffing all round Cornelius in order so much the better to recognise him in case he should be ordered to pounce upon him

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The young girl, whilst the prisoner was mounting the staircase, appeared at the narrow door of her chamber, which opened on that very flight of steps; and, holding the lamp in her right hand, she at the same time lit up her pretty blooming face, surrounded by a profusion of rich wavy golden locks, whilst with her left she held her white nightdress closely over her breast, having been roused from her first slumber by the unexpected arrival of Van Baerle.
children.prevalue: The young girl whilst the prisoner was mounting the staircase appeared at the narrow door of her chamber which opened on that very flight of steps and holding the lamp in her right hand she at the same time lit up her pretty blooming face surrounded by a profusion of rich wavy golden locks whilst with her left she held her white nightdress closely over her breast having been roused from her first slumber by the unexpected arrival of Van Baerle

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: It would have made a fine picture, worthy of Rembrandt, the gloomy winding stairs illuminated by the reddish glare of the cresset of Gryphus, with his scowling jailer's countenance at the top, the melancholy figure of Cornelius bending over the banister to look down upon the sweet face of Rosa, standing, as it were, in the bright frame of the door of her chamber, with embarrassed mien at being thus seen by a stranger.
children.prevalue: It would have made a fine picture worthy of Rembrandt the gloomy winding stairs illuminated by the reddish glare of the cresset of Gryphus with his scowling jailer s countenance at the top the melancholy figure of Cornelius bending over the banister to look down upon the sweet face of Rosa standing as it were in the bright frame of the door of her chamber with embarrassed mien at being thus seen by a stranger

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: And at the bottom, quite in the shade, where the details are absorbed in the obscurity, the mastiff, with his eyes glistening like carbuncles, and shaking his chain, on which the double light from the lamp of Rosa and the lantern of Gryphus threw a brilliant glitter.
children.prevalue: And at the bottom quite in the shade where the details are absorbed in the obscurity the mastiff with his eyes glistening like carbuncles and shaking his chain on which the double light from the lamp of Rosa and the lantern of Gryphus threw a brilliant glitter

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: The sublime master would, however, have been altogether unable to render the sorrow expressed in the face of Rosa, when she saw this pale, handsome young man slowly climbing the stairs, and thought of the full import of the words, which her father had just spoken, You will have the family cell.
children.prevalue: The sublime master would however have been altogether unable to render the sorrow expressed in the face of Rosa when she saw this pale handsome young man slowly climbing the stairs and thought of the full import of the words which her father had just spoken You will have the family cell

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: This vision lasted but a moment,much less time than we have taken to describe it. Gryphus then proceeded on his way, Cornelius was forced to follow him, and five minutes afterwards he entered his prison, of which it is unnecessary to say more, as the reader is already acquainted with it.
children.prevalue: This vision lasted but a moment much less time than we have taken to describe it Gryphus then proceeded on his way Cornelius was forced to follow him and five minutes afterwards he entered his prison of which it is unnecessary to say more as the reader is already acquainted with it

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Gryphus pointed with his finger to the bed on which the martyr had suffered so much, who on that day had rendered his soul to God. Then, taking up his cresset, he quitted the cell.
children.prevalue: Gryphus pointed with his finger to the bed on which the martyr had suffered so much who on that day had rendered his soul to God Then taking up his cresset he quitted the cell

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Thus left alone, Cornelius threw himself on his bed, but he slept not, he kept his eye fixed on the narrow window, barred with iron, which looked on the Buytenhof; and in this way saw from behind the trees that first pale beam of light which morning sheds on the earth as a white mantle.
children.prevalue: Thus left alone Cornelius threw himself on his bed but he slept not he kept his eye fixed on the narrow window barred with iron which looked on the Buytenhof and in this way saw from behind the trees that first pale beam of light which morning sheds on the earth as a white mantle

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Now and then during the night horses had galloped at a smart pace over the Buytenhof, the heavy tramp of the patrols had resounded from the pavement, and the slow matches of the arquebuses, flaring in the east wind, had thrown up at intervals a sudden glare as far as to the panes of his window.
children.prevalue: Now and then during the night horses had galloped at a smart pace over the Buytenhof the heavy tramp of the patrols had resounded from the pavement and the slow matches of the arquebuses flaring in the east wind had thrown up at intervals a sudden glare as far as to the panes of his window

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: But when the rising sun began to gild the coping stones at the gable ends of the houses, Cornelius, eager to know whether there was any living creature about him, approached the window, and cast a sad look round the circular yard before him.
children.prevalue: But when the rising sun began to gild the coping stones at the gable ends of the houses Cornelius eager to know whether there was any living creature about him approached the window and cast a sad look round the circular yard before him

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: At the end of the yard a dark mass, tinted with a dingy blue by the morning dawn, rose before him, its dark outlines standing out in contrast to the houses already illuminated by the pale light of early morning.
children.prevalue: At the end of the yard a dark mass tinted with a dingy blue by the morning dawn rose before him its dark outlines standing out in contrast to the houses already illuminated by the pale light of early morning

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Cornelius recognised the gibbet.
children.prevalue: Cornelius recognised the gibbet

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: On it were suspended two shapeless trunks, which indeed were no more than bleeding skeletons.
children.prevalue: On it were suspended two shapeless trunks which indeed were no more than bleeding skeletons

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The good people of the Hague had chopped off the flesh of its victims, but faithfully carried the remainder to the gibbet, to have a pretext for a double inscription written on a huge placard, on which Cornelius; with the keen sight of a young man of twentyeight, was able to read the following lines, daubed by the coarse brush of a signpainter:
children.prevalue: The good people of the Hague had chopped off the flesh of its victims but faithfully carried the remainder to the gibbet to have a pretext for a double inscription written on a huge placard on which Cornelius with the keen sight of a young man of twentyeight was able to read the following lines daubed by the coarse brush of a signpainter

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Here are hanging the great rogue of the name of John de Witt, and the little rogue Cornelius de Witt, his brother, two enemies of the people, but great friends of the king of France.
children.prevalue: Here are hanging the great rogue of the name of John de Witt and the little rogue Cornelius de Witt his brother two enemies of the people but great friends of the king of France

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Cornelius uttered a cry of horror, and in the agony of his frantic terror knocked with his hands and feet at the door so violently and continuously, that Gryphus, with his huge bunch of keys in his hand, ran furiously up.
children.prevalue: Cornelius uttered a cry of horror and in the agony of his frantic terror knocked with his hands and feet at the door so violently and continuously that Gryphus with his huge bunch of keys in his hand ran furiously up

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: The jailer opened the door, with terrible imprecations against the prisoner who disturbed him at an hour which Master Gryphus was not accustomed to be aroused.
children.prevalue: The jailer opened the door with terrible imprecations against the prisoner who disturbed him at an hour which Master Gryphus was not accustomed to be aroused

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Well, now, by my soul, he is mad, this new De Witt, he cried, but all those De Witts have the devil in them.
children.prevalue: Well now by my soul he is mad this new De Witt he cried but all those De Witts have the devil in them

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Master, master, cried Cornelius, seizing the jailer by the arm and dragging him towards the window,master, what have I read down there?
children.prevalue: Master master cried Cornelius seizing the jailer by the arm and dragging him towards the window master what have I read down there

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Where down there?
children.prevalue: Where down there

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: On that placard.
children.prevalue: On that placard

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: And, trembling, pale, and gasping for breath, he pointed to the gibbet at the other side of the yard, with the cynical inscription surmounting it.
children.prevalue: And trembling pale and gasping for breath he pointed to the gibbet at the other side of the yard with the cynical inscription surmounting it

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Gryphus broke out into a laugh.
children.prevalue: Gryphus broke out into a laugh

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Eh! eh! he answered, so, you have read it. Well, my good sir, that's what people will get for corresponding with the enemies of his Highness the Prince of Orange.
children.prevalue: Eh eh he answered so you have read it Well my good sir that s what people will get for corresponding with the enemies of his Highness the Prince of Orange

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: The brothers De Witt are murdered! Cornelius muttered, with the cold sweat on his brow, and sank on his bed, his arms hanging by his side, and his eyes closed.
children.prevalue: The brothers De Witt are murdered Cornelius muttered with the cold sweat on his brow and sank on his bed his arms hanging by his side and his eyes closed

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The brothers De Witt have been judged by the people, said Gryphus; you call that murdered, do you? well, I call it executed.
