children.prevalue: The brothers De Witt have been judged by the people said Gryphus you call that murdered do you well I call it executed

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: And seeing that the prisoner was not only quiet, but entirely prostrate and senseless, he rushed from the cell, violently slamming the door, and noisily drawing the bolts.
children.prevalue: And seeing that the prisoner was not only quiet but entirely prostrate and senseless he rushed from the cell violently slamming the door and noisily drawing the bolts

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Recovering his consciousness, Cornelius found himself alone, and recognised the room where he was,the family cell, as Gryphus had called it,as the fatal passage leading to ignominious death.
children.prevalue: Recovering his consciousness Cornelius found himself alone and recognised the room where he was the family cell as Gryphus had called it as the fatal passage leading to ignominious death

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: And as he was a philosopher, and, more than that, as he was a Christian, he began to pray for the soul of his godfather, then for that of the Grand Pensionary, and at last submitted with resignation to all the sufferings which God might ordain for him.
children.prevalue: And as he was a philosopher and more than that as he was a Christian he began to pray for the soul of his godfather then for that of the Grand Pensionary and at last submitted with resignation to all the sufferings which God might ordain for him

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Then turning again to the concerns of earth, and having satisfied himself that he was alone in his dungeon, he drew from his breast the three bulbs of the black tulip, and concealed them behind a block of stone, on which the traditional waterjug of the prison was standing, in the darkest corner of his cell.
children.prevalue: Then turning again to the concerns of earth and having satisfied himself that he was alone in his dungeon he drew from his breast the three bulbs of the black tulip and concealed them behind a block of stone on which the traditional waterjug of the prison was standing in the darkest corner of his cell

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Useless labour of so many years! such sweet hopes crushed; his discovery was, after all, to lead to naught, just as his own career was to be cut short. Here, in his prison, there was not a trace of vegetation, not an atom of soil, not a ray of sunshine.
children.prevalue: Useless labour of so many years such sweet hopes crushed his discovery was after all to lead to naught just as his own career was to be cut short Here in his prison there was not a trace of vegetation not an atom of soil not a ray of sunshine

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: At this thought Cornelius fell into a gloomy despair, from which he was only aroused by an extraordinary circumstance.
children.prevalue: At this thought Cornelius fell into a gloomy despair from which he was only aroused by an extraordinary circumstance

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: What was this circumstance?
children.prevalue: What was this circumstance

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: We shall inform the reader in our next chapter.
children.prevalue: We shall inform the reader in our next chapter

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: On the same evening Gryphus, as he brought the prisoner his mess, slipped on the damp flags whilst opening the door of the cell, and fell, in the attempt to steady himself, on his hand; but as it was turned the wrong way, he broke his arm just above the wrist.
children.prevalue: On the same evening Gryphus as he brought the prisoner his mess slipped on the damp flags whilst opening the door of the cell and fell in the attempt to steady himself on his hand but as it was turned the wrong way he broke his arm just above the wrist

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Cornelius rushed forward towards the jailer, but Gryphus, who was not yet aware of the serious nature of his injury, called out to him,
children.prevalue: Cornelius rushed forward towards the jailer but Gryphus who was not yet aware of the serious nature of his injury called out to him

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: It is nothing: don't you stir.
children.prevalue: It is nothing don t you stir

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: He then tried to support himself on his arm, but the bone gave way; then only he felt the pain, and uttered a cry.
children.prevalue: He then tried to support himself on his arm but the bone gave way then only he felt the pain and uttered a cry

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: When he became aware that his arm was broken, this man, so harsh to others, fell swooning on the threshold, where he remained motionless and cold, as if dead.
children.prevalue: When he became aware that his arm was broken this man so harsh to others fell swooning on the threshold where he remained motionless and cold as if dead

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: During all this time the door of the cell stood open and Cornelius found himself almost free. But the thought never entered his mind of profiting by this accident; he had seen from the manner in which the arm was bent, and from the noise it made in bending, that the bone was fractured, and that the patient must be in great pain; and now he thought of nothing else but of administering relief to the sufferer, however little benevolent the man had shown himself during their short interview.
children.prevalue: During all this time the door of the cell stood open and Cornelius found himself almost free But the thought never entered his mind of profiting by this accident he had seen from the manner in which the arm was bent and from the noise it made in bending that the bone was fractured and that the patient must be in great pain and now he thought of nothing else but of administering relief to the sufferer however little benevolent the man had shown himself during their short interview

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: At the noise of Gryphus's fall, and at the cry which escaped him, a hasty step was heard on the staircase, and immediately after a lovely apparition presented itself to the eyes of Cornelius.
children.prevalue: At the noise of Gryphus s fall and at the cry which escaped him a hasty step was heard on the staircase and immediately after a lovely apparition presented itself to the eyes of Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: It was the beautiful young Frisian, who, seeing her father stretched on the ground, and the prisoner bending over him, uttered a faint cry, as in the first fright she thought Gryphus, whose brutality she well knew, had fallen in consequence of a struggle between him and the prisoner.
children.prevalue: It was the beautiful young Frisian who seeing her father stretched on the ground and the prisoner bending over him uttered a faint cry as in the first fright she thought Gryphus whose brutality she well knew had fallen in consequence of a struggle between him and the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Cornelius understood what was passing in the mind of the girl, at the very moment when the suspicion arose in her heart.
children.prevalue: Cornelius understood what was passing in the mind of the girl at the very moment when the suspicion arose in her heart

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: But one moment told her the true state of the case and, ashamed of her first thoughts, she cast her beautiful eyes, wet with tears, on the young man, and said to him,
children.prevalue: But one moment told her the true state of the case and ashamed of her first thoughts she cast her beautiful eyes wet with tears on the young man and said to him

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I beg your pardon, and thank you, sir; the first for what I have thought, and the second for what you are doing.
children.prevalue: I beg your pardon and thank you sir the first for what I have thought and the second for what you are doing

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Cornelius blushed, and said, I am but doing my duty as a Christian in helping my neighbour.
children.prevalue: Cornelius blushed and said I am but doing my duty as a Christian in helping my neighbour

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Yes, and affording him your help this evening, you have forgotten the abuse which he heaped on you this morning. Oh, sir! this is more than humanity,this is indeed Christian charity.
children.prevalue: Yes and affording him your help this evening you have forgotten the abuse which he heaped on you this morning Oh sir this is more than humanity this is indeed Christian charity

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Cornelius cast his eyes on the beautiful girl, quite astonished to hear from the mouth of one so humble such a noble and feeling speech.
children.prevalue: Cornelius cast his eyes on the beautiful girl quite astonished to hear from the mouth of one so humble such a noble and feeling speech

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: But he had no time to express his surprise. Gryphus recovered from his swoon, opened his eyes, and as his brutality was returning with his senses, he growled That's it, a fellow is in a hurry to bring to a prisoner his supper, and falls and breaks his arm, and is left lying on the ground.
children.prevalue: But he had no time to express his surprise Gryphus recovered from his swoon opened his eyes and as his brutality was returning with his senses he growled That s it a fellow is in a hurry to bring to a prisoner his supper and falls and breaks his arm and is left lying on the ground

children.value: His aid? Gryphus replied, with a doubtful air.
children.prevalue: His aid Gryphus replied with a doubtful air

children.value: You! said Gryphus, are you a medical man?
children.prevalue: You said Gryphus are you a medical man

children.prevalue: It was formerly my profession

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: And so you would be able to set my arm?
children.prevalue: And so you would be able to set my arm

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Perfectly.
children.prevalue: Perfectly

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: And what would you need to do it? let us hear.
children.prevalue: And what would you need to do it let us hear

children.prevalue: Two splinters of wood and some linen for a bandage

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Do you hear, Rosa? said Gryphus, the prisoner is going to set my arm, that's a saving; come, assist me to get up, I feel as heavy as lead.
children.prevalue: Do you hear Rosa said Gryphus the prisoner is going to set my arm that s a saving come assist me to get up I feel as heavy as lead

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Rosa lent the sufferer her shoulder; he put his unhurt arm around her neck, and making an effort, got on his legs, whilst Cornelius, to save him a walk, pushed a chair towards him.
children.prevalue: Rosa lent the sufferer her shoulder he put his unhurt arm around her neck and making an effort got on his legs whilst Cornelius to save him a walk pushed a chair towards him

children.value: Gryphus sat down; then, turning towards his daughter, he said,
children.prevalue: Gryphus sat down then turning towards his daughter he said

children.prevalue: Well didn t you hear go and fetch what is wanted

children.prevalue: Rosa went down and immediately after returned with two staves of a small barrel and a large roll of linen bandage

children.prevalue: Cornelius had made use of the intervening moments to take off the man s coat and to tuck up his shirt sleeve

children.value: Is this what you require, sir? asked Rosa.
children.prevalue: Is this what you require sir asked Rosa

children.value: Yes, mademoiselle, answered Cornelius, looking at the things she had brought,yes, that's right. Now push this table, whilst I support the arm of your father.
children.prevalue: Yes mademoiselle answered Cornelius looking at the things she had brought yes that s right Now push this table whilst I support the arm of your father

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Rosa pushed the table, Cornelius placed the broken arm on it so as to make it flat, and with perfect skill set the bone, adjusted the splinters, and fastened the bandages.
children.prevalue: Rosa pushed the table Cornelius placed the broken arm on it so as to make it flat and with perfect skill set the bone adjusted the splinters and fastened the bandages

children.prevalue: At the last touch the jailer fainted a second time

children.prevalue: Go and fetch vinegar mademoiselle said Cornelius we will bathe his temples and he will recover

children.value: But, instead of acting up to the doctor's prescription, Rosa, after having satisfied herself that her father was still unconscious, approached Cornelius and said,

children.prevalue: Service for service sir

children.prevalue: What do you mean my pretty child said Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: I mean to say, sir, that the judge who is to examine you tomorrow has inquired today for the room in which you are confined, and, on being told that you are occupying the cell of Mynheer Cornelius de Witt, laughed in a very strange and very disagreeable manner, which makes me fear that no good awaits you.
children.prevalue: I mean to say sir that the judge who is to examine you tomorrow has inquired today for the room in which you are confined and on being told that you are occupying the cell of Mynheer Cornelius de Witt laughed in a very strange and very disagreeable manner which makes me fear that no good awaits you

children.prevalue: But asked Cornelius what harm can they do to me

children.prevalue: Look at that gibbet

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: But I am not guilty, said Cornelius.
children.prevalue: But I am not guilty said Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_43

children.prevalue: Were they guilty whom you see down there gibbeted mangled and torn to pieces

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: That's true, said Cornelius, gravely.
children.prevalue: That s true said Cornelius gravely

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: And besides, continued Rosa, the people want to find you guilty. But whether innocent or guilty, your trial begins tomorrow, and the day after you will be condemned. Matters are settled very quickly in these times.
children.prevalue: And besides continued Rosa the people want to find you guilty But whether innocent or guilty your trial begins tomorrow and the day after you will be condemned Matters are settled very quickly in these times

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Well, and what do you conclude from all this?
children.prevalue: Well and what do you conclude from all this

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I conclude that I am alone, that I am weak, that my father is lying in a swoon, that the dog is muzzled, and that consequently there is nothing to prevent your making your escape. Fly, then; that's what I mean.
children.prevalue: I conclude that I am alone that I am weak that my father is lying in a swoon that the dog is muzzled and that consequently there is nothing to prevent your making your escape Fly then that s what I mean

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: What do you say?
children.prevalue: What do you say

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: I say that I was not able to save Mynheer Cornelius or Mynheer John de Witt, and that I should like to save you. Only be quick; there, my father is regaining his breath, one minute more, and he will open his eyes, and it will be too late. Do you hesitate?
children.prevalue: I say that I was not able to save Mynheer Cornelius or Mynheer John de Witt and that I should like to save you Only be quick there my father is regaining his breath one minute more and he will open his eyes and it will be too late Do you hesitate

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: In fact, Cornelius stood immovable, looking at Rosa, yet looking at her as if he did not hear her.
children.prevalue: In fact Cornelius stood immovable looking at Rosa yet looking at her as if he did not hear her

children.value: Don't you understand me? said the young girl, with some impatience.
children.prevalue: Don t you understand me said the young girl with some impatience

children.prevalue: Yes I do said Cornelius but

children.value: But?
children.prevalue: But

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: I will not, they would accuse you.
children.prevalue: I will not they would accuse you

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Never mind, said Rosa, blushing, never mind that.
children.prevalue: Never mind said Rosa blushing never mind that

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: You are very good, my dear child, replied Cornelius, but I stay.
children.prevalue: You are very good my dear child replied Cornelius but I stay

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: You stay, oh, sir! oh, sir! don't you understand that you will be condemned to death, executed on the scaffold, perhaps assassinated and torn to pieces, just like Mynheer John and Mynheer Cornelius. For heaven's sake, don't think of me, but fly from this place, Take care, it bears ill luck to the De Witts!

children.value: Halloa! cried the jailer, recovering his senses, who is talking of those rogues, those wretches, those villains, the De Witts?
children.prevalue: Halloa cried the jailer recovering his senses who is talking of those rogues those wretches those villains the De Witts

children.value: Don't be angry, my good man, said Cornelius, with his goodtempered smile, the worst thing for a fracture is excitement, by which the blood is heated.
children.prevalue: Don t be angry my good man said Cornelius with his goodtempered smile the worst thing for a fracture is excitement by which the blood is heated

children.value: Thereupon, he said in an undertone to Rosa
children.prevalue: Thereupon he said in an undertone to Rosa

children.prevalue: My child I am innocent and I shall await my trial with tranquillity and an easy mind

children.value: Hush, said Rosa.
children.prevalue: Hush said Rosa

children.prevalue: Why hush

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: What harm would that do?
children.prevalue: What harm would that do

children.prevalue: What harm He would never allow me to come here any more said Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Cornelius received this innocent confidence with a smile; he felt as if a ray of good fortune were shining on his path.

children.value: Now, then, what are you chattering there together about? said Gryphus, rising and supporting his right arm with his left.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Rosa had not been mistaken; the judges came on the following day to the Buytenhof, and proceeded with the trial of Cornelius van Baerle. The examination, however, did not last long, it having appeared on evidence that Cornelius had kept at his house that fatal correspondence of the brothers De Witt with France.
children.prevalue: Rosa had not been mistaken the judges came on the following day to the Buytenhof and proceeded with the trial of Cornelius van Baerle The examination however did not last long it having appeared on evidence that Cornelius had kept at his house that fatal correspondence of the brothers De Witt with France

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: He did not deny it.
children.prevalue: He did not deny it

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The only point about which there seemed any difficulty was whether this correspondence had been intrusted to him by his godfather, Cornelius de Witt.
children.prevalue: The only point about which there seemed any difficulty was whether this correspondence had been intrusted to him by his godfather Cornelius de Witt

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: But as, since the death of those two martyrs, Van Baerle had no longer any reason for withholding the truth, he not only did not deny that the parcel had been delivered to him by Cornelius de Witt himself, but he also stated all the circumstances under which it was done.
children.prevalue: But as since the death of those two martyrs Van Baerle had no longer any reason for withholding the truth he not only did not deny that the parcel had been delivered to him by Cornelius de Witt himself but he also stated all the circumstances under which it was done

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: This confession involved the godson in the crime of the godfather; manifest complicity being considered to exist between Cornelius de Witt and Cornelius van Baerle.
children.prevalue: This confession involved the godson in the crime of the godfather manifest complicity being considered to exist between Cornelius de Witt and Cornelius van Baerle

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The honest doctor did not confine himself to this avowal, but told the whole truth with regard to his own tastes, habits, and daily life. He described his indifference to politics, his love of study, of the fine arts, of science, and of flowers. He explained that, since the day when Cornelius de Witt handed to him the parcel at Dort, he himself had never touched, nor even noticed it.
children.prevalue: The honest doctor did not confine himself to this avowal but told the whole truth with regard to his own tastes habits and daily life He described his indifference to politics his love of study of the fine arts of science and of flowers He explained that since the day when Cornelius de Witt handed to him the parcel at Dort he himself had never touched nor even noticed it

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: To this it was objected, that in this respect he could not possibly be speaking the truth, since the papers had been deposited in a press in which both his hands and his eyes must have been engaged every day.
children.prevalue: To this it was objected that in this respect he could not possibly be speaking the truth since the papers had been deposited in a press in which both his hands and his eyes must have been engaged every day

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Cornelius answered that it was indeed so; that, however, he never put his hand into the press but to ascertain whether his bulbs were dry, and that he never looked into it but to see if they were beginning to sprout.
children.prevalue: Cornelius answered that it was indeed so that however he never put his hand into the press but to ascertain whether his bulbs were dry and that he never looked into it but to see if they were beginning to sprout

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: To this again it was objected, that his pretended indifference respecting this deposit was not to be reasonably entertained, as he could not have received such papers from the hand of his godfather without being made acquainted with their important character.
children.prevalue: To this again it was objected that his pretended indifference respecting this deposit was not to be reasonably entertained as he could not have received such papers from the hand of his godfather without being made acquainted with their important character

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: He replied that his godfather Cornelius loved him too well, and, above all, that he was too considerate a man to have communicated to him anything of the contents of the parcel, well knowing that such a confidence would only have caused anxiety to him who received it.
children.prevalue: He replied that his godfather Cornelius loved him too well and above all that he was too considerate a man to have communicated to him anything of the contents of the parcel well knowing that such a confidence would only have caused anxiety to him who received it

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: To this it was objected that, if De Witt had wished to act in such a way, he would have added to the parcel, in case of accidents, a certificate setting forth that his godson was an entire stranger to the nature of this correspondence, or at least he would during his trial have written a letter to him, which might be produced as his justification.
children.prevalue: To this it was objected that if De Witt had wished to act in such a way he would have added to the parcel in case of accidents a certificate setting forth that his godson was an entire stranger to the nature of this correspondence or at least he would during his trial have written a letter to him which might be produced as his justification

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Cornelius replied that undoubtedly his godfather could not have thought that there was any risk for the safety of his deposit, hidden as it was in a press which was looked upon as sacred as the tabernacle by the whole household of Van Baerle; and that consequently he had considered the certificate as useless. As to a letter, he certainly had some remembrance that some moments previous to his arrest, whilst he was absorbed in the contemplation of one of the rarest of his bulbs, John de Witt's servant entered his dryroom, and handed to him a paper, but the whole was to him only like a vague dream; the servant had disappeared, and as to the paper, perhaps it might be found if a proper search were made.
children.prevalue: Cornelius replied that undoubtedly his godfather could not have thought that there was any risk for the safety of his deposit hidden as it was in a press which was looked upon as sacred as the tabernacle by the whole household of Van Baerle and that consequently he had considered the certificate as useless As to a letter he certainly had some remembrance that some moments previous to his arrest whilst he was absorbed in the contemplation of one of the rarest of his bulbs John de Witt s servant entered his dryroom and handed to him a paper but the whole was to him only like a vague dream the servant had disappeared and as to the paper perhaps it might be found if a proper search were made

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: As far as Craeke was concerned, it was impossible to find him, as he had left Holland.
children.prevalue: As far as Craeke was concerned it was impossible to find him as he had left Holland

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The paper also was not very likely to be found, and no one gave himself the trouble to look for it.
children.prevalue: The paper also was not very likely to be found and no one gave himself the trouble to look for it

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Cornelius himself did not much press this point, since, even supposing that the paper should turn up, it could not have any direct connection with the correspondence which constituted the crime.
children.prevalue: Cornelius himself did not much press this point since even supposing that the paper should turn up it could not have any direct connection with the correspondence which constituted the crime

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: The judges wished to make it appear as though they wanted to urge Cornelius to make a better defence; they displayed that benevolent patience which is generally a sign of the magistrate's being interested for the prisoner, or of a man's having so completely got the better of his adversary that he needs no longer any oppressive means to ruin him.
children.prevalue: The judges wished to make it appear as though they wanted to urge Cornelius to make a better defence they displayed that benevolent patience which is generally a sign of the magistrate s being interested for the prisoner or of a man s having so completely got the better of his adversary that he needs no longer any oppressive means to ruin him

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Cornelius did not accept of this hypocritical protection, and in a last answer, which he set forth with the noble bearing of a martyr and the calm serenity of a righteous man, he said,
children.prevalue: Cornelius did not accept of this hypocritical protection and in a last answer which he set forth with the noble bearing of a martyr and the calm serenity of a righteous man he said

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: You ask me things, gentlemen, to which I can answer only the exact truth. Hear it. The parcel was put into my hands in the way I have described; I vow before God that I was, and am still, ignorant of its contents, and that it was not until my arrest that I learned that this deposit was the correspondence of the Grand Pensionary with the Marquis de Louvois. And lastly, I vow and protest that I do not understand how any one should have known that this parcel was in my house; and, above all, how I can be deemed criminal for having received what my illustrious and unfortunate godfather brought to my house.
children.prevalue: You ask me things gentlemen to which I can answer only the exact truth Hear it The parcel was put into my hands in the way I have described I vow before God that I was and am still ignorant of its contents and that it was not until my arrest that I learned that this deposit was the correspondence of the Grand Pensionary with the Marquis de Louvois And lastly I vow and protest that I do not understand how any one should have known that this parcel was in my house and above all how I can be deemed criminal for having received what my illustrious and unfortunate godfather brought to my house

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: This was Van Baerle's whole defence; after which the judges began to deliberate on the verdict.
children.prevalue: This was Van Baerle s whole defence after which the judges began to deliberate on the verdict

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: They considered that every offshoot of civil discord is mischievous, because it revives the contest which it is the interest of all to put down.
children.prevalue: They considered that every offshoot of civil discord is mischievous because it revives the contest which it is the interest of all to put down

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: One of them, who bore the character of a profound observer, laid down as his opinion that this young man, so phlegmatic in appearance, must in reality be very dangerous, as under this icy exterior he was sure to conceal an ardent desire to avenge his friends, the De Witts.
children.prevalue: One of them who bore the character of a profound observer laid down as his opinion that this young man so phlegmatic in appearance must in reality be very dangerous as under this icy exterior he was sure to conceal an ardent desire to avenge his friends the De Witts

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Another observed that the love of tulips agreed perfectly well with that of politics, and that it was proved in history that many very dangerous men were engaged in gardening, just as if it had been their profession, whilst really they occupied themselves with perfectly different concerns; witness Tarquin the Elder, who grew poppies at Gabii, and the Great Conde, who watered his carnations at the dungeon of Vincennes at the very moment when the former meditated his return to Rome, and the latter his escape from prison.
children.prevalue: Another observed that the love of tulips agreed perfectly well with that of politics and that it was proved in history that many very dangerous men were engaged in gardening just as if it had been their profession whilst really they occupied themselves with perfectly different concerns witness Tarquin the Elder who grew poppies at Gabii and the Great Conde who watered his carnations at the dungeon of Vincennes at the very moment when the former meditated his return to Rome and the latter his escape from prison

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The judge summed up with the following dilemma:
children.prevalue: The judge summed up with the following dilemma

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Either Cornelius van Baerle is a great lover of tulips, or a great lover of politics; in either case, he has told us a falsehood; first, because his having occupied himself with politics is proved by the letters which were found at his house; and secondly, because his having occupied himself with tulips is proved by the bulbs which leave no doubt of the fact. And herein lies the enormity of the case. As Cornelius van Baerle was concerned in the growing of tulips and in the pursuit of politics at one and the same time, the prisoner is of hybrid character, of an amphibious organisation, working with equal ardour at politics and at tulips, which proves him to belong to the class of men most dangerous to public tranquillity, and shows a certain, or rather a complete, analogy between his character and that of those master minds of which Tarquin the Elder and the Great Conde have been felicitously quoted as examples.
children.prevalue: Either Cornelius van Baerle is a great lover of tulips or a great lover of politics in either case he has told us a falsehood first because his having occupied himself with politics is proved by the letters which were found at his house and secondly because his having occupied himself with tulips is proved by the bulbs which leave no doubt of the fact And herein lies the enormity of the case As Cornelius van Baerle was concerned in the growing of tulips and in the pursuit of politics at one and the same time the prisoner is of hybrid character of an amphibious organisation working with equal ardour at politics and at tulips which proves him to belong to the class of men most dangerous to public tranquillity and shows a certain or rather a complete analogy between his character and that of those master minds of which Tarquin the Elder and the Great Conde have been felicitously quoted as examples

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The upshot of all these reasonings was, that his Highness the Prince Stadtholder of Holland would feel infinitely obliged to the magistracy of the Hague if they simplified for him the government of the Seven Provinces by destroying even the least germ of conspiracy against his authority.
children.prevalue: The upshot of all these reasonings was that his Highness the Prince Stadtholder of Holland would feel infinitely obliged to the magistracy of the Hague if they simplified for him the government of the Seven Provinces by destroying even the least germ of conspiracy against his authority

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: This argument capped all the others, and, in order so much the more effectually to destroy the germ of conspiracy, sentence of death was unanimously pronounced against Cornelius van Baerle, as being arraigned, and convicted, for having, under the innocent appearance of a tulipfancier, participated in the detestable intrigues and abominable plots of the brothers De Witt against Dutch nationality and in their secret relations with their French enemy.
children.prevalue: This argument capped all the others and in order so much the more effectually to destroy the germ of conspiracy sentence of death was unanimously pronounced against Cornelius van Baerle as being arraigned and convicted for having under the innocent appearance of a tulipfancier participated in the detestable intrigues and abominable plots of the brothers De Witt against Dutch nationality and in their secret relations with their French enemy

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: A supplementary clause was tacked to the sentence, to the effect that the aforesaid Cornelius van Baerle should be led from the prison of the Buytenhof to the scaffold in the yard of the same name, where the public executioner would cut off his head.
children.prevalue: A supplementary clause was tacked to the sentence to the effect that the aforesaid Cornelius van Baerle should be led from the prison of the Buytenhof to the scaffold in the yard of the same name where the public executioner would cut off his head

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: As this deliberation was a most serious affair, it lasted a full halfhour, during which the prisoner was remanded to his cell.
children.prevalue: As this deliberation was a most serious affair it lasted a full halfhour during which the prisoner was remanded to his cell

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: There the Recorder of the States came to read the sentence to him.
children.prevalue: There the Recorder of the States came to read the sentence to him

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Master Gryphus was detained in bed by the fever caused by the fracture of his arm. His keys passed into the hands of one of his assistants. Behind this turnkey, who introduced the Recorder, Rosa, the fair Frisian maid, had slipped into the recess of the door, with a handkerchief to her mouth to stifle her sobs.
children.prevalue: Master Gryphus was detained in bed by the fever caused by the fracture of his arm His keys passed into the hands of one of his assistants Behind this turnkey who introduced the Recorder Rosa the fair Frisian maid had slipped into the recess of the door with a handkerchief to her mouth to stifle her sobs

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Cornelius listened to the sentence with an expression rather of surprise than sadness.
children.prevalue: Cornelius listened to the sentence with an expression rather of surprise than sadness

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: After the sentence was read, the Recorder asked him whether he had anything to answer.
children.prevalue: After the sentence was read the Recorder asked him whether he had anything to answer

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Indeed, I have not, he replied. Only I confess that, among all the causes of death against which a cautious man may guard, I should never have supposed this to be comprised.
children.prevalue: Indeed I have not he replied Only I confess that among all the causes of death against which a cautious man may guard I should never have supposed this to be comprised

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: On this answer, the Recorder saluted Van Baerle with all that consideration which such functionaries generally bestow upon great criminals of every sort.
children.prevalue: On this answer the Recorder saluted Van Baerle with all that consideration which such functionaries generally bestow upon great criminals of every sort

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: But whilst he was about to withdraw, Cornelius asked, By the bye, Mr. Recorder, what day is the thingyou know what I meanto take place?
children.prevalue: But whilst he was about to withdraw Cornelius asked By the bye Mr Recorder what day is the thingyou know what I meanto take place

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Why, today, answered the Recorder, a little surprised by the selfpossession of the condemned man.
children.prevalue: Why today answered the Recorder a little surprised by the selfpossession of the condemned man

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: A sob was heard behind the door, and Cornelius turned round to look from whom it came; but Rosa, who had foreseen this movement, had fallen back.
children.prevalue: A sob was heard behind the door and Cornelius turned round to look from whom it came but Rosa who had foreseen this movement had fallen back

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: And, continued Cornelius, what hour is appointed?
children.prevalue: And continued Cornelius what hour is appointed

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Twelve o'clock, sir.
children.prevalue: Twelve o clock sir

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Indeed, said Cornelius, I think I heard the clock strike ten about twenty minutes ago; I have not much time to spare.
children.prevalue: Indeed said Cornelius I think I heard the clock strike ten about twenty minutes ago I have not much time to spare

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Indeed you have not, if you wish to make your peace with God, said the Recorder, bowing to the ground. You may ask for any clergyman you please.
children.prevalue: Indeed you have not if you wish to make your peace with God said the Recorder bowing to the ground You may ask for any clergyman you please

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Saying these words he went out backwards, and the assistant turnkey was going to follow him, and to lock the door of Cornelius's cell, when a white and trembling arm interposed between him and the heavy door.
children.prevalue: Saying these words he went out backwards and the assistant turnkey was going to follow him and to lock the door of Cornelius s cell when a white and trembling arm interposed between him and the heavy door

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Cornelius saw nothing but the golden brocade cap, tipped with lace, such as the Frisian girls wore; he heard nothing but some one whispering into the ear of the turnkey. But the latter put his heavy keys into the white hand which was stretched out to receive them, and, descending some steps, sat down on the staircase which was thus guarded above by himself, and below by the dog. The headdress turned round, and Cornelius beheld the face of Rosa, blanched with grief, and her beautiful eyes streaming with tears.
children.prevalue: Cornelius saw nothing but the golden brocade cap tipped with lace such as the Frisian girls wore he heard nothing but some one whispering into the ear of the turnkey But the latter put his heavy keys into the white hand which was stretched out to receive them and descending some steps sat down on the staircase which was thus guarded above by himself and below by the dog The headdress turned round and Cornelius beheld the face of Rosa blanched with grief and her beautiful eyes streaming with tears

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: She went up to Cornelius, crossing her arms on her heaving breast.
children.prevalue: She went up to Cornelius crossing her arms on her heaving breast

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Oh, sir, sir! she said, but sobs choked her utterance.
children.prevalue: Oh sir sir she said but sobs choked her utterance

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: My good girl, Cornelius replied with emotion, what do you wish? I may tell you that my time on earth is short.
children.prevalue: My good girl Cornelius replied with emotion what do you wish I may tell you that my time on earth is short

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I come to ask a favour of you, said Rosa, extending her arms partly towards him and partly towards heaven.
children.prevalue: I come to ask a favour of you said Rosa extending her arms partly towards him and partly towards heaven

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Don't weep so, Rosa, said the prisoner, for your tears go much more to my heart than my approaching fate, and you know, the less guilty a prisoner is, the more it is his duty to die calmly, and even joyfully, as he dies a martyr. Come, there's a dear, don't cry any more, and tell me what you want, my pretty Rosa.
children.prevalue: Don t weep so Rosa said the prisoner for your tears go much more to my heart than my approaching fate and you know the less guilty a prisoner is the more it is his duty to die calmly and even joyfully as he dies a martyr Come there s a dear don t cry any more and tell me what you want my pretty Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: She fell on her knees. Forgive my father, she said.
children.prevalue: She fell on her knees Forgive my father she said

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Your father, your father! said Cornelius, astonished.
children.prevalue: Your father your father said Cornelius astonished

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Yes, he has been so harsh to you; but it is his nature, he is so to every one, and you are not the only one whom he has bullied.
children.prevalue: Yes he has been so harsh to you but it is his nature he is so to every one and you are not the only one whom he has bullied

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: He is punished, my dear Rosa, more than punished, by the accident that has befallen him, and I forgive him.
children.prevalue: He is punished my dear Rosa more than punished by the accident that has befallen him and I forgive him

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: I thank you, sir, said Rosa. And now tell meoh, tell mecan I do anything for you?
children.prevalue: I thank you sir said Rosa And now tell meoh tell mecan I do anything for you

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: You can dry your beautiful eyes, my dear child, answered Cornelius, with a goodtempered smile.
children.prevalue: You can dry your beautiful eyes my dear child answered Cornelius with a goodtempered smile

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: But what can I do for you,for you I mean?
children.prevalue: But what can I do for you for you I mean

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: A man who has only one hour longer to live must be a great Sybarite still to want anything, my dear Rosa.
children.prevalue: A man who has only one hour longer to live must be a great Sybarite still to want anything my dear Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: The clergyman whom they have proposed to you?
children.prevalue: The clergyman whom they have proposed to you

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: I have worshipped God all my life, I have worshipped Him in His works, and praised Him in His decrees. I am at peace with Him and do not wish for a clergyman. The last thought which occupies my mind, however has reference to the glory of the Almighty, and, indeed, my dear, I should ask you to help me in carrying out this last thought.
children.prevalue: I have worshipped God all my life I have worshipped Him in His works and praised Him in His decrees I am at peace with Him and do not wish for a clergyman The last thought which occupies my mind however has reference to the glory of the Almighty and indeed my dear I should ask you to help me in carrying out this last thought

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Oh, Mynheer Cornelius, speak, speak! exclaimed Rosa, still bathed in tears.
children.prevalue: Oh Mynheer Cornelius speak speak exclaimed Rosa still bathed in tears

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Give me your hand, and promise me not to laugh, my dear child.
children.prevalue: Give me your hand and promise me not to laugh my dear child

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Laugh, exclaimed Rosa, frantic with grief, laugh at this moment! do you not see my tears?
children.prevalue: Laugh exclaimed Rosa frantic with grief laugh at this moment do you not see my tears

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Rosa, you are no stranger to me. I have not seen much of you, but that little is enough to make me appreciate your character. I have never seen a woman more fair or more pure than you are, and if from this moment I take no more notice of you, forgive me; it is only because, on leaving this world, I do not wish to have any further regret.
children.prevalue: Rosa you are no stranger to me I have not seen much of you but that little is enough to make me appreciate your character I have never seen a woman more fair or more pure than you are and if from this moment I take no more notice of you forgive me it is only because on leaving this world I do not wish to have any further regret

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Rosa felt a shudder creeping over her frame, for, whilst the prisoner pronounced these words, the belfry clock of the Buytenhof struck eleven.
children.prevalue: Rosa felt a shudder creeping over her frame for whilst the prisoner pronounced these words the belfry clock of the Buytenhof struck eleven

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Cornelius understood her. Yes, yes, let us make haste, he said, you are right, Rosa.
children.prevalue: Cornelius understood her Yes yes let us make haste he said you are right Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Then, taking the paper with the three suckers from his breast, where he had again put it, since he had no longer any fear of being searched, he said: My dear girl, I have been very fond of flowers. That was at a time when I did not know that there was anything else to be loved. Don't blush, Rosa, nor turn away; and even if I were making you a declaration of love, alas! poor dear, it would be of no more consequence. Down there in the yard, there is an instrument of steel, which in sixty minutes will put an end to my boldness. Well, Rosa, I loved flowers dearly, and I have found, or at least I believe so, the secret of the great black tulip, which it has been considered impossible to grow, and for which, as you know, or may not know, a prize of a hundred thousand guilders has been offered by the Horticultural Society of Haarlem. These hundred thousand guildersand Heaven knows I do not regret themthese hundred thousand guilders I have here in this paper, for they are won by the three bulbs wrapped up in it, which you may take, Rosa, as I make you a present of them.
children.prevalue: Then taking the paper with the three suckers from his breast where he had again put it since he had no longer any fear of being searched he said My dear girl I have been very fond of flowers That was at a time when I did not know that there was anything else to be loved Don t blush Rosa nor turn away and even if I were making you a declaration of love alas poor dear it would be of no more consequence Down there in the yard there is an instrument of steel which in sixty minutes will put an end to my boldness Well Rosa I loved flowers dearly and I have found or at least I believe so the secret of the great black tulip which it has been considered impossible to grow and for which as you know or may not know a prize of a hundred thousand guilders has been offered by the Horticultural Society of Haarlem These hundred thousand guildersand Heaven knows I do not regret themthese hundred thousand guilders I have here in this paper for they are won by the three bulbs wrapped up in it which you may take Rosa as I make you a present of them

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Mynheer Cornelius!
children.prevalue: Mynheer Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Yes, yes, Rosa, you may take them; you are not wronging any one, my child. I am alone in this world; my parents are dead; I never had a sister or a brother. I have never had a thought of loving any one with what is called love, and if any one has loved me, I have not known it. However, you see well, Rosa, that I am abandoned by everybody, as in this sad hour you alone are with me in my prison, consoling and assisting me.
children.prevalue: Yes yes Rosa you may take them you are not wronging any one my child I am alone in this world my parents are dead I never had a sister or a brother I have never had a thought of loving any one with what is called love and if any one has loved me I have not known it However you see well Rosa that I am abandoned by everybody as in this sad hour you alone are with me in my prison consoling and assisting me

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: But, sir, a hundred thousand guilders!
children.prevalue: But sir a hundred thousand guilders

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Well, let us talk seriously, my dear child: those hundred thousand guilders will be a nice marriage portion, with your pretty face; you shall have them, Rosa, dear Rosa, and I ask nothing in return but your promise that you will marry a fine young man, whom you love, and who will love you, as dearly as I loved my flowers. Don't interrupt me, Rosa dear, I have only a few minutes more.
children.prevalue: Well let us talk seriously my dear child those hundred thousand guilders will be a nice marriage portion with your pretty face you shall have them Rosa dear Rosa and I ask nothing in return but your promise that you will marry a fine young man whom you love and who will love you as dearly as I loved my flowers Don t interrupt me Rosa dear I have only a few minutes more

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: The poor girl was nearly choking with her sobs.
children.prevalue: The poor girl was nearly choking with her sobs

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Cornelius took her by the hand.
children.prevalue: Cornelius took her by the hand

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Listen to me, he continued: I'll tell you how to manage it. Go to Dort and ask Butruysheim, my gardener, for soil from my border number six, fill a deep box with it, and plant in it these three bulbs. They will flower next May, that is to say, in seven months; and, when you see the flower forming on the stem, be careful at night to protect them from the wind, and by day to screen them from the sun. They will flower black, I am quite sure of it. You are then to apprise the President of the Haarlem Society. He will cause the color of the flower to be proved before a committee and these hundred thousand guilders will be paid to you.
children.prevalue: Listen to me he continued I ll tell you how to manage it Go to Dort and ask Butruysheim my gardener for soil from my border number six fill a deep box with it and plant in it these three bulbs They will flower next May that is to say in seven months and when you see the flower forming on the stem be careful at night to protect them from the wind and by day to screen them from the sun They will flower black I am quite sure of it You are then to apprise the President of the Haarlem Society He will cause the color of the flower to be proved before a committee and these hundred thousand guilders will be paid to you

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Rosa heaved a deep sigh.
children.prevalue: Rosa heaved a deep sigh

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: And now, continued Cornelius,wiping away a tear which was glistening in his eye, and which was shed much more for that marvellous black tulip which he was not to see than for the life which he was about to lose,I have no wish left, except that the tulip should be called Rosa Barlaensis, that is to say, that its name should combine yours and mine; and as, of course, you do not understand Latin, and might therefore forget this name, try to get for me pencil and paper, that I may write it down for you.
children.prevalue: And now continued Cornelius wiping away a tear which was glistening in his eye and which was shed much more for that marvellous black tulip which he was not to see than for the life which he was about to lose I have no wish left except that the tulip should be called Rosa Barlaensis that is to say that its name should combine yours and mine and as of course you do not understand Latin and might therefore forget this name try to get for me pencil and paper that I may write it down for you

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Rosa sobbed afresh, and handed to him a book, bound in shagreen, which bore the initials C. W.
children.prevalue: Rosa sobbed afresh and handed to him a book bound in shagreen which bore the initials C W

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: What is this? asked the prisoner.
children.prevalue: What is this asked the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Alas! replied Rosa, it is the Bible of your poor godfather, Cornelius de Witt. From it he derived strength to endure the torture, and to bear his sentence without flinching. I found it in this cell, after the death of the martyr, and have preserved it as a relic. Today I brought it to you, for it seemed to me that this book must possess in itself a divine power. Write in it what you have to write, Mynheer Cornelius; and though, unfortunately, I am not able to read, I will take care that what you write shall be accomplished.
children.prevalue: Alas replied Rosa it is the Bible of your poor godfather Cornelius de Witt From it he derived strength to endure the torture and to bear his sentence without flinching I found it in this cell after the death of the martyr and have preserved it as a relic Today I brought it to you for it seemed to me that this book must possess in itself a divine power Write in it what you have to write Mynheer Cornelius and though unfortunately I am not able to read I will take care that what you write shall be accomplished

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Cornelius took the Bible, and kissed it reverently.
children.prevalue: Cornelius took the Bible and kissed it reverently

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: With what shall I write? asked Cornelius.
children.prevalue: With what shall I write asked Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: There is a pencil in the Bible, said Rosa.
children.prevalue: There is a pencil in the Bible said Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: This was the pencil which John de Witt had lent to his brother, and which he had forgotten to take away with him.
children.prevalue: This was the pencil which John de Witt had lent to his brother and which he had forgotten to take away with him

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Cornelius took it, and on the second fly leaf (for it will be remembered that the first was torn out), drawing near his end like his godfather, he wrote with a no less firm hand:
children.prevalue: Cornelius took it and on the second fly leaf for it will be remembered that the first was torn out drawing near his end like his godfather he wrote with a no less firm hand

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: On this day, the 23d of August, 1672, being on the point of rendering, although innocent, my soul to God on the scaffold, I bequeath to Rosa Gryphus the only worldly goods which remain to me of all that I have possessed in this world, the rest having been confiscated; I bequeath, I say, to Rosa Gryphus three bulbs, which I am convinced must produce, in the next May, the Grand Black Tulip for which a prize of a hundred thousand guilders has been offered by the Haarlem Society, requesting that she may be paid the same sum in my stead, as my sole heiress, under the only condition of her marrying a respectable young man of about my age, who loves her, and whom she loves, and of her giving the black tulip, which will constitute a new species, the name of Rosa Barlaensis, that is to say, hers and mine combined.
children.prevalue: On this day the 23d of August 1672 being on the point of rendering although innocent my soul to God on the scaffold I bequeath to Rosa Gryphus the only worldly goods which remain to me of all that I have possessed in this world the rest having been confiscated I bequeath I say to Rosa Gryphus three bulbs which I am convinced must produce in the next May the Grand Black Tulip for which a prize of a hundred thousand guilders has been offered by the Haarlem Society requesting that she may be paid the same sum in my stead as my sole heiress under the only condition of her marrying a respectable young man of about my age who loves her and whom she loves and of her giving the black tulip which will constitute a new species the name of Rosa Barlaensis that is to say hers and mine combined

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: So may God grant me mercy, and to her health and long life!
children.prevalue: So may God grant me mercy and to her health and long life

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Cornelius van Baerle.
children.prevalue: Cornelius van Baerle

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: The prisoner then, giving the Bible to Rosa, said,
children.prevalue: The prisoner then giving the Bible to Rosa said

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Read.
children.prevalue: Read

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Alas! she answered, I have already told you I cannot read.
children.prevalue: Alas she answered I have already told you I cannot read

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Cornelius then read to Rosa the testament that he had just made.
children.prevalue: Cornelius then read to Rosa the testament that he had just made

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: The agony of the poor girl almost overpowered her.
children.prevalue: The agony of the poor girl almost overpowered her

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Do you accept my conditions? asked the prisoner, with a melancholy smile, kissing the trembling hands of the afflicted girl.
children.prevalue: Do you accept my conditions asked the prisoner with a melancholy smile kissing the trembling hands of the afflicted girl

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Oh, I don't know, sir, she stammered.
children.prevalue: Oh I don t know sir she stammered

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: You don't know, child, and why not?
children.prevalue: You don t know child and why not

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Because there is one condition which I am afraid I cannot keep.
children.prevalue: Because there is one condition which I am afraid I cannot keep

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Which? I should have thought that all was settled between us.
children.prevalue: Which I should have thought that all was settled between us

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: You give me the hundred thousand guilders as a marriage portion, don't you?
children.prevalue: You give me the hundred thousand guilders as a marriage portion don t you

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: And under the condition of my marrying a man whom I love?
children.prevalue: And under the condition of my marrying a man whom I love

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Well, then, sir, this money cannot belong to me. I shall never love any one; neither shall I marry.
children.prevalue: Well then sir this money cannot belong to me I shall never love any one neither shall I marry

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: And, after having with difficulty uttered these words, Rosa almost swooned away in the violence of her grief.
children.prevalue: And after having with difficulty uttered these words Rosa almost swooned away in the violence of her grief

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Cornelius, frightened at seeing her so pale and sinking, was going to take her in his arms, when a heavy step, followed by other dismal sounds, was heard on the staircase, amidst the continued barking of the dog.
children.prevalue: Cornelius frightened at seeing her so pale and sinking was going to take her in his arms when a heavy step followed by other dismal sounds was heard on the staircase amidst the continued barking of the dog

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: They are coming to fetch you. Oh God! Oh God! cried Rosa, wringing her hands. And have you nothing more to tell me?
children.prevalue: They are coming to fetch you Oh God Oh God cried Rosa wringing her hands And have you nothing more to tell me

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: She fell on her knees with her face buried in her hands and became almost senseless.
children.prevalue: She fell on her knees with her face buried in her hands and became almost senseless

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: I have only to say, that I wish you to preserve these bulbs as a most precious treasure, and carefully to treat them according to the directions I have given you. Do it for my sake, and now farewell, Rosa.
children.prevalue: I have only to say that I wish you to preserve these bulbs as a most precious treasure and carefully to treat them according to the directions I have given you Do it for my sake and now farewell Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Yes, yes, she said, without raising her head, I will do anything you bid me, except marrying, she added, in a low voice, for that, oh! that is impossible for me.
children.prevalue: Yes yes she said without raising her head I will do anything you bid me except marrying she added in a low voice for that oh that is impossible for me

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: She then put the cherished treasure next her beating heart.
children.prevalue: She then put the cherished treasure next her beating heart

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: The noise on the staircase which Cornelius and Rosa had heard was caused by the Recorder, who was coming for the prisoner. He was followed by the executioner, by the soldiers who were to form the guard round the scaffold, and by some curious hangerson of the prison.
children.prevalue: The noise on the staircase which Cornelius and Rosa had heard was caused by the Recorder who was coming for the prisoner He was followed by the executioner by the soldiers who were to form the guard round the scaffold and by some curious hangerson of the prison

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Cornelius, without showing any weakness, but likewise without any bravado, received them rather as friends than as persecutors, and quietly submitted to all those preparations which these men were obliged to make in performance of their duty.
children.prevalue: Cornelius without showing any weakness but likewise without any bravado received them rather as friends than as persecutors and quietly submitted to all those preparations which these men were obliged to make in performance of their duty

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Then, casting a glance into the yard through the narrow ironbarred window of his cell, he perceived the scaffold, and, at twenty paces distant from it, the gibbet, from which, by order of the Stadtholder, the outraged remains of the two brothers De Witt had been taken down.
children.prevalue: Then casting a glance into the yard through the narrow ironbarred window of his cell he perceived the scaffold and at twenty paces distant from it the gibbet from which by order of the Stadtholder the outraged remains of the two brothers De Witt had been taken down

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: When the moment came to descend in order to follow the guards, Cornelius sought with his eyes the angelic look of Rosa, but he saw, behind the swords and halberds, only a form lying outstretched near a wooden bench, and a deathlike face half covered with long golden locks.
children.prevalue: When the moment came to descend in order to follow the guards Cornelius sought with his eyes the angelic look of Rosa but he saw behind the swords and halberds only a form lying outstretched near a wooden bench and a deathlike face half covered with long golden locks

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: But Rosa, whilst falling down senseless, still obeying her friend, had pressed her hand on her velvet bodice and, forgetting everything in the world besides, instinctively grasped the precious deposit which Cornelius had intrusted to her care.
children.prevalue: But Rosa whilst falling down senseless still obeying her friend had pressed her hand on her velvet bodice and forgetting everything in the world besides instinctively grasped the precious deposit which Cornelius had intrusted to her care

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Leaving the cell, the young man could still see in the convulsively clinched fingers of Rosa the yellowish leaf from that Bible on which Cornelius de Witt had with such difficulty and pain written these few lines, which, if Van Baerle had read them, would undoubtedly have been the saving of a man and a tulip.
children.prevalue: Leaving the cell the young man could still see in the convulsively clinched fingers of Rosa the yellowish leaf from that Bible on which Cornelius de Witt had with such difficulty and pain written these few lines which if Van Baerle had read them would undoubtedly have been the saving of a man and a tulip

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Cornelius had not three hundred paces to walk outside the prison to reach the foot of the scaffold. At the bottom of the staircase, the dog quietly looked at him whilst he was passing; Cornelius even fancied he saw in the eyes of the monster a certain expression as it were of compassion.
children.prevalue: Cornelius had not three hundred paces to walk outside the prison to reach the foot of the scaffold At the bottom of the staircase the dog quietly looked at him whilst he was passing Cornelius even fancied he saw in the eyes of the monster a certain expression as it were of compassion

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The dog perhaps knew the condemned prisoners, and only bit those who left as free men.
children.prevalue: The dog perhaps knew the condemned prisoners and only bit those who left as free men

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The shorter the way from the door of the prison to the foot of the scaffold, the more fully, of course, it was crowded with curious people.
children.prevalue: The shorter the way from the door of the prison to the foot of the scaffold the more fully of course it was crowded with curious people

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: These were the same who, not satisfied with the blood which they had shed three days before, were now craving for a new victim.
children.prevalue: These were the same who not satisfied with the blood which they had shed three days before were now craving for a new victim

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: And scarcely had Cornelius made his appearance than a fierce groan ran through the whole street, spreading all over the yard, and reechoing from the streets which led to the scaffold, and which were likewise crowded with spectators.
children.prevalue: And scarcely had Cornelius made his appearance than a fierce groan ran through the whole street spreading all over the yard and reechoing from the streets which led to the scaffold and which were likewise crowded with spectators

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The scaffold indeed looked like an islet at the confluence of several rivers.
children.prevalue: The scaffold indeed looked like an islet at the confluence of several rivers

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: In the midst of these threats, groans, and yells, Cornelius, very likely in order not to hear them, had buried himself in his own thoughts.
children.prevalue: In the midst of these threats groans and yells Cornelius very likely in order not to hear them had buried himself in his own thoughts

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: And what did he think of in his last melancholy journey?
children.prevalue: And what did he think of in his last melancholy journey

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Neither of his enemies, nor of his judges, nor of his executioners.
children.prevalue: Neither of his enemies nor of his judges nor of his executioners

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: He thought of the beautiful tulips which he would see from heaven above, at Ceylon, or Bengal, or elsewhere, when he would be able to look with pity on this earth, where John and Cornelius de Witt had been murdered for having thought too much of politics, and where Cornelius van Baerle was about to be murdered for having thought too much of tulips.
children.prevalue: He thought of the beautiful tulips which he would see from heaven above at Ceylon or Bengal or elsewhere when he would be able to look with pity on this earth where John and Cornelius de Witt had been murdered for having thought too much of politics and where Cornelius van Baerle was about to be murdered for having thought too much of tulips

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: It is only one stroke of the axe, said the philosopher to himself, and my beautiful dream will begin to be realised.
children.prevalue: It is only one stroke of the axe said the philosopher to himself and my beautiful dream will begin to be realised

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Only there was still a chance, just as it had happened before to M. de Chalais, to M. de Thou, and other slovenly executed people, that the headsman might inflict more than one stroke, that is to say, more than one martyrdom, on the poor tulipfancier.
children.prevalue: Only there was still a chance just as it had happened before to M de Chalais to M de Thou and other slovenly executed people that the headsman might inflict more than one stroke that is to say more than one martyrdom on the poor tulipfancier

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Yet, notwithstanding all this, Van Baerle mounted the scaffold not the less resolutely, proud of having been the friend of that illustrious John, and godson of that noble Cornelius de Witt, whom the ruffians, who were now crowding to witness his own doom, had torn to pieces and burnt three days before.
children.prevalue: Yet notwithstanding all this Van Baerle mounted the scaffold not the less resolutely proud of having been the friend of that illustrious John and godson of that noble Cornelius de Witt whom the ruffians who were now crowding to witness his own doom had torn to pieces and burnt three days before

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: He knelt down, said his prayers, and observed, not without a feeling of sincere joy, that, laying his head on the block, and keeping his eyes open, he would be able to his last moment to see the grated window of the Buytenhof.
children.prevalue: He knelt down said his prayers and observed not without a feeling of sincere joy that laying his head on the block and keeping his eyes open he would be able to his last moment to see the grated window of the Buytenhof

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: At length the fatal moment arrived, and Cornelius placed his chin on the cold damp block. But at this moment his eyes closed involuntarily, to receive more resolutely the terrible avalanche which was about to fall on his head, and to engulf his life.
children.prevalue: At length the fatal moment arrived and Cornelius placed his chin on the cold damp block But at this moment his eyes closed involuntarily to receive more resolutely the terrible avalanche which was about to fall on his head and to engulf his life

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: A gleam like that of lightning passed across the scaffold: it was the executioner raising his sword.
children.prevalue: A gleam like that of lightning passed across the scaffold it was the executioner raising his sword

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Van Baerle bade farewell to the great black tulip, certain of awaking in another world full of light and glorious tints.
children.prevalue: Van Baerle bade farewell to the great black tulip certain of awaking in another world full of light and glorious tints

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Three times he felt, with a shudder, the cold current of air from the knife near his neck, but what a surprise! he felt neither pain nor shock.
children.prevalue: Three times he felt with a shudder the cold current of air from the knife near his neck but what a surprise he felt neither pain nor shock

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: He saw no change in the colour of the sky, or of the world around him.
children.prevalue: He saw no change in the colour of the sky or of the world around him

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Then suddenly Van Baerle felt gentle hands raising him, and soon stood on his feet again, although trembling a little.
children.prevalue: Then suddenly Van Baerle felt gentle hands raising him and soon stood on his feet again although trembling a little

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: He looked around him. There was some one by his side, reading a large parchment, sealed with a huge seal of red wax.
children.prevalue: He looked around him There was some one by his side reading a large parchment sealed with a huge seal of red wax

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: And the same sun, yellow and pale, as it behooves a Dutch sun to be, was shining in the skies; and the same grated window looked down upon him from the Buytenhof; and the same rabble, no longer yelling, but completely thunderstruck, were staring at him from the streets below.
children.prevalue: And the same sun yellow and pale as it behooves a Dutch sun to be was shining in the skies and the same grated window looked down upon him from the Buytenhof and the same rabble no longer yelling but completely thunderstruck were staring at him from the streets below

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Van Baerle began to be sensible to what was going on around him.
children.prevalue: Van Baerle began to be sensible to what was going on around him

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: His Highness, William, Prince of Orange, very likely afraid that Van Baerle's blood would turn the scale of judgment against him, had compassionately taken into consideration his good character, and the apparent proofs of his innocence.
children.prevalue: His Highness William Prince of Orange very likely afraid that Van Baerle s blood would turn the scale of judgment against him had compassionately taken into consideration his good character and the apparent proofs of his innocence

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: His Highness, accordingly, had granted him his life.
children.prevalue: His Highness accordingly had granted him his life

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Cornelius at first hoped that the pardon would be complete, and that he would be restored to his full liberty and to his flower borders at Dort.
children.prevalue: Cornelius at first hoped that the pardon would be complete and that he would be restored to his full liberty and to his flower borders at Dort

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: But Cornelius was mistaken. To use an expression of Madame de Sevigne, who wrote about the same time, there was a postscript to the letter; and the most important part of the letter was contained in the postscript.
children.prevalue: But Cornelius was mistaken To use an expression of Madame de Sevigne who wrote about the same time there was a postscript to the letter and the most important part of the letter was contained in the postscript

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: In this postscript, William of Orange, Stadtholder of Holland, condemned Cornelius van Baerle to imprisonment for life. He was not sufficiently guilty to suffer death, but he was too much so to be set at liberty.
children.prevalue: In this postscript William of Orange Stadtholder of Holland condemned Cornelius van Baerle to imprisonment for life He was not sufficiently guilty to suffer death but he was too much so to be set at liberty

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Cornelius heard this clause, but, the first feeling of vexation and disappointment over, he said to himself,
children.prevalue: Cornelius heard this clause but the first feeling of vexation and disappointment over he said to himself

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Never mind, all this is not lost yet; there is some good in this perpetual imprisonment; Rosa will be there, and also my three bulbs of the black tulip are there.
children.prevalue: Never mind all this is not lost yet there is some good in this perpetual imprisonment Rosa will be there and also my three bulbs of the black tulip are there

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: But Cornelius forgot that the Seven Provinces had seven prisons, one for each, and that the board of the prisoner is anywhere else less expensive than at the Hague, which is a capital.
