children.prevalue: But Cornelius forgot that the Seven Provinces had seven prisons one for each and that the board of the prisoner is anywhere else less expensive than at the Hague which is a capital

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: His Highness, who, as it seems, did not possess the means to feed Van Baerle at the Hague, sent him to undergo his perpetual imprisonment at the fortress of Loewestein, very near Dort, but, alas! also very far from it; for Loewestein, as the geographers tell us, is situated at the point of the islet which is formed by the confluence of the Waal and the Meuse, opposite Gorcum.
children.prevalue: His Highness who as it seems did not possess the means to feed Van Baerle at the Hague sent him to undergo his perpetual imprisonment at the fortress of Loewestein very near Dort but alas also very far from it for Loewestein as the geographers tell us is situated at the point of the islet which is formed by the confluence of the Waal and the Meuse opposite Gorcum

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Van Baerle was sufficiently versed in the history of his country to know that the celebrated Grotius was confined in that castle after the death of Barneveldt; and that the States, in their generosity to the illustrious publicist, jurist, historian, poet, and divine, had granted to him for his daily maintenance the sum of twentyfour stivers.
children.prevalue: Van Baerle was sufficiently versed in the history of his country to know that the celebrated Grotius was confined in that castle after the death of Barneveldt and that the States in their generosity to the illustrious publicist jurist historian poet and divine had granted to him for his daily maintenance the sum of twentyfour stivers

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I, said Van Baerle to himself, I am worth much less than Grotius. They will hardly give me twelve stivers, and I shall live miserably; but never mind, at all events I shall live.
children.prevalue: I said Van Baerle to himself I am worth much less than Grotius They will hardly give me twelve stivers and I shall live miserably but never mind at all events I shall live

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Then suddenly a terrible thought struck him.
children.prevalue: Then suddenly a terrible thought struck him

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Ah! he exclaimed, how damp and misty that part of the country is, and the soil so bad for the tulips! And then Rosa will not be at Loewestein!
children.prevalue: Ah he exclaimed how damp and misty that part of the country is and the soil so bad for the tulips And then Rosa will not be at Loewestein

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Whilst Cornelius was engaged with his own thoughts, a coach had driven up to the scaffold. This vehicle was for the prisoner. He was invited to enter it, and he obeyed.
children.prevalue: Whilst Cornelius was engaged with his own thoughts a coach had driven up to the scaffold This vehicle was for the prisoner He was invited to enter it and he obeyed

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: His last look was towards the Buytenhof. He hoped to see at the window the face of Rosa, brightening up again.
children.prevalue: His last look was towards the Buytenhof He hoped to see at the window the face of Rosa brightening up again

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: But the coach was drawn by good horses, who soon carried Van Baerle away from among the shouts which the rabble roared in honour of the most magnanimous Stadtholder, mixing with it a spice of abuse against the brothers De Witt and the godson of Cornelius, who had just now been saved from death.
children.prevalue: But the coach was drawn by good horses who soon carried Van Baerle away from among the shouts which the rabble roared in honour of the most magnanimous Stadtholder mixing with it a spice of abuse against the brothers De Witt and the godson of Cornelius who had just now been saved from death

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: This reprieve suggested to the worthy spectators remarks such as the following:
children.prevalue: This reprieve suggested to the worthy spectators remarks such as the following

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: It's very fortunate that we used such speed in having justice done to that great villain John, and to that little rogue Cornelius, otherwise his Highness might have snatched them from us, just as he has done this fellow.
children.prevalue: It s very fortunate that we used such speed in having justice done to that great villain John and to that little rogue Cornelius otherwise his Highness might have snatched them from us just as he has done this fellow

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Among all the spectators whom Van Baerle's execution had attracted to the Buytenhof, and whom the sudden turn of affairs had disagreeably surprised, undoubtedly the one most disappointed was a certain respectably dressed burgher, who from early morning had made such a good use of his feet and elbows that he at last was separated from the scaffold only by the file of soldiers which surrounded it.
children.prevalue: Among all the spectators whom Van Baerle s execution had attracted to the Buytenhof and whom the sudden turn of affairs had disagreeably surprised undoubtedly the one most disappointed was a certain respectably dressed burgher who from early morning had made such a good use of his feet and elbows that he at last was separated from the scaffold only by the file of soldiers which surrounded it

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Many had shown themselves eager to see the perfidious blood of the guilty Cornelius flow, but not one had shown such a keen anxiety as the individual just alluded to.
children.prevalue: Many had shown themselves eager to see the perfidious blood of the guilty Cornelius flow but not one had shown such a keen anxiety as the individual just alluded to

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The most furious had come to the Buytenhof at daybreak, to secure a better place; but he, outdoing even them, had passed the night at the threshold of the prison, from whence, as we have already said, he had advanced to the very foremost rank, unguibus et rostro,that is to say, coaxing some, and kicking the others.
children.prevalue: The most furious had come to the Buytenhof at daybreak to secure a better place but he outdoing even them had passed the night at the threshold of the prison from whence as we have already said he had advanced to the very foremost rank unguibus et rostro that is to say coaxing some and kicking the others

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: And when the executioner had conducted the prisoner to the scaffold, the burgher, who had mounted on the stone of the pump the better to see and be seen, made to the executioner a sign which meant,
children.prevalue: And when the executioner had conducted the prisoner to the scaffold the burgher who had mounted on the stone of the pump the better to see and be seen made to the executioner a sign which meant

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: It's a bargain, isn't it?
children.prevalue: It s a bargain isn t it

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The executioner answered by another sign, which was meant to say,
children.prevalue: The executioner answered by another sign which was meant to say

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Be quiet, it's all right.
children.prevalue: Be quiet it s all right

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: This burgher was no other than Mynheer Isaac Boxtel, who since the arrest of Cornelius had come to the Hague to try if he could not get hold of the three bulbs of the black tulip.
children.prevalue: This burgher was no other than Mynheer Isaac Boxtel who since the arrest of Cornelius had come to the Hague to try if he could not get hold of the three bulbs of the black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Boxtel had at first tried to gain over Gryphus to his interest, but the jailer had not only the snarling fierceness, but likewise the fidelity, of a dog. He had therefore bristled up at Boxtel's hatred, whom he had suspected to be a warm friend of the prisoner, making trifling inquiries to contrive with the more certainty some means of escape for him.
children.prevalue: Boxtel had at first tried to gain over Gryphus to his interest but the jailer had not only the snarling fierceness but likewise the fidelity of a dog He had therefore bristled up at Boxtel s hatred whom he had suspected to be a warm friend of the prisoner making trifling inquiries to contrive with the more certainty some means of escape for him

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Thus to the very first proposals which Boxtel made to Gryphus to filch the bulbs which Cornelius van Baerle must be supposed to conceal, if not in his breast, at least in some corner of his cell, the surly jailer had only answered by kicking Mynheer Isaac out, and setting the dog at him.
children.prevalue: Thus to the very first proposals which Boxtel made to Gryphus to filch the bulbs which Cornelius van Baerle must be supposed to conceal if not in his breast at least in some corner of his cell the surly jailer had only answered by kicking Mynheer Isaac out and setting the dog at him

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: The piece which the mastiff had torn from his hose did not discourage Boxtel. He came back to the charge, but this time Gryphus was in bed, feverish, and with a broken arm. He therefore was not able to admit the petitioner, who then addressed himself to Rosa, offering to buy her a headdress of pure gold if she would get the bulbs for him. On this, the generous girl, although not yet knowing the value of the object of the robbery, which was to be so well remunerated, had directed the tempter to the executioner, as the heir of the prisoner.
children.prevalue: The piece which the mastiff had torn from his hose did not discourage Boxtel He came back to the charge but this time Gryphus was in bed feverish and with a broken arm He therefore was not able to admit the petitioner who then addressed himself to Rosa offering to buy her a headdress of pure gold if she would get the bulbs for him On this the generous girl although not yet knowing the value of the object of the robbery which was to be so well remunerated had directed the tempter to the executioner as the heir of the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: In the meanwhile the sentence had been pronounced. Thus Isaac had no more time to bribe any one. He therefore clung to the idea which Rosa had suggested: he went to the executioner.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile the sentence had been pronounced Thus Isaac had no more time to bribe any one He therefore clung to the idea which Rosa had suggested he went to the executioner

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Isaac had not the least doubt that Cornelius would die with the bulbs on his heart.
children.prevalue: Isaac had not the least doubt that Cornelius would die with the bulbs on his heart

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: But there were two things which Boxtel did not calculate upon:
children.prevalue: But there were two things which Boxtel did not calculate upon

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Rosa, that is to say, love;
children.prevalue: Rosa that is to say love

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: William of Orange, that is to say, clemency.
children.prevalue: William of Orange that is to say clemency

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: But for Rosa and William, the calculations of the envious neighbour would have been correct.
children.prevalue: But for Rosa and William the calculations of the envious neighbour would have been correct

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: But for William, Cornelius would have died.
children.prevalue: But for William Cornelius would have died

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: But for Rosa, Cornelius would have died with his bulbs on his heart.
children.prevalue: But for Rosa Cornelius would have died with his bulbs on his heart

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Mynheer Boxtel went to the headsman, to whom he gave himself out as a great friend of the condemned man; and from whom he bought all the clothes of the dead man that was to be, for one hundred guilders; rather an exorbitant sum, as he engaged to leave all the trinkets of gold and silver to the executioner.
children.prevalue: Mynheer Boxtel went to the headsman to whom he gave himself out as a great friend of the condemned man and from whom he bought all the clothes of the dead man that was to be for one hundred guilders rather an exorbitant sum as he engaged to leave all the trinkets of gold and silver to the executioner

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: But what was the sum of a hundred guilders to a man who was all but sure to buy with it the prize of the Haarlem Society?
children.prevalue: But what was the sum of a hundred guilders to a man who was all but sure to buy with it the prize of the Haarlem Society

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: It was money lent at a thousand per cent., which, as nobody will deny, was a very handsome investment.
children.prevalue: It was money lent at a thousand per cent which as nobody will deny was a very handsome investment

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: The headsman, on the other hand, had scarcely anything to do to earn his hundred guilders. He needed only, as soon as the execution was over, to allow Mynheer Boxtel to ascend the scaffold with his servants, to remove the inanimate remains of his friend.
children.prevalue: The headsman on the other hand had scarcely anything to do to earn his hundred guilders He needed only as soon as the execution was over to allow Mynheer Boxtel to ascend the scaffold with his servants to remove the inanimate remains of his friend

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: The thing was, moreover, quite customary among the faithful brethren, when one of their masters died a public death in the yard of the Buytenhof.
children.prevalue: The thing was moreover quite customary among the faithful brethren when one of their masters died a public death in the yard of the Buytenhof

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: A fanatic like Cornelius might very easily have found another fanatic who would give a hundred guilders for his remains.
children.prevalue: A fanatic like Cornelius might very easily have found another fanatic who would give a hundred guilders for his remains

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: The executioner also readily acquiesced in the proposal, making only one condition,that of being paid in advance.
children.prevalue: The executioner also readily acquiesced in the proposal making only one condition that of being paid in advance

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Boxtel, like the people who enter a show at a fair, might be disappointed, and refuse to pay on going out.
children.prevalue: Boxtel like the people who enter a show at a fair might be disappointed and refuse to pay on going out

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Boxtel paid in advance, and waited.
children.prevalue: Boxtel paid in advance and waited

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: After this, the reader may imagine how excited Boxtel was; with what anxiety he watched the guards, the Recorder, and the executioner; and with what intense interest he surveyed the movements of Van Baerle. How would he place himself on the block? how would he fall? and would he not, in falling, crush those inestimable bulbs? had not he at least taken care to enclose them in a golden box,as gold is the hardest of all metals?
children.prevalue: After this the reader may imagine how excited Boxtel was with what anxiety he watched the guards the Recorder and the executioner and with what intense interest he surveyed the movements of Van Baerle How would he place himself on the block how would he fall and would he not in falling crush those inestimable bulbs had not he at least taken care to enclose them in a golden box as gold is the hardest of all metals

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Every trifling delay irritated him. Why did that stupid executioner thus lose time in brandishing his sword over the head of Cornelius, instead of cutting that head off?
children.prevalue: Every trifling delay irritated him Why did that stupid executioner thus lose time in brandishing his sword over the head of Cornelius instead of cutting that head off

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: But when he saw the Recorder take the hand of the condemned, and raise him, whilst drawing forth the parchment from his pocket,when he heard the pardon of the Stadtholder publicly read out,then Boxtel was no more like a human being; the rage and malice of the tiger, of the hyena, and of the serpent glistened in his eyes, and vented itself in his yell and his movements. Had he been able to get at Van Baerle, he would have pounced upon him and strangled him.
children.prevalue: But when he saw the Recorder take the hand of the condemned and raise him whilst drawing forth the parchment from his pocket when he heard the pardon of the Stadtholder publicly read out then Boxtel was no more like a human being the rage and malice of the tiger of the hyena and of the serpent glistened in his eyes and vented itself in his yell and his movements Had he been able to get at Van Baerle he would have pounced upon him and strangled him

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: And so, then, Cornelius was to live, and was to go with him to Loewestein, and thither to his prison he would take with him his bulbs; and perhaps he would even find a garden where the black tulip would flower for him.
children.prevalue: And so then Cornelius was to live and was to go with him to Loewestein and thither to his prison he would take with him his bulbs and perhaps he would even find a garden where the black tulip would flower for him

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Boxtel, quite overcome by his frenzy, fell from the stone upon some Orangemen, who, like him, were sorely vexed at the turn which affairs had taken. They, mistaking the frantic cries of Mynheer Isaac for demonstrations of joy, began to belabour him with kicks and cuffs, such as could not have been administered in better style by any prizefighter on the other side of the Channel.
children.prevalue: Boxtel quite overcome by his frenzy fell from the stone upon some Orangemen who like him were sorely vexed at the turn which affairs had taken They mistaking the frantic cries of Mynheer Isaac for demonstrations of joy began to belabour him with kicks and cuffs such as could not have been administered in better style by any prizefighter on the other side of the Channel

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Blows were, however, nothing to him. He wanted to run after the coach which was carrying away Cornelius with his bulbs. But in his hurry he overlooked a pavingstone in his way, stumbled, lost his centre of gravity, rolled over to a distance of some yards, and only rose again, bruised and begrimed, after the whole rabble of the Hague, with their muddy feet, had passed over him.
children.prevalue: Blows were however nothing to him He wanted to run after the coach which was carrying away Cornelius with his bulbs But in his hurry he overlooked a pavingstone in his way stumbled lost his centre of gravity rolled over to a distance of some yards and only rose again bruised and begrimed after the whole rabble of the Hague with their muddy feet had passed over him

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: One would think that this was enough for one day, but Mynheer Boxtel did not seem to think so, as, in addition to having his clothes torn, his back bruised, and his hands scratched, he inflicted upon himself the further punishment of tearing out his hair by handfuls, as an offering to that goddess of envy who, as mythology teaches us, wears a headdress of serpents.
children.prevalue: One would think that this was enough for one day but Mynheer Boxtel did not seem to think so as in addition to having his clothes torn his back bruised and his hands scratched he inflicted upon himself the further punishment of tearing out his hair by handfuls as an offering to that goddess of envy who as mythology teaches us wears a headdress of serpents

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: It was indeed in itself a great honour for Cornelius van Baerle to be confined in the same prison which had once received the learned master Grotius.
children.prevalue: It was indeed in itself a great honour for Cornelius van Baerle to be confined in the same prison which had once received the learned master Grotius

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: But on arriving at the prison he met with an honour even greater. As chance would have it, the cell formerly inhabited by the illustrious Barneveldt happened to be vacant, when the clemency of the Prince of Orange sent the tulipfancier Van Baerle there.
children.prevalue: But on arriving at the prison he met with an honour even greater As chance would have it the cell formerly inhabited by the illustrious Barneveldt happened to be vacant when the clemency of the Prince of Orange sent the tulipfancier Van Baerle there

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The cell had a very bad character at the castle since the time when Grotius, by means of the device of his wife, made escape from it in that famous bookchest which the jailers forgot to examine.
children.prevalue: The cell had a very bad character at the castle since the time when Grotius by means of the device of his wife made escape from it in that famous bookchest which the jailers forgot to examine

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: On the other hand, it seemed to Van Baerle an auspicious omen that this very cell was assigned to him, for according to his ideas, a jailer ought never to have given to a second pigeon the cage from which the first had so easily flown.
children.prevalue: On the other hand it seemed to Van Baerle an auspicious omen that this very cell was assigned to him for according to his ideas a jailer ought never to have given to a second pigeon the cage from which the first had so easily flown

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The cell had an historical character. We will only state here that, with the exception of an alcove which was contrived there for the use of Madame Grotius, it differed in no respect from the other cells of the prison; only, perhaps, it was a little higher, and had a splendid view from the grated window.
children.prevalue: The cell had an historical character We will only state here that with the exception of an alcove which was contrived there for the use of Madame Grotius it differed in no respect from the other cells of the prison only perhaps it was a little higher and had a splendid view from the grated window

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Cornelius felt himself perfectly indifferent as to the place where he had to lead an existence which was little more than vegetation. There were only two things now for which he cared, and the possession of which was a happiness enjoyed only in imagination.
children.prevalue: Cornelius felt himself perfectly indifferent as to the place where he had to lead an existence which was little more than vegetation There were only two things now for which he cared and the possession of which was a happiness enjoyed only in imagination

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: A flower, and a woman; both of them, as he conceived, lost to him for ever.
children.prevalue: A flower and a woman both of them as he conceived lost to him for ever

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Fortunately the good doctor was mistaken. In his prison cell the most adventurous life which ever fell to the lot of any tulipfancier was reserved for him.
children.prevalue: Fortunately the good doctor was mistaken In his prison cell the most adventurous life which ever fell to the lot of any tulipfancier was reserved for him

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: One morning, whilst at his window inhaling the fresh air which came from the river, and casting a longing look to the windmills of his dear old city Dort, which were looming in the distance behind a forest of chimneys, he saw flocks of pigeons coming from that quarter to perch fluttering on the pointed gables of Loewestein.
children.prevalue: One morning whilst at his window inhaling the fresh air which came from the river and casting a longing look to the windmills of his dear old city Dort which were looming in the distance behind a forest of chimneys he saw flocks of pigeons coming from that quarter to perch fluttering on the pointed gables of Loewestein

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: These pigeons, Van Baerle said to himself, are coming from Dort, and consequently may return there. By fastening a little note to the wing of one of these pigeons, one might have a chance to send a message there. Then, after a few moments' consideration, he exclaimed,
children.prevalue: These pigeons Van Baerle said to himself are coming from Dort and consequently may return there By fastening a little note to the wing of one of these pigeons one might have a chance to send a message there Then after a few moments consideration he exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I will do it.
children.prevalue: I will do it

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: A man grows very patient who is twentyeight years of age, and condemned to a prison for life,that is to say, to something like twentytwo or twentythree thousand days of captivity.
children.prevalue: A man grows very patient who is twentyeight years of age and condemned to a prison for life that is to say to something like twentytwo or twentythree thousand days of captivity

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Van Baerle, from whose thoughts the three bulbs were never absent, made a snare for catching the pigeons, baiting the birds with all the resources of his kitchen, such as it was for eight slivers (sixpence English) a day; and, after a month of unsuccessful attempts, he at last caught a female bird.
children.prevalue: Van Baerle from whose thoughts the three bulbs were never absent made a snare for catching the pigeons baiting the birds with all the resources of his kitchen such as it was for eight slivers sixpence English a day and after a month of unsuccessful attempts he at last caught a female bird

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: It cost him two more months to catch a male bird; he then shut them up together, and having about the beginning of the year 1673 obtained some eggs from them, he released the female, which, leaving the male behind to hatch the eggs in her stead, flew joyously to Dort, with the note under her wing.
children.prevalue: It cost him two more months to catch a male bird he then shut them up together and having about the beginning of the year 1673 obtained some eggs from them he released the female which leaving the male behind to hatch the eggs in her stead flew joyously to Dort with the note under her wing

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: She returned in the evening. She had preserved the note.
children.prevalue: She returned in the evening She had preserved the note

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Thus it went on for fifteen days, at first to the disappointment, and then to the great grief, of Van Baerle.
children.prevalue: Thus it went on for fifteen days at first to the disappointment and then to the great grief of Van Baerle

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: On the sixteenth day, at last, she came back without it.
children.prevalue: On the sixteenth day at last she came back without it

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Van Baerle had addressed it to his nurse, the old Frisian woman; and implored any charitable soul who might find it to convey it to her as safely and as speedily as possible.
children.prevalue: Van Baerle had addressed it to his nurse the old Frisian woman and implored any charitable soul who might find it to convey it to her as safely and as speedily as possible

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: In this letter there was a little note enclosed for Rosa.
children.prevalue: In this letter there was a little note enclosed for Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Van Baerle's nurse had received the letter in the following way.
children.prevalue: Van Baerle s nurse had received the letter in the following way

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Leaving Dort, Mynheer Isaac Boxtel had abandoned, not only his house, his servants, his observatory, and his telescope, but also his pigeons.
children.prevalue: Leaving Dort Mynheer Isaac Boxtel had abandoned not only his house his servants his observatory and his telescope but also his pigeons

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The servant, having been left without wages, first lived on his little savings, and then on his master's pigeons.
children.prevalue: The servant having been left without wages first lived on his little savings and then on his master s pigeons

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Seeing this, the pigeons emigrated from the roof of Isaac Boxtel to that of Cornelius van Baerle.
children.prevalue: Seeing this the pigeons emigrated from the roof of Isaac Boxtel to that of Cornelius van Baerle

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The nurse was a kindhearted woman, who could not live without something to love. She conceived an affection for the pigeons which had thrown themselves on her hospitality; and when Boxtel's servant reclaimed them with culinary intentions, having eaten the first fifteen already, and now wishing to eat the other fifteen, she offered to buy them from him for a consideration of six stivers per head.
children.prevalue: The nurse was a kindhearted woman who could not live without something to love She conceived an affection for the pigeons which had thrown themselves on her hospitality and when Boxtel s servant reclaimed them with culinary intentions having eaten the first fifteen already and now wishing to eat the other fifteen she offered to buy them from him for a consideration of six stivers per head

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: This being just double their value, the man was very glad to close the bargain, and the nurse found herself in undisputed possession of the pigeons of her master's envious neighbour.
children.prevalue: This being just double their value the man was very glad to close the bargain and the nurse found herself in undisputed possession of the pigeons of her master s envious neighbour

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: In the course of their wanderings, these pigeons with others visited the Hague, Loewestein, and Rotterdam, seeking variety, doubtless, in the flavour of their wheat or hempseed.
children.prevalue: In the course of their wanderings these pigeons with others visited the Hague Loewestein and Rotterdam seeking variety doubtless in the flavour of their wheat or hempseed

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Chance, or rather God, for we can see the hand of God in everything, had willed that Cornelius van Baerle should happen to hit upon one of these very pigeons.
children.prevalue: Chance or rather God for we can see the hand of God in everything had willed that Cornelius van Baerle should happen to hit upon one of these very pigeons

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Therefore, if the envious wretch had not left Dort to follow his rival to the Hague in the first place, and then to Gorcum or to Loewestein,for the two places are separated only by the confluence of the Waal and the Meuse,Van Baerle's letter would have fallen into his hands and not the nurse's: in which event the poor prisoner, like the raven of the Roman cobbler, would have thrown away his time, his trouble, and, instead of having to relate the series of exciting events which are about to flow from beneath our pen like the varied hues of a many coloured tapestry, we should have naught to describe but a weary waste of days, dull and melancholy and gloomy as night's dark mantle.
children.prevalue: Therefore if the envious wretch had not left Dort to follow his rival to the Hague in the first place and then to Gorcum or to Loewestein for the two places are separated only by the confluence of the Waal and the Meuse Van Baerle s letter would have fallen into his hands and not the nurse s in which event the poor prisoner like the raven of the Roman cobbler would have thrown away his time his trouble and instead of having to relate the series of exciting events which are about to flow from beneath our pen like the varied hues of a many coloured tapestry we should have naught to describe but a weary waste of days dull and melancholy and gloomy as night s dark mantle

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: The note, as we have said, had reached Van Baerle's nurse.
children.prevalue: The note as we have said had reached Van Baerle s nurse

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: And also it came to pass, that one evening in the beginning of February, just when the stars were beginning to twinkle, Cornelius heard on the staircase of the little turret a voice which thrilled through him.
children.prevalue: And also it came to pass that one evening in the beginning of February just when the stars were beginning to twinkle Cornelius heard on the staircase of the little turret a voice which thrilled through him

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: He put his hand on his heart, and listened.
children.prevalue: He put his hand on his heart and listened

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: It was the sweet harmonious voice of Rosa.
children.prevalue: It was the sweet harmonious voice of Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Let us confess it, Cornelius was not so stupefied with surprise, or so beyond himself with joy, as he would have been but for the pigeon, which, in answer to his letter, had brought back hope to him under her empty wing; and, knowing Rosa, he expected, if the note had ever reached her, to hear of her whom he loved, and also of his three darling bulbs.
children.prevalue: Let us confess it Cornelius was not so stupefied with surprise or so beyond himself with joy as he would have been but for the pigeon which in answer to his letter had brought back hope to him under her empty wing and knowing Rosa he expected if the note had ever reached her to hear of her whom he loved and also of his three darling bulbs

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: He rose, listened once more, and bent forward towards the door.
children.prevalue: He rose listened once more and bent forward towards the door

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Yes, they were indeed the accents which had fallen so sweetly on his heart at the Hague.
children.prevalue: Yes they were indeed the accents which had fallen so sweetly on his heart at the Hague

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The question now was, whether Rosa, who had made the journey from the Hague to Loewestein, and whoCornelius did not understand howhad succeeded even in penetrating into the prison, would also be fortunate enough in penetrating to the prisoner himself.
children.prevalue: The question now was whether Rosa who had made the journey from the Hague to Loewestein and whoCornelius did not understand howhad succeeded even in penetrating into the prison would also be fortunate enough in penetrating to the prisoner himself

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Whilst Cornelius, debating this point within himself, was building all sorts of castles in the air, and was struggling between hope and fear, the shutter of the grating in the door opened, and Rosa, beaming with joy, and beautiful in her pretty national costumebut still more beautiful from the grief which for the last five months had blanched her cheekspressed her little face against the wire grating of the window, saying to him,
children.prevalue: Whilst Cornelius debating this point within himself was building all sorts of castles in the air and was struggling between hope and fear the shutter of the grating in the door opened and Rosa beaming with joy and beautiful in her pretty national costumebut still more beautiful from the grief which for the last five months had blanched her cheekspressed her little face against the wire grating of the window saying to him

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Oh, sir, sir! here I am!
children.prevalue: Oh sir sir here I am

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Cornelius stretched out his arms, and, looking to heaven, uttered a cry of joy,
children.prevalue: Cornelius stretched out his arms and looking to heaven uttered a cry of joy

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Oh, Rosa, Rosa!
children.prevalue: Oh Rosa Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Hush! let us speak low: my father follows on my heels, said the girl.
children.prevalue: Hush let us speak low my father follows on my heels said the girl

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Your father?
children.prevalue: Your father

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Yes, he is in the courtyard at the bottom of the staircase, receiving the instructions of the Governor; he will presently come up.
children.prevalue: Yes he is in the courtyard at the bottom of the staircase receiving the instructions of the Governor he will presently come up

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: The instructions of the Governor?
children.prevalue: The instructions of the Governor

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Listen to me, I'll try to tell you all in a few words. The Stadtholder has a countryhouse, one league distant from Leyden, properly speaking a kind of large dairy, and my aunt, who was his nurse, has the management of it. As soon as I received your letter, which, alas! I could not read myself, but which your housekeeper read to me, I hastened to my aunt; there I remained until the Prince should come to the dairy; and when he came, I asked him as a favour to allow my father to exchange his post at the prison of the Hague with the jailer of the fortress of Loewestein. The Prince could not have suspected my object; had he known it, he would have refused my request, but as it is he granted it.
children.prevalue: Listen to me I ll try to tell you all in a few words The Stadtholder has a countryhouse one league distant from Leyden properly speaking a kind of large dairy and my aunt who was his nurse has the management of it As soon as I received your letter which alas I could not read myself but which your housekeeper read to me I hastened to my aunt there I remained until the Prince should come to the dairy and when he came I asked him as a favour to allow my father to exchange his post at the prison of the Hague with the jailer of the fortress of Loewestein The Prince could not have suspected my object had he known it he would have refused my request but as it is he granted it

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: And so you are here?
children.prevalue: And so you are here

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: As you see.
children.prevalue: As you see

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: And thus I shall see you every day?
children.prevalue: And thus I shall see you every day

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: As often as I can manage it.
children.prevalue: As often as I can manage it

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Oh, Rosa, my beautiful Rosa, do you love me a little?
children.prevalue: Oh Rosa my beautiful Rosa do you love me a little

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: A little? she said, you make no great pretensions, Mynheer Cornelius.
children.prevalue: A little she said you make no great pretensions Mynheer Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Cornelius tenderly stretched out his hands towards her, but they were only able to touch each other with the tips of their fingers through the wire grating.
children.prevalue: Cornelius tenderly stretched out his hands towards her but they were only able to touch each other with the tips of their fingers through the wire grating

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Here is my father, said she.
children.prevalue: Here is my father said she

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Rosa then abruptly drew back from the door, and ran to meet old Gryphus, who made his appearance at the top of the staircase.
children.prevalue: Rosa then abruptly drew back from the door and ran to meet old Gryphus who made his appearance at the top of the staircase

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Gryphus was followed by the mastiff.
children.prevalue: Gryphus was followed by the mastiff

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The turnkey took the animal round the jail, so that, if needs be, he might recognize the prisoners.
children.prevalue: The turnkey took the animal round the jail so that if needs be he might recognize the prisoners

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Father, said Rosa, here is the famous prison from which Mynheer Grotius escaped. You know Mynheer Grotius?
children.prevalue: Father said Rosa here is the famous prison from which Mynheer Grotius escaped You know Mynheer Grotius

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Oh, yes, that rogue Grotius, a friend of that villain Barneveldt, whom I saw executed when I was a child. Ah! so Grotius; and that's the chamber from which he escaped. Well, I'll answer for it that no one shall escape after him in my time.
children.prevalue: Oh yes that rogue Grotius a friend of that villain Barneveldt whom I saw executed when I was a child Ah so Grotius and that s the chamber from which he escaped Well I ll answer for it that no one shall escape after him in my time

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: And thus opening the door, he began in the dark to talk to the prisoner.
children.prevalue: And thus opening the door he began in the dark to talk to the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The dog, on his part, went up to the prisoner, and, growling, smelled about his legs just as though to ask him what right he had still to be alive, after having left the prison in the company of the Recorder and the executioner.
children.prevalue: The dog on his part went up to the prisoner and growling smelled about his legs just as though to ask him what right he had still to be alive after having left the prison in the company of the Recorder and the executioner

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: But the fair Rosa called him to her side.
children.prevalue: But the fair Rosa called him to her side

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Well, my master, said Gryphus, holding up his lantern to throw a little light around, you see in me your new jailer. I am head turnkey, and have all the cells under my care. I am not vicious, but I'm not to be trifled with, as far as discipline goes.
children.prevalue: Well my master said Gryphus holding up his lantern to throw a little light around you see in me your new jailer I am head turnkey and have all the cells under my care I am not vicious but I m not to be trifled with as far as discipline goes

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: My good Master Gryphus, I know you perfectly well, said the prisoner, approaching within the circle of light cast around by the lantern.
children.prevalue: My good Master Gryphus I know you perfectly well said the prisoner approaching within the circle of light cast around by the lantern

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Halloa! that's you, Mynheer van Baerle, said Gryphus. That's you; well, I declare, it's astonishing how people do meet.
children.prevalue: Halloa that s you Mynheer van Baerle said Gryphus That s you well I declare it s astonishing how people do meet

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Oh, yes; and it's really a great pleasure to me, good Master Gryphus, to see that your arm is doing well, as you are able to hold your lantern with it.
children.prevalue: Oh yes and it s really a great pleasure to me good Master Gryphus to see that your arm is doing well as you are able to hold your lantern with it

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Gryphus knitted his brow. Now, that's just it, he said, people always make blunders in politics. His Highness has granted you your life; I'm sure I should never have done so.
children.prevalue: Gryphus knitted his brow Now that s just it he said people always make blunders in politics His Highness has granted you your life I m sure I should never have done so

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Don't say so, replied Cornelius; why not?
children.prevalue: Don t say so replied Cornelius why not

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Because you are the very man to conspire again. You learned people have dealings with the devil.
children.prevalue: Because you are the very man to conspire again You learned people have dealings with the devil

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Nonsense, Master Gryphus. Are you dissatisfied with the manner in which I have set your arm, or with the price that I asked you? said Cornelius, laughing.
children.prevalue: Nonsense Master Gryphus Are you dissatisfied with the manner in which I have set your arm or with the price that I asked you said Cornelius laughing

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: On the contrary, growled the jailer, you have set it only too well. There is some witchcraft in this. After six weeks, I was able to use it as if nothing had happened, so much so, that the doctor of the Buytenhof, who knows his trade well, wanted to break it again, to set it in the regular way, and promised me that I should have my blessed three months for my money before I should be able to move it.
children.prevalue: On the contrary growled the jailer you have set it only too well There is some witchcraft in this After six weeks I was able to use it as if nothing had happened so much so that the doctor of the Buytenhof who knows his trade well wanted to break it again to set it in the regular way and promised me that I should have my blessed three months for my money before I should be able to move it

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: And you did not want that?
children.prevalue: And you did not want that

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I said, 'Nay, as long as I can make the sign of the cross with that arm' (Gryphus was a Roman Catholic), 'I laugh at the devil.'
children.prevalue: I said Nay as long as I can make the sign of the cross with that arm Gryphus was a Roman Catholic I laugh at the devil

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: But if you laugh at the devil, Master Gryphus, you ought with so much more reason to laugh at learned people.
children.prevalue: But if you laugh at the devil Master Gryphus you ought with so much more reason to laugh at learned people

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Ah, learned people, learned people! Why, I would rather have to guard ten soldiers than one scholar. The soldiers smoke, guzzle, and get drunk; they are gentle as lambs if you only give them brandy or Moselle, but scholars, and drink, smoke, and fuddleah, yes, that's altogether different. They keep sober, spend nothing, and have their heads always clear to make conspiracies. But I tell you, at the very outset, it won't be such an easy matter for you to conspire. First of all, you will have no books, no paper, and no conjuring book. It's books that helped Mynheer Grotius to get off.
children.prevalue: Ah learned people learned people Why I would rather have to guard ten soldiers than one scholar The soldiers smoke guzzle and get drunk they are gentle as lambs if you only give them brandy or Moselle but scholars and drink smoke and fuddleah yes that s altogether different They keep sober spend nothing and have their heads always clear to make conspiracies But I tell you at the very outset it won t be such an easy matter for you to conspire First of all you will have no books no paper and no conjuring book It s books that helped Mynheer Grotius to get off

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I assure you, Master Gryphus, replied Van Baerle, that if I have entertained the idea of escaping, I most decidedly have it no longer.
children.prevalue: I assure you Master Gryphus replied Van Baerle that if I have entertained the idea of escaping I most decidedly have it no longer

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Well, well, said Gryphus, just look sharp: that's what I shall do also. But, for all that, I say his Highness has made a great mistake.
children.prevalue: Well well said Gryphus just look sharp that s what I shall do also But for all that I say his Highness has made a great mistake

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Not to have cut off my head? thank you, Master Gryphus.
children.prevalue: Not to have cut off my head thank you Master Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Just so, look whether the Mynheer de Witt don't keep very quiet now.
children.prevalue: Just so look whether the Mynheer de Witt don t keep very quiet now

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: That's very shocking what you say now, Master Gryphus, cried Van Baerle, turning away his head to conceal his disgust. You forget that one of those unfortunate gentlemen was my friend, and the other my second father.
children.prevalue: That s very shocking what you say now Master Gryphus cried Van Baerle turning away his head to conceal his disgust You forget that one of those unfortunate gentlemen was my friend and the other my second father

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Yes, but I also remember that the one, as well as the other, was a conspirator. And, moreover, I am speaking from Christian charity.
children.prevalue: Yes but I also remember that the one as well as the other was a conspirator And moreover I am speaking from Christian charity

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Oh, indeed! explain that a little to me, my good Master Gryphus. I do not quite understand it.
children.prevalue: Oh indeed explain that a little to me my good Master Gryphus I do not quite understand it

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Well, then, if you had remained on the block of Master Harbruck
children.prevalue: Well then if you had remained on the block of Master Harbruck

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: What?
children.prevalue: What

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: You would not suffer any longer; whereas, I will not disguise it from you, I shall lead you a sad life of it.
children.prevalue: You would not suffer any longer whereas I will not disguise it from you I shall lead you a sad life of it

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Thank you for the promise, Master Gryphus.
children.prevalue: Thank you for the promise Master Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: And whilst the prisoner smiled ironically at the old jailer, Rosa, from the outside, answered by a bright smile, which carried sweet consolation to the heart of Van Baerle.
children.prevalue: And whilst the prisoner smiled ironically at the old jailer Rosa from the outside answered by a bright smile which carried sweet consolation to the heart of Van Baerle

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Gryphus stepped towards the window.
children.prevalue: Gryphus stepped towards the window

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: It was still light enough to see, although indistinctly, through the gray haze of the evening, the vast expanse of the horizon.
children.prevalue: It was still light enough to see although indistinctly through the gray haze of the evening the vast expanse of the horizon

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: What view has one from here? asked Gryphus.
children.prevalue: What view has one from here asked Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Why, a very fine and pleasant one, said Cornelius, looking at Rosa.
children.prevalue: Why a very fine and pleasant one said Cornelius looking at Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Yes, yes, too much of a view, too much.
children.prevalue: Yes yes too much of a view too much

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: And at this moment the two pigeons, scared by the sight and especially by the voice of the stranger, left their nest, and disappeared, quite frightened in the evening mist.
children.prevalue: And at this moment the two pigeons scared by the sight and especially by the voice of the stranger left their nest and disappeared quite frightened in the evening mist

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Halloa! what's this? cried Gryphus.
children.prevalue: Halloa what s this cried Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: My pigeons, answered Cornelius.
children.prevalue: My pigeons answered Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Your pigeons, cried the jailer, your pigeons! has a prisoner anything of his own?
children.prevalue: Your pigeons cried the jailer your pigeons has a prisoner anything of his own

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Why, then, said Cornelius, the pigeons which a merciful Father in Heaven has lent to me.
children.prevalue: Why then said Cornelius the pigeons which a merciful Father in Heaven has lent to me

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: So, here we have a breach of the rules already, replied Gryphus. Pigeons! ah, young man, young man! I'll tell you one thing, that before tomorrow is over, your pigeons will boil in my pot.
children.prevalue: So here we have a breach of the rules already replied Gryphus Pigeons ah young man young man I ll tell you one thing that before tomorrow is over your pigeons will boil in my pot

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: First of all you should catch them, Master Gryphus. You won't allow these pigeons to be mine! Well, I vow they are even less yours than mine.
children.prevalue: First of all you should catch them Master Gryphus You won t allow these pigeons to be mine Well I vow they are even less yours than mine

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Omittance is no acquittance, growled the jailer, and I shall certainly wring their necks before twentyfour hours are over: you may be sure of that.
children.prevalue: Omittance is no acquittance growled the jailer and I shall certainly wring their necks before twentyfour hours are over you may be sure of that

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Whilst giving utterance to this illnatured promise, Gryphus put his head out of the window to examine the nest. This gave Van Baerle time to run to the door, and squeeze the hand of Rosa, who whispered to him,
children.prevalue: Whilst giving utterance to this illnatured promise Gryphus put his head out of the window to examine the nest This gave Van Baerle time to run to the door and squeeze the hand of Rosa who whispered to him

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: At nine o'clock this evening.
children.prevalue: At nine o clock this evening

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Gryphus, quite taken up with the desire of catching the pigeons next day, as he had promised he would do, saw and heard nothing of this short interlude; and, after having closed the window, he took the arm of his daughter, left the cell, turned the key twice, drew the bolts, and went off to make the same kind promise to the other prisoners.
children.prevalue: Gryphus quite taken up with the desire of catching the pigeons next day as he had promised he would do saw and heard nothing of this short interlude and after having closed the window he took the arm of his daughter left the cell turned the key twice drew the bolts and went off to make the same kind promise to the other prisoners

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: He had scarcely withdrawn, when Cornelius went to the door to listen to the sound of his footsteps, and, as soon as they had died away, he ran to the window, and completely demolished the nest of the pigeons.
children.prevalue: He had scarcely withdrawn when Cornelius went to the door to listen to the sound of his footsteps and as soon as they had died away he ran to the window and completely demolished the nest of the pigeons

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Rather than expose them to the tender mercies of his bullying jailer, he drove away for ever those gentle messengers to whom he owed the happiness of having seen Rosa again.
children.prevalue: Rather than expose them to the tender mercies of his bullying jailer he drove away for ever those gentle messengers to whom he owed the happiness of having seen Rosa again

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: This visit of the jailer, his brutal threats, and the gloomy prospect of the harshness with which, as he had before experienced, Gryphus watched his prisoners,all this was unable to extinguish in Cornelius the sweet thoughts, and especially the sweet hope, which the presence of Rosa had reawakened in his heart.
children.prevalue: This visit of the jailer his brutal threats and the gloomy prospect of the harshness with which as he had before experienced Gryphus watched his prisoners all this was unable to extinguish in Cornelius the sweet thoughts and especially the sweet hope which the presence of Rosa had reawakened in his heart

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: He waited eagerly to hear the clock of the tower of Loewestein strike nine.
children.prevalue: He waited eagerly to hear the clock of the tower of Loewestein strike nine

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: The last chime was still vibrating through the air, when Cornelius heard on the staircase the light step and the rustle of the flowing dress of the fair Frisian maid, and soon after a light appeared at the little grated window in the door, on which the prisoner fixed his earnest gaze.
children.prevalue: The last chime was still vibrating through the air when Cornelius heard on the staircase the light step and the rustle of the flowing dress of the fair Frisian maid and soon after a light appeared at the little grated window in the door on which the prisoner fixed his earnest gaze

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: The shutter opened on the outside.
children.prevalue: The shutter opened on the outside

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Here I am, said Rosa, out of breath from running up the stairs, here I am.
children.prevalue: Here I am said Rosa out of breath from running up the stairs here I am

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Oh, my good Rosa.
children.prevalue: Oh my good Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: You are then glad to see me?
children.prevalue: You are then glad to see me

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Can you ask? But how did you contrive to get here? tell me.
children.prevalue: Can you ask But how did you contrive to get here tell me

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Now listen to me. My father falls asleep every evening almost immediately after his supper; I then make him lie down, a little stupefied with his gin. Don't say anything about it, because, thanks to this nap, I shall be able to come every evening and chat for an hour with you.
children.prevalue: Now listen to me My father falls asleep every evening almost immediately after his supper I then make him lie down a little stupefied with his gin Don t say anything about it because thanks to this nap I shall be able to come every evening and chat for an hour with you

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Oh, I thank you, Rosa, dear Rosa.
children.prevalue: Oh I thank you Rosa dear Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Saying these words, Cornelius put his face so near the little window that Rosa withdrew hers.
children.prevalue: Saying these words Cornelius put his face so near the little window that Rosa withdrew hers

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I have brought back to you your bulbs.
children.prevalue: I have brought back to you your bulbs

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Cornelius's heart leaped with joy. He had not yet dared to ask Rosa what she had done with the precious treasure which he had intrusted to her.
children.prevalue: Cornelius s heart leaped with joy He had not yet dared to ask Rosa what she had done with the precious treasure which he had intrusted to her

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Oh, you have preserved them, then?
children.prevalue: Oh you have preserved them then

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Did you not give them to me as a thing which was dear to you?
children.prevalue: Did you not give them to me as a thing which was dear to you

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Yes, but as I have given them to you, it seems to me that they belong to you.
children.prevalue: Yes but as I have given them to you it seems to me that they belong to you

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: They would have belonged to me after your death, but, fortunately, you are alive now. Oh how I blessed his Highness in my heart! If God grants to him all the happiness that I have wished him, certainly Prince William will be the happiest man on earth. When I looked at the Bible of your godfather Cornelius, I was resolved to bring back to you your bulbs, only I did not know how to accomplish it. I had, however, already formed the plan of going to the Stadtholder, to ask from him for my father the appointment of jailer of Loewestein, when your housekeeper brought me your letter. Oh, how we wept together! But your letter only confirmed me the more in my resolution. I then left for Leyden, and the rest you know.
children.prevalue: They would have belonged to me after your death but fortunately you are alive now Oh how I blessed his Highness in my heart If God grants to him all the happiness that I have wished him certainly Prince William will be the happiest man on earth When I looked at the Bible of your godfather Cornelius I was resolved to bring back to you your bulbs only I did not know how to accomplish it I had however already formed the plan of going to the Stadtholder to ask from him for my father the appointment of jailer of Loewestein when your housekeeper brought me your letter Oh how we wept together But your letter only confirmed me the more in my resolution I then left for Leyden and the rest you know

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: What, my dear Rosa, you thought, even before receiving my letter, of coming to meet me again?
children.prevalue: What my dear Rosa you thought even before receiving my letter of coming to meet me again

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: If I thought of it, said Rosa, allowing her love to get the better of her bashfulness, I thought of nothing else.
children.prevalue: If I thought of it said Rosa allowing her love to get the better of her bashfulness I thought of nothing else

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: And, saying these words, Rosa looked so exceedingly pretty, that for the second time Cornelius placed his forehead and lips against the wire grating; of course, we must presume with the laudable desire to thank the young lady.
children.prevalue: And saying these words Rosa looked so exceedingly pretty that for the second time Cornelius placed his forehead and lips against the wire grating of course we must presume with the laudable desire to thank the young lady

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Rosa, however, drew back as before.
children.prevalue: Rosa however drew back as before

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: In truth, she said, with that coquetry which somehow or other is in the heart of every young girl, I have often been sorry that I am not able to read, but never so much so as when your housekeeper brought me your letter. I kept the paper in my hands, which spoke to other people, and which was dumb to poor stupid me.
children.prevalue: In truth she said with that coquetry which somehow or other is in the heart of every young girl I have often been sorry that I am not able to read but never so much so as when your housekeeper brought me your letter I kept the paper in my hands which spoke to other people and which was dumb to poor stupid me

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: So you have often regretted not being able to read, said Cornelius. I should just like to know on what occasions.
children.prevalue: So you have often regretted not being able to read said Cornelius I should just like to know on what occasions

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Troth, she said, laughing, to read all the letters which were written to me.
children.prevalue: Troth she said laughing to read all the letters which were written to me

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Oh, you received letters, Rosa?
children.prevalue: Oh you received letters Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: By hundreds.
children.prevalue: By hundreds

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: But who wrote to you?
children.prevalue: But who wrote to you

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Who! why, in the first place, all the students who passed over the Buytenhof, all the officers who went to parade, all the clerks, and even the merchants who saw me at my little window.
children.prevalue: Who why in the first place all the students who passed over the Buytenhof all the officers who went to parade all the clerks and even the merchants who saw me at my little window

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: And what did you do with all these notes, my dear Rosa?
children.prevalue: And what did you do with all these notes my dear Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Formerly, she answered, I got some friend to read them to me, which was capital fun, but since a certain timewell, what use is it to attend to all this nonsense?since a certain time I have burnt them.
children.prevalue: Formerly she answered I got some friend to read them to me which was capital fun but since a certain timewell what use is it to attend to all this nonsense since a certain time I have burnt them

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Since a certain time! exclaimed Cornelius, with a look beaming with love and joy.
children.prevalue: Since a certain time exclaimed Cornelius with a look beaming with love and joy

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Rosa cast down her eyes, blushing. In her sweet confusion, she did not observe the lips of Cornelius, which, alas! only met the cold wiregrating. Yet, in spite of this obstacle, they communicated to the lips of the young girl the glowing breath of the most tender kiss.
children.prevalue: Rosa cast down her eyes blushing In her sweet confusion she did not observe the lips of Cornelius which alas only met the cold wiregrating Yet in spite of this obstacle they communicated to the lips of the young girl the glowing breath of the most tender kiss

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: At this sudden outburst of tenderness, Rosa grew very pale,perhaps paler than she had been on the day of the execution. She uttered a plaintive sob, closed her fine eyes, and fled, trying in vain to still the beating of her heart.
children.prevalue: At this sudden outburst of tenderness Rosa grew very pale perhaps paler than she had been on the day of the execution She uttered a plaintive sob closed her fine eyes and fled trying in vain to still the beating of her heart

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: And thus Cornelius was again alone.
children.prevalue: And thus Cornelius was again alone

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Rosa had fled so precipitately, that she completely forgot to return to Cornelius the three bulbs of the Black Tulip.
children.prevalue: Rosa had fled so precipitately that she completely forgot to return to Cornelius the three bulbs of the Black Tulip

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The worthy Master Gryphus, as the reader may have seen, was far from sharing the kindly feeling of his daughter for the godson of Cornelius de Witt.
children.prevalue: The worthy Master Gryphus as the reader may have seen was far from sharing the kindly feeling of his daughter for the godson of Cornelius de Witt

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: There being only five prisoners at Loewestein, the post of turnkey was not a very onerous one, but rather a sort of sinecure, given after a long period of service.
children.prevalue: There being only five prisoners at Loewestein the post of turnkey was not a very onerous one but rather a sort of sinecure given after a long period of service

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: But the worthy jailer, in his zeal, had magnified with all the power of his imagination the importance of his office. To him Cornelius had swelled to the gigantic proportions of a criminal of the first order. He looked upon him, therefore, as the most dangerous of all his prisoners. He watched all his steps, and always spoke to him with an angry countenance; punishing him for what he called his dreadful rebellion against such a clement prince as the Stadtholder.
children.prevalue: But the worthy jailer in his zeal had magnified with all the power of his imagination the importance of his office To him Cornelius had swelled to the gigantic proportions of a criminal of the first order He looked upon him therefore as the most dangerous of all his prisoners He watched all his steps and always spoke to him with an angry countenance punishing him for what he called his dreadful rebellion against such a clement prince as the Stadtholder

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Three times a day he entered Van Baerle's cell, expecting to find him trespassing; but Cornelius had ceased to correspond, since his correspondent was at hand. It is even probable that, if Cornelius had obtained his full liberty, with permission to go wherever he liked, the prison, with Rosa and his bulbs, would have appeared to him preferable to any other habitation in the world without Rosa and his bulbs.
children.prevalue: Three times a day he entered Van Baerle s cell expecting to find him trespassing but Cornelius had ceased to correspond since his correspondent was at hand It is even probable that if Cornelius had obtained his full liberty with permission to go wherever he liked the prison with Rosa and his bulbs would have appeared to him preferable to any other habitation in the world without Rosa and his bulbs

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Rosa, in fact, had promised to come and see him every evening, and from the first evening she had kept her word.
children.prevalue: Rosa in fact had promised to come and see him every evening and from the first evening she had kept her word

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: On the following evening she went up as before, with the same mysteriousness and the same precaution. Only she had this time resolved within herself not to approach too near the grating. In order, however, to engage Van Baerle in a conversation from the very first which would seriously occupy his attention, she tendered to him through the grating the three bulbs, which were still wrapped up in the same paper.
children.prevalue: On the following evening she went up as before with the same mysteriousness and the same precaution Only she had this time resolved within herself not to approach too near the grating In order however to engage Van Baerle in a conversation from the very first which would seriously occupy his attention she tendered to him through the grating the three bulbs which were still wrapped up in the same paper

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: But to the great astonishment of Rosa, Van Baerle pushed back her white hand with the tips of his fingers.
children.prevalue: But to the great astonishment of Rosa Van Baerle pushed back her white hand with the tips of his fingers

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The young man had been considering about the matter.
children.prevalue: The young man had been considering about the matter

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Listen to me, he said. I think we should risk too much by embarking our whole fortune in one ship. Only think, my dear Rosa, that the question is to carry out an enterprise which until now has been considered impossible, namely, that of making the great black tulip flower. Let us, therefore, take every possible precaution, so that in case of a failure we may not have anything to reproach ourselves with. I will now tell you the way I have traced out for us.
children.prevalue: Listen to me he said I think we should risk too much by embarking our whole fortune in one ship Only think my dear Rosa that the question is to carry out an enterprise which until now has been considered impossible namely that of making the great black tulip flower Let us therefore take every possible precaution so that in case of a failure we may not have anything to reproach ourselves with I will now tell you the way I have traced out for us

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Rosa was all attention to what he would say, much more on account of the importance which the unfortunate tulipfancier attached to it, than that she felt interested in the matter herself.
children.prevalue: Rosa was all attention to what he would say much more on account of the importance which the unfortunate tulipfancier attached to it than that she felt interested in the matter herself

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I will explain to you, Rosa, he said. I dare say you have in this fortress a small garden, or some courtyard, or, if not that, at least some terrace.
children.prevalue: I will explain to you Rosa he said I dare say you have in this fortress a small garden or some courtyard or if not that at least some terrace

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: We have a very fine garden, said Rosa, it runs along the edge of the Waal, and is full of fine old trees.
children.prevalue: We have a very fine garden said Rosa it runs along the edge of the Waal and is full of fine old trees

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Could you bring me some soil from the garden, that I may judge?
children.prevalue: Could you bring me some soil from the garden that I may judge

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I will do so tomorrow.
children.prevalue: I will do so tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Take some from a sunny spot, and some from a shady, so that I may judge of its properties in a dry and in a moist state.
children.prevalue: Take some from a sunny spot and some from a shady so that I may judge of its properties in a dry and in a moist state

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Be assured I shall.
children.prevalue: Be assured I shall

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: After having chosen the soil, and, if it be necessary, modified it, we will divide our three bulbs; you will take one and plant it, on the day that I will tell you, in the soil chosen by me. It is sure to flower, if you tend it according to my directions.
children.prevalue: After having chosen the soil and if it be necessary modified it we will divide our three bulbs you will take one and plant it on the day that I will tell you in the soil chosen by me It is sure to flower if you tend it according to my directions

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I will not lose sight of it for a minute.
children.prevalue: I will not lose sight of it for a minute

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: You will give me another, which I will try to grow here in my cell, and which will help me to beguile those long weary hours when I cannot see you. I confess to you I have very little hope for the latter one, and I look beforehand on this unfortunate bulb as sacrificed to my selfishness. However, the sun sometimes visits me. I will, besides, try to convert everything into an artificial help, even the heat and the ashes of my pipe, and lastly, we, or rather you, will keep in reserve the third sucker as our last resource, in case our first two experiments should prove a failure. In this manner, my dear Rosa, it is impossible that we should not succeed in gaining the hundred thousand guilders for your marriage portion; and how dearly shall we enjoy that supreme happiness of seeing our work brought to a successful issue!
children.prevalue: You will give me another which I will try to grow here in my cell and which will help me to beguile those long weary hours when I cannot see you I confess to you I have very little hope for the latter one and I look beforehand on this unfortunate bulb as sacrificed to my selfishness However the sun sometimes visits me I will besides try to convert everything into an artificial help even the heat and the ashes of my pipe and lastly we or rather you will keep in reserve the third sucker as our last resource in case our first two experiments should prove a failure In this manner my dear Rosa it is impossible that we should not succeed in gaining the hundred thousand guilders for your marriage portion and how dearly shall we enjoy that supreme happiness of seeing our work brought to a successful issue

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: I know it all now, said Rosa. I will bring you the soil tomorrow, and you will choose it for your bulb and for mine. As to that in which yours is to grow, I shall have several journeys to convey it to you, as I cannot bring much at a time.
children.prevalue: I know it all now said Rosa I will bring you the soil tomorrow and you will choose it for your bulb and for mine As to that in which yours is to grow I shall have several journeys to convey it to you as I cannot bring much at a time

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: There is no hurry for it, dear Rosa; our tulips need not be put into the ground for a month at least. So you see we have plenty of time before us. Only I hope that, in planting your bulb, you will strictly follow all my instructions.
children.prevalue: There is no hurry for it dear Rosa our tulips need not be put into the ground for a month at least So you see we have plenty of time before us Only I hope that in planting your bulb you will strictly follow all my instructions

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I promise you I will.
children.prevalue: I promise you I will

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: And when you have once planted it, you will communicate to me all the circumstances which may interest our nursling; such as change of weather, footprints on the walks, or footprints in the borders. You will listen at night whether our garden is not resorted to by cats. A couple of those untoward animals laid waste two of my borders at Dort.
children.prevalue: And when you have once planted it you will communicate to me all the circumstances which may interest our nursling such as change of weather footprints on the walks or footprints in the borders You will listen at night whether our garden is not resorted to by cats A couple of those untoward animals laid waste two of my borders at Dort

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: I will listen.
children.prevalue: I will listen

children.name: Paragraph_25
