children.value: On moonlight nights have you ever looked at your garden, my dear child?
children.prevalue: On moonlight nights have you ever looked at your garden my dear child

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The window of my sleepingroom overlooks it.
children.prevalue: The window of my sleepingroom overlooks it

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Well, on moonlight nights you will observe whether any rats come out from the holes in the wall. The rats are most mischievous by their gnawing everything; and I have heard unfortunate tulipgrowers complain most bitterly of Noah for having put a couple of rats in the ark.
children.prevalue: Well on moonlight nights you will observe whether any rats come out from the holes in the wall The rats are most mischievous by their gnawing everything and I have heard unfortunate tulipgrowers complain most bitterly of Noah for having put a couple of rats in the ark

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I will observe, and if there are cats or rats
children.prevalue: I will observe and if there are cats or rats

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: You will apprise me of it,that's right. And, moreover, Van Baerle, having become mistrustful in his captivity, continued, there is an animal much more to be feared than even the cat or the rat.
children.prevalue: You will apprise me of it that s right And moreover Van Baerle having become mistrustful in his captivity continued there is an animal much more to be feared than even the cat or the rat

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: What animal?
children.prevalue: What animal

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Man. You comprehend, my dear Rosa, a man may steal a guilder, and risk the prison for such a trifle, and, consequently, it is much more likely that some one might steal a hundred thousand guilders.
children.prevalue: Man You comprehend my dear Rosa a man may steal a guilder and risk the prison for such a trifle and consequently it is much more likely that some one might steal a hundred thousand guilders

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: No one ever enters the garden but myself.
children.prevalue: No one ever enters the garden but myself

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Thank you, thank you, my dear Rosa. All the joy of my life has still to come from you.
children.prevalue: Thank you thank you my dear Rosa All the joy of my life has still to come from you

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: And as the lips of Van Baerle approached the grating with the same ardor as the day before, and as, moreover, the hour for retiring had struck, Rosa drew back her head, and stretched out her hand.
children.prevalue: And as the lips of Van Baerle approached the grating with the same ardor as the day before and as moreover the hour for retiring had struck Rosa drew back her head and stretched out her hand

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: In this pretty little hand, of which the coquettish damsel was particularly proud, was the bulb.
children.prevalue: In this pretty little hand of which the coquettish damsel was particularly proud was the bulb

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Cornelius kissed most tenderly the tips of her fingers. Did he do so because the hand kept one of the bulbs of the great black tulip, or because this hand was Rosa's? We shall leave this point to the decision of wiser heads than ours.
children.prevalue: Cornelius kissed most tenderly the tips of her fingers Did he do so because the hand kept one of the bulbs of the great black tulip or because this hand was Rosa s We shall leave this point to the decision of wiser heads than ours

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Rosa withdrew with the other two suckers, pressing them to her heart.
children.prevalue: Rosa withdrew with the other two suckers pressing them to her heart

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Did she press them to her heart because they were the bulbs of the great black tulip, or because she had them from Cornelius?
children.prevalue: Did she press them to her heart because they were the bulbs of the great black tulip or because she had them from Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: This point, we believe, might be more readily decided than the other.
children.prevalue: This point we believe might be more readily decided than the other

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: However that may have been, from that moment life became sweet, and again full of interest to the prisoner.
children.prevalue: However that may have been from that moment life became sweet and again full of interest to the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Rosa, as we have seen, had returned to him one of the suckers.
children.prevalue: Rosa as we have seen had returned to him one of the suckers

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Every evening she brought to him, handful by handful, a quantity of soil from that part of the garden which he had found to be the best, and which, indeed, was excellent.
children.prevalue: Every evening she brought to him handful by handful a quantity of soil from that part of the garden which he had found to be the best and which indeed was excellent

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: A large jug, which Cornelius had skilfully broken, did service as a flowerpot. He half filled it, and mixed the earth of the garden with a small portion of dried river mud, a mixture which formed an excellent soil.
children.prevalue: A large jug which Cornelius had skilfully broken did service as a flowerpot He half filled it and mixed the earth of the garden with a small portion of dried river mud a mixture which formed an excellent soil

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Then, at the beginning of April, he planted his first sucker in that jug.
children.prevalue: Then at the beginning of April he planted his first sucker in that jug

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Not a day passed on which Rosa did not come to have her chat with Cornelius.
children.prevalue: Not a day passed on which Rosa did not come to have her chat with Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: The tulips, concerning whose cultivation Rosa was taught all the mysteries of the art, formed the principal topic of the conversation; but, interesting as the subject was, people cannot always talk about tulips.
children.prevalue: The tulips concerning whose cultivation Rosa was taught all the mysteries of the art formed the principal topic of the conversation but interesting as the subject was people cannot always talk about tulips

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: They therefore began to chat also about other things, and the tulipfancier found out to his great astonishment what a vast range of subjects a conversation may comprise.
children.prevalue: They therefore began to chat also about other things and the tulipfancier found out to his great astonishment what a vast range of subjects a conversation may comprise

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Only Rosa had made it a habit to keep her pretty face invariably six inches distant from the grating, having perhaps become distrustful of herself.
children.prevalue: Only Rosa had made it a habit to keep her pretty face invariably six inches distant from the grating having perhaps become distrustful of herself

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: There was one thing especially which gave Cornelius almost as much anxiety as his bulbsa subject to which he always returnedthe dependence of Rosa on her father.
children.prevalue: There was one thing especially which gave Cornelius almost as much anxiety as his bulbsa subject to which he always returnedthe dependence of Rosa on her father

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Indeed, Van Baerle's happiness depended on the whim of this man. He might one day find Loewestein dull, or the air of the place unhealthy, or the gin bad, and leave the fortress, and take his daughter with him, when Cornelius and Rosa would again be separated.
children.prevalue: Indeed Van Baerle s happiness depended on the whim of this man He might one day find Loewestein dull or the air of the place unhealthy or the gin bad and leave the fortress and take his daughter with him when Cornelius and Rosa would again be separated

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Of what use would the carrier pigeons then be? said Cornelius to Rosa, as you, my dear girl, would not be able to read what I should write to you, nor to write to me your thoughts in return.
children.prevalue: Of what use would the carrier pigeons then be said Cornelius to Rosa as you my dear girl would not be able to read what I should write to you nor to write to me your thoughts in return

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Well, answered Rosa, who in her heart was as much afraid of a separation as Cornelius himself, we have one hour every evening, let us make good use of it.
children.prevalue: Well answered Rosa who in her heart was as much afraid of a separation as Cornelius himself we have one hour every evening let us make good use of it

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: I don't think we make such a bad use of it as it is.
children.prevalue: I don t think we make such a bad use of it as it is

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Let us employ it even better, said Rosa, smiling. Teach me to read and write. I shall make the best of your lessons, believe me; and, in this way, we shall never be separated any more, except by our own will.
children.prevalue: Let us employ it even better said Rosa smiling Teach me to read and write I shall make the best of your lessons believe me and in this way we shall never be separated any more except by our own will

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Oh, then, we have an eternity before us, said Cornelius.
children.prevalue: Oh then we have an eternity before us said Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Rosa smiled, and quietly shrugged her shoulders.
children.prevalue: Rosa smiled and quietly shrugged her shoulders

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Will you remain for ever in prison? she said, and after having granted you your life, will not his Highness also grant you your liberty? And will you not then recover your fortune, and be a rich man, and then, when you are driving in your own coach, riding your own horse, will you still look at poor Rosa, the daughter of a jailer, scarcely better than a hangman?
children.prevalue: Will you remain for ever in prison she said and after having granted you your life will not his Highness also grant you your liberty And will you not then recover your fortune and be a rich man and then when you are driving in your own coach riding your own horse will you still look at poor Rosa the daughter of a jailer scarcely better than a hangman

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Cornelius tried to contradict her, and certainly he would have done so with all his heart, and with all the sincerity of a soul full of love.
children.prevalue: Cornelius tried to contradict her and certainly he would have done so with all his heart and with all the sincerity of a soul full of love

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: She, however, smilingly interrupted him, saying, How is your tulip going on?
children.prevalue: She however smilingly interrupted him saying How is your tulip going on

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: To speak to Cornelius of his tulip was an expedient resorted to by her to make him forget everything, even Rosa herself.
children.prevalue: To speak to Cornelius of his tulip was an expedient resorted to by her to make him forget everything even Rosa herself

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Very well, indeed, he said, the coat is growing black, the sprouting has commenced, the veins of the bulb are swelling, in eight days hence, and perhaps sooner, we may distinguish the first buds of the leaves protruding. And yours Rosa?
children.prevalue: Very well indeed he said the coat is growing black the sprouting has commenced the veins of the bulb are swelling in eight days hence and perhaps sooner we may distinguish the first buds of the leaves protruding And yours Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Oh, I have done things on a large scale, and according to your directions.
children.prevalue: Oh I have done things on a large scale and according to your directions

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Now, let me hear, Rosa, what you have done, said Cornelius, with as tender an anxiety as he had lately shown to herself.
children.prevalue: Now let me hear Rosa what you have done said Cornelius with as tender an anxiety as he had lately shown to herself

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Well, she said, smiling, for in her own heart she could not help studying this double love of the prisoner for herself and for the black tulip, I have done things on a large scale; I have prepared a bed as you described it to me, on a clear spot, far from trees and walls, in a soil slightly mixed with sand, rather moist than dry without a fragment of stone or pebble.
children.prevalue: Well she said smiling for in her own heart she could not help studying this double love of the prisoner for herself and for the black tulip I have done things on a large scale I have prepared a bed as you described it to me on a clear spot far from trees and walls in a soil slightly mixed with sand rather moist than dry without a fragment of stone or pebble

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Well done, Rosa, well done.
children.prevalue: Well done Rosa well done

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: I am now only waiting for your further orders to put in the bulb, you know that I must be behindhand with you, as I have in my favour all the chances of good air, of the sun, and abundance of moisture.
children.prevalue: I am now only waiting for your further orders to put in the bulb you know that I must be behindhand with you as I have in my favour all the chances of good air of the sun and abundance of moisture

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: All true, all true, exclaimed Cornelius, clapping his hands with joy, you are a good pupil, Rosa, and you are sure to gain your hundred thousand guilders.
children.prevalue: All true all true exclaimed Cornelius clapping his hands with joy you are a good pupil Rosa and you are sure to gain your hundred thousand guilders

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Don't forget, said Rosa, smiling, that your pupil, as you call me, has still other things to learn besides the cultivation of tulips.
children.prevalue: Don t forget said Rosa smiling that your pupil as you call me has still other things to learn besides the cultivation of tulips

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Yes, yes, and I am as anxious as you are, Rosa, that you should learn to read.
children.prevalue: Yes yes and I am as anxious as you are Rosa that you should learn to read

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: When shall we begin?
children.prevalue: When shall we begin

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: At once.
children.prevalue: At once

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: No, tomorrow.
children.prevalue: No tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Why tomorrow?
children.prevalue: Why tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Because today our hour is expired, and I must leave you.
children.prevalue: Because today our hour is expired and I must leave you

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Already? But what shall we read?
children.prevalue: Already But what shall we read

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Oh, said Rosa, I have a book,a book which I hope will bring us luck.
children.prevalue: Oh said Rosa I have a book a book which I hope will bring us luck

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Tomorrow, then.
children.prevalue: Tomorrow then

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Yes, tomorrow.
children.prevalue: Yes tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: On the following evening Rosa returned with the Bible of Cornelius de Witt.
children.prevalue: On the following evening Rosa returned with the Bible of Cornelius de Witt

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: On the following evening, as we have said, Rosa returned with the Bible of Cornelius de Witt.
children.prevalue: On the following evening as we have said Rosa returned with the Bible of Cornelius de Witt

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Then began between the master and the pupil one of those charming scenes which are the delight of the novelist who has to describe them.
children.prevalue: Then began between the master and the pupil one of those charming scenes which are the delight of the novelist who has to describe them

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The grated window, the only opening through which the two lovers were able to communicate, was too high for conveniently reading a book, although it had been quite convenient for them to read each other's faces.
children.prevalue: The grated window the only opening through which the two lovers were able to communicate was too high for conveniently reading a book although it had been quite convenient for them to read each other s faces

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Rosa therefore had to press the open book against the grating edgewise, holding above it in her right hand the lamp, but Cornelius hit upon the lucky idea of fixing it to the bars, so as to afford her a little rest. Rosa was then enabled to follow with her finger the letters and syllables, which she was to spell for Cornelius, who with a straw pointed out the letters to his attentive pupil through the holes of the grating.
children.prevalue: Rosa therefore had to press the open book against the grating edgewise holding above it in her right hand the lamp but Cornelius hit upon the lucky idea of fixing it to the bars so as to afford her a little rest Rosa was then enabled to follow with her finger the letters and syllables which she was to spell for Cornelius who with a straw pointed out the letters to his attentive pupil through the holes of the grating

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The light of the lamp illuminated the rich complexion of Rosa, her blue liquid eyes, and her golden hair under her headdress of gold brocade, with her fingers held up, and showing in the blood, as it flowed downwards in the veins that pale pink hue which shines before the light owing to the living transparency of the flesh tint.
children.prevalue: The light of the lamp illuminated the rich complexion of Rosa her blue liquid eyes and her golden hair under her headdress of gold brocade with her fingers held up and showing in the blood as it flowed downwards in the veins that pale pink hue which shines before the light owing to the living transparency of the flesh tint

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Rosa's intellect rapidly developed itself under the animating influence of Cornelius, and when the difficulties seemed too arduous, the sympathy of two loving hearts seemed to smooth them away.
children.prevalue: Rosa s intellect rapidly developed itself under the animating influence of Cornelius and when the difficulties seemed too arduous the sympathy of two loving hearts seemed to smooth them away

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: And Rosa, after having returned to her room, repeated in her solitude the reading lessons, and at the same time recalled all the delight which she had felt whilst receiving them.
children.prevalue: And Rosa after having returned to her room repeated in her solitude the reading lessons and at the same time recalled all the delight which she had felt whilst receiving them

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: One evening she came half an hour later than usual. This was too extraordinary an instance not to call forth at once Cornelius's inquiries after its cause.
children.prevalue: One evening she came half an hour later than usual This was too extraordinary an instance not to call forth at once Cornelius s inquiries after its cause

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Oh! do not be angry with me, she said, it is not my fault. My father has renewed an acquaintance with an old crony who used to visit him at the Hague, and to ask him to let him see the prison. He is a good sort of fellow, fond of his bottle, tells funny stories, and moreover is very free with his money, so as always to be ready to stand a treat.
children.prevalue: Oh do not be angry with me she said it is not my fault My father has renewed an acquaintance with an old crony who used to visit him at the Hague and to ask him to let him see the prison He is a good sort of fellow fond of his bottle tells funny stories and moreover is very free with his money so as always to be ready to stand a treat

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: You don't know anything further of him? asked Cornelius, surprised.
children.prevalue: You don t know anything further of him asked Cornelius surprised

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: No, she answered; it's only for about a fortnight that my father has taken such a fancy to this friend who is so assiduous in visiting him.
children.prevalue: No she answered it s only for about a fortnight that my father has taken such a fancy to this friend who is so assiduous in visiting him

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Ah, so, said Cornelius, shaking his head uneasily as every new incident seemed to him to forebode some catastrophe; very likely some spy, one of those who are sent into jails to watch both prisoners and their keepers.
children.prevalue: Ah so said Cornelius shaking his head uneasily as every new incident seemed to him to forebode some catastrophe very likely some spy one of those who are sent into jails to watch both prisoners and their keepers

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I don't believe that, said Rosa, smiling; if that worthy person is spying after any one, it is certainly not after my father.
children.prevalue: I don t believe that said Rosa smiling if that worthy person is spying after any one it is certainly not after my father

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: After whom, then?
children.prevalue: After whom then

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Me, for instance.
children.prevalue: Me for instance

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: You?
children.prevalue: You

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Why not? said Rosa, smiling.
children.prevalue: Why not said Rosa smiling

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Ah, that's true, Cornelius observed, with a sigh. You will not always have suitors in vain; this man may become your husband.
children.prevalue: Ah that s true Cornelius observed with a sigh You will not always have suitors in vain this man may become your husband

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: I don't say anything to the contrary.
children.prevalue: I don t say anything to the contrary

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: What cause have you to entertain such a happy prospect?
children.prevalue: What cause have you to entertain such a happy prospect

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Rather say, this fear, Mynheer Cornelius.
children.prevalue: Rather say this fear Mynheer Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Thank you, Rosa, you are right; well, I will say then, this fear?
children.prevalue: Thank you Rosa you are right well I will say then this fear

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: I have only this reason
children.prevalue: I have only this reason

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Tell me, I am anxious to hear.
children.prevalue: Tell me I am anxious to hear

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: This man came several times before to the Buytenhof, at the Hague. I remember now, it was just about the time when you were confined there. When I left, he left too; when I came here, he came after me. At the Hague his pretext was that he wanted to see you.
children.prevalue: This man came several times before to the Buytenhof at the Hague I remember now it was just about the time when you were confined there When I left he left too when I came here he came after me At the Hague his pretext was that he wanted to see you

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: See me?
children.prevalue: See me

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Yes, it must have undoubtedly been only a pretext for now, when he could plead the same reason, as you are my father's prisoner again, he does not care any longer for you; quite the contrary,I heard him say to my father only yesterday that he did not know you.
children.prevalue: Yes it must have undoubtedly been only a pretext for now when he could plead the same reason as you are my father s prisoner again he does not care any longer for you quite the contrary I heard him say to my father only yesterday that he did not know you

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Go on, Rosa, pray do, that I may guess who that man is, and what he wants.
children.prevalue: Go on Rosa pray do that I may guess who that man is and what he wants

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Are you quite sure, Mynheer Cornelius, that none of your friends can interest himself for you?
children.prevalue: Are you quite sure Mynheer Cornelius that none of your friends can interest himself for you

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: I have no friends, Rosa; I have only my old nurse, whom you know, and who knows you. Alas, poor Sue! she would come herself, and use no roundabout ways. She would at once say to your father, or to you, 'My good sir, or my good miss, my child is here; see how grieved I am; let me see him only for one hour, and I'll pray for you as long as I live.' No, no, continued Cornelius; with the exception of my poor old Sue, I have no friends in this world.
children.prevalue: I have no friends Rosa I have only my old nurse whom you know and who knows you Alas poor Sue she would come herself and use no roundabout ways She would at once say to your father or to you My good sir or my good miss my child is here see how grieved I am let me see him only for one hour and I ll pray for you as long as I live No no continued Cornelius with the exception of my poor old Sue I have no friends in this world

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Then I come back to what I thought before; and the more so as last evening at sunset, whilst I was arranging the border where I am to plant your bulb, I saw a shadow gliding between the alder trees and the aspens. I did not appear to see him, but it was this man. He concealed himself and saw me digging the ground, and certainly it was me whom he followed, and me whom he was spying after. I could not move my rake, or touch one atom of soil, without his noticing it.
children.prevalue: Then I come back to what I thought before and the more so as last evening at sunset whilst I was arranging the border where I am to plant your bulb I saw a shadow gliding between the alder trees and the aspens I did not appear to see him but it was this man He concealed himself and saw me digging the ground and certainly it was me whom he followed and me whom he was spying after I could not move my rake or touch one atom of soil without his noticing it

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Oh, yes, yes, he is in love with you, said Cornelius. Is he young? Is he handsome?
children.prevalue: Oh yes yes he is in love with you said Cornelius Is he young Is he handsome

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Saying this he looked anxiously at Rosa, eagerly waiting for her answer.
children.prevalue: Saying this he looked anxiously at Rosa eagerly waiting for her answer

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Young? handsome? cried Rosa, bursting into a laugh. He is hideous to look at; crooked, nearly fifty years of age, and never dares to look me in the face, or to speak, except in an undertone.
children.prevalue: Young handsome cried Rosa bursting into a laugh He is hideous to look at crooked nearly fifty years of age and never dares to look me in the face or to speak except in an undertone

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: And his name?
children.prevalue: And his name

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Jacob Gisels.
children.prevalue: Jacob Gisels

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I don't know him.
children.prevalue: I don t know him

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Then you see that, at all events, he does not come after you.
children.prevalue: Then you see that at all events he does not come after you

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: At any rate, if he loves you, Rosa, which is very likely, as to see you is to love you, at least you don't love him.
children.prevalue: At any rate if he loves you Rosa which is very likely as to see you is to love you at least you don t love him

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: To be sure I don't.
children.prevalue: To be sure I don t

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Then you wish me to keep my mind easy?
children.prevalue: Then you wish me to keep my mind easy

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I should certainly ask you to do so.
children.prevalue: I should certainly ask you to do so

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Well, then, now as you begin to know how to read you will read all that I write to you of the pangs of jealousy and of absence, won't you, Rosa?
children.prevalue: Well then now as you begin to know how to read you will read all that I write to you of the pangs of jealousy and of absence won t you Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: I shall read it, if you write with good big letters.
children.prevalue: I shall read it if you write with good big letters

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Then, as the turn which the conversation took began to make Rosa uneasy, she asked,
children.prevalue: Then as the turn which the conversation took began to make Rosa uneasy she asked

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: By the bye, how is your tulip going on?
children.prevalue: By the bye how is your tulip going on

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Oh, Rosa, only imagine my joy, this morning I looked at it in the sun, and after having moved the soil aside which covers the bulb, I saw the first sprouting of the leaves. This small germ has caused me a much greater emotion than the order of his Highness which turned aside the sword already raised at the Buytenhof.
children.prevalue: Oh Rosa only imagine my joy this morning I looked at it in the sun and after having moved the soil aside which covers the bulb I saw the first sprouting of the leaves This small germ has caused me a much greater emotion than the order of his Highness which turned aside the sword already raised at the Buytenhof

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: You hope, then? said Rosa, smiling.
children.prevalue: You hope then said Rosa smiling

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Yes, yes, I hope.
children.prevalue: Yes yes I hope

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: And I, in my turn, when shall I plant my bulb?
children.prevalue: And I in my turn when shall I plant my bulb

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Oh, the first favourable day I will tell you; but, whatever you do, let nobody help you, and don't confide your secret to any one in the world; do you see, a connoisseur by merely looking at the bulb would be able to distinguish its value; and so, my dearest Rosa, be careful in locking up the third sucker which remains to you.
children.prevalue: Oh the first favourable day I will tell you but whatever you do let nobody help you and don t confide your secret to any one in the world do you see a connoisseur by merely looking at the bulb would be able to distinguish its value and so my dearest Rosa be careful in locking up the third sucker which remains to you

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: It is still wrapped up in the same paper in which you put it, and just as you gave it me. I have laid it at the bottom of my chest under my point lace, which keeps it dry, without pressing upon it. But good night, my poor captive gentleman.
children.prevalue: It is still wrapped up in the same paper in which you put it and just as you gave it me I have laid it at the bottom of my chest under my point lace which keeps it dry without pressing upon it But good night my poor captive gentleman

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: How? already?
children.prevalue: How already

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: It must be, it must be.
children.prevalue: It must be it must be

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Coming so late and going so soon.
children.prevalue: Coming so late and going so soon

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: My father might grow impatient not seeing me return, and that precious lover might suspect a rival.
children.prevalue: My father might grow impatient not seeing me return and that precious lover might suspect a rival

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Here she listened uneasily.
children.prevalue: Here she listened uneasily

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: What is it? asked Van Baerle. I thought I heard something.
children.prevalue: What is it asked Van Baerle I thought I heard something

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: What, then?
children.prevalue: What then

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Something like a step, creaking on the staircase.
children.prevalue: Something like a step creaking on the staircase

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Surely, said the prisoner, that cannot be Master Gryphus, he is always heard at a distance.
children.prevalue: Surely said the prisoner that cannot be Master Gryphus he is always heard at a distance

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: No, it is not my father, I am quite sure, but
children.prevalue: No it is not my father I am quite sure but

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: But?
children.prevalue: But

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: But it might be Mynheer Jacob.
children.prevalue: But it might be Mynheer Jacob

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Rosa rushed toward the staircase, and a door was really heard rapidly to close before the young damsel had got down the first ten steps.
children.prevalue: Rosa rushed toward the staircase and a door was really heard rapidly to close before the young damsel had got down the first ten steps

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Cornelius was very uneasy about it, but it was after all only a prelude to greater anxieties.
children.prevalue: Cornelius was very uneasy about it but it was after all only a prelude to greater anxieties

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: The flowing day passed without any remarkable incident. Gryphus made his three visits, and discovered nothing. He never came at the same hours as he hoped thus to discover the secrets of the prisoner. Van Baerle, therefore, had devised a contrivance, a sort of pulley, by means of which he was able to lower or to raise his jug below the ledge of tiles and stone before his window. The strings by which this was effected he had found means to cover with that moss which generally grows on tiles, or in the crannies of the walls.
children.prevalue: The flowing day passed without any remarkable incident Gryphus made his three visits and discovered nothing He never came at the same hours as he hoped thus to discover the secrets of the prisoner Van Baerle therefore had devised a contrivance a sort of pulley by means of which he was able to lower or to raise his jug below the ledge of tiles and stone before his window The strings by which this was effected he had found means to cover with that moss which generally grows on tiles or in the crannies of the walls

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Gryphus suspected nothing, and the device succeeded for eight days. One morning, however, when Cornelius, absorbed in the contemplation of his bulb, from which a germ of vegetation was already peeping forth, had not heard old Gryphus coming upstairs as a gale of wind was blowing which shook the whole tower, the door suddenly opened.
children.prevalue: Gryphus suspected nothing and the device succeeded for eight days One morning however when Cornelius absorbed in the contemplation of his bulb from which a germ of vegetation was already peeping forth had not heard old Gryphus coming upstairs as a gale of wind was blowing which shook the whole tower the door suddenly opened

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Gryphus, perceiving an unknown and consequently a forbidden object in the hands of his prisoner, pounced upon it with the same rapidity as the hawk on its prey.
children.prevalue: Gryphus perceiving an unknown and consequently a forbidden object in the hands of his prisoner pounced upon it with the same rapidity as the hawk on its prey

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: As ill luck would have it, his coarse, hard hand, the same which he had broken, and which Cornelius van Baerle had set so well, grasped at once in the midst of the jug, on the spot where the bulb was lying in the soil.
children.prevalue: As ill luck would have it his coarse hard hand the same which he had broken and which Cornelius van Baerle had set so well grasped at once in the midst of the jug on the spot where the bulb was lying in the soil

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: What have you got here? he roared. Ah! have I caught you? and with this he grabbed in the soil.
children.prevalue: What have you got here he roared Ah have I caught you and with this he grabbed in the soil

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: I? nothing, nothing, cried Cornelius, trembling.
children.prevalue: I nothing nothing cried Cornelius trembling

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Ah! have I caught you? a jug and earth in it There is some criminal secret at the bottom of all this.
children.prevalue: Ah have I caught you a jug and earth in it There is some criminal secret at the bottom of all this

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Oh, my good Master Gryphus, said Van Baerle, imploringly, and anxious as the partridge robbed of her young by the reaper.
children.prevalue: Oh my good Master Gryphus said Van Baerle imploringly and anxious as the partridge robbed of her young by the reaper

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: In fact, Gryphus was beginning to dig the soil with his crooked fingers.
children.prevalue: In fact Gryphus was beginning to dig the soil with his crooked fingers

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Take care, sir, take care, said Cornelius, growing quite pale.
children.prevalue: Take care sir take care said Cornelius growing quite pale

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Care of what? Zounds! of what? roared the jailer.
children.prevalue: Care of what Zounds of what roared the jailer

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Take care, I say, you will crush it, Master Gryphus.
children.prevalue: Take care I say you will crush it Master Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: And with a rapid and almost frantic movement he snatched the jug from the hands of Gryphus, and hid it like a treasure under his arms.
children.prevalue: And with a rapid and almost frantic movement he snatched the jug from the hands of Gryphus and hid it like a treasure under his arms

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: But Gryphus, obstinate, like an old man, and more and more convinced that he was discovering here a conspiracy against the Prince of Orange, rushed up to his prisoner, raising his stick; seeing, however, the impassible resolution of the captive to protect his flowerpot he was convinced that Cornelius trembled much less for his head than for his jug.
children.prevalue: But Gryphus obstinate like an old man and more and more convinced that he was discovering here a conspiracy against the Prince of Orange rushed up to his prisoner raising his stick seeing however the impassible resolution of the captive to protect his flowerpot he was convinced that Cornelius trembled much less for his head than for his jug

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: He therefore tried to wrest it from him by force.
children.prevalue: He therefore tried to wrest it from him by force

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Halloa! said the jailer, furious, here, you see, you are rebelling.
children.prevalue: Halloa said the jailer furious here you see you are rebelling

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Leave me my tulip, cried Van Baerle.
children.prevalue: Leave me my tulip cried Van Baerle

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Ah, yes, tulip, replied the old man, we know well the shifts of prisoners.
children.prevalue: Ah yes tulip replied the old man we know well the shifts of prisoners

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: But I vow to you
children.prevalue: But I vow to you

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Let go, repeated Gryphus, stamping his foot, let go, or I shall call the guard.
children.prevalue: Let go repeated Gryphus stamping his foot let go or I shall call the guard

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Call whoever you like, but you shall not have this flower except with my life.
children.prevalue: Call whoever you like but you shall not have this flower except with my life

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Gryphus, exasperated, plunged his finger a second time into the soil, and now he drew out the bulb, which certainly looked quite black; and whilst Van Baerle, quite happy to have saved the vessel, did not suspect that the adversary had possessed himself of its precious contents, Gryphus hurled the softened bulb with all his force on the flags, where almost immediately after it was crushed to atoms under his heavy shoe.
children.prevalue: Gryphus exasperated plunged his finger a second time into the soil and now he drew out the bulb which certainly looked quite black and whilst Van Baerle quite happy to have saved the vessel did not suspect that the adversary had possessed himself of its precious contents Gryphus hurled the softened bulb with all his force on the flags where almost immediately after it was crushed to atoms under his heavy shoe

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Van Baerle saw the work of destruction, got a glimpse of the juicy remains of his darling bulb, and, guessing the cause of the ferocious joy of Gryphus, uttered a cry of agony, which would have melted the heart even of that ruthless jailer who some years before killed Pelisson's spider.
children.prevalue: Van Baerle saw the work of destruction got a glimpse of the juicy remains of his darling bulb and guessing the cause of the ferocious joy of Gryphus uttered a cry of agony which would have melted the heart even of that ruthless jailer who some years before killed Pelisson s spider

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: The idea of striking down this spiteful bully passed like lightning through the brain of the tulipfancier. The blood rushed to his brow, and seemed like fire in his eyes, which blinded him, and he raised in his two hands the heavy jug with all the now useless earth which remained in it. One instant more, and he would have flung it on the bald head of old Gryphus.
children.prevalue: The idea of striking down this spiteful bully passed like lightning through the brain of the tulipfancier The blood rushed to his brow and seemed like fire in his eyes which blinded him and he raised in his two hands the heavy jug with all the now useless earth which remained in it One instant more and he would have flung it on the bald head of old Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: But a cry stopped him; a cry of agony, uttered by poor Rosa, who, trembling and pale, with her arms raised to heaven, made her appearance behind the grated window, and thus interposed between her father and her friend.
children.prevalue: But a cry stopped him a cry of agony uttered by poor Rosa who trembling and pale with her arms raised to heaven made her appearance behind the grated window and thus interposed between her father and her friend

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Gryphus then understood the danger with which he had been threatened, and he broke out in a volley of the most terrible abuse.
children.prevalue: Gryphus then understood the danger with which he had been threatened and he broke out in a volley of the most terrible abuse

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Indeed, said Cornelius to him, you must be a very mean and spiteful fellow to rob a poor prisoner of his only consolation, a tulip bulb.
children.prevalue: Indeed said Cornelius to him you must be a very mean and spiteful fellow to rob a poor prisoner of his only consolation a tulip bulb

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: For shame, my father, Rosa chimed in, it is indeed a crime you have committed here.
children.prevalue: For shame my father Rosa chimed in it is indeed a crime you have committed here

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Ah, is that you, my little chatterbox? the old man cried, boiling with rage and turning towards her; don't you meddle with what don't concern you, but go down as quickly as possible.
children.prevalue: Ah is that you my little chatterbox the old man cried boiling with rage and turning towards her don t you meddle with what don t concern you but go down as quickly as possible

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Unfortunate me, continued Cornelius, overwhelmed with grief.
children.prevalue: Unfortunate me continued Cornelius overwhelmed with grief

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: After all, it is but a tulip, Gryphus resumed, as he began to be a little ashamed of himself. You may have as many tulips as you like: I have three hundred of them in my loft.
children.prevalue: After all it is but a tulip Gryphus resumed as he began to be a little ashamed of himself You may have as many tulips as you like I have three hundred of them in my loft

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: To the devil with your tulips! cried Cornelius; you are worthy of each other: had I a hundred thousand millions of them, I would gladly give them for the one which you have just destroyed.
children.prevalue: To the devil with your tulips cried Cornelius you are worthy of each other had I a hundred thousand millions of them I would gladly give them for the one which you have just destroyed

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Oh, so! Gryphus said, in a tone of triumph; now there we have it. It was not your tulip you cared for. There was in that false bulb some witchcraft, perhaps some means of correspondence with conspirators against his Highness who has granted you your life. I always said they were wrong in not cutting your head off.
children.prevalue: Oh so Gryphus said in a tone of triumph now there we have it It was not your tulip you cared for There was in that false bulb some witchcraft perhaps some means of correspondence with conspirators against his Highness who has granted you your life I always said they were wrong in not cutting your head off

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Father, father! cried Rosa.
children.prevalue: Father father cried Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Yes, yes! it is better as it is now, repeated Gryphus, growing warm; I have destroyed it, and I'll do the same again, as often as you repeat the trick. Didn't I tell you, my fine fellow, that I would make your life a hard one?
children.prevalue: Yes yes it is better as it is now repeated Gryphus growing warm I have destroyed it and I ll do the same again as often as you repeat the trick Didn t I tell you my fine fellow that I would make your life a hard one

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: A curse on you! Cornelius exclaimed, quite beyond himself with despair, as he gathered, with his trembling fingers, the remnants of that bulb on which he had rested so many joys and so many hopes.
children.prevalue: A curse on you Cornelius exclaimed quite beyond himself with despair as he gathered with his trembling fingers the remnants of that bulb on which he had rested so many joys and so many hopes

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: We shall plant the other tomorrow, my dear Mynheer Cornelius, said Rosa, in a low voice, who understood the intense grief of the unfortunate tulipfancier, and who, with the pure sacred love of her innocent heart, poured these kind words, like a drop of balm, on the bleeding wounds of Cornelius.
children.prevalue: We shall plant the other tomorrow my dear Mynheer Cornelius said Rosa in a low voice who understood the intense grief of the unfortunate tulipfancier and who with the pure sacred love of her innocent heart poured these kind words like a drop of balm on the bleeding wounds of Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Rosa had scarcely pronounced these consolatory words when a voice was heard from the staircase asking Gryphus how matters were going on.
children.prevalue: Rosa had scarcely pronounced these consolatory words when a voice was heard from the staircase asking Gryphus how matters were going on

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Do you hear, father? said Rosa.
children.prevalue: Do you hear father said Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: What?
children.prevalue: What

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Master Jacob calls you, he is uneasy.
children.prevalue: Master Jacob calls you he is uneasy

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: There was such a noise, said Gryphus; wouldn't you have thought he would murder me, this doctor? They are always very troublesome fellows, these scholars.
children.prevalue: There was such a noise said Gryphus wouldn t you have thought he would murder me this doctor They are always very troublesome fellows these scholars

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Then, pointing with his finger towards the staircase, he said to Rosa: Just lead the way, Miss.
children.prevalue: Then pointing with his finger towards the staircase he said to Rosa Just lead the way Miss

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: After this he locked the door and called out: I shall be with you directly, friend Jacob.
children.prevalue: After this he locked the door and called out I shall be with you directly friend Jacob

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Poor Cornelius, thus left alone with his bitter grief, muttered to himself,
children.prevalue: Poor Cornelius thus left alone with his bitter grief muttered to himself

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Ah, you old hangman! it is me you have trodden under foot; you have murdered me; I shall not survive it.
children.prevalue: Ah you old hangman it is me you have trodden under foot you have murdered me I shall not survive it

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: And certainly the unfortunate prisoner would have fallen ill but for the counterpoise which Providence had granted to his grief, and which was called Rosa.
children.prevalue: And certainly the unfortunate prisoner would have fallen ill but for the counterpoise which Providence had granted to his grief and which was called Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: In the evening she came back. Her first words announced to Cornelius that henceforth her father would make no objection to his cultivating flowers.
children.prevalue: In the evening she came back Her first words announced to Cornelius that henceforth her father would make no objection to his cultivating flowers

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: And how do you know that? the prisoner asked, with a doleful look.
children.prevalue: And how do you know that the prisoner asked with a doleful look

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I know it because he has said so.
children.prevalue: I know it because he has said so

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: To deceive me, perhaps.
children.prevalue: To deceive me perhaps

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: No, he repents.
children.prevalue: No he repents

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Ah yes! but too late.
children.prevalue: Ah yes but too late

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: This repentance is not of himself.
children.prevalue: This repentance is not of himself

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: And who put it into him?
children.prevalue: And who put it into him

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: If you only knew how his friend scolded him!
children.prevalue: If you only knew how his friend scolded him

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Ah, Master Jacob; he does not leave you, then, that Master Jacob?
children.prevalue: Ah Master Jacob he does not leave you then that Master Jacob

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: At any rate, he leaves us as little as he can help.
children.prevalue: At any rate he leaves us as little as he can help

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Saying this, she smiled in such a way that the little cloud of jealousy which had darkened the brow of Cornelius speedily vanished.
children.prevalue: Saying this she smiled in such a way that the little cloud of jealousy which had darkened the brow of Cornelius speedily vanished

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: How was it? asked the prisoner.
children.prevalue: How was it asked the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Well, being asked by his friend, my father told at supper the whole story of the tulip, or rather of the bulb, and of his own fine exploit of crushing it.
children.prevalue: Well being asked by his friend my father told at supper the whole story of the tulip or rather of the bulb and of his own fine exploit of crushing it

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Cornelius heaved a sigh, which might have been called a groan.
children.prevalue: Cornelius heaved a sigh which might have been called a groan

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Had you only seen Master Jacob at that moment! continued Rosa. I really thought he would set fire to the castle; his eyes were like two flaming torches, his hair stood on end, and he clinched his fist for a moment; I thought he would have strangled my father.
children.prevalue: Had you only seen Master Jacob at that moment continued Rosa I really thought he would set fire to the castle his eyes were like two flaming torches his hair stood on end and he clinched his fist for a moment I thought he would have strangled my father

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'You have done that,' he cried, 'you have crushed the bulb?'
children.prevalue: You have done that he cried you have crushed the bulb

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: 'Indeed I have.'
children.prevalue: Indeed I have

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: 'It is infamous,' said Master Jacob, 'it is odious! You have committed a great crime!'
children.prevalue: It is infamous said Master Jacob it is odious You have committed a great crime

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: My father was quite dumbfounded.
children.prevalue: My father was quite dumbfounded

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: 'Are you mad, too?' he asked his friend.
children.prevalue: Are you mad too he asked his friend

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Oh, what a worthy man is this Master Jacob! muttered Cornelius,an honest soul, an excellent heart that he is.
children.prevalue: Oh what a worthy man is this Master Jacob muttered Cornelius an honest soul an excellent heart that he is

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: The truth is, that it is impossible to treat a man more rudely than he did my father; he was really quite in despair, repeating over and over again,
children.prevalue: The truth is that it is impossible to treat a man more rudely than he did my father he was really quite in despair repeating over and over again

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: 'Crushed, crushed the bulb! my God, my God! crushed!'
children.prevalue: Crushed crushed the bulb my God my God crushed

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Then, turning toward me, he asked, 'But it was not the only one that he had?'
children.prevalue: Then turning toward me he asked But it was not the only one that he had

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Did he ask that? inquired Cornelius, with some anxiety.
children.prevalue: Did he ask that inquired Cornelius with some anxiety

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: 'You think it was not the only one?' said my father. 'Very well, we shall search for the others.'
children.prevalue: You think it was not the only one said my father Very well we shall search for the others

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: 'You will search for the others?' cried Jacob, taking my father by the collar; but he immediately loosed him. Then, turning towards me, he continued, asking 'And what did that poor young man say?'
children.prevalue: You will search for the others cried Jacob taking my father by the collar but he immediately loosed him Then turning towards me he continued asking And what did that poor young man say

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: I did not know what to answer, as you had so strictly enjoined me never to allow any one to guess the interest which you are taking in the bulb. Fortunately, my father saved me from the difficulty by chiming in,
children.prevalue: I did not know what to answer as you had so strictly enjoined me never to allow any one to guess the interest which you are taking in the bulb Fortunately my father saved me from the difficulty by chiming in

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: 'What did he say? Didn't he fume and fret?'
children.prevalue: What did he say Didn t he fume and fret

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I interrupted him, saying, 'Was it not natural that he should be furious, you were so unjust and brutal, father?'
children.prevalue: I interrupted him saying Was it not natural that he should be furious you were so unjust and brutal father

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: 'Well, now, are you mad?' cried my father; 'what immense misfortune is it to crush a tulip bulb? You may buy a hundred of them in the market of Gorcum.'
children.prevalue: Well now are you mad cried my father what immense misfortune is it to crush a tulip bulb You may buy a hundred of them in the market of Gorcum

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: 'Perhaps some less precious one than that was!' I quite incautiously replied.
children.prevalue: Perhaps some less precious one than that was I quite incautiously replied

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: And what did Jacob say or do at these words? asked Cornelius.
children.prevalue: And what did Jacob say or do at these words asked Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: At these words, if I must say it, his eyes seemed to flash like lightning.
children.prevalue: At these words if I must say it his eyes seemed to flash like lightning

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: But, said Cornelius, that was not all; I am sure he said something in his turn.
children.prevalue: But said Cornelius that was not all I am sure he said something in his turn

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: 'So, then, my pretty Rosa,' he said, with a voice as sweet a honey,'so you think that bulb to have been a precious one?'
children.prevalue: So then my pretty Rosa he said with a voice as sweet a honey so you think that bulb to have been a precious one

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: I saw that I had made a blunder.
children.prevalue: I saw that I had made a blunder

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: 'What do I know?' I said, negligently; 'do I understand anything of tulips? I only knowas unfortunately it is our lot to live with prisonersthat for them any pastime is of value. This poor Mynheer van Baerle amused himself with this bulb. Well, I think it very cruel to take from him the only thing that he could have amused himself with.'
children.prevalue: What do I know I said negligently do I understand anything of tulips I only knowas unfortunately it is our lot to live with prisonersthat for them any pastime is of value This poor Mynheer van Baerle amused himself with this bulb Well I think it very cruel to take from him the only thing that he could have amused himself with

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: 'But, first of all,' said my father, 'we ought to know how he has contrived to procure this bulb.'
children.prevalue: But first of all said my father we ought to know how he has contrived to procure this bulb

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: I turned my eyes away to avoid my father's look; but I met those of Jacob.
children.prevalue: I turned my eyes away to avoid my father s look but I met those of Jacob

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: It was as if he had tried to read my thoughts at the bottom of my heart.
children.prevalue: It was as if he had tried to read my thoughts at the bottom of my heart

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Some little show of anger sometimes saves an answer. I shrugged my shoulders, turned my back, and advanced towards the door.
children.prevalue: Some little show of anger sometimes saves an answer I shrugged my shoulders turned my back and advanced towards the door

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: But I was kept by something which I heard, although it was uttered in a very low voice only.
children.prevalue: But I was kept by something which I heard although it was uttered in a very low voice only

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Jacob said to my father,
children.prevalue: Jacob said to my father

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: 'It would not be so difficult to ascertain that.'
children.prevalue: It would not be so difficult to ascertain that

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: 'How so?'
children.prevalue: How so

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: 'You need only search his person: and if he has the other bulbs, we shall find them, as there usually are three suckers!'
children.prevalue: You need only search his person and if he has the other bulbs we shall find them as there usually are three suckers

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Three suckers! cried Cornelius. Did you say that I have three?
children.prevalue: Three suckers cried Cornelius Did you say that I have three

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: The word certainly struck me just as much as it does you. I turned round. They were both of them so deeply engaged in their conversation that they did not observe my movement.
children.prevalue: The word certainly struck me just as much as it does you I turned round They were both of them so deeply engaged in their conversation that they did not observe my movement

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: 'But,' said my father, 'perhaps he has not got his bulbs about him?'
children.prevalue: But said my father perhaps he has not got his bulbs about him

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: 'Then take him down, under some pretext or other and I will search his cell in the meanwhile.'
children.prevalue: Then take him down under some pretext or other and I will search his cell in the meanwhile

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Halloa, halloa! said Cornelius. But this Mr. Jacob of yours is a villain, it seems.
children.prevalue: Halloa halloa said Cornelius But this Mr Jacob of yours is a villain it seems

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: I am afraid he is.
children.prevalue: I am afraid he is

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Tell me, Rosa, continued Cornelius, with a pensive air.
children.prevalue: Tell me Rosa continued Cornelius with a pensive air

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: What?
children.prevalue: What

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Did you not tell me that on the day when you prepared your borders this man followed you?
children.prevalue: Did you not tell me that on the day when you prepared your borders this man followed you

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: So he did.
children.prevalue: So he did

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: That he glided like a shadow behind the elder trees?
children.prevalue: That he glided like a shadow behind the elder trees

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: That not one of your movements escaped him?
children.prevalue: That not one of your movements escaped him

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Not one, indeed.
children.prevalue: Not one indeed

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Rosa, said Cornelius, growing quite pale.
children.prevalue: Rosa said Cornelius growing quite pale

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: It was not you he was after.
children.prevalue: It was not you he was after

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Who else, then?
children.prevalue: Who else then

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: It is not you that he was in love with!
children.prevalue: It is not you that he was in love with

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: But with whom else?
children.prevalue: But with whom else

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: He was after my bulb, and is in love with my tulip!
children.prevalue: He was after my bulb and is in love with my tulip

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: You don't say so! And yet it is very possible, said Rosa.
children.prevalue: You don t say so And yet it is very possible said Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Will you make sure of it?
children.prevalue: Will you make sure of it

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: In what manner?
children.prevalue: In what manner

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Oh, it would be very easy!
children.prevalue: Oh it would be very easy

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Tell me.
children.prevalue: Tell me

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Go tomorrow into the garden; manage matters so that Jacob may know, as he did the first time, that you are going there, and that he may follow you. Feign to put the bulb into the ground; leave the garden, but look through the keyhole of the door and watch him.
children.prevalue: Go tomorrow into the garden manage matters so that Jacob may know as he did the first time that you are going there and that he may follow you Feign to put the bulb into the ground leave the garden but look through the keyhole of the door and watch him

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Well, and what then?
children.prevalue: Well and what then

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: What then? We shall do as he does.
children.prevalue: What then We shall do as he does

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Oh! said Rosa, with a sigh, you are very fond of your bulbs.
children.prevalue: Oh said Rosa with a sigh you are very fond of your bulbs

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: To tell the truth, said the prisoner, sighing likewise, since your father crushed that unfortunate bulb, I feel as if part of my own self had been paralyzed.
children.prevalue: To tell the truth said the prisoner sighing likewise since your father crushed that unfortunate bulb I feel as if part of my own self had been paralyzed

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Now just hear me, said Rosa; will you try something else?
children.prevalue: Now just hear me said Rosa will you try something else

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: What?
children.prevalue: What

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Will you accept the proposition of my father?
children.prevalue: Will you accept the proposition of my father

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Which proposition?
children.prevalue: Which proposition

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Did not he offer to you tulip bulbs by hundreds?
children.prevalue: Did not he offer to you tulip bulbs by hundreds

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Indeed he did.
children.prevalue: Indeed he did

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Accept two or three, and, along with them, you may grow the third sucker.
children.prevalue: Accept two or three and along with them you may grow the third sucker

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Yes, that would do very well, said Cornelius, knitting his brow; if your father were alone, but there is that Master Jacob, who watches all our ways.
children.prevalue: Yes that would do very well said Cornelius knitting his brow if your father were alone but there is that Master Jacob who watches all our ways

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Well, that is true; but only think! you are depriving yourself, as I can easily see, of a very great pleasure.
children.prevalue: Well that is true but only think you are depriving yourself as I can easily see of a very great pleasure

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: She pronounced these words with a smile, which was not altogether without a tinge of irony.
children.prevalue: She pronounced these words with a smile which was not altogether without a tinge of irony

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Cornelius reflected for a moment; he evidently was struggling against some vehement desire.
children.prevalue: Cornelius reflected for a moment he evidently was struggling against some vehement desire

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: No! he cried at last, with the stoicism of a Roman of old, it would be a weakness, it would be a folly, it would be a meanness! If I thus give up the only and last resource which we possess to the uncertain chances of the bad passions of anger and envy, I should never deserve to be forgiven. No, Rosa, no; tomorrow we shall come to a conclusion as to the spot to be chosen for your tulip; you will plant it according to my instructions; and as to the third sucker,Cornelius here heaved a deep sigh,watch over it as a miser over his first or last piece of gold; as the mother over her child; as the wounded over the last drop of blood in his veins; watch over it, Rosa! Some voice within me tells me that it will be our saving, that it will be a source of good to us.
children.prevalue: No he cried at last with the stoicism of a Roman of old it would be a weakness it would be a folly it would be a meanness If I thus give up the only and last resource which we possess to the uncertain chances of the bad passions of anger and envy I should never deserve to be forgiven No Rosa no tomorrow we shall come to a conclusion as to the spot to be chosen for your tulip you will plant it according to my instructions and as to the third sucker Cornelius here heaved a deep sigh watch over it as a miser over his first or last piece of gold as the mother over her child as the wounded over the last drop of blood in his veins watch over it Rosa Some voice within me tells me that it will be our saving that it will be a source of good to us

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Be easy, Mynheer Cornelius, said Rosa, with a sweet mixture of melancholy and gravity, be easy; your wishes are commands to me.
children.prevalue: Be easy Mynheer Cornelius said Rosa with a sweet mixture of melancholy and gravity be easy your wishes are commands to me

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: And even, continued Van Baerle, warming more and more with his subject, if you should perceive that your steps are watched, and that your speech has excited the suspicion of your father and of that detestable Master Jacob,well, Rosa, don't hesitate for one moment to sacrifice me, who am only still living through you,me, who have no one in the world but you; sacrifice me,don't come to see me any more.
children.prevalue: And even continued Van Baerle warming more and more with his subject if you should perceive that your steps are watched and that your speech has excited the suspicion of your father and of that detestable Master Jacob well Rosa don t hesitate for one moment to sacrifice me who am only still living through you me who have no one in the world but you sacrifice me don t come to see me any more

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Rosa felt her heart sink within her, and her eyes were filling with tears.
children.prevalue: Rosa felt her heart sink within her and her eyes were filling with tears

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Alas! she said.
children.prevalue: Alas she said

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: What is it? asked Cornelius.
children.prevalue: What is it asked Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: I see one thing.
children.prevalue: I see one thing

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: What do you see?
children.prevalue: What do you see

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: I see, said she, bursting out in sobs, I see that you love your tulips with such love as to have no more room in your heart left for other affections.
children.prevalue: I see said she bursting out in sobs I see that you love your tulips with such love as to have no more room in your heart left for other affections

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Saying this, she fled.
children.prevalue: Saying this she fled

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Cornelius, after this, passed one of the worst nights he ever had in his life.
children.prevalue: Cornelius after this passed one of the worst nights he ever had in his life

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Rosa was vexed with him, and with good reason. Perhaps she would never return to see the prisoner, and then he would have no more news, either of Rosa or of his tulips.
children.prevalue: Rosa was vexed with him and with good reason Perhaps she would never return to see the prisoner and then he would have no more news either of Rosa or of his tulips

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: We have to confess, to the disgrace of our hero and of floriculture, that of his two affections he felt most strongly inclined to regret the loss of Rosa; and when, at about three in the morning, he fell asleep overcome with fatigue, and harassed with remorse, the grand black tulip yielded precedence in his dreams to the sweet blue eyes of the fair maid of Friesland.
children.prevalue: We have to confess to the disgrace of our hero and of floriculture that of his two affections he felt most strongly inclined to regret the loss of Rosa and when at about three in the morning he fell asleep overcome with fatigue and harassed with remorse the grand black tulip yielded precedence in his dreams to the sweet blue eyes of the fair maid of Friesland

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: But poor Rosa, in her secluded chamber, could not have known of whom or of what Cornelius was dreaming.
children.prevalue: But poor Rosa in her secluded chamber could not have known of whom or of what Cornelius was dreaming

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: From what he had said she was more ready to believe that he dreamed of the black tulip than of her; and yet Rosa was mistaken.
children.prevalue: From what he had said she was more ready to believe that he dreamed of the black tulip than of her and yet Rosa was mistaken

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: But as there was no one to tell her so, and as the words of Cornelius's thoughtless speech had fallen upon her heart like drops of poison, she did not dream, but she wept.
children.prevalue: But as there was no one to tell her so and as the words of Cornelius s thoughtless speech had fallen upon her heart like drops of poison she did not dream but she wept

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The fact was, that, as Rosa was a highspirited creature, of no mean perception and a noble heart, she took a very clear and judicious view of her own social position, if not of her moral and physical qualities.
children.prevalue: The fact was that as Rosa was a highspirited creature of no mean perception and a noble heart she took a very clear and judicious view of her own social position if not of her moral and physical qualities

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Cornelius was a scholar, and was wealthy,at least he had been before the confiscation of his property; Cornelius belonged to the merchantbourgeoisie, who were prouder of their richly emblazoned shop signs than the hereditary nobility of their heraldic bearings. Therefore, although he might find Rosa a pleasant companion for the dreary hours of his captivity, when it came to a question of bestowing his heart it was almost certain that he would bestow it upon a tulip,that is to say, upon the proudest and noblest of flowers, rather than upon poor Rosa, the jailer's lowly child.
children.prevalue: Cornelius was a scholar and was wealthy at least he had been before the confiscation of his property Cornelius belonged to the merchantbourgeoisie who were prouder of their richly emblazoned shop signs than the hereditary nobility of their heraldic bearings Therefore although he might find Rosa a pleasant companion for the dreary hours of his captivity when it came to a question of bestowing his heart it was almost certain that he would bestow it upon a tulip that is to say upon the proudest and noblest of flowers rather than upon poor Rosa the jailer s lowly child

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Thus Rosa understood Cornelius's preference of the tulip to herself, but was only so much the more unhappy therefor.
children.prevalue: Thus Rosa understood Cornelius s preference of the tulip to herself but was only so much the more unhappy therefor

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: During the whole of this terrible night the poor girl did not close an eye, and before she rose in the morning she had come to the resolution of making her appearance at the grated window no more.
children.prevalue: During the whole of this terrible night the poor girl did not close an eye and before she rose in the morning she had come to the resolution of making her appearance at the grated window no more

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: But as she knew with what ardent desire Cornelius looked forward to the news about his tulip; and as, notwithstanding her determination not to see any more a man her pity for whose fate was fast growing into love, she did not, on the other hand, wish to drive him to despair, she resolved to continue by herself the reading and writing lessons; and, fortunately, she had made sufficient progress to dispense with the help of a master when the master was not to be Cornelius.
