children.prevalue: But as she knew with what ardent desire Cornelius looked forward to the news about his tulip and as notwithstanding her determination not to see any more a man her pity for whose fate was fast growing into love she did not on the other hand wish to drive him to despair she resolved to continue by herself the reading and writing lessons and fortunately she had made sufficient progress to dispense with the help of a master when the master was not to be Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Rosa therefore applied herself most diligently to reading poor Cornelius de Witt's Bible, on the second fly leaf of which the last will of Cornelius van Baerle was written.
children.prevalue: Rosa therefore applied herself most diligently to reading poor Cornelius de Witt s Bible on the second fly leaf of which the last will of Cornelius van Baerle was written

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Alas! she muttered, when perusing again this document, which she never finished without a tear, the pearl of love, rolling from her limpid eyes on her pale cheeksalas! at that time I thought for one moment he loved me.
children.prevalue: Alas she muttered when perusing again this document which she never finished without a tear the pearl of love rolling from her limpid eyes on her pale cheeksalas at that time I thought for one moment he loved me

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Poor Rosa! she was mistaken. Never had the love of the prisoner been more sincere than at the time at which we are now arrived, when in the contest between the black tulip and Rosa the tulip had had to yield to her the first and foremost place in Cornelius's heart.
children.prevalue: Poor Rosa she was mistaken Never had the love of the prisoner been more sincere than at the time at which we are now arrived when in the contest between the black tulip and Rosa the tulip had had to yield to her the first and foremost place in Cornelius s heart

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: But Rosa was not aware of it.
children.prevalue: But Rosa was not aware of it

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Having finished reading, she took her pen, and began with as laudable diligence the by far more difficult task of writing.
children.prevalue: Having finished reading she took her pen and began with as laudable diligence the by far more difficult task of writing

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: As, however, Rosa was already able to write a legible hand when Cornelius so uncautiously opened his heart, she did not despair of progressing quickly enough to write, after eight days at the latest, to the prisoner an account of his tulip.
children.prevalue: As however Rosa was already able to write a legible hand when Cornelius so uncautiously opened his heart she did not despair of progressing quickly enough to write after eight days at the latest to the prisoner an account of his tulip

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: She had not forgotten one word of the directions given to her by Cornelius, whose speeches she treasured in her heart, even when they did not take the shape of directions.
children.prevalue: She had not forgotten one word of the directions given to her by Cornelius whose speeches she treasured in her heart even when they did not take the shape of directions

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: He, on his part, awoke deeper in love than ever. The tulip, indeed, was still a luminous and prominent object in his mind; but he no longer looked upon it as a treasure to which he ought to sacrifice everything, and even Rosa, but as a marvellous combination of nature and art with which he would have been happy to adorn the bosom of his beloved one.
children.prevalue: He on his part awoke deeper in love than ever The tulip indeed was still a luminous and prominent object in his mind but he no longer looked upon it as a treasure to which he ought to sacrifice everything and even Rosa but as a marvellous combination of nature and art with which he would have been happy to adorn the bosom of his beloved one

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Yet during the whole of that day he was haunted with a vague uneasiness, at the bottom of which was the fear lest Rosa should not come in the evening to pay him her usual visit. This thought took more and more hold of him, until at the approach of evening his whole mind was absorbed in it.
children.prevalue: Yet during the whole of that day he was haunted with a vague uneasiness at the bottom of which was the fear lest Rosa should not come in the evening to pay him her usual visit This thought took more and more hold of him until at the approach of evening his whole mind was absorbed in it

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: How his heart beat when darkness closed in! The words which he had said to Rosa on the evening before and which had so deeply afflicted her, now came back to his mind more vividly than ever, and he asked himself how he could have told his gentle comforter to sacrifice him to his tulip,that is to say, to give up seeing him, if need be,whereas to him the sight of Rosa had become a condition of life.
children.prevalue: How his heart beat when darkness closed in The words which he had said to Rosa on the evening before and which had so deeply afflicted her now came back to his mind more vividly than ever and he asked himself how he could have told his gentle comforter to sacrifice him to his tulip that is to say to give up seeing him if need be whereas to him the sight of Rosa had become a condition of life

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: In Cornelius's cell one heard the chimes of the clock of the fortress. It struck seven, it struck eight, it struck nine. Never did the metal voice vibrate more forcibly through the heart of any man than did the last stroke, marking the ninth hour, through the heart of Cornelius.
children.prevalue: In Cornelius s cell one heard the chimes of the clock of the fortress It struck seven it struck eight it struck nine Never did the metal voice vibrate more forcibly through the heart of any man than did the last stroke marking the ninth hour through the heart of Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: All was then silent again. Cornelius put his hand on his heart, to repress as it were its violent palpitation, and listened.
children.prevalue: All was then silent again Cornelius put his hand on his heart to repress as it were its violent palpitation and listened

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: The noise of her footstep, the rustling of her gown on the staircase, were so familiar to his ear, that she had no sooner mounted one step than he used to say to himself,
children.prevalue: The noise of her footstep the rustling of her gown on the staircase were so familiar to his ear that she had no sooner mounted one step than he used to say to himself

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Here comes Rosa.
children.prevalue: Here comes Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: This evening none of those little noises broke the silence of the lobby, the clock struck nine, and a quarter; the halfhour, then a quarter to ten, and at last its deep tone announced, not only to the inmates of the fortress, but also to all the inhabitants of Loewestein, that it was ten.
children.prevalue: This evening none of those little noises broke the silence of the lobby the clock struck nine and a quarter the halfhour then a quarter to ten and at last its deep tone announced not only to the inmates of the fortress but also to all the inhabitants of Loewestein that it was ten

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: This was the hour at which Rosa generally used to leave Cornelius. The hour had struck, but Rosa had not come.
children.prevalue: This was the hour at which Rosa generally used to leave Cornelius The hour had struck but Rosa had not come

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Thus then his foreboding had not deceived him; Rosa, being vexed, shut herself up in her room and left him to himself.
children.prevalue: Thus then his foreboding had not deceived him Rosa being vexed shut herself up in her room and left him to himself

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Alas! he thought, I have deserved all this. She will come no more, and she is right in staying away; in her place I should do just the same.
children.prevalue: Alas he thought I have deserved all this She will come no more and she is right in staying away in her place I should do just the same

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Yet notwithstanding all this, Cornelius listened, waited, and hoped until midnight, then he threw himself upon the bed, with his clothes on.
children.prevalue: Yet notwithstanding all this Cornelius listened waited and hoped until midnight then he threw himself upon the bed with his clothes on

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: It was a long and sad night for him, and the day brought no hope to the prisoner.
children.prevalue: It was a long and sad night for him and the day brought no hope to the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: At eight in the morning, the door of his cell opened; but Cornelius did not even turn his head; he had heard the heavy step of Gryphus in the lobby, but this step had perfectly satisfied the prisoner that his jailer was coming alone.
children.prevalue: At eight in the morning the door of his cell opened but Cornelius did not even turn his head he had heard the heavy step of Gryphus in the lobby but this step had perfectly satisfied the prisoner that his jailer was coming alone

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Thus Cornelius did not even look at Gryphus.
children.prevalue: Thus Cornelius did not even look at Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: And yet he would have been so glad to draw him out, and to inquire about Rosa. He even very nearly made this inquiry, strange as it would needs have appeared to her father. To tell the truth, there was in all this some selfish hope to hear from Gryphus that his daughter was ill.
children.prevalue: And yet he would have been so glad to draw him out and to inquire about Rosa He even very nearly made this inquiry strange as it would needs have appeared to her father To tell the truth there was in all this some selfish hope to hear from Gryphus that his daughter was ill

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Except on extraordinary occasions, Rosa never came during the day. Cornelius therefore did not really expect her as long as the day lasted. Yet his sudden starts, his listening at the door, his rapid glances at every little noise towards the grated window, showed clearly that the prisoner entertained some latent hope that Rosa would, somehow or other, break her rule.
children.prevalue: Except on extraordinary occasions Rosa never came during the day Cornelius therefore did not really expect her as long as the day lasted Yet his sudden starts his listening at the door his rapid glances at every little noise towards the grated window showed clearly that the prisoner entertained some latent hope that Rosa would somehow or other break her rule

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: At the second visit of Gryphus, Cornelius, contrary to all his former habits, asked the old jailer, with the most winning voice, about her health; but Gryphus contented himself with giving the laconical answer,
children.prevalue: At the second visit of Gryphus Cornelius contrary to all his former habits asked the old jailer with the most winning voice about her health but Gryphus contented himself with giving the laconical answer

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: All's well.
children.prevalue: All s well

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: At the third visit of the day, Cornelius changed his former inquiry:
children.prevalue: At the third visit of the day Cornelius changed his former inquiry

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I hope nobody is ill at Loewestein?
children.prevalue: I hope nobody is ill at Loewestein

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Nobody, replied, even more laconically, the jailer, shutting the door before the nose of the prisoner.
children.prevalue: Nobody replied even more laconically the jailer shutting the door before the nose of the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Gryphus, being little used to this sort of civility on the part of Cornelius, began to suspect that his prisoner was about to try and bribe him.
children.prevalue: Gryphus being little used to this sort of civility on the part of Cornelius began to suspect that his prisoner was about to try and bribe him

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Cornelius was now alone once more; it was seven o'clock in the evening, and the anxiety of yesterday returned with increased intensity.
children.prevalue: Cornelius was now alone once more it was seven o clock in the evening and the anxiety of yesterday returned with increased intensity

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: But another time the hours passed away without bringing the sweet vision which lighted up, through the grated window, the cell of poor Cornelius, and which, in retiring, left light enough in his heart to last until it came back again.
children.prevalue: But another time the hours passed away without bringing the sweet vision which lighted up through the grated window the cell of poor Cornelius and which in retiring left light enough in his heart to last until it came back again

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Van Baerle passed the night in an agony of despair. On the following day Gryphus appeared to him even more hideous, brutal, and hateful than usual; in his mind, or rather in his heart, there had been some hope that it was the old man who prevented his daughter from coming.
children.prevalue: Van Baerle passed the night in an agony of despair On the following day Gryphus appeared to him even more hideous brutal and hateful than usual in his mind or rather in his heart there had been some hope that it was the old man who prevented his daughter from coming

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: In his wrath he would have strangled Gryphus, but would not this have separated him for ever from Rosa?
children.prevalue: In his wrath he would have strangled Gryphus but would not this have separated him for ever from Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: The evening closing in, his despair changed into melancholy, which was the more gloomy as, involuntarily, Van Baerle mixed up with it the thought of his poor tulip. It was now just that week in April which the most experienced gardeners point out as the precise time when tulips ought to be planted. He had said to Rosa,
children.prevalue: The evening closing in his despair changed into melancholy which was the more gloomy as involuntarily Van Baerle mixed up with it the thought of his poor tulip It was now just that week in April which the most experienced gardeners point out as the precise time when tulips ought to be planted He had said to Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: I shall tell you the day when you are to put the bulb in the ground.
children.prevalue: I shall tell you the day when you are to put the bulb in the ground

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: He had intended to fix, at the vainly hoped for interview, the following day as the time for that momentous operation. The weather was propitious; the air, though still damp, began to be tempered by those pale rays of the April sun which, being the first, appear so congenial, although so pale. How if Rosa allowed the right moment for planting the bulb to pass by,if, in addition to the grief of seeing her no more, he should have to deplore the misfortune of seeing his tulip fail on account of its having been planted too late, or of its not having been planted at all!
children.prevalue: He had intended to fix at the vainly hoped for interview the following day as the time for that momentous operation The weather was propitious the air though still damp began to be tempered by those pale rays of the April sun which being the first appear so congenial although so pale How if Rosa allowed the right moment for planting the bulb to pass by if in addition to the grief of seeing her no more he should have to deplore the misfortune of seeing his tulip fail on account of its having been planted too late or of its not having been planted at all

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: These two vexations combined might well make him leave off eating and drinking.
children.prevalue: These two vexations combined might well make him leave off eating and drinking

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: This was the case on the fourth day.
children.prevalue: This was the case on the fourth day

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: It was pitiful to see Cornelius, dumb with grief, and pale from utter prostration, stretch out his head through the iron bars of his window, at the risk of not being able to draw it back again, to try and get a glimpse of the garden on the left spoken of by Rosa, who had told him that its parapet overlooked the river. He hoped that perhaps he might see, in the light of the April sun, Rosa or the tulip, the two lost objects of his love.
children.prevalue: It was pitiful to see Cornelius dumb with grief and pale from utter prostration stretch out his head through the iron bars of his window at the risk of not being able to draw it back again to try and get a glimpse of the garden on the left spoken of by Rosa who had told him that its parapet overlooked the river He hoped that perhaps he might see in the light of the April sun Rosa or the tulip the two lost objects of his love

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: In the evening, Gryphus took away the breakfast and dinner of Cornelius, who had scarcely touched them.
children.prevalue: In the evening Gryphus took away the breakfast and dinner of Cornelius who had scarcely touched them

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: On the following day he did not touch them at all, and Gryphus carried the dishes away just as he had brought them.
children.prevalue: On the following day he did not touch them at all and Gryphus carried the dishes away just as he had brought them

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Cornelius had remained in bed the whole day.
children.prevalue: Cornelius had remained in bed the whole day

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Well, said Gryphus, coming down from the last visit, I think we shall soon get rid of our scholar.
children.prevalue: Well said Gryphus coming down from the last visit I think we shall soon get rid of our scholar

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Rosa was startled.
children.prevalue: Rosa was startled

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Nonsense! said Jacob. What do you mean?
children.prevalue: Nonsense said Jacob What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: He doesn't drink, he doesn't eat, he doesn't leave his bed. He will get out of it, like Mynheer Grotius, in a chest, only the chest will be a coffin.
children.prevalue: He doesn t drink he doesn t eat he doesn t leave his bed He will get out of it like Mynheer Grotius in a chest only the chest will be a coffin

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Rosa grew pale as death.
children.prevalue: Rosa grew pale as death

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Ah! she said to herself, he is uneasy about his tulip.
children.prevalue: Ah she said to herself he is uneasy about his tulip

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: And, rising with a heavy heart, she returned to her chamber, where she took a pen and paper, and during the whole of that night busied herself with tracing letters.
children.prevalue: And rising with a heavy heart she returned to her chamber where she took a pen and paper and during the whole of that night busied herself with tracing letters

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: On the following morning, when Cornelius got up to drag himself to the window, he perceived a paper which had been slipped under the door.
children.prevalue: On the following morning when Cornelius got up to drag himself to the window he perceived a paper which had been slipped under the door

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: He pounced upon it, opened it, and read the following words, in a handwriting which he could scarcely have recognized as that of Rosa, so much had she improved during her short absence of seven days,
children.prevalue: He pounced upon it opened it and read the following words in a handwriting which he could scarcely have recognized as that of Rosa so much had she improved during her short absence of seven days

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Be easy; your tulip is going on well.
children.prevalue: Be easy your tulip is going on well

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Although these few words of Rosa's somewhat soothed the grief of Cornelius, yet he felt not the less the irony which was at the bottom of them. Rosa, then, was not ill, she was offended; she had not been forcibly prevented from coming, but had voluntarily stayed away. Thus Rosa, being at liberty, found in her own will the force not to come and see him, who was dying with grief at not having seen her.
children.prevalue: Although these few words of Rosa s somewhat soothed the grief of Cornelius yet he felt not the less the irony which was at the bottom of them Rosa then was not ill she was offended she had not been forcibly prevented from coming but had voluntarily stayed away Thus Rosa being at liberty found in her own will the force not to come and see him who was dying with grief at not having seen her

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Cornelius had paper and a pencil which Rosa had brought to him. He guessed that she expected an answer, but that she would not come before the evening to fetch it. He therefore wrote on a piece of paper, similar to that which he had received,
children.prevalue: Cornelius had paper and a pencil which Rosa had brought to him He guessed that she expected an answer but that she would not come before the evening to fetch it He therefore wrote on a piece of paper similar to that which he had received

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: It was not my anxiety about the tulip that has made me ill, but the grief at not seeing you.
children.prevalue: It was not my anxiety about the tulip that has made me ill but the grief at not seeing you

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: After Gryphus had made his last visit of the day, and darkness had set in, he slipped the paper under the door, and listened with the most intense attention, but he neither heard Rosa's footsteps nor the rustling of her gown.
children.prevalue: After Gryphus had made his last visit of the day and darkness had set in he slipped the paper under the door and listened with the most intense attention but he neither heard Rosa s footsteps nor the rustling of her gown

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: He only heard a voice as feeble as a breath, and gentle like a caress, which whispered through the grated little window in the door the word,
children.prevalue: He only heard a voice as feeble as a breath and gentle like a caress which whispered through the grated little window in the door the word

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Tomorrow!
children.prevalue: Tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Now tomorrow was the eighth day. For eight days Cornelius and Rosa had not seen each other.
children.prevalue: Now tomorrow was the eighth day For eight days Cornelius and Rosa had not seen each other

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: On the following evening, at the usual hour, Van Baerle heard some one scratch at the grated little window, just as Rosa had been in the habit of doing in the heyday of their friendship.
children.prevalue: On the following evening at the usual hour Van Baerle heard some one scratch at the grated little window just as Rosa had been in the habit of doing in the heyday of their friendship

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Cornelius being, as may easily be imagined, not far off from the door, perceived Rosa, who at last was waiting again for him with her lamp in her hand.
children.prevalue: Cornelius being as may easily be imagined not far off from the door perceived Rosa who at last was waiting again for him with her lamp in her hand

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Seeing him so sad and pale, she was startled, and said,
children.prevalue: Seeing him so sad and pale she was startled and said

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: You are ill, Mynheer Cornelius?
children.prevalue: You are ill Mynheer Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Yes, I am, he answered, as indeed he was suffering in mind and in body.
children.prevalue: Yes I am he answered as indeed he was suffering in mind and in body

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: I saw that you did not eat, said Rosa; my father told me that you remained in bed all day. I then wrote to calm your uneasiness concerning the fate of the most precious object of your anxiety.
children.prevalue: I saw that you did not eat said Rosa my father told me that you remained in bed all day I then wrote to calm your uneasiness concerning the fate of the most precious object of your anxiety

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: And I, said Cornelius, I have answered. Seeing your return, my dear Rosa, I thought you had received my letter.
children.prevalue: And I said Cornelius I have answered Seeing your return my dear Rosa I thought you had received my letter

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: It is true; I have received it.
children.prevalue: It is true I have received it

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: You cannot this time excuse yourself with not being able to read. Not only do you read very fluently, but also you have made marvellous progress in writing.
children.prevalue: You cannot this time excuse yourself with not being able to read Not only do you read very fluently but also you have made marvellous progress in writing

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Indeed, I have not only received, but also read your note. Accordingly I am come to see whether there might not be some remedy to restore you to health.
children.prevalue: Indeed I have not only received but also read your note Accordingly I am come to see whether there might not be some remedy to restore you to health

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Restore me to health? cried Cornelius; but have you any good news to communicate to me?
children.prevalue: Restore me to health cried Cornelius but have you any good news to communicate to me

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Saying this, the poor prisoner looked at Rosa, his eyes sparkling with hope.
children.prevalue: Saying this the poor prisoner looked at Rosa his eyes sparkling with hope

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Whether she did not, or would not, understand this look, Rosa answered gravely,
children.prevalue: Whether she did not or would not understand this look Rosa answered gravely

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I have only to speak to you about your tulip, which, as I well know, is the object uppermost in your mind.
children.prevalue: I have only to speak to you about your tulip which as I well know is the object uppermost in your mind

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Rosa pronounced those few words in a freezing tone, which cut deeply into the heart of Cornelius. He did not suspect what lay hidden under this appearance of indifference with which the poor girl affected to speak of her rival, the black tulip.
children.prevalue: Rosa pronounced those few words in a freezing tone which cut deeply into the heart of Cornelius He did not suspect what lay hidden under this appearance of indifference with which the poor girl affected to speak of her rival the black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Oh! muttered Cornelius, again! again! Have I not told you, Rosa, that I thought but of you? that it was you alone whom I regretted, you whom I missed, you whose absence I felt more than the loss of liberty and of life itself?
children.prevalue: Oh muttered Cornelius again again Have I not told you Rosa that I thought but of you that it was you alone whom I regretted you whom I missed you whose absence I felt more than the loss of liberty and of life itself

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Rosa smiled with a melancholy air.
children.prevalue: Rosa smiled with a melancholy air

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Ah! she said, your tulip has been in such danger.
children.prevalue: Ah she said your tulip has been in such danger

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Cornelius trembled involuntarily, and showed himself clearly to be caught in the trap, if ever the remark was meant as such.
children.prevalue: Cornelius trembled involuntarily and showed himself clearly to be caught in the trap if ever the remark was meant as such

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Danger! he cried, quite alarmed; what danger?
children.prevalue: Danger he cried quite alarmed what danger

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Rosa looked at him with gentle compassion; she felt that what she wished was beyond the power of this man, and that he must be taken as he was, with his little foible.
children.prevalue: Rosa looked at him with gentle compassion she felt that what she wished was beyond the power of this man and that he must be taken as he was with his little foible

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Yes, she said, you have guessed the truth; that suitor and amorous swain, Jacob, did not come on my account.
children.prevalue: Yes she said you have guessed the truth that suitor and amorous swain Jacob did not come on my account

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: And what did he come for? Cornelius anxiously asked.
children.prevalue: And what did he come for Cornelius anxiously asked

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: He came for the sake of the tulip.
children.prevalue: He came for the sake of the tulip

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Alas! said Cornelius, growing even paler at this piece of information than he had been when Rosa, a fortnight before, had told him that Jacob was coming for her sake.
children.prevalue: Alas said Cornelius growing even paler at this piece of information than he had been when Rosa a fortnight before had told him that Jacob was coming for her sake

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Rosa saw this alarm, and Cornelius guessed, from the expression of her face, in what direction her thoughts were running.
children.prevalue: Rosa saw this alarm and Cornelius guessed from the expression of her face in what direction her thoughts were running

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Oh, pardon me, Rosa! he said, I know you, and I am well aware of the kindness and sincerity of your heart. To you God has given the thought and strength for defending yourself; but to my poor tulip, when it is in danger, God has given nothing of the sort.
children.prevalue: Oh pardon me Rosa he said I know you and I am well aware of the kindness and sincerity of your heart To you God has given the thought and strength for defending yourself but to my poor tulip when it is in danger God has given nothing of the sort

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Rosa, without replying to this excuse of the prisoner, continued,
children.prevalue: Rosa without replying to this excuse of the prisoner continued

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: From the moment when I first knew that you were uneasy on account of the man who followed me, and in whom I had recognized Jacob, I was even more uneasy myself. On the day, therefore, after that on which I saw you last, and on which you said
children.prevalue: From the moment when I first knew that you were uneasy on account of the man who followed me and in whom I had recognized Jacob I was even more uneasy myself On the day therefore after that on which I saw you last and on which you said

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Cornelius interrupted her.
children.prevalue: Cornelius interrupted her

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Once more, pardon me, Rosa! he cried. I was wrong in saying to you what I said. I have asked your pardon for that unfortunate speech before. I ask it again: shall I always ask it in vain?
children.prevalue: Once more pardon me Rosa he cried I was wrong in saying to you what I said I have asked your pardon for that unfortunate speech before I ask it again shall I always ask it in vain

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: On the following day, Rosa continued, remembering what you had told me about the stratagem which I was to employ to ascertain whether that odious man was after the tulip, or after me
children.prevalue: On the following day Rosa continued remembering what you had told me about the stratagem which I was to employ to ascertain whether that odious man was after the tulip or after me

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Yes, yes, odious. Tell me, he said, do you hate that man?
children.prevalue: Yes yes odious Tell me he said do you hate that man

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I do hate him, said Rosa, as he is the cause of all the unhappiness I have suffered these eight days.
children.prevalue: I do hate him said Rosa as he is the cause of all the unhappiness I have suffered these eight days

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: You, too, have been unhappy, Rosa? I thank you a thousand times for this kind confession.
children.prevalue: You too have been unhappy Rosa I thank you a thousand times for this kind confession

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Well, on the day after that unfortunate one, I went down into the garden and proceeded towards the border where I was to plant your tulip, looking round all the while to see whether I was again followed as I was last time.
children.prevalue: Well on the day after that unfortunate one I went down into the garden and proceeded towards the border where I was to plant your tulip looking round all the while to see whether I was again followed as I was last time

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: And then? Cornelius asked.
children.prevalue: And then Cornelius asked

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: And then the same shadow glided between the gate and the wall, and once more disappeared behind the eldertrees.
children.prevalue: And then the same shadow glided between the gate and the wall and once more disappeared behind the eldertrees

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: You feigned not to see him, didn't you? Cornelius asked, remembering all the details of the advice which he had given to Rosa.
children.prevalue: You feigned not to see him didn t you Cornelius asked remembering all the details of the advice which he had given to Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Yes, and I stooped over the border, in which I dug with a spade, as if I was going to put the bulb in.
children.prevalue: Yes and I stooped over the border in which I dug with a spade as if I was going to put the bulb in

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: And he,what did he do during all this time?
children.prevalue: And he what did he do during all this time

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I saw his eyes glisten through the branches of the tree like those of a tiger.
children.prevalue: I saw his eyes glisten through the branches of the tree like those of a tiger

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: There you see, there you see! cried Cornelius.
children.prevalue: There you see there you see cried Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Then, after having finished my makebelieve work, I retired.
children.prevalue: Then after having finished my makebelieve work I retired

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: But only behind the garden door, I dare say, so that you might see through the keyhole what he was going to do when you had left?
children.prevalue: But only behind the garden door I dare say so that you might see through the keyhole what he was going to do when you had left

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: He waited for a moment, very likely to make sure of my not coming back, after which he sneaked forth from his hidingplace, and approached the border by a long roundabout; at last, having reached his goal, that is to say, the spot where the ground was newly turned, he stopped with a careless air, looking about in all directions, and scanning every corner of the garden, every window of the neighbouring houses, and even the sky; after which, thinking himself quite alone, quite isolated, and out of everybody's sight, he pounced upon the border, plunged both his hands into the soft soil, took a handful of the mould, which he gently frittered between his fingers to see whether the bulb was in it, and repeated the same thing twice or three times, until at last he perceived that he was outwitted. Then, keeping down the agitation which was raging in his breast, he took up the rake, smoothed the ground, so as to leave it on his retiring in the same state as he had found it, and, quite abashed and rueful, walked back to the door, affecting the unconcerned air of an ordinary visitor of the garden.
children.prevalue: He waited for a moment very likely to make sure of my not coming back after which he sneaked forth from his hidingplace and approached the border by a long roundabout at last having reached his goal that is to say the spot where the ground was newly turned he stopped with a careless air looking about in all directions and scanning every corner of the garden every window of the neighbouring houses and even the sky after which thinking himself quite alone quite isolated and out of everybody s sight he pounced upon the border plunged both his hands into the soft soil took a handful of the mould which he gently frittered between his fingers to see whether the bulb was in it and repeated the same thing twice or three times until at last he perceived that he was outwitted Then keeping down the agitation which was raging in his breast he took up the rake smoothed the ground so as to leave it on his retiring in the same state as he had found it and quite abashed and rueful walked back to the door affecting the unconcerned air of an ordinary visitor of the garden

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Oh, the wretch! muttered Cornelius, wiping the cold sweat from his brow. Oh, the wretch! I guessed his intentions. But the bulb, Rosa; what have you done with it? It is already rather late to plant it.
children.prevalue: Oh the wretch muttered Cornelius wiping the cold sweat from his brow Oh the wretch I guessed his intentions But the bulb Rosa what have you done with it It is already rather late to plant it

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The bulb? It has been in the ground for these six days.
children.prevalue: The bulb It has been in the ground for these six days

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Where? and how? cried Cornelius. Good Heaven, what imprudence! What is it? In what sort of soil is it? In what aspect? Good or bad? Is there no risk of having it filched by that detestable Jacob?
children.prevalue: Where and how cried Cornelius Good Heaven what imprudence What is it In what sort of soil is it In what aspect Good or bad Is there no risk of having it filched by that detestable Jacob

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: There is no danger of its being stolen, said Rosa, unless Jacob will force the door of my chamber.
children.prevalue: There is no danger of its being stolen said Rosa unless Jacob will force the door of my chamber

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Oh! then it is with you in your bedroom? said Cornelius, somewhat relieved. But in what soil? in what vessel? You don't let it grow, I hope, in water like those good ladies of Haarlem and Dort, who imagine that water could replace the earth?
children.prevalue: Oh then it is with you in your bedroom said Cornelius somewhat relieved But in what soil in what vessel You don t let it grow I hope in water like those good ladies of Haarlem and Dort who imagine that water could replace the earth

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: You may make yourself comfortable on that score, said Rosa, smiling; your bulb is not growing in water.
children.prevalue: You may make yourself comfortable on that score said Rosa smiling your bulb is not growing in water

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: I breathe again.
children.prevalue: I breathe again

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: It is in a good, sound stone pot, just about the size of the jug in which you had planted yours. The soil is composed of three parts of common mould, taken from the best spot of the garden, and one of the sweepings of the road. I have heard you and that detestable Jacob, as you call him, so often talk about what is the soil best fitted for growing tulips, that I know it as well as the first gardener of Haarlem.
children.prevalue: It is in a good sound stone pot just about the size of the jug in which you had planted yours The soil is composed of three parts of common mould taken from the best spot of the garden and one of the sweepings of the road I have heard you and that detestable Jacob as you call him so often talk about what is the soil best fitted for growing tulips that I know it as well as the first gardener of Haarlem

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: And now what is the aspect, Rosa?
children.prevalue: And now what is the aspect Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: At present it has the sun all day long,that is to say when the sun shines. But when it once peeps out of the ground, I shall do as you have done here, dear Mynheer Cornelius: I shall put it out of my window on the eastern side from eight in the morning until eleven and in my window towards the west from three to five in the afternoon.
children.prevalue: At present it has the sun all day long that is to say when the sun shines But when it once peeps out of the ground I shall do as you have done here dear Mynheer Cornelius I shall put it out of my window on the eastern side from eight in the morning until eleven and in my window towards the west from three to five in the afternoon

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: That's it! that's it! cried Cornelius; and you are a perfect gardener, my pretty Rosa. But I am afraid the nursing of my tulip will take up all your time.
children.prevalue: That s it that s it cried Cornelius and you are a perfect gardener my pretty Rosa But I am afraid the nursing of my tulip will take up all your time

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Yes, it will, said Rosa; but never mind. Your tulip is my daughter. I shall devote to it the same time as I should to a child of mine, if I were a mother. Only by becoming its mother, Rosa added, smilingly, can I cease to be its rival.
children.prevalue: Yes it will said Rosa but never mind Your tulip is my daughter I shall devote to it the same time as I should to a child of mine if I were a mother Only by becoming its mother Rosa added smilingly can I cease to be its rival

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: My kind and pretty Rosa! muttered Cornelius casting on her a glance in which there was much more of the lover than of the gardener, and which afforded Rosa some consolation.
children.prevalue: My kind and pretty Rosa muttered Cornelius casting on her a glance in which there was much more of the lover than of the gardener and which afforded Rosa some consolation

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Then, after a silence of some moments, during which Cornelius had grasped through the openings of the grating for the receding hand of Rosa, he said,
children.prevalue: Then after a silence of some moments during which Cornelius had grasped through the openings of the grating for the receding hand of Rosa he said

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Do you mean to say that the bulb has now been in the ground for six days?
children.prevalue: Do you mean to say that the bulb has now been in the ground for six days

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Yes, six days, Mynheer Cornelius, she answered.
children.prevalue: Yes six days Mynheer Cornelius she answered

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: And it does not yet show leaf?
children.prevalue: And it does not yet show leaf

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: No, but I think it will tomorrow.
children.prevalue: No but I think it will tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Well, then, tomorrow you will bring me news about it, and about yourself, won't you, Rosa? I care very much for the daughter, as you called it just now, but I care even much more for the mother.
children.prevalue: Well then tomorrow you will bring me news about it and about yourself won t you Rosa I care very much for the daughter as you called it just now but I care even much more for the mother

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Tomorrow? said Rosa, looking at Cornelius askance. I don't know whether I shall be able to come tomorrow.
children.prevalue: Tomorrow said Rosa looking at Cornelius askance I don t know whether I shall be able to come tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Good heavens! said Cornelius, why can't you come tomorrow?
children.prevalue: Good heavens said Cornelius why can t you come tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Mynheer Cornelius, I have lots of things to do.
children.prevalue: Mynheer Cornelius I have lots of things to do

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: And I have only one, muttered Cornelius.
children.prevalue: And I have only one muttered Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Yes, said Rosa, to love your tulip.
children.prevalue: Yes said Rosa to love your tulip

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: To love you, Rosa.
children.prevalue: To love you Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Rosa shook her head, after which followed a pause.
children.prevalue: Rosa shook her head after which followed a pause

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Well,Cornelius at last broke the silence,well, Rosa, everything changes in the realm of nature; the flowers of spring are succeeded by other flowers; and the bees, which so tenderly caressed the violets and the wallflowers, will flutter with just as much love about the honeysuckles, the rose, the jessamine, and the carnation.
children.prevalue: Well Cornelius at last broke the silence well Rosa everything changes in the realm of nature the flowers of spring are succeeded by other flowers and the bees which so tenderly caressed the violets and the wallflowers will flutter with just as much love about the honeysuckles the rose the jessamine and the carnation

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: What does all this mean? asked Rosa.
children.prevalue: What does all this mean asked Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: You have abandoned me, Miss Rosa, to seek your pleasure elsewhere. You have done well, and I will not complain. What claim have I to your fidelity?
children.prevalue: You have abandoned me Miss Rosa to seek your pleasure elsewhere You have done well and I will not complain What claim have I to your fidelity

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: My fidelity! Rosa exclaimed, with her eyes full of tears, and without caring any longer to hide from Cornelius this dew of pearls dropping on her cheeks, my fidelity! have I not been faithful to you?
children.prevalue: My fidelity Rosa exclaimed with her eyes full of tears and without caring any longer to hide from Cornelius this dew of pearls dropping on her cheeks my fidelity have I not been faithful to you

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Do you call it faithful to desert me, and to leave me here to die?
children.prevalue: Do you call it faithful to desert me and to leave me here to die

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: But, Mynheer Cornelius, said Rosa, am I not doing everything for you that could give you pleasure? have I not devoted myself to your tulip?
children.prevalue: But Mynheer Cornelius said Rosa am I not doing everything for you that could give you pleasure have I not devoted myself to your tulip

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: You are bitter, Rosa, you reproach me with the only unalloyed pleasure which I have had in this world.
children.prevalue: You are bitter Rosa you reproach me with the only unalloyed pleasure which I have had in this world

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: I reproach you with nothing, Mynheer Cornelius, except, perhaps, with the intense grief which I felt when people came to tell me at the Buytenhof that you were about to be put to death.
children.prevalue: I reproach you with nothing Mynheer Cornelius except perhaps with the intense grief which I felt when people came to tell me at the Buytenhof that you were about to be put to death

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: You are displeased, Rosa, my sweet girl, with my loving flowers.
children.prevalue: You are displeased Rosa my sweet girl with my loving flowers

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: I am not displeased with your loving them, Mynheer Cornelius, only it makes me sad to think that you love them better than you do me.
children.prevalue: I am not displeased with your loving them Mynheer Cornelius only it makes me sad to think that you love them better than you do me

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Oh, my dear, dear Rosa! look how my hands tremble; look at my pale cheek, hear how my heart beats. It is for you, my love, not for the black tulip. Destroy the bulb, destroy the germ of that flower, extinguish the gentle light of that innocent and delightful dream, to which I have accustomed myself; but love me, Rosa, love me; for I feel deeply that I love but you.
children.prevalue: Oh my dear dear Rosa look how my hands tremble look at my pale cheek hear how my heart beats It is for you my love not for the black tulip Destroy the bulb destroy the germ of that flower extinguish the gentle light of that innocent and delightful dream to which I have accustomed myself but love me Rosa love me for I feel deeply that I love but you

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Yes, after the black tulip, sighed Rosa, who at last no longer coyly withdrew her warm hands from the grating, as Cornelius most affectionately kissed them.
children.prevalue: Yes after the black tulip sighed Rosa who at last no longer coyly withdrew her warm hands from the grating as Cornelius most affectionately kissed them

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Above and before everything in this world, Rosa.
children.prevalue: Above and before everything in this world Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: May I believe you?
children.prevalue: May I believe you

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: As you believe in your own existence.
children.prevalue: As you believe in your own existence

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Well, then, be it so; but loving me does not bind you too much.
children.prevalue: Well then be it so but loving me does not bind you too much

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Unfortunately, it does not bind me more than I am bound; but it binds you, Rosa, you.
children.prevalue: Unfortunately it does not bind me more than I am bound but it binds you Rosa you

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: To what?
children.prevalue: To what

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: First of all, not to marry.
children.prevalue: First of all not to marry

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: She smiled.
children.prevalue: She smiled

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: That's your way, she said; you are tyrants all of you. You worship a certain beauty, you think of nothing but her. Then you are condemned to death, and whilst walking to the scaffold, you devote to her your last sigh; and now you expect poor me to sacrifice to you all my dreams and my happiness.
children.prevalue: That s your way she said you are tyrants all of you You worship a certain beauty you think of nothing but her Then you are condemned to death and whilst walking to the scaffold you devote to her your last sigh and now you expect poor me to sacrifice to you all my dreams and my happiness

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: But who is the beauty you are talking of, Rosa? said Cornelius, trying in vain to remember a woman to whom Rosa might possibly be alluding.
children.prevalue: But who is the beauty you are talking of Rosa said Cornelius trying in vain to remember a woman to whom Rosa might possibly be alluding

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: The dark beauty with a slender waist, small feet, and a noble head; in short, I am speaking of your flower.
children.prevalue: The dark beauty with a slender waist small feet and a noble head in short I am speaking of your flower

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Cornelius smiled.
children.prevalue: Cornelius smiled

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: That is an imaginary lady love, at all events; whereas, without counting that amorous Jacob, you by your own account are surrounded with all sorts of swains eager to make love to you. Do you remember Rosa, what you told me of the students, officers, and clerks of the Hague? Are there no clerks, officers, or students at Loewestein?
children.prevalue: That is an imaginary lady love at all events whereas without counting that amorous Jacob you by your own account are surrounded with all sorts of swains eager to make love to you Do you remember Rosa what you told me of the students officers and clerks of the Hague Are there no clerks officers or students at Loewestein

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Indeed there are, and lots of them.
children.prevalue: Indeed there are and lots of them

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Who write letters?
children.prevalue: Who write letters

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: They do write.
children.prevalue: They do write

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: And now, as you know how to read
children.prevalue: And now as you know how to read

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Here Cornelius heaved a sigh at the thought, that, poor captive as he was, to him alone Rosa owed the faculty of reading the loveletters which she received.
children.prevalue: Here Cornelius heaved a sigh at the thought that poor captive as he was to him alone Rosa owed the faculty of reading the loveletters which she received

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: As to that, said Rosa, I think that in reading the notes addressed to me, and passing the different swains in review who send them to me, I am only following your instructions.
children.prevalue: As to that said Rosa I think that in reading the notes addressed to me and passing the different swains in review who send them to me I am only following your instructions

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: How so? My instructions?
children.prevalue: How so My instructions

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Indeed, your instructions, sir, said Rosa, sighing in her turn; have you forgotten the will written by your hand on the Bible of Cornelius de Witt? I have not forgotten it; for now, as I know how to read, I read it every day over and over again. In that will you bid me to love and marry a handsome young man of twentysix or eight years. I am on the lookout for that young man, and as the whole of my day is taken up with your tulip, you must needs leave me the evenings to find him.
children.prevalue: Indeed your instructions sir said Rosa sighing in her turn have you forgotten the will written by your hand on the Bible of Cornelius de Witt I have not forgotten it for now as I know how to read I read it every day over and over again In that will you bid me to love and marry a handsome young man of twentysix or eight years I am on the lookout for that young man and as the whole of my day is taken up with your tulip you must needs leave me the evenings to find him

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: But, Rosa, the will was made in the expectation of death, and, thanks to Heaven, I am still alive.
children.prevalue: But Rosa the will was made in the expectation of death and thanks to Heaven I am still alive

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Well, then, I shall not be after the handsome young man, and I shall come to see you.
children.prevalue: Well then I shall not be after the handsome young man and I shall come to see you

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: That's it, Rosa, come! come!
children.prevalue: That s it Rosa come come

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Under one condition.
children.prevalue: Under one condition

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Granted beforehand!
children.prevalue: Granted beforehand

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: That the black tulip shall not be mentioned for the next three days.
children.prevalue: That the black tulip shall not be mentioned for the next three days

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: It shall never be mentioned any more, if you wish it, Rosa.
children.prevalue: It shall never be mentioned any more if you wish it Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: No, no, the damsel said, laughing, I will not ask for impossibilities.
children.prevalue: No no the damsel said laughing I will not ask for impossibilities

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: And, saying this, she brought her fresh cheek, as if unconsciously, so near the iron grating, that Cornelius was able to touch it with his lips.
children.prevalue: And saying this she brought her fresh cheek as if unconsciously so near the iron grating that Cornelius was able to touch it with his lips

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Rosa uttered a little scream, which, however, was full of love, and disappeared.
children.prevalue: Rosa uttered a little scream which however was full of love and disappeared

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The night was a happy one, and the whole of the next day happier still.
children.prevalue: The night was a happy one and the whole of the next day happier still

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: During the last few days, the prison had been heavy, dark, and lowering, as it were, with all its weight on the unfortunate captive. Its walls were black, its air chilling, the iron bars seemed to exclude every ray of light.
children.prevalue: During the last few days the prison had been heavy dark and lowering as it were with all its weight on the unfortunate captive Its walls were black its air chilling the iron bars seemed to exclude every ray of light

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: But when Cornelius awoke next morning, a beam of the morning sun was playing about those iron bars; pigeons were hovering about with outspread wings, whilst others were lovingly cooing on the roof or near the still closed window.
children.prevalue: But when Cornelius awoke next morning a beam of the morning sun was playing about those iron bars pigeons were hovering about with outspread wings whilst others were lovingly cooing on the roof or near the still closed window

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Cornelius ran to that window and opened it; it seemed to him as if new life, and joy, and liberty itself were entering with this sunbeam into his cell, which, so dreary of late, was now cheered and irradiated by the light of love.
children.prevalue: Cornelius ran to that window and opened it it seemed to him as if new life and joy and liberty itself were entering with this sunbeam into his cell which so dreary of late was now cheered and irradiated by the light of love

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: When Gryphus, therefore, came to see his prisoner in the morning, he no longer found him morose and lying in bed, but standing at the window, and singing a little ditty.
children.prevalue: When Gryphus therefore came to see his prisoner in the morning he no longer found him morose and lying in bed but standing at the window and singing a little ditty

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Halloa! exclaimed the jailer.
children.prevalue: Halloa exclaimed the jailer

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: How are you this morning? asked Cornelius.
children.prevalue: How are you this morning asked Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Gryphus looked at him with a scowl.
children.prevalue: Gryphus looked at him with a scowl

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: And how is the dog, and Master Jacob, and our pretty Rosa?
children.prevalue: And how is the dog and Master Jacob and our pretty Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Gryphus ground his teeth, saying.
children.prevalue: Gryphus ground his teeth saying

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Here is your breakfast.
children.prevalue: Here is your breakfast

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Thank you, friend Cerberus, said the prisoner; you are just in time; I am very hungry.
children.prevalue: Thank you friend Cerberus said the prisoner you are just in time I am very hungry

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Oh! you are hungry, are you? said Gryphus.
children.prevalue: Oh you are hungry are you said Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: And why not? asked Van Baerle.
children.prevalue: And why not asked Van Baerle

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The conspiracy seems to thrive, remarked Gryphus.
children.prevalue: The conspiracy seems to thrive remarked Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: What conspiracy?
children.prevalue: What conspiracy

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Very well, I know what I know, Master Scholar; just be quiet, we shall be on our guard.
children.prevalue: Very well I know what I know Master Scholar just be quiet we shall be on our guard

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Be on your guard, friend Gryphus; be on your guard as long as you please; my conspiracy, as well as my person, is entirely at your service.
children.prevalue: Be on your guard friend Gryphus be on your guard as long as you please my conspiracy as well as my person is entirely at your service

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: We'll see that at noon.
children.prevalue: We ll see that at noon

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Saying this, Gryphus went out.
children.prevalue: Saying this Gryphus went out

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: At noon? repeated Cornelius; what does that mean? Well, let us wait until the clock strikes twelve, and we shall see.
children.prevalue: At noon repeated Cornelius what does that mean Well let us wait until the clock strikes twelve and we shall see

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: It was very easy for Cornelius to wait for twelve at midday, as he was already waiting for nine at night.
children.prevalue: It was very easy for Cornelius to wait for twelve at midday as he was already waiting for nine at night

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: It struck twelve, and there were heard on the staircase not only the steps of Gryphus, but also those of three or four soldiers, who were coming up with him.
children.prevalue: It struck twelve and there were heard on the staircase not only the steps of Gryphus but also those of three or four soldiers who were coming up with him

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The door opened. Gryphus entered, led his men in, and shut the door after them.
children.prevalue: The door opened Gryphus entered led his men in and shut the door after them

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: There, now search!
children.prevalue: There now search

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: They searched not only the pockets of Cornelius, but even his person; yet they found nothing.
children.prevalue: They searched not only the pockets of Cornelius but even his person yet they found nothing

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: They then searched the sheets, the mattress, and the straw mattress of his bed; and again they found nothing.
children.prevalue: They then searched the sheets the mattress and the straw mattress of his bed and again they found nothing

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Now, Cornelius rejoiced that he had not taken the third sucker under his own care. Gryphus would have been sure to ferret it out in the search, and would then have treated it as he did the first.
children.prevalue: Now Cornelius rejoiced that he had not taken the third sucker under his own care Gryphus would have been sure to ferret it out in the search and would then have treated it as he did the first

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: And certainly never did prisoner look with greater complacency at a search made in his cell than Cornelius.
children.prevalue: And certainly never did prisoner look with greater complacency at a search made in his cell than Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Gryphus retired with the pencil and the two or three leaves of white paper which Rosa had given to Van Baerle, this was the only trophy brought back from the expedition.
children.prevalue: Gryphus retired with the pencil and the two or three leaves of white paper which Rosa had given to Van Baerle this was the only trophy brought back from the expedition

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: At six Gryphus came back again, but alone; Cornelius tried to propitiate him, but Gryphus growled, showed a large tooth like a tusk, which he had in the corner of his mouth, and went out backwards, like a man who is afraid of being attacked from behind.
children.prevalue: At six Gryphus came back again but alone Cornelius tried to propitiate him but Gryphus growled showed a large tooth like a tusk which he had in the corner of his mouth and went out backwards like a man who is afraid of being attacked from behind

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Cornelius burst out laughing, to which Gryphus answered through the grating,
children.prevalue: Cornelius burst out laughing to which Gryphus answered through the grating

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Let him laugh that wins.
children.prevalue: Let him laugh that wins

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The winner that day was Cornelius; Rosa came at nine.
children.prevalue: The winner that day was Cornelius Rosa came at nine

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: She was without a lantern. She needed no longer a light, as she could now read. Moreover, the light might betray her, as Jacob was dogging her steps more than ever. And lastly, the light would have shown her blushes.
children.prevalue: She was without a lantern She needed no longer a light as she could now read Moreover the light might betray her as Jacob was dogging her steps more than ever And lastly the light would have shown her blushes

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Of what did the young people speak that evening? Of those matters of which lovers speak at the house doors in France, or from a balcony into the street in Spain, or down from a terrace into a garden in the East.
children.prevalue: Of what did the young people speak that evening Of those matters of which lovers speak at the house doors in France or from a balcony into the street in Spain or down from a terrace into a garden in the East

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: They spoke of those things which give wings to the hours; they spoke of everything except the black tulip.
children.prevalue: They spoke of those things which give wings to the hours they spoke of everything except the black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: At last, when the clock struck ten, they parted as usual.
children.prevalue: At last when the clock struck ten they parted as usual

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Cornelius was happy, as thoroughly happy as a tulipfancier would be to whom one has not spoken of his tulip.
children.prevalue: Cornelius was happy as thoroughly happy as a tulipfancier would be to whom one has not spoken of his tulip

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: He found Rosa pretty, good, graceful, and charming.
children.prevalue: He found Rosa pretty good graceful and charming

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: But why did Rosa object to the tulip being spoken of?
children.prevalue: But why did Rosa object to the tulip being spoken of

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: This was indeed a great defect in Rosa.
children.prevalue: This was indeed a great defect in Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Cornelius confessed to himself, sighing, that woman was not perfect.
children.prevalue: Cornelius confessed to himself sighing that woman was not perfect

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Part of the night he thought of this imperfection; that is to say, so long as he was awake he thought of Rosa.
children.prevalue: Part of the night he thought of this imperfection that is to say so long as he was awake he thought of Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: After having fallen asleep, he dreamed of her.
children.prevalue: After having fallen asleep he dreamed of her

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: But the Rosa of his dreams was by far more perfect than the Rosa of real life. Not only did the Rosa of his dreams speak of the tulip, but also brought to him a black one in a china vase.
children.prevalue: But the Rosa of his dreams was by far more perfect than the Rosa of real life Not only did the Rosa of his dreams speak of the tulip but also brought to him a black one in a china vase

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Cornelius then awoke, trembling with joy, and muttering,
children.prevalue: Cornelius then awoke trembling with joy and muttering

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Rosa, Rosa, I love you.
children.prevalue: Rosa Rosa I love you

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: And as it was already day, he thought it right not to fall asleep again, and he continued following up the line of thought in which his mind was engaged when he awoke.
children.prevalue: And as it was already day he thought it right not to fall asleep again and he continued following up the line of thought in which his mind was engaged when he awoke

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Ah! if Rosa had only conversed about the tulip, Cornelius would have preferred her to Queen Semiramis, to Queen Cleopatra, to Queen Elizabeth, to Queen Anne of Austria; that is to say, to the greatest or most beautiful queens whom the world has seen.
children.prevalue: Ah if Rosa had only conversed about the tulip Cornelius would have preferred her to Queen Semiramis to Queen Cleopatra to Queen Elizabeth to Queen Anne of Austria that is to say to the greatest or most beautiful queens whom the world has seen

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: But Rosa had forbidden it under pain of not returning; Rosa had forbidden the least mention of the tulip for three days. That meant seventytwo hours given to the lover to be sure; but it was seventytwo hours stolen from the horticulturist.
children.prevalue: But Rosa had forbidden it under pain of not returning Rosa had forbidden the least mention of the tulip for three days That meant seventytwo hours given to the lover to be sure but it was seventytwo hours stolen from the horticulturist

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: There was one consolation: of the seventytwo hours during which Rosa would not allow the tulip to be mentioned, thirtysix had passed already; and the remaining thirtysix would pass quickly enough: eighteen with waiting for the evening's interview, and eighteen with rejoicing in its remembrance.
children.prevalue: There was one consolation of the seventytwo hours during which Rosa would not allow the tulip to be mentioned thirtysix had passed already and the remaining thirtysix would pass quickly enough eighteen with waiting for the evening s interview and eighteen with rejoicing in its remembrance

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Rosa came at the same hour, and Cornelius submitted most heroically to the pangs which the compulsory silence concerning the tulip gave him.
children.prevalue: Rosa came at the same hour and Cornelius submitted most heroically to the pangs which the compulsory silence concerning the tulip gave him

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: His fair visitor, however, was well aware that, to command on the one point, people must yield on another; she therefore no longer drew back her hands from the grating, and even allowed Cornelius tenderly to kiss her beautiful golden tresses.
children.prevalue: His fair visitor however was well aware that to command on the one point people must yield on another she therefore no longer drew back her hands from the grating and even allowed Cornelius tenderly to kiss her beautiful golden tresses

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Poor girl! she had no idea that these playful little lovers' tricks were much more dangerous than speaking of the tulip was; but she became aware of the fact as she returned with a beating heart, with glowing cheeks, dry lips, and moist eyes.
children.prevalue: Poor girl she had no idea that these playful little lovers tricks were much more dangerous than speaking of the tulip was but she became aware of the fact as she returned with a beating heart with glowing cheeks dry lips and moist eyes

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: And on the following evening, after the first exchange of salutations, she retired a step, looking at him with a glance, the expression of which would have rejoiced his heart could he but have seen it.
children.prevalue: And on the following evening after the first exchange of salutations she retired a step looking at him with a glance the expression of which would have rejoiced his heart could he but have seen it

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Well, she said, she is up.
children.prevalue: Well she said she is up

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: She is up! Who? What? asked Cornelius, who did not venture on a belief that Rosa would, of her own accord, have abridged the term of his probation.
children.prevalue: She is up Who What asked Cornelius who did not venture on a belief that Rosa would of her own accord have abridged the term of his probation

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: She? Well, my daughter, the tulip, said Rosa.
children.prevalue: She Well my daughter the tulip said Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: What! cried Cornelius, you give me permission, then?
children.prevalue: What cried Cornelius you give me permission then

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: I do, said Rosa, with the tone of an affectionate mother who grants a pleasure to her child.
children.prevalue: I do said Rosa with the tone of an affectionate mother who grants a pleasure to her child

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Ah, Rosa! said Cornelius, putting his lips to the grating with the hope of touching a cheek, a hand, a forehead,anything, in short.
children.prevalue: Ah Rosa said Cornelius putting his lips to the grating with the hope of touching a cheek a hand a forehead anything in short

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: He touched something much better,two warm and half open lips.
children.prevalue: He touched something much better two warm and half open lips

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Rosa uttered a slight scream.
children.prevalue: Rosa uttered a slight scream

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Cornelius understood that he must make haste to continue the conversation. He guessed that this unexpected kiss had frightened Rosa.
children.prevalue: Cornelius understood that he must make haste to continue the conversation He guessed that this unexpected kiss had frightened Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Is it growing up straight?
children.prevalue: Is it growing up straight

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Straight as a rocket, said Rosa.
children.prevalue: Straight as a rocket said Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: How high?
children.prevalue: How high

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: At least two inches.
children.prevalue: At least two inches

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Oh, Rosa, take good care of it, and we shall soon see it grow quickly.
children.prevalue: Oh Rosa take good care of it and we shall soon see it grow quickly

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Can I take more care of it? said she. Indeed, I think of nothing else but the tulip.
children.prevalue: Can I take more care of it said she Indeed I think of nothing else but the tulip

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Of nothing else, Rosa? Why, now I shall grow jealous in my turn.
children.prevalue: Of nothing else Rosa Why now I shall grow jealous in my turn

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Oh, you know that to think of the tulip is to think of you; I never lose sight of it. I see it from my bed, on awaking it is the first object that meets my eyes, and on falling asleep the last on which they rest. During the day I sit and work by its side, for I have never left my chamber since I put it there.
children.prevalue: Oh you know that to think of the tulip is to think of you I never lose sight of it I see it from my bed on awaking it is the first object that meets my eyes and on falling asleep the last on which they rest During the day I sit and work by its side for I have never left my chamber since I put it there

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: You are right Rosa, it is your dowry, you know.
children.prevalue: You are right Rosa it is your dowry you know

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Yes, and with it I may marry a young man of twentysix or twentyeight years, whom I shall be in love with.
children.prevalue: Yes and with it I may marry a young man of twentysix or twentyeight years whom I shall be in love with

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Don't talk in that way, you naughty girl.
children.prevalue: Don t talk in that way you naughty girl

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: That evening Cornelius was one of the happiest of men. Rosa allowed him to press her hand in his, and to keep it as long as he would, besides which he might talk of his tulip as much as he liked.
children.prevalue: That evening Cornelius was one of the happiest of men Rosa allowed him to press her hand in his and to keep it as long as he would besides which he might talk of his tulip as much as he liked

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: From that hour every day marked some progress in the growth of the tulip and in the affection of the two young people.
