children.prevalue: From that hour every day marked some progress in the growth of the tulip and in the affection of the two young people

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: At one time it was that the leaves had expanded, and at another that the flower itself had formed.
children.prevalue: At one time it was that the leaves had expanded and at another that the flower itself had formed

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Great was the joy of Cornelius at this news, and his questions succeeded one another with a rapidity which gave proof of their importance.
children.prevalue: Great was the joy of Cornelius at this news and his questions succeeded one another with a rapidity which gave proof of their importance

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Formed! exclaimed Cornelius, is it really formed?
children.prevalue: Formed exclaimed Cornelius is it really formed

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: It is, repeated Rosa.
children.prevalue: It is repeated Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Cornelius trembled with joy, so much so that he was obliged to hold by the grating.
children.prevalue: Cornelius trembled with joy so much so that he was obliged to hold by the grating

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Good heavens! he exclaimed.
children.prevalue: Good heavens he exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Then, turning again to Rosa, he continued his questions.
children.prevalue: Then turning again to Rosa he continued his questions

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Is the oval regular? the cylinder full? and are the points very green?
children.prevalue: Is the oval regular the cylinder full and are the points very green

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: The oval is almost one inch long, and tapers like a needle, the cylinder swells at the sides, and the points are ready to open.
children.prevalue: The oval is almost one inch long and tapers like a needle the cylinder swells at the sides and the points are ready to open

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Two days after Rosa announced that they were open.
children.prevalue: Two days after Rosa announced that they were open

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Open, Rosa! cried Cornelius. Is the involucrum open? but then one may see and already distinguish
children.prevalue: Open Rosa cried Cornelius Is the involucrum open but then one may see and already distinguish

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Here the prisoner paused, anxiously taking breath.
children.prevalue: Here the prisoner paused anxiously taking breath

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Yes, answered Rosa, one may already distinguish a thread of different colour, as thin as a hair.
children.prevalue: Yes answered Rosa one may already distinguish a thread of different colour as thin as a hair

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: And its colour? asked Cornelius, trembling.
children.prevalue: And its colour asked Cornelius trembling

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Oh, answered Rosa, it is very dark!
children.prevalue: Oh answered Rosa it is very dark

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Brown?
children.prevalue: Brown

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Darker than that.
children.prevalue: Darker than that

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Darker, my good Rosa, darker? Thank you. Dark as
children.prevalue: Darker my good Rosa darker Thank you Dark as

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Dark as the ink with which I wrote to you.
children.prevalue: Dark as the ink with which I wrote to you

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Cornelius uttered a cry of mad joy.
children.prevalue: Cornelius uttered a cry of mad joy

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Then, suddenly stopping and clasping his hands, he said,
children.prevalue: Then suddenly stopping and clasping his hands he said

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Oh, there is not an angel in heaven that may be compared to you, Rosa!
children.prevalue: Oh there is not an angel in heaven that may be compared to you Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Indeed! said Rosa, smiling at his enthusiasm.
children.prevalue: Indeed said Rosa smiling at his enthusiasm

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Rosa, you have worked with such ardour,you have done so much for me! Rosa, my tulip is about to flower, and it will flower black! Rosa, Rosa, you are the most perfect being on earth!
children.prevalue: Rosa you have worked with such ardour you have done so much for me Rosa my tulip is about to flower and it will flower black Rosa Rosa you are the most perfect being on earth

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: After the tulip, though.
children.prevalue: After the tulip though

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Ah! be quiet, you malicious little creature, be quiet! For shame! Do not spoil my pleasure. But tell me, Rosa,as the tulip is so far advanced, it will flower in two or three days, at the latest?
children.prevalue: Ah be quiet you malicious little creature be quiet For shame Do not spoil my pleasure But tell me Rosa as the tulip is so far advanced it will flower in two or three days at the latest

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Tomorrow, or the day after.
children.prevalue: Tomorrow or the day after

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Ah! and I shall not see it, cried Cornelius, starting back, I shall not kiss it, as a wonderful work of the Almighty, as I kiss your hand and your cheek, Rosa, when by chance they are near the grating.
children.prevalue: Ah and I shall not see it cried Cornelius starting back I shall not kiss it as a wonderful work of the Almighty as I kiss your hand and your cheek Rosa when by chance they are near the grating

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Rosa drew near, not by accident, but intentionally, and Cornelius kissed her tenderly.
children.prevalue: Rosa drew near not by accident but intentionally and Cornelius kissed her tenderly

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Faith, I shall cull it, if you wish it.
children.prevalue: Faith I shall cull it if you wish it

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Oh, no, no, Rosa! when it is open, place it carefully in the shade, and immediately send a message to Haarlem, to the President of the Horticultural Society, that the grand black tulip is in flower. I know well it is far to Haarlem, but with money you will find a messenger. Have you any money, Rosa?
children.prevalue: Oh no no Rosa when it is open place it carefully in the shade and immediately send a message to Haarlem to the President of the Horticultural Society that the grand black tulip is in flower I know well it is far to Haarlem but with money you will find a messenger Have you any money Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Rosa smiled.
children.prevalue: Rosa smiled

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Oh, yes! she said.
children.prevalue: Oh yes she said

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Enough? said Cornelius.
children.prevalue: Enough said Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: I have three hundred guilders.
children.prevalue: I have three hundred guilders

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Oh, if you have three hundred guilders, you must not send a messenger, Rosa, but you must go to Haarlem yourself.
children.prevalue: Oh if you have three hundred guilders you must not send a messenger Rosa but you must go to Haarlem yourself

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: But what in the meantime is to become of the flower?
children.prevalue: But what in the meantime is to become of the flower

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Oh, the flower! you must take it with you. You understand that you must not separate from it for an instant.
children.prevalue: Oh the flower you must take it with you You understand that you must not separate from it for an instant

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: But whilst I am not separating from it, I am separating from you, Mynheer Cornelius.
children.prevalue: But whilst I am not separating from it I am separating from you Mynheer Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Ah! that's true, my sweet Rosa. Oh, my God! how wicked men are! What have I done to offend them, and why have they deprived me of my liberty? You are right, Rosa, I cannot live without you. Well, you will send some one to Haarlem,that's settled; really, the matter is wonderful enough for the President to put himself to some trouble. He will come himself to Loewestein to see the tulip.
children.prevalue: Ah that s true my sweet Rosa Oh my God how wicked men are What have I done to offend them and why have they deprived me of my liberty You are right Rosa I cannot live without you Well you will send some one to Haarlem that s settled really the matter is wonderful enough for the President to put himself to some trouble He will come himself to Loewestein to see the tulip

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Then, suddenly checking himself, he said, with a faltering voice,
children.prevalue: Then suddenly checking himself he said with a faltering voice

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Rosa, Rosa, if after all it should not flower black!
children.prevalue: Rosa Rosa if after all it should not flower black

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Oh, surely, surely, you will know tomorrow, or the day after.
children.prevalue: Oh surely surely you will know tomorrow or the day after

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: And to wait until evening to know it, Rosa! I shall die with impatience. Could we not agree about a signal?
children.prevalue: And to wait until evening to know it Rosa I shall die with impatience Could we not agree about a signal

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: I shall do better than that.
children.prevalue: I shall do better than that

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: What will you do?
children.prevalue: What will you do

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: If it opens at night, I shall come and tell you myself. If it is day, I shall pass your door, and slip you a note either under the door, or through the grating, during the time between my father's first and second inspection.
children.prevalue: If it opens at night I shall come and tell you myself If it is day I shall pass your door and slip you a note either under the door or through the grating during the time between my father s first and second inspection

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: Yes, Rosa, let it be so. One word of yours, announcing this news to me, will be a double happiness.
children.prevalue: Yes Rosa let it be so One word of yours announcing this news to me will be a double happiness

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: There, ten o'clock strikes, said Rosa, I must now leave you.
children.prevalue: There ten o clock strikes said Rosa I must now leave you

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Yes, yes, said Cornelius, go, Rosa, go!
children.prevalue: Yes yes said Cornelius go Rosa go

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: Rosa withdrew, almost melancholy, for Cornelius had all but sent her away.
children.prevalue: Rosa withdrew almost melancholy for Cornelius had all but sent her away

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: It is true that he did so in order that she might watch over his black tulip.
children.prevalue: It is true that he did so in order that she might watch over his black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The night passed away very sweetly for Cornelius, although in great agitation. Every instant he fancied he heard the gentle voice of Rosa calling him. He then started up, went to the door, and looked through the grating, but no one was behind it, and the lobby was empty.
children.prevalue: The night passed away very sweetly for Cornelius although in great agitation Every instant he fancied he heard the gentle voice of Rosa calling him He then started up went to the door and looked through the grating but no one was behind it and the lobby was empty

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Rosa, no doubt, would be watching too, but, happier than he, she watched over the tulip; she had before her eyes that noble flower, that wonder of wonders, which not only was unknown, but was not even thought possible until then.
children.prevalue: Rosa no doubt would be watching too but happier than he she watched over the tulip she had before her eyes that noble flower that wonder of wonders which not only was unknown but was not even thought possible until then

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: What would the world say when it heard that the black tulip was found, that it existed and that it was the prisoner Van Baerle who had found it?
children.prevalue: What would the world say when it heard that the black tulip was found that it existed and that it was the prisoner Van Baerle who had found it

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: How Cornelius would have spurned the offer of his liberty in exchange for his tulip!
children.prevalue: How Cornelius would have spurned the offer of his liberty in exchange for his tulip

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Day came, without any news; the tulip was not yet in flower.
children.prevalue: Day came without any news the tulip was not yet in flower

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The day passed as the night. Night came, and with it Rosa, joyous and cheerful as a bird.
children.prevalue: The day passed as the night Night came and with it Rosa joyous and cheerful as a bird

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Well? asked Cornelius.
children.prevalue: Well asked Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Well, all is going on prosperously. This night, without any doubt, our tulip will be in flower.
children.prevalue: Well all is going on prosperously This night without any doubt our tulip will be in flower

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: And will it flower black?
children.prevalue: And will it flower black

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Black as jet.
children.prevalue: Black as jet

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Without a speck of any other colour.
children.prevalue: Without a speck of any other colour

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Without one speck.
children.prevalue: Without one speck

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Good Heavens! my dear Rosa, I have been dreaming all night, in the first place of you, (Rosa made a sign of incredulity,) and then of what we must do.
children.prevalue: Good Heavens my dear Rosa I have been dreaming all night in the first place of you Rosa made a sign of incredulity and then of what we must do

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Well, and I will tell you now what I have decided on. The tulip once being in flower, and it being quite certain that it is perfectly black, you must find a messenger.
children.prevalue: Well and I will tell you now what I have decided on The tulip once being in flower and it being quite certain that it is perfectly black you must find a messenger

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: If it is no more than that, I have a messenger quite ready.
children.prevalue: If it is no more than that I have a messenger quite ready

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Is he safe?
children.prevalue: Is he safe

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: One for whom I will answer,he is one of my lovers.
children.prevalue: One for whom I will answer he is one of my lovers

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: I hope not Jacob.
children.prevalue: I hope not Jacob

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: No, be quiet, it is the ferryman of Loewestein, a smart young man of twentyfive.
children.prevalue: No be quiet it is the ferryman of Loewestein a smart young man of twentyfive

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: By Jove!
children.prevalue: By Jove

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Be quiet, said Rosa, smiling, he is still under age, as you have yourself fixed it from twentysix to twentyeight.
children.prevalue: Be quiet said Rosa smiling he is still under age as you have yourself fixed it from twentysix to twentyeight

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: In fine, do you think you may rely on this young man?
children.prevalue: In fine do you think you may rely on this young man

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: As on myself; he would throw himself into the Waal or the Meuse if I bade him.
children.prevalue: As on myself he would throw himself into the Waal or the Meuse if I bade him

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Well, Rosa, this lad may be at Haarlem in ten hours; you will give me paper and pencil, and, perhaps better still, pen and ink, and I will write, or rather, on second thoughts, you will, for if I did, being a poor prisoner, people might, like your father, see a conspiracy in it. You will write to the President of the Horticultural Society, and I am sure he will come.
children.prevalue: Well Rosa this lad may be at Haarlem in ten hours you will give me paper and pencil and perhaps better still pen and ink and I will write or rather on second thoughts you will for if I did being a poor prisoner people might like your father see a conspiracy in it You will write to the President of the Horticultural Society and I am sure he will come

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: But if he tarries?
children.prevalue: But if he tarries

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Well, let us suppose that he tarries one day, or even two; but it is impossible. A tulipfancier like him will not tarry one hour, not one minute, not one second, to set out to see the eighth wonder of the world. But, as I said, if he tarried one or even two days, the tulip will still be in its full splendour. The flower once being seen by the President, and the protocol being drawn up, all is in order; you will only keep a duplicate of the protocol, and intrust the tulip to him. Ah! if we had been able to carry it ourselves, Rosa, it would never have left my hands but to pass into yours; but this is a dream, which we must not entertain, continued Cornelius with a sigh, the eyes of strangers will see it flower to the last. And above all, Rosa, before the President has seen it, let it not be seen by any one. Alas! if any one saw the black tulip, it would be stolen.
children.prevalue: Well let us suppose that he tarries one day or even two but it is impossible A tulipfancier like him will not tarry one hour not one minute not one second to set out to see the eighth wonder of the world But as I said if he tarried one or even two days the tulip will still be in its full splendour The flower once being seen by the President and the protocol being drawn up all is in order you will only keep a duplicate of the protocol and intrust the tulip to him Ah if we had been able to carry it ourselves Rosa it would never have left my hands but to pass into yours but this is a dream which we must not entertain continued Cornelius with a sigh the eyes of strangers will see it flower to the last And above all Rosa before the President has seen it let it not be seen by any one Alas if any one saw the black tulip it would be stolen

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Oh!
children.prevalue: Oh

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Did you not tell me yourself of what you apprehended from your lover Jacob? People will steal one guilder, why not a hundred thousand?
children.prevalue: Did you not tell me yourself of what you apprehended from your lover Jacob People will steal one guilder why not a hundred thousand

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: I shall watch; be quiet.
children.prevalue: I shall watch be quiet

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: But if it opened whilst you were here?
children.prevalue: But if it opened whilst you were here

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The whimsical little thing would indeed be quite capable of playing such a trick, said Rosa.
children.prevalue: The whimsical little thing would indeed be quite capable of playing such a trick said Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: And if on your return you find it open?
children.prevalue: And if on your return you find it open

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Oh, Rosa, whenever it opens, remember that not a moment must be lost in apprising the President.
children.prevalue: Oh Rosa whenever it opens remember that not a moment must be lost in apprising the President

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: And in apprising you. Yes, I understand.
children.prevalue: And in apprising you Yes I understand

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Rosa sighed, yet without any bitter feeling, but rather like a woman who begins to understand a foible, and to accustom herself to it.
children.prevalue: Rosa sighed yet without any bitter feeling but rather like a woman who begins to understand a foible and to accustom herself to it

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: I return to your tulip, Mynheer van Baerle, and as soon as it opens I will give you news, which being done the messenger will set out immediately.
children.prevalue: I return to your tulip Mynheer van Baerle and as soon as it opens I will give you news which being done the messenger will set out immediately

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Rosa, Rosa, I don't know to what wonder under the sun I shall compare you.
children.prevalue: Rosa Rosa I don t know to what wonder under the sun I shall compare you

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Compare me to the black tulip, and I promise you I shall feel very much flattered. Good night, then, till we meet again, Mynheer Cornelius.
children.prevalue: Compare me to the black tulip and I promise you I shall feel very much flattered Good night then till we meet again Mynheer Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Oh, say 'Good night, my friend.'
children.prevalue: Oh say Good night my friend

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Good night, my friend, said Rosa, a little consoled.
children.prevalue: Good night my friend said Rosa a little consoled

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Say, 'My very dear friend.'
children.prevalue: Say My very dear friend

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Oh, my friend
children.prevalue: Oh my friend

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Very dear friend, I entreat you, say 'very dear,' Rosa, very dear.
children.prevalue: Very dear friend I entreat you say very dear Rosa very dear

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Very dear, yes, very dear, said Rosa, with a beating heart, beyond herself with happiness.
children.prevalue: Very dear yes very dear said Rosa with a beating heart beyond herself with happiness

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: And now that you have said 'very dear,' dear Rosa, say also 'most happy': say 'happier and more blessed than ever man was under the sun.' I only lack one thing, Rosa.
children.prevalue: And now that you have said very dear dear Rosa say also most happy say happier and more blessed than ever man was under the sun I only lack one thing Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: And that is?
children.prevalue: And that is

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Your cheek,your fresh cheek, your soft, rosy cheek. Oh, Rosa, give it me of your own free will, and not by chance. Ah!
children.prevalue: Your cheek your fresh cheek your soft rosy cheek Oh Rosa give it me of your own free will and not by chance Ah

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: The prisoner's prayer ended in a sigh of ecstasy; his lips met those of the maiden,not by chance, nor by stratagem, but as SaintPreux's was to meet the lips of Julie a hundred years later.
children.prevalue: The prisoner s prayer ended in a sigh of ecstasy his lips met those of the maiden not by chance nor by stratagem but as SaintPreux s was to meet the lips of Julie a hundred years later

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Rosa made her escape.
children.prevalue: Rosa made her escape

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Cornelius stood with his heart upon his lips, and his face glued to the wicket in the door.
children.prevalue: Cornelius stood with his heart upon his lips and his face glued to the wicket in the door

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: He was fairly choking with happiness and joy. He opened his window, and gazed long, with swelling heart, at the cloudless vault of heaven, and the moon, which shone like silver upon the twofold stream flowing from far beyond the hills. He filled his lungs with the pure, sweet air, while his brain dwelt upon thoughts of happiness, and his heart overflowed with gratitude and religious fervour.
children.prevalue: He was fairly choking with happiness and joy He opened his window and gazed long with swelling heart at the cloudless vault of heaven and the moon which shone like silver upon the twofold stream flowing from far beyond the hills He filled his lungs with the pure sweet air while his brain dwelt upon thoughts of happiness and his heart overflowed with gratitude and religious fervour

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Oh Thou art always watching from on high, my God, he cried, half prostrate, his glowing eyes fixed upon the stars: forgive me that I almost doubted Thy existence during these latter days, for Thou didst hide Thy face behind the clouds, and wert for a moment lost to my sight, O Thou merciful God, Thou pitying Father everlasting! But today, this evening, and tonight, again I see Thee in all Thy wondrous glory in the mirror of Thy heavenly abode, and more clearly still in the mirror of my grateful heart.
children.prevalue: Oh Thou art always watching from on high my God he cried half prostrate his glowing eyes fixed upon the stars forgive me that I almost doubted Thy existence during these latter days for Thou didst hide Thy face behind the clouds and wert for a moment lost to my sight O Thou merciful God Thou pitying Father everlasting But today this evening and tonight again I see Thee in all Thy wondrous glory in the mirror of Thy heavenly abode and more clearly still in the mirror of my grateful heart

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: He was well again, the poor invalid; the wretched captive was free once more.
children.prevalue: He was well again the poor invalid the wretched captive was free once more

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: During part of the night Cornelius, with his heart full of joy and delight, remained at his window, gazing at the stars, and listening for every sound.
children.prevalue: During part of the night Cornelius with his heart full of joy and delight remained at his window gazing at the stars and listening for every sound

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Then casting a glance from time to time towards the lobby,
children.prevalue: Then casting a glance from time to time towards the lobby

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Down there, he said, is Rosa, watching like myself, and waiting from minute to minute; down there, under Rosa's eyes, is the mysterious flower, which lives, which expands, which opens, perhaps Rosa holds in this moment the stem of the tulip between her delicate fingers. Touch it gently, Rosa. Perhaps she touches with her lips its expanding chalice. Touch it cautiously, Rosa, your lips are burning. Yes, perhaps at this moment the two objects of my dearest love caress each other under the eye of Heaven.
children.prevalue: Down there he said is Rosa watching like myself and waiting from minute to minute down there under Rosa s eyes is the mysterious flower which lives which expands which opens perhaps Rosa holds in this moment the stem of the tulip between her delicate fingers Touch it gently Rosa Perhaps she touches with her lips its expanding chalice Touch it cautiously Rosa your lips are burning Yes perhaps at this moment the two objects of my dearest love caress each other under the eye of Heaven

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: At this moment, a star blazed in the southern sky, and shot through the whole horizon, falling down, as it were, on the fortress of Loewestein.
children.prevalue: At this moment a star blazed in the southern sky and shot through the whole horizon falling down as it were on the fortress of Loewestein

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Cornelius felt a thrill run through his frame.
children.prevalue: Cornelius felt a thrill run through his frame

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Ah! he said, here is Heaven sending a soul to my flower.
children.prevalue: Ah he said here is Heaven sending a soul to my flower

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: And as if he had guessed correctly, nearly at that very moment the prisoner heard in the lobby a step light as that of a sylph, and the rustling of a gown, and a wellknown voice, which said to him,
children.prevalue: And as if he had guessed correctly nearly at that very moment the prisoner heard in the lobby a step light as that of a sylph and the rustling of a gown and a wellknown voice which said to him

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Cornelius, my friend, my very dear friend, and very happy friend, come, come quickly.
children.prevalue: Cornelius my friend my very dear friend and very happy friend come come quickly

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Cornelius darted with one spring from the window to the door, his lips met those of Rosa, who told him, with a kiss,
children.prevalue: Cornelius darted with one spring from the window to the door his lips met those of Rosa who told him with a kiss

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: It is open, it is black, here it is.
children.prevalue: It is open it is black here it is

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: How! here it is? exclaimed Cornelius.
children.prevalue: How here it is exclaimed Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Yes, yes, we ought indeed to run some little risk to give a great joy; here it is, take it.
children.prevalue: Yes yes we ought indeed to run some little risk to give a great joy here it is take it

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: And with one hand she raised to the level of the grating a dark lantern, which she had lit in the meanwhile, whilst with the other she held to the same height the miraculous tulip.
children.prevalue: And with one hand she raised to the level of the grating a dark lantern which she had lit in the meanwhile whilst with the other she held to the same height the miraculous tulip

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Cornelius uttered a cry, and was nearly fainting.
children.prevalue: Cornelius uttered a cry and was nearly fainting

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Oh! muttered he, my God, my God, Thou dost reward me for my innocence and my captivity, as Thou hast allowed two such flowers to grow at the grated window of my prison!
children.prevalue: Oh muttered he my God my God Thou dost reward me for my innocence and my captivity as Thou hast allowed two such flowers to grow at the grated window of my prison

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: The tulip was beautiful, splendid, magnificent; its stem was more than eighteen inches high; it rose from out of four green leaves, which were as smooth and straight as iron lanceheads; the whole of the flower was as black and shining as jet.
children.prevalue: The tulip was beautiful splendid magnificent its stem was more than eighteen inches high it rose from out of four green leaves which were as smooth and straight as iron lanceheads the whole of the flower was as black and shining as jet

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Rosa, said Cornelius, almost gasping, Rosa, there is not one moment to lose in writing the letter.
children.prevalue: Rosa said Cornelius almost gasping Rosa there is not one moment to lose in writing the letter

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: It is written, my dearest Cornelius, said Rosa.
children.prevalue: It is written my dearest Cornelius said Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Is it, indeed?
children.prevalue: Is it indeed

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Whilst the tulip opened I wrote it myself, for I did not wish to lose a moment. Here is the letter, and tell me whether you approve of it.
children.prevalue: Whilst the tulip opened I wrote it myself for I did not wish to lose a moment Here is the letter and tell me whether you approve of it

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Cornelius took the letter, and read, in a handwriting which was much improved even since the last little note he had received from Rosa, as follows:
children.prevalue: Cornelius took the letter and read in a handwriting which was much improved even since the last little note he had received from Rosa as follows

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Mynheer President,The black tulip is about to open, perhaps in ten minutes. As soon as it is open, I shall send a messenger to you, with the request that you will come and fetch it in person from the fortress at Loewestein. I am the daughter of the jailer, Gryphus, almost as much of a captive as the prisoners of my father. I cannot, therefore, bring to you this wonderful flower. This is the reason why I beg you to come and fetch it yourself.
children.prevalue: Mynheer President The black tulip is about to open perhaps in ten minutes As soon as it is open I shall send a messenger to you with the request that you will come and fetch it in person from the fortress at Loewestein I am the daughter of the jailer Gryphus almost as much of a captive as the prisoners of my father I cannot therefore bring to you this wonderful flower This is the reason why I beg you to come and fetch it yourself

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: It is my wish that it should be called Rosa Barlaensis.
children.prevalue: It is my wish that it should be called Rosa Barlaensis

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: It has opened; it is perfectly black; come, Mynheer President, come.
children.prevalue: It has opened it is perfectly black come Mynheer President come

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: I have the honour to be your humble servant,
children.prevalue: I have the honour to be your humble servant

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Rosa Gryphus.
children.prevalue: Rosa Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: That's it, dear Rosa, that's it. Your letter is admirable! I could not have written it with such beautiful simplicity. You will give to the committee all the information that will be required of you. They will then know how the tulip has been grown, how much care and anxiety, and how many sleepless nights, it has cost. But for the present not a minute must be lost. The messenger! the messenger!
children.prevalue: That s it dear Rosa that s it Your letter is admirable I could not have written it with such beautiful simplicity You will give to the committee all the information that will be required of you They will then know how the tulip has been grown how much care and anxiety and how many sleepless nights it has cost But for the present not a minute must be lost The messenger the messenger

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: What's the name of the President?
children.prevalue: What s the name of the President

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Give me the letter, I will direct it. Oh, he is very well known: it is Mynheer van Systens, the burgomaster of Haarlem; give it to me, Rosa, give it to me.
children.prevalue: Give me the letter I will direct it Oh he is very well known it is Mynheer van Systens the burgomaster of Haarlem give it to me Rosa give it to me

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: And with a trembling hand Cornelius wrote the address,
children.prevalue: And with a trembling hand Cornelius wrote the address

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: To Mynheer Peter van Systens, Burgomaster, and President of the Horticultural Society of Haarlem.
children.prevalue: To Mynheer Peter van Systens Burgomaster and President of the Horticultural Society of Haarlem

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: And now, Rosa, go, go, said Cornelius, and let us implore the protection of God, who has so kindly watched over us until now.
children.prevalue: And now Rosa go go said Cornelius and let us implore the protection of God who has so kindly watched over us until now

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: And in fact the poor young people were in great need of protection.
children.prevalue: And in fact the poor young people were in great need of protection

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: They had never been so near the destruction of their hopes as at this moment, when they thought themselves certain of their fulfilment.
children.prevalue: They had never been so near the destruction of their hopes as at this moment when they thought themselves certain of their fulfilment

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The reader cannot but have recognized in Jacob our old friend, or rather enemy, Isaac Boxtel, and has guessed, no doubt, that this worthy had followed from the Buytenhof to Loewestein the object of his love and the object of his hatred,the black tulip and Cornelius van Baerle.
children.prevalue: The reader cannot but have recognized in Jacob our old friend or rather enemy Isaac Boxtel and has guessed no doubt that this worthy had followed from the Buytenhof to Loewestein the object of his love and the object of his hatred the black tulip and Cornelius van Baerle

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: What no one but a tulipfancier, and an envious tulipfancier, could have discovered,the existence of the bulbs and the endeavours of the prisoner,jealousy had enabled Boxtel, if not to discover, at least to guess.
children.prevalue: What no one but a tulipfancier and an envious tulipfancier could have discovered the existence of the bulbs and the endeavours of the prisoner jealousy had enabled Boxtel if not to discover at least to guess

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: We have seen him, more successful under the name of Jacob than under that of Isaac, gain the friendship of Gryphus, which for several months he cultivated by means of the best Genievre ever distilled from the Texel to Antwerp, and he lulled the suspicion of the jealous turnkey by holding out to him the flattering prospect of his designing to marry Rosa.
children.prevalue: We have seen him more successful under the name of Jacob than under that of Isaac gain the friendship of Gryphus which for several months he cultivated by means of the best Genievre ever distilled from the Texel to Antwerp and he lulled the suspicion of the jealous turnkey by holding out to him the flattering prospect of his designing to marry Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Besides thus offering a bait to the ambition of the father, he managed, at the same time, to interest his zeal as a jailer, picturing to him in the blackest colours the learned prisoner whom Gryphus had in his keeping, and who, as the sham Jacob had it, was in league with Satan, to the detriment of his Highness the Prince of Orange.
children.prevalue: Besides thus offering a bait to the ambition of the father he managed at the same time to interest his zeal as a jailer picturing to him in the blackest colours the learned prisoner whom Gryphus had in his keeping and who as the sham Jacob had it was in league with Satan to the detriment of his Highness the Prince of Orange

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: At first he had also made some way with Rosa; not, indeed, in her affections, but inasmuch as, by talking to her of marriage and of love, he had evaded all the suspicions which he might otherwise have excited.
children.prevalue: At first he had also made some way with Rosa not indeed in her affections but inasmuch as by talking to her of marriage and of love he had evaded all the suspicions which he might otherwise have excited

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: We have seen how his imprudence in following Rosa into the garden had unmasked him in the eyes of the young damsel, and how the instinctive fears of Cornelius had put the two lovers on their guard against him.
children.prevalue: We have seen how his imprudence in following Rosa into the garden had unmasked him in the eyes of the young damsel and how the instinctive fears of Cornelius had put the two lovers on their guard against him

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The reader will remember that the first cause of uneasiness was given to the prisoner by the rage of Jacob when Gryphus crushed the first bulb. In that moment Boxtel's exasperation was the more fierce, as, though suspecting that Cornelius possessed a second bulb, he by no means felt sure of it.
children.prevalue: The reader will remember that the first cause of uneasiness was given to the prisoner by the rage of Jacob when Gryphus crushed the first bulb In that moment Boxtel s exasperation was the more fierce as though suspecting that Cornelius possessed a second bulb he by no means felt sure of it

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: From that moment he began to dodge the steps of Rosa, not only following her to the garden, but also to the lobbies.
children.prevalue: From that moment he began to dodge the steps of Rosa not only following her to the garden but also to the lobbies

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Only as this time he followed her in the night, and barefooted, he was neither seen nor heard except once, when Rosa thought she saw something like a shadow on the staircase.
children.prevalue: Only as this time he followed her in the night and barefooted he was neither seen nor heard except once when Rosa thought she saw something like a shadow on the staircase

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Her discovery, however, was made too late, as Boxtel had heard from the mouth of the prisoner himself that a second bulb existed.
children.prevalue: Her discovery however was made too late as Boxtel had heard from the mouth of the prisoner himself that a second bulb existed

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Taken in by the stratagem of Rosa, who had feigned to put it in the ground, and entertaining no doubt that this little farce had been played in order to force him to betray himself, he redoubled his precaution, and employed every means suggested by his crafty nature to watch the others without being watched himself.
children.prevalue: Taken in by the stratagem of Rosa who had feigned to put it in the ground and entertaining no doubt that this little farce had been played in order to force him to betray himself he redoubled his precaution and employed every means suggested by his crafty nature to watch the others without being watched himself

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: He saw Rosa conveying a large flowerpot of white earthenware from her father's kitchen to her bedroom. He saw Rosa washing in pails of water her pretty little hands, begrimed as they were with the mould which she had handled, to give her tulip the best soil possible.
children.prevalue: He saw Rosa conveying a large flowerpot of white earthenware from her father s kitchen to her bedroom He saw Rosa washing in pails of water her pretty little hands begrimed as they were with the mould which she had handled to give her tulip the best soil possible

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: And at last he hired, just opposite Rosa's window, a little attic, distant enough not to allow him to be recognized with the naked eye, but sufficiently near to enable him, with the help of his telescope, to watch everything that was going on at the Loewestein in Rosa's room, just as at Dort he had watched the dryroom of Cornelius.
children.prevalue: And at last he hired just opposite Rosa s window a little attic distant enough not to allow him to be recognized with the naked eye but sufficiently near to enable him with the help of his telescope to watch everything that was going on at the Loewestein in Rosa s room just as at Dort he had watched the dryroom of Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: He had not been installed more than three days in his attic before all his doubts were removed.
children.prevalue: He had not been installed more than three days in his attic before all his doubts were removed

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: From morning to sunset the flowerpot was in the window, and, like those charming female figures of Mieris and Metzys, Rosa appeared at that window as in a frame, formed by the first budding sprays of the wild vine and the honeysuckle encircling her window.
children.prevalue: From morning to sunset the flowerpot was in the window and like those charming female figures of Mieris and Metzys Rosa appeared at that window as in a frame formed by the first budding sprays of the wild vine and the honeysuckle encircling her window

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Rosa watched the flowerpot with an interest which betrayed to Boxtel the real value of the object enclosed in it.
children.prevalue: Rosa watched the flowerpot with an interest which betrayed to Boxtel the real value of the object enclosed in it

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: This object could not be anything else but the second bulb, that is to say, the quintessence of all the hopes of the prisoner.
children.prevalue: This object could not be anything else but the second bulb that is to say the quintessence of all the hopes of the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: When the nights threatened to be too cold, Rosa took in the flowerpot.
children.prevalue: When the nights threatened to be too cold Rosa took in the flowerpot

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Well, it was then quite evident she was following the instructions of Cornelius, who was afraid of the bulb being killed by frost.
children.prevalue: Well it was then quite evident she was following the instructions of Cornelius who was afraid of the bulb being killed by frost

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: When the sun became too hot, Rosa likewise took in the pot from eleven in the morning until two in the afternoon.
children.prevalue: When the sun became too hot Rosa likewise took in the pot from eleven in the morning until two in the afternoon

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Another proof: Cornelius was afraid lest the soil should become too dry.
children.prevalue: Another proof Cornelius was afraid lest the soil should become too dry

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: But when the first leaves peeped out of the earth Boxtel was fully convinced; and his telescope left him no longer in any uncertainty before they had grown one inch in height.
children.prevalue: But when the first leaves peeped out of the earth Boxtel was fully convinced and his telescope left him no longer in any uncertainty before they had grown one inch in height

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Cornelius possessed two bulbs, and the second was intrusted to the love and care of Rosa.
children.prevalue: Cornelius possessed two bulbs and the second was intrusted to the love and care of Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: For it may well be imagined that the tender secret of the two lovers had not escaped the prying curiosity of Boxtel.
children.prevalue: For it may well be imagined that the tender secret of the two lovers had not escaped the prying curiosity of Boxtel

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The question, therefore, was how to wrest the second bulb from the care of Rosa.
children.prevalue: The question therefore was how to wrest the second bulb from the care of Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Certainly this was no easy task.
children.prevalue: Certainly this was no easy task

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Rosa watched over her tulip as a mother over her child, or a dove over her eggs.
children.prevalue: Rosa watched over her tulip as a mother over her child or a dove over her eggs

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Rosa never left her room during the day, and, more than that, strange to say, she never left it in the evening.
children.prevalue: Rosa never left her room during the day and more than that strange to say she never left it in the evening

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: For seven days Boxtel in vain watched Rosa; she was always at her post.
children.prevalue: For seven days Boxtel in vain watched Rosa she was always at her post

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: This happened during those seven days which made Cornelius so unhappy, depriving him at the same time of all news of Rosa and of his tulip.
children.prevalue: This happened during those seven days which made Cornelius so unhappy depriving him at the same time of all news of Rosa and of his tulip

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Would the coolness between Rosa and Cornelius last for ever?
children.prevalue: Would the coolness between Rosa and Cornelius last for ever

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: This would have made the theft much more difficult than Mynheer Isaac had at first expected.
children.prevalue: This would have made the theft much more difficult than Mynheer Isaac had at first expected

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: We say the theft, for Isaac had simply made up his mind to steal the tulip; and as it grew in the most profound secrecy, and as, moreover, his word, being that of a renowned tulipgrower, would any day be taken against that of an unknown girl without any knowledge of horticulture, or against that of a prisoner convicted of high treason, he confidently hoped that, having once got possession of the bulb, he would be certain to obtain the prize; and then the tulip, instead of being called Tulipa nigra Barlaensis, would go down to posterity under the name of Tulipa nigra Boxtellensis or Boxtellea.
children.prevalue: We say the theft for Isaac had simply made up his mind to steal the tulip and as it grew in the most profound secrecy and as moreover his word being that of a renowned tulipgrower would any day be taken against that of an unknown girl without any knowledge of horticulture or against that of a prisoner convicted of high treason he confidently hoped that having once got possession of the bulb he would be certain to obtain the prize and then the tulip instead of being called Tulipa nigra Barlaensis would go down to posterity under the name of Tulipa nigra Boxtellensis or Boxtellea

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Mynheer Isaac had not yet quite decided which of these two names he would give to the tulip, but, as both meant the same thing, this was, after all, not the important point.
children.prevalue: Mynheer Isaac had not yet quite decided which of these two names he would give to the tulip but as both meant the same thing this was after all not the important point

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The point was to steal the tulip. But in order that Boxtel might steal the tulip, it was necessary that Rosa should leave her room.
children.prevalue: The point was to steal the tulip But in order that Boxtel might steal the tulip it was necessary that Rosa should leave her room

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Great therefore was his joy when he saw the usual evening meetings of the lovers resumed.
children.prevalue: Great therefore was his joy when he saw the usual evening meetings of the lovers resumed

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: He first of all took advantage of Rosa's absence to make himself fully acquainted with all the peculiarities of the door of her chamber. The lock was a double one and in good order, but Rosa always took the key with her.
children.prevalue: He first of all took advantage of Rosa s absence to make himself fully acquainted with all the peculiarities of the door of her chamber The lock was a double one and in good order but Rosa always took the key with her

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Boxtel at first entertained an idea of stealing the key, but it soon occurred to him, not only that it would be exceedingly difficult to abstract it from her pocket, but also that, when she perceived her loss, she would not leave her room until the lock was changed, and then Boxtel's first theft would be useless.
children.prevalue: Boxtel at first entertained an idea of stealing the key but it soon occurred to him not only that it would be exceedingly difficult to abstract it from her pocket but also that when she perceived her loss she would not leave her room until the lock was changed and then Boxtel s first theft would be useless

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: He thought it, therefore, better to employ a different expedient. He collected as many keys as he could, and tried all of them during one of those delightful hours which Rosa and Cornelius passed together at the grating of the cell.
children.prevalue: He thought it therefore better to employ a different expedient He collected as many keys as he could and tried all of them during one of those delightful hours which Rosa and Cornelius passed together at the grating of the cell

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Two of the keys entered the lock, and one of them turned round once, but not the second time.
children.prevalue: Two of the keys entered the lock and one of them turned round once but not the second time

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: There was, therefore, only a little to be done to this key.
children.prevalue: There was therefore only a little to be done to this key

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Boxtel covered it with a slight coat of wax, and when he thus renewed the experiment, the obstacle which prevented the key from being turned a second time left its impression on the wax.
children.prevalue: Boxtel covered it with a slight coat of wax and when he thus renewed the experiment the obstacle which prevented the key from being turned a second time left its impression on the wax

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: It cost Boxtel two days more to bring his key to perfection, with the aid of a small file.
children.prevalue: It cost Boxtel two days more to bring his key to perfection with the aid of a small file

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Rosa's door thus opened without noise and without difficulty, and Boxtel found himself in her room alone with the tulip.
children.prevalue: Rosa s door thus opened without noise and without difficulty and Boxtel found himself in her room alone with the tulip

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: The first guilty act of Boxtel had been to climb over a wall in order to dig up the tulip; the second, to introduce himself into the dryroom of Cornelius, through an open window; and the third, to enter Rosa's room by means of a false key.
children.prevalue: The first guilty act of Boxtel had been to climb over a wall in order to dig up the tulip the second to introduce himself into the dryroom of Cornelius through an open window and the third to enter Rosa s room by means of a false key

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Thus envy urged Boxtel on with rapid steps in the career of crime.
children.prevalue: Thus envy urged Boxtel on with rapid steps in the career of crime

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Boxtel, as we have said, was alone with the tulip.
children.prevalue: Boxtel as we have said was alone with the tulip

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: A common thief would have taken the pot under his arm, and carried it off.
children.prevalue: A common thief would have taken the pot under his arm and carried it off

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: But Boxtel was not a common thief, and he reflected.
children.prevalue: But Boxtel was not a common thief and he reflected

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: It was not yet certain, although very probable, that the tulip would flower black; if, therefore, he stole it now, he not only might be committing a useless crime, but also the theft might be discovered in the time which must elapse until the flower should open.
children.prevalue: It was not yet certain although very probable that the tulip would flower black if therefore he stole it now he not only might be committing a useless crime but also the theft might be discovered in the time which must elapse until the flower should open

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: He thereforeas being in possession of the key, he might enter Rosa's chamber whenever he likedthought it better to wait and to take it either an hour before or after opening, and to start on the instant to Haarlem, where the tulip would be before the judges of the committee before any one else could put in a reclamation.
children.prevalue: He thereforeas being in possession of the key he might enter Rosa s chamber whenever he likedthought it better to wait and to take it either an hour before or after opening and to start on the instant to Haarlem where the tulip would be before the judges of the committee before any one else could put in a reclamation

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Should any one then reclaim it, Boxtel would in his turn charge him or her with theft.
children.prevalue: Should any one then reclaim it Boxtel would in his turn charge him or her with theft

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: This was a deeplaid scheme, and quite worthy of its author.
children.prevalue: This was a deeplaid scheme and quite worthy of its author

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Thus, every evening during that delightful hour which the two lovers passed together at the grated window, Boxtel entered Rosa's chamber to watch the progress which the black tulip had made towards flowering.
children.prevalue: Thus every evening during that delightful hour which the two lovers passed together at the grated window Boxtel entered Rosa s chamber to watch the progress which the black tulip had made towards flowering

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: On the evening at which we have arrived he was going to enter according to custom; but the two lovers, as we have seen, only exchanged a few words before Cornelius sent Rosa back to watch over the tulip.
children.prevalue: On the evening at which we have arrived he was going to enter according to custom but the two lovers as we have seen only exchanged a few words before Cornelius sent Rosa back to watch over the tulip

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Seeing Rosa enter her room ten minutes after she had left it, Boxtel guessed that the tulip had opened, or was about to open.
children.prevalue: Seeing Rosa enter her room ten minutes after she had left it Boxtel guessed that the tulip had opened or was about to open

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: During that night, therefore, the great blow was to be struck. Boxtel presented himself before Gryphus with a double supply of Genievre, that is to say, with a bottle in each pocket.
children.prevalue: During that night therefore the great blow was to be struck Boxtel presented himself before Gryphus with a double supply of Genievre that is to say with a bottle in each pocket

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Gryphus being once fuddled, Boxtel was very nearly master of the house.
children.prevalue: Gryphus being once fuddled Boxtel was very nearly master of the house

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: At eleven o'clock Gryphus was dead drunk. At two in the morning Boxtel saw Rosa leaving the chamber; but evidently she held in her arms something which she carried with great care.
children.prevalue: At eleven o clock Gryphus was dead drunk At two in the morning Boxtel saw Rosa leaving the chamber but evidently she held in her arms something which she carried with great care

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: He did not doubt that this was the black tulip which was in flower.
children.prevalue: He did not doubt that this was the black tulip which was in flower

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: But what was she going to do with it? Would she set out that instant to Haarlem with it?
children.prevalue: But what was she going to do with it Would she set out that instant to Haarlem with it

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: It was not possible that a young girl should undertake such a journey alone during the night.
children.prevalue: It was not possible that a young girl should undertake such a journey alone during the night

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Was she only going to show the tulip to Cornelius? This was more likely.
children.prevalue: Was she only going to show the tulip to Cornelius This was more likely

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: He followed Rosa in his stocking feet, walking on tiptoe.
children.prevalue: He followed Rosa in his stocking feet walking on tiptoe

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: He saw her approach the grated window. He heard her calling Cornelius. By the light of the dark lantern he saw the tulip open, and black as the night in which he was hidden.
children.prevalue: He saw her approach the grated window He heard her calling Cornelius By the light of the dark lantern he saw the tulip open and black as the night in which he was hidden

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: He heard the plan concerted between Cornelius and Rosa to send a messenger to Haarlem. He saw the lips of the lovers meet, and then heard Cornelius send Rosa away.
children.prevalue: He heard the plan concerted between Cornelius and Rosa to send a messenger to Haarlem He saw the lips of the lovers meet and then heard Cornelius send Rosa away

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: He saw Rosa extinguish the light and return to her chamber. Ten minutes after, he saw her leave the room again, and lock it twice.
children.prevalue: He saw Rosa extinguish the light and return to her chamber Ten minutes after he saw her leave the room again and lock it twice

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Boxtel, who saw all this whilst hiding himself on the landingplace of the staircase above, descended step by step from his story as Rosa descended from hers; so that, when she touched with her light foot the lowest step of the staircase, Boxtel touched with a still lighter hand the lock of Rosa's chamber.
children.prevalue: Boxtel who saw all this whilst hiding himself on the landingplace of the staircase above descended step by step from his story as Rosa descended from hers so that when she touched with her light foot the lowest step of the staircase Boxtel touched with a still lighter hand the lock of Rosa s chamber

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: And in that hand, it must be understood, he held the false key which opened Rosa's door as easily as did the real one.
children.prevalue: And in that hand it must be understood he held the false key which opened Rosa s door as easily as did the real one

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: And this is why, in the beginning of the chapter, we said that the poor young people were in great need of the protection of God.
children.prevalue: And this is why in the beginning of the chapter we said that the poor young people were in great need of the protection of God

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Cornelius remained standing on the spot where Rosa had left him. He was quite overpowered with the weight of his twofold happiness.
children.prevalue: Cornelius remained standing on the spot where Rosa had left him He was quite overpowered with the weight of his twofold happiness

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Half an hour passed away. Already did the first rays of the sun enter through the iron grating of the prison, when Cornelius was suddenly startled at the noise of steps which came up the staircase, and of cries which approached nearer and nearer.
children.prevalue: Half an hour passed away Already did the first rays of the sun enter through the iron grating of the prison when Cornelius was suddenly startled at the noise of steps which came up the staircase and of cries which approached nearer and nearer

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Almost at the same instant he saw before him the pale and distracted face of Rosa.
children.prevalue: Almost at the same instant he saw before him the pale and distracted face of Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: He started, and turned pale with fright.
children.prevalue: He started and turned pale with fright

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Cornelius, Cornelius! she screamed, gasping for breath.
children.prevalue: Cornelius Cornelius she screamed gasping for breath

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Good Heaven! what is it? asked the prisoner.
children.prevalue: Good Heaven what is it asked the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Cornelius! the tulip
children.prevalue: Cornelius the tulip

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: How shall I tell you?
children.prevalue: How shall I tell you

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Speak, speak, Rosa!
children.prevalue: Speak speak Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Some one has takenstolen it from us.
children.prevalue: Some one has takenstolen it from us

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Stolentaken? said Cornelius.
children.prevalue: Stolentaken said Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Yes, said Rosa, leaning against the door to support herself; yes, taken, stolen!
children.prevalue: Yes said Rosa leaning against the door to support herself yes taken stolen

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: And saying this, she felt her limbs failing her, and she fell on her knees.
children.prevalue: And saying this she felt her limbs failing her and she fell on her knees

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: But how? Tell me, explain to me.
children.prevalue: But how Tell me explain to me

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Oh, it is not my fault, my friend.
children.prevalue: Oh it is not my fault my friend

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Poor Rosa! she no longer dared to call him My beloved one.
children.prevalue: Poor Rosa she no longer dared to call him My beloved one

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: You have then left it alone, said Cornelius, ruefully.
children.prevalue: You have then left it alone said Cornelius ruefully

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: One minute only, to instruct our messenger, who lives scarcely fifty yards off, on the banks of the Waal.
children.prevalue: One minute only to instruct our messenger who lives scarcely fifty yards off on the banks of the Waal

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: And during that time, notwithstanding all my injunctions, you left the key behind, unfortunate child!
children.prevalue: And during that time notwithstanding all my injunctions you left the key behind unfortunate child

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: No, no, no! this is what I cannot understand. The key was never out of my hands; I clinched it as if I were afraid it would take wings.
children.prevalue: No no no this is what I cannot understand The key was never out of my hands I clinched it as if I were afraid it would take wings

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: But how did it happen, then?
children.prevalue: But how did it happen then

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: That's what I cannot make out. I had given the letter to my messenger; he started before I left his house; I came home, and my door was locked, everything in my room was as I had left it, except the tulip,that was gone. Some one must have had a key for my room, or have got a false one made on purpose.
children.prevalue: That s what I cannot make out I had given the letter to my messenger he started before I left his house I came home and my door was locked everything in my room was as I had left it except the tulip that was gone Some one must have had a key for my room or have got a false one made on purpose

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: She was nearly choking with sobs, and was unable to continue.
children.prevalue: She was nearly choking with sobs and was unable to continue

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Cornelius, immovable and full of consternation, heard almost without understanding, and only muttered,
children.prevalue: Cornelius immovable and full of consternation heard almost without understanding and only muttered

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Stolen, stolen, and I am lost!
children.prevalue: Stolen stolen and I am lost

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: O Cornelius, forgive me, forgive me, it will kill me!
children.prevalue: O Cornelius forgive me forgive me it will kill me

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Seeing Rosa's distress, Cornelius seized the iron bars of the grating, and furiously shaking them, called out,
children.prevalue: Seeing Rosa s distress Cornelius seized the iron bars of the grating and furiously shaking them called out

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Rosa, Rosa, we have been robbed, it is true, but shall we allow ourselves to be dejected for all that? No, no; the misfortune is great, but it may perhaps be remedied. Rosa, we know the thief!
children.prevalue: Rosa Rosa we have been robbed it is true but shall we allow ourselves to be dejected for all that No no the misfortune is great but it may perhaps be remedied Rosa we know the thief

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Alas! what can I say about it?
children.prevalue: Alas what can I say about it

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: But I say that it is no one else but that infamous Jacob. Shall we allow him to carry to Haarlem the fruit of our labour, the fruit of our sleepless nights, the child of our love? Rosa, we must pursue, we must overtake him!
children.prevalue: But I say that it is no one else but that infamous Jacob Shall we allow him to carry to Haarlem the fruit of our labour the fruit of our sleepless nights the child of our love Rosa we must pursue we must overtake him

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: But how can we do all this, my friend, without letting my father know we were in communication with each other? How should I, a poor girl, with so little knowledge of the world and its ways, be able to attain this end, which perhaps you could not attain yourself?
children.prevalue: But how can we do all this my friend without letting my father know we were in communication with each other How should I a poor girl with so little knowledge of the world and its ways be able to attain this end which perhaps you could not attain yourself

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Rosa, Rosa, open this door to me, and you will see whether I will not find the thief,whether I will not make him confess his crime and beg for mercy.
children.prevalue: Rosa Rosa open this door to me and you will see whether I will not find the thief whether I will not make him confess his crime and beg for mercy

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Alas! cried Rosa, sobbing, can I open the door for you? have I the keys? If I had had them, would not you have been free long ago?
children.prevalue: Alas cried Rosa sobbing can I open the door for you have I the keys If I had had them would not you have been free long ago

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Your father has them,your wicked father, who has already crushed the first bulb of my tulip. Oh, the wretch! he is an accomplice of Jacob!
children.prevalue: Your father has them your wicked father who has already crushed the first bulb of my tulip Oh the wretch he is an accomplice of Jacob

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Don't speak so loud, for Heaven's sake!
children.prevalue: Don t speak so loud for Heaven s sake

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Oh, Rosa, if you don't open the door to me, Cornelius cried in his rage, I shall force these bars, and kill everything I find in the prison.
children.prevalue: Oh Rosa if you don t open the door to me Cornelius cried in his rage I shall force these bars and kill everything I find in the prison

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Be merciful, be merciful, my friend!
children.prevalue: Be merciful be merciful my friend

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: I tell you, Rosa, that I shall demolish this prison, stone for stone! and the unfortunate man, whose strength was increased tenfold by his rage, began to shake the door with a great noise, little heeding that the thunder of his voice was reechoing through the spiral staircase.
children.prevalue: I tell you Rosa that I shall demolish this prison stone for stone and the unfortunate man whose strength was increased tenfold by his rage began to shake the door with a great noise little heeding that the thunder of his voice was reechoing through the spiral staircase

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Rosa, in her fright, made vain attempts to check this furious outbreak.
children.prevalue: Rosa in her fright made vain attempts to check this furious outbreak

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I tell you that I shall kill that infamous Gryphus? roared Cornelius. I tell you I shall shed his blood as he did that of my black tulip.
children.prevalue: I tell you that I shall kill that infamous Gryphus roared Cornelius I tell you I shall shed his blood as he did that of my black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: The wretched prisoner began really to rave.
children.prevalue: The wretched prisoner began really to rave

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Well, then, yes, said Rosa, all in a tremble. Yes, yes, only be quiet. Yes, yes, I will take his keys, I will open the door for you! Yes, only be quiet, my own dear Cornelius.
children.prevalue: Well then yes said Rosa all in a tremble Yes yes only be quiet Yes yes I will take his keys I will open the door for you Yes only be quiet my own dear Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: She did not finish her speech, as a growl by her side interrupted her.
children.prevalue: She did not finish her speech as a growl by her side interrupted her

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: My father! cried Rosa.
children.prevalue: My father cried Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Gryphus! roared Van Baerle. Oh, you villain!
children.prevalue: Gryphus roared Van Baerle Oh you villain

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Old Gryphus, in the midst of all the noise, had ascended the staircase without being heard.
children.prevalue: Old Gryphus in the midst of all the noise had ascended the staircase without being heard

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: He rudely seized his daughter by the wrist.
children.prevalue: He rudely seized his daughter by the wrist

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: So you will take my keys? he said, in a voice choked with rage. Ah! this dastardly fellow, this monster, this gallowsbird of a conspirator, is your own dear Cornelius, is he? Ah! Missy has communications with prisoners of state. Ah! won't I teach youwon't I?
children.prevalue: So you will take my keys he said in a voice choked with rage Ah this dastardly fellow this monster this gallowsbird of a conspirator is your own dear Cornelius is he Ah Missy has communications with prisoners of state Ah won t I teach youwon t I

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Rosa clasped her hands in despair.
children.prevalue: Rosa clasped her hands in despair

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Ah! Gryphus continued, passing from the madness of anger to the cool irony of a man who has got the better of his enemy,Ah, you innocent tulipfancier, you gentle scholar; you will kill me, and drink my blood! Very well! very well! And you have my daughter for an accomplice. Am I, forsooth, in a den of thieves,in a cave of brigands? Yes, but the Governor shall know all tomorrow, and his Highness the Stadtholder the day after. We know the law,we shall give a second edition of the Buytenhof, Master Scholar, and a good one this time. Yes, yes, just gnaw your paws like a bear in his cage, and you, my fine little lady, devour your dear Cornelius with your eyes. I tell you, my lambkins, you shall not much longer have the felicity of conspiring together. Away with you, unnatural daughter! And as to you, Master Scholar, we shall see each other again. Just be quiet,we shall.
children.prevalue: Ah Gryphus continued passing from the madness of anger to the cool irony of a man who has got the better of his enemy Ah you innocent tulipfancier you gentle scholar you will kill me and drink my blood Very well very well And you have my daughter for an accomplice Am I forsooth in a den of thieves in a cave of brigands Yes but the Governor shall know all tomorrow and his Highness the Stadtholder the day after We know the law we shall give a second edition of the Buytenhof Master Scholar and a good one this time Yes yes just gnaw your paws like a bear in his cage and you my fine little lady devour your dear Cornelius with your eyes I tell you my lambkins you shall not much longer have the felicity of conspiring together Away with you unnatural daughter And as to you Master Scholar we shall see each other again Just be quiet we shall

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Rosa, beyond herself with terror and despair, kissed her hands to her friend; then, suddenly struck with a bright thought, she rushed toward the staircase, saying,
children.prevalue: Rosa beyond herself with terror and despair kissed her hands to her friend then suddenly struck with a bright thought she rushed toward the staircase saying

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: All is not yet lost, Cornelius. Rely on me, my Cornelius.
children.prevalue: All is not yet lost Cornelius Rely on me my Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Her father followed her, growling.
children.prevalue: Her father followed her growling

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: As to poor Cornelius, he gradually loosened his hold of the bars, which his fingers still grasped convulsively. His head was heavy, his eyes almost started from their sockets, and he fell heavily on the floor of his cell, muttering,
children.prevalue: As to poor Cornelius he gradually loosened his hold of the bars which his fingers still grasped convulsively His head was heavy his eyes almost started from their sockets and he fell heavily on the floor of his cell muttering

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Stolen! it has been stolen from me!
children.prevalue: Stolen it has been stolen from me

children.name: Paragraph_57
