children.value: During this time Boxtel had left the fortress by the door which Rosa herself had opened. He carried the black tulip wrapped up in a cloak, and, throwing himself into a coach, which was waiting for him at Gorcum, he drove off, without, as may well be imagined, having informed his friend Gryphus of his sudden departure.
children.prevalue: During this time Boxtel had left the fortress by the door which Rosa herself had opened He carried the black tulip wrapped up in a cloak and throwing himself into a coach which was waiting for him at Gorcum he drove off without as may well be imagined having informed his friend Gryphus of his sudden departure

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: And now, as we have seen him enter his coach, we shall with the consent of the reader, follow him to the end of his journey.
children.prevalue: And now as we have seen him enter his coach we shall with the consent of the reader follow him to the end of his journey

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: He proceeded but slowly, as the black tulip could not bear travelling posthaste.
children.prevalue: He proceeded but slowly as the black tulip could not bear travelling posthaste

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: But Boxtel, fearing that he might not arrive early enough, procured at Delft a box, lined all round with fresh moss, in which he packed the tulip. The flower was so lightly pressed upon all sides, with a supply of air from above, that the coach could now travel full speed without any possibility of injury to the tulip.
children.prevalue: But Boxtel fearing that he might not arrive early enough procured at Delft a box lined all round with fresh moss in which he packed the tulip The flower was so lightly pressed upon all sides with a supply of air from above that the coach could now travel full speed without any possibility of injury to the tulip

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: He arrived next morning at Haarlem, fatigued but triumphant; and, to do away with every trace of the theft, he transplanted the tulip, and, breaking the original flowerpot, threw the pieces into the canal. After which he wrote the President of the Horticultural Society a letter, in which he announced to him that he had just arrived at Haarlem with a perfectly black tulip; and, with his flower all safe, took up his quarters at a good hotel in the town, and there he waited.
children.prevalue: He arrived next morning at Haarlem fatigued but triumphant and to do away with every trace of the theft he transplanted the tulip and breaking the original flowerpot threw the pieces into the canal After which he wrote the President of the Horticultural Society a letter in which he announced to him that he had just arrived at Haarlem with a perfectly black tulip and with his flower all safe took up his quarters at a good hotel in the town and there he waited

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Rosa, on leaving Cornelius, had fixed on her plan, which was no other than to restore to Cornelius the stolen tulip, or never to see him again.
children.prevalue: Rosa on leaving Cornelius had fixed on her plan which was no other than to restore to Cornelius the stolen tulip or never to see him again

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: She had seen the despair of the prisoner, and she knew that it was derived from a double source, and that it was incurable.
children.prevalue: She had seen the despair of the prisoner and she knew that it was derived from a double source and that it was incurable

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: On the one hand, separation became inevitable,Gryphus having at the same time surprised the secret of their love and of their secret meetings.
children.prevalue: On the one hand separation became inevitable Gryphus having at the same time surprised the secret of their love and of their secret meetings

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: On the other hand, all the hopes on the fulfilment of which Cornelius van Baerle had rested his ambition for the last seven years were now crushed.
children.prevalue: On the other hand all the hopes on the fulfilment of which Cornelius van Baerle had rested his ambition for the last seven years were now crushed

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Rosa was one of those women who are dejected by trifles, but who in great emergencies are supplied by the misfortune itself with the energy for combating or with the resources for remedying it.
children.prevalue: Rosa was one of those women who are dejected by trifles but who in great emergencies are supplied by the misfortune itself with the energy for combating or with the resources for remedying it

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: She went to her room, and cast a last glance about her to see whether she had not been mistaken, and whether the tulip was not stowed away in some corner where it had escaped her notice. But she sought in vain, the tulip was still missing; the tulip was indeed stolen.
children.prevalue: She went to her room and cast a last glance about her to see whether she had not been mistaken and whether the tulip was not stowed away in some corner where it had escaped her notice But she sought in vain the tulip was still missing the tulip was indeed stolen

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Rosa made up a little parcel of things indispensable for a journey; took her three hundred guilders,that is to say, all her fortune,fetched the third bulb from among her lace, where she had laid it up, and carefully hid it in her bosom; after which she locked her door twice to disguise her flight as long as possible, and, leaving the prison by the same door which an hour before had let out Boxtel, she went to a stablekeeper to hire a carriage.
children.prevalue: Rosa made up a little parcel of things indispensable for a journey took her three hundred guilders that is to say all her fortune fetched the third bulb from among her lace where she had laid it up and carefully hid it in her bosom after which she locked her door twice to disguise her flight as long as possible and leaving the prison by the same door which an hour before had let out Boxtel she went to a stablekeeper to hire a carriage

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The man had only a twowheel chaise, and this was the vehicle which Boxtel had hired since last evening, and in which he was now driving along the road to Delft; for the road from Loewestein to Haarlem, owing to the many canals, rivers, and rivulets intersecting the country, is exceedingly circuitous.
children.prevalue: The man had only a twowheel chaise and this was the vehicle which Boxtel had hired since last evening and in which he was now driving along the road to Delft for the road from Loewestein to Haarlem owing to the many canals rivers and rivulets intersecting the country is exceedingly circuitous

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Not being able to procure a vehicle, Rosa was obliged to take a horse, with which the stablekeeper readily intrusted her, knowing her to be the daughter of the jailer of the fortress.
children.prevalue: Not being able to procure a vehicle Rosa was obliged to take a horse with which the stablekeeper readily intrusted her knowing her to be the daughter of the jailer of the fortress

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Rosa hoped to overtake her messenger, a kindhearted and honest lad, whom she would take with her, and who might at the same time serve her as a guide and a protector.
children.prevalue: Rosa hoped to overtake her messenger a kindhearted and honest lad whom she would take with her and who might at the same time serve her as a guide and a protector

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: And in fact she had not proceeded more than a league before she saw him hastening along one of the side paths of a very pretty road by the river. Setting her horse off at a canter, she soon came up with him.
children.prevalue: And in fact she had not proceeded more than a league before she saw him hastening along one of the side paths of a very pretty road by the river Setting her horse off at a canter she soon came up with him

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The honest lad was not aware of the important character of his message; nevertheless, he used as much speed as if he had known it; and in less than an hour he had already gone a league and a half.
children.prevalue: The honest lad was not aware of the important character of his message nevertheless he used as much speed as if he had known it and in less than an hour he had already gone a league and a half

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Rosa took from him the note, which had now become useless, and explained to him what she wanted him to do for her. The boatman placed himself entirely at her disposal, promising to keep pace with the horse if Rosa would allow him to take hold of either the croup or the bridle of her horse. The two travellers had been on their way for five hours, and made more than eight leagues, and yet Gryphus had not the least suspicion of his daughter having left the fortress.
children.prevalue: Rosa took from him the note which had now become useless and explained to him what she wanted him to do for her The boatman placed himself entirely at her disposal promising to keep pace with the horse if Rosa would allow him to take hold of either the croup or the bridle of her horse The two travellers had been on their way for five hours and made more than eight leagues and yet Gryphus had not the least suspicion of his daughter having left the fortress

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The jailer, who was of a very spiteful and cruel disposition, chuckled within himself at the idea of having struck such terror into his daughter's heart.
children.prevalue: The jailer who was of a very spiteful and cruel disposition chuckled within himself at the idea of having struck such terror into his daughter s heart

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: But whilst he was congratulating himself on having such a nice story to tell to his boon companion, Jacob, that worthy was on his road to Delft; and, thanks to the swiftness of the horse, had already the start of Rosa and her companion by four leagues.
children.prevalue: But whilst he was congratulating himself on having such a nice story to tell to his boon companion Jacob that worthy was on his road to Delft and thanks to the swiftness of the horse had already the start of Rosa and her companion by four leagues

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: And whilst the affectionate father was rejoicing at the thought of his daughter weeping in her room, Rosa was making the best of her way towards Haarlem.
children.prevalue: And whilst the affectionate father was rejoicing at the thought of his daughter weeping in her room Rosa was making the best of her way towards Haarlem

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Thus the prisoner alone was where Gryphus thought him to be.
children.prevalue: Thus the prisoner alone was where Gryphus thought him to be

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Rosa was so little with her father since she took care of the tulip, that at his dinner hour, that is to say, at twelve o'clock, he was reminded for the first time by his appetite that his daughter was fretting rather too long.
children.prevalue: Rosa was so little with her father since she took care of the tulip that at his dinner hour that is to say at twelve o clock he was reminded for the first time by his appetite that his daughter was fretting rather too long

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: He sent one of the underturnkeys to call her; and, when the man came back to tell him that he had called and sought her in vain, he resolved to go and call her himself.
children.prevalue: He sent one of the underturnkeys to call her and when the man came back to tell him that he had called and sought her in vain he resolved to go and call her himself

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: He first went to her room, but, loud as he knocked, Rosa answered not.
children.prevalue: He first went to her room but loud as he knocked Rosa answered not

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: The locksmith of the fortress was sent for; he opened the door, but Gryphus no more found Rosa than she had found the tulip.
children.prevalue: The locksmith of the fortress was sent for he opened the door but Gryphus no more found Rosa than she had found the tulip

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: At that very moment she entered Rotterdam.
children.prevalue: At that very moment she entered Rotterdam

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Gryphus therefore had just as little chance of finding her in the kitchen as in her room, and just as little in the garden as in the kitchen.
children.prevalue: Gryphus therefore had just as little chance of finding her in the kitchen as in her room and just as little in the garden as in the kitchen

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The reader may imagine the anger of the jailer when, after having made inquiries about the neighbourhood, he heard that his daughter had hired a horse, and, like an adventuress, set out on a journey without saying where she was going.
children.prevalue: The reader may imagine the anger of the jailer when after having made inquiries about the neighbourhood he heard that his daughter had hired a horse and like an adventuress set out on a journey without saying where she was going

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Gryphus again went up in his fury to Van Baerle, abused him, threatened him, knocked all the miserable furniture of his cell about, and promised him all sorts of misery, even starvation and flogging.
children.prevalue: Gryphus again went up in his fury to Van Baerle abused him threatened him knocked all the miserable furniture of his cell about and promised him all sorts of misery even starvation and flogging

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Cornelius, without even hearing what his jailer said, allowed himself to be illtreated, abused, and threatened, remaining all the while sullen, immovable, dead to every emotion and fear.
children.prevalue: Cornelius without even hearing what his jailer said allowed himself to be illtreated abused and threatened remaining all the while sullen immovable dead to every emotion and fear

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: After having sought for Rosa in every direction, Gryphus looked out for Jacob, and, as he could not find him either, he began to suspect from that moment that Jacob had run away with her.
children.prevalue: After having sought for Rosa in every direction Gryphus looked out for Jacob and as he could not find him either he began to suspect from that moment that Jacob had run away with her

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: The damsel, meanwhile, after having stopped for two hours at Rotterdam, had started again on her journey. On that evening she slept at Delft, and on the following morning she reached Haarlem, four hours after Boxtel had arrived there.
children.prevalue: The damsel meanwhile after having stopped for two hours at Rotterdam had started again on her journey On that evening she slept at Delft and on the following morning she reached Haarlem four hours after Boxtel had arrived there

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Rosa, first of all, caused herself to be led before Mynheer van Systens, the President of the Horticultural Society of Haarlem.
children.prevalue: Rosa first of all caused herself to be led before Mynheer van Systens the President of the Horticultural Society of Haarlem

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: She found that worthy gentleman in a situation which, to do justice to our story, we must not pass over in our description.
children.prevalue: She found that worthy gentleman in a situation which to do justice to our story we must not pass over in our description

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: The President was drawing up a report to the committee of the society.
children.prevalue: The President was drawing up a report to the committee of the society

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: This report was written on largesized paper, in the finest handwriting of the President.
children.prevalue: This report was written on largesized paper in the finest handwriting of the President

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Rosa was announced simply as Rosa Gryphus; but as her name, well as it might sound, was unknown to the President, she was refused admittance.
children.prevalue: Rosa was announced simply as Rosa Gryphus but as her name well as it might sound was unknown to the President she was refused admittance

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Rosa, however, was by no means abashed, having vowed in her heart, in pursuing her cause, not to allow herself to be put down either by refusal, or abuse, or even brutality.
children.prevalue: Rosa however was by no means abashed having vowed in her heart in pursuing her cause not to allow herself to be put down either by refusal or abuse or even brutality

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Announce to the President, she said to the servant, that I want to speak to him about the black tulip.
children.prevalue: Announce to the President she said to the servant that I want to speak to him about the black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: These words seemed to be an Open Sesame, for she soon found herself in the office of the President, Van Systens, who gallantly rose from his chair to meet her.
children.prevalue: These words seemed to be an Open Sesame for she soon found herself in the office of the President Van Systens who gallantly rose from his chair to meet her

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: He was a spare little man, resembling the stem of a flower, his head forming its chalice, and his two limp arms representing the double leaf of the tulip; the resemblance was rendered complete by his waddling gait which made him even more like that flower when it bends under a breeze.
children.prevalue: He was a spare little man resembling the stem of a flower his head forming its chalice and his two limp arms representing the double leaf of the tulip the resemblance was rendered complete by his waddling gait which made him even more like that flower when it bends under a breeze

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Well, miss, he said, you are coming, I am told, about the affair of the black tulip.
children.prevalue: Well miss he said you are coming I am told about the affair of the black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: To the President of the Horticultural Society the Tulipa nigra was a firstrate power, which, in its character as queen of the tulips, might send ambassadors.
children.prevalue: To the President of the Horticultural Society the Tulipa nigra was a firstrate power which in its character as queen of the tulips might send ambassadors

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Yes, sir, answered Rosa; I come at least to speak of it.
children.prevalue: Yes sir answered Rosa I come at least to speak of it

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Is it doing well, then? asked Van Systens, with a smile of tender veneration.
children.prevalue: Is it doing well then asked Van Systens with a smile of tender veneration

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Alas! sir, I don't know, said Rosa.
children.prevalue: Alas sir I don t know said Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: How is that? could any misfortune have happened to it?
children.prevalue: How is that could any misfortune have happened to it

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: A very great one, sir; yet not to it, but to me.
children.prevalue: A very great one sir yet not to it but to me

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: What?
children.prevalue: What

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: It has been stolen from me.
children.prevalue: It has been stolen from me

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Stolen! the black tulip?
children.prevalue: Stolen the black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Yes, sir.
children.prevalue: Yes sir

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Do you know the thief?
children.prevalue: Do you know the thief

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: I have my suspicions, but I must not yet accuse any one.
children.prevalue: I have my suspicions but I must not yet accuse any one

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: But the matter may very easily be ascertained.
children.prevalue: But the matter may very easily be ascertained

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: How is that?
children.prevalue: How is that

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: As it has been stolen from you, the thief cannot be far off.
children.prevalue: As it has been stolen from you the thief cannot be far off

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Why not?
children.prevalue: Why not

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Because I have seen the black tulip only two hours ago.
children.prevalue: Because I have seen the black tulip only two hours ago

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: You have seen the black tulip! cried Rosa, rushing up to Mynheer van Systens.
children.prevalue: You have seen the black tulip cried Rosa rushing up to Mynheer van Systens

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: As I see you, miss.
children.prevalue: As I see you miss

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: But where?
children.prevalue: But where

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Well, with your master, of course.
children.prevalue: Well with your master of course

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: With my master?
children.prevalue: With my master

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Yes, are you not in the service of Master Isaac Boxtel?
children.prevalue: Yes are you not in the service of Master Isaac Boxtel

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I?
children.prevalue: I

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Yes, you.
children.prevalue: Yes you

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: But for whom do you take me, sir?
children.prevalue: But for whom do you take me sir

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: And for whom do you take me?
children.prevalue: And for whom do you take me

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: I hope, sir, I take you for what you are,that is to say, for the honorable Mynheer van Systens, Burgomaster of Haarlem, and President of the Horticultural Society.
children.prevalue: I hope sir I take you for what you are that is to say for the honorable Mynheer van Systens Burgomaster of Haarlem and President of the Horticultural Society

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: And what is it you told me just now?
children.prevalue: And what is it you told me just now

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: I told you, sir, that my tulip has been stolen.
children.prevalue: I told you sir that my tulip has been stolen

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Then your tulip is that of Mynheer Boxtel. Well, my child, you express yourself very badly. The tulip has been stolen, not from you, but from Mynheer Boxtel.
children.prevalue: Then your tulip is that of Mynheer Boxtel Well my child you express yourself very badly The tulip has been stolen not from you but from Mynheer Boxtel

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: I repeat to you, sir, that I do not know who this Mynheer Boxtel is, and that I have now heard his name pronounced for the first time.
children.prevalue: I repeat to you sir that I do not know who this Mynheer Boxtel is and that I have now heard his name pronounced for the first time

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: You do not know who Mynheer Boxtel is, and you also had a black tulip?
children.prevalue: You do not know who Mynheer Boxtel is and you also had a black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: But is there any other besides mine? asked Rosa, trembling.
children.prevalue: But is there any other besides mine asked Rosa trembling

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Yes,that of Mynheer Boxtel.
children.prevalue: Yes that of Mynheer Boxtel

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: How is it?
children.prevalue: How is it

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Black, of course.
children.prevalue: Black of course

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Without speck?
children.prevalue: Without speck

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Without a single speck, or even point.
children.prevalue: Without a single speck or even point

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: And you have this tulip,you have it deposited here?
children.prevalue: And you have this tulip you have it deposited here

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: No, but it will be, as it has to be exhibited before the committee previous to the prize being awarded.
children.prevalue: No but it will be as it has to be exhibited before the committee previous to the prize being awarded

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Oh, sir! cried Rosa, this Boxtelthis Isaac Boxtelwho calls himself the owner of the black tulip
children.prevalue: Oh sir cried Rosa this Boxtelthis Isaac Boxtelwho calls himself the owner of the black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: And who is its owner?
children.prevalue: And who is its owner

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Is he not a very thin man?
children.prevalue: Is he not a very thin man

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Bald?
children.prevalue: Bald

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: With sunken eyes?
children.prevalue: With sunken eyes

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: I think he has.
children.prevalue: I think he has

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Restless, stooping, and bowlegged?
children.prevalue: Restless stooping and bowlegged

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: In truth, you draw Master Boxtel's portrait feature by feature.
children.prevalue: In truth you draw Master Boxtel s portrait feature by feature

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: And the tulip, sir? Is it not in a pot of white and blue earthenware, with yellowish flowers in a basket on three sides?
children.prevalue: And the tulip sir Is it not in a pot of white and blue earthenware with yellowish flowers in a basket on three sides

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Oh, as to that I am not quite sure; I looked more at the flower than at the pot.
children.prevalue: Oh as to that I am not quite sure I looked more at the flower than at the pot

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Oh, sir! that's my tulip, which has been stolen from me. I came here to reclaim it before you and from you.
children.prevalue: Oh sir that s my tulip which has been stolen from me I came here to reclaim it before you and from you

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Oh! oh! said Van Systens, looking at Rosa. What! you are here to claim the tulip of Master Boxtel? Well, I must say, you are cool enough.
children.prevalue: Oh oh said Van Systens looking at Rosa What you are here to claim the tulip of Master Boxtel Well I must say you are cool enough

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Honoured sir, a little put out by this apostrophe, I do not say that I am coming to claim the tulip of Master Boxtel, but to reclaim my own.
children.prevalue: Honoured sir a little put out by this apostrophe I do not say that I am coming to claim the tulip of Master Boxtel but to reclaim my own

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Yours?
children.prevalue: Yours

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Yes, the one which I have myself planted and nursed.
children.prevalue: Yes the one which I have myself planted and nursed

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Well, then, go and find out Master Boxtel, at the White Swan Inn, and you can then settle matters with him; as for me, considering that the cause seems to me as difficult to judge as that which was brought before King Solomon, and that I do not pretend to be as wise as he was, I shall content myself with making my report, establishing the existence of the black tulip, and ordering the hundred thousand guilders to be paid to its grower. Goodbye, my child.
children.prevalue: Well then go and find out Master Boxtel at the White Swan Inn and you can then settle matters with him as for me considering that the cause seems to me as difficult to judge as that which was brought before King Solomon and that I do not pretend to be as wise as he was I shall content myself with making my report establishing the existence of the black tulip and ordering the hundred thousand guilders to be paid to its grower Goodbye my child

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Oh, sir, sir! said Rosa, imploringly.
children.prevalue: Oh sir sir said Rosa imploringly

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Only, my child, continued Van Systens, as you are young and pretty, and as there may be still some good in you, I'll give you some good advice. Be prudent in this matter, for we have a court of justice and a prison here at Haarlem, and, moreover, we are exceedingly ticklish as far as the honour of our tulips is concerned. Go, my child, go, remember, Master Isaac Boxtel at the White Swan Inn.
children.prevalue: Only my child continued Van Systens as you are young and pretty and as there may be still some good in you I ll give you some good advice Be prudent in this matter for we have a court of justice and a prison here at Haarlem and moreover we are exceedingly ticklish as far as the honour of our tulips is concerned Go my child go remember Master Isaac Boxtel at the White Swan Inn

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: And Mynheer van Systens, taking up his fine pen, resumed his report, which had been interrupted by Rosa's visit.
children.prevalue: And Mynheer van Systens taking up his fine pen resumed his report which had been interrupted by Rosa s visit

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Rosa, beyond herself and nearly mad with joy and fear at the idea of the black tulip being found again, started for the White Swan, followed by the boatman, a stout lad from Frisia, who was strong enough to knock down a dozen Boxtels singlehanded.
children.prevalue: Rosa beyond herself and nearly mad with joy and fear at the idea of the black tulip being found again started for the White Swan followed by the boatman a stout lad from Frisia who was strong enough to knock down a dozen Boxtels singlehanded

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: He had been made acquainted in the course of the journey with the state of affairs, and was not afraid of any encounter; only he had orders, in such a case, to spare the tulip.
children.prevalue: He had been made acquainted in the course of the journey with the state of affairs and was not afraid of any encounter only he had orders in such a case to spare the tulip

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: But on arriving in the great marketplace Rosa at once stopped, a sudden thought had struck her, just as Homer's Minerva seizes Achilles by the hair at the moment when he is about to be carried away by his anger.
children.prevalue: But on arriving in the great marketplace Rosa at once stopped a sudden thought had struck her just as Homer s Minerva seizes Achilles by the hair at the moment when he is about to be carried away by his anger

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Good Heaven! she muttered to herself, I have made a grievous blunder; it may be I have ruined Cornelius, the tulip, and myself. I have given the alarm, and perhaps awakened suspicion. I am but a woman; these men may league themselves against me, and then I shall be lost. If I am lost that matters nothing,but Cornelius and the tulip!
children.prevalue: Good Heaven she muttered to herself I have made a grievous blunder it may be I have ruined Cornelius the tulip and myself I have given the alarm and perhaps awakened suspicion I am but a woman these men may league themselves against me and then I shall be lost If I am lost that matters nothing but Cornelius and the tulip

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: She reflected for a moment.
children.prevalue: She reflected for a moment

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: If I go to that Boxtel, and do not know him; if that Boxtel is not my Jacob, but another fancier, who has also discovered the black tulip; or if my tulip has been stolen by some one else, or has already passed into the hands of a third person;if I do not recognize the man, only the tulip, how shall I prove that it belongs to me? On the other hand, if I recognise this Boxtel as Jacob, who knows what will come out of it? whilst we are contesting with each other, the tulip will die.
children.prevalue: If I go to that Boxtel and do not know him if that Boxtel is not my Jacob but another fancier who has also discovered the black tulip or if my tulip has been stolen by some one else or has already passed into the hands of a third person if I do not recognize the man only the tulip how shall I prove that it belongs to me On the other hand if I recognise this Boxtel as Jacob who knows what will come out of it whilst we are contesting with each other the tulip will die

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: In the meanwhile, a great noise was heard, like the distant roar of the sea, at the other extremity of the marketplace. People were running about, doors opening and shutting, Rosa alone was unconscious of all this hubbub among the multitude.
children.prevalue: In the meanwhile a great noise was heard like the distant roar of the sea at the other extremity of the marketplace People were running about doors opening and shutting Rosa alone was unconscious of all this hubbub among the multitude

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: We must return to the President, she muttered.
children.prevalue: We must return to the President she muttered

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Well, then, let us return, said the boatman.
children.prevalue: Well then let us return said the boatman

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: They took a small street, which led them straight to the mansion of Mynheer van Systens, who with his best pen in his finest hand continued to draw up his report.
children.prevalue: They took a small street which led them straight to the mansion of Mynheer van Systens who with his best pen in his finest hand continued to draw up his report

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Everywhere on her way Rosa heard people speaking only of the black tulip, and the prize of a hundred thousand guilders. The news had spread like wildfire through the town.
children.prevalue: Everywhere on her way Rosa heard people speaking only of the black tulip and the prize of a hundred thousand guilders The news had spread like wildfire through the town

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Rosa had not a little difficulty is penetrating a second time into the office of Mynheer van Systens, who, however, was again moved by the magic name of the black tulip.
children.prevalue: Rosa had not a little difficulty is penetrating a second time into the office of Mynheer van Systens who however was again moved by the magic name of the black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: But when he recognised Rosa, whom in his own mind he had set down as mad, or even worse, he grew angry, and wanted to send her away.
children.prevalue: But when he recognised Rosa whom in his own mind he had set down as mad or even worse he grew angry and wanted to send her away

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Rosa, however, clasped her hands, and said with that tone of honest truth which generally finds its way to the hearts of men,
children.prevalue: Rosa however clasped her hands and said with that tone of honest truth which generally finds its way to the hearts of men

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: For Heaven's sake, sir, do not turn me away; listen to what I have to tell you, and if it be not possible for you to do me justice, at least you will not one day have to reproach yourself before God for having made yourself the accomplice of a bad action.
children.prevalue: For Heaven s sake sir do not turn me away listen to what I have to tell you and if it be not possible for you to do me justice at least you will not one day have to reproach yourself before God for having made yourself the accomplice of a bad action

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Van Systens stamped his foot with impatience; it was the second time that Rosa interrupted him in the midst of a composition which stimulated his vanity, both as a burgomaster and as President of the Horticultural Society.
children.prevalue: Van Systens stamped his foot with impatience it was the second time that Rosa interrupted him in the midst of a composition which stimulated his vanity both as a burgomaster and as President of the Horticultural Society

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: But my report! he cried,my report on the black tulip!
children.prevalue: But my report he cried my report on the black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Mynheer van Systens, Rosa continued, with the firmness of innocence and truth, your report on the black tulip will, if you don't hear me, be based on crime or on falsehood. I implore you, sir, let this Master Boxtel, whom I assert to be Master Jacob, be brought here before you and me, and I swear that I will leave him in undisturbed possession of the tulip if I do not recognise the flower and its holder.
children.prevalue: Mynheer van Systens Rosa continued with the firmness of innocence and truth your report on the black tulip will if you don t hear me be based on crime or on falsehood I implore you sir let this Master Boxtel whom I assert to be Master Jacob be brought here before you and me and I swear that I will leave him in undisturbed possession of the tulip if I do not recognise the flower and its holder

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Well, I declare, here is a proposal, said Van Systens.
children.prevalue: Well I declare here is a proposal said Van Systens

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I ask you what can be proved by your recognising them?
children.prevalue: I ask you what can be proved by your recognising them

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: After all, said Rosa, in her despair, you are an honest man, sir; how would you feel if one day you found out that you had given the prize to a man for something which he not only had not produced, but which he had even stolen?
children.prevalue: After all said Rosa in her despair you are an honest man sir how would you feel if one day you found out that you had given the prize to a man for something which he not only had not produced but which he had even stolen

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Rosa's speech seemed to have brought a certain conviction into the heart of Van Systens, and he was going to answer her in a gentler tone, when at once a great noise was heard in the street, and loud cheers shook the house.
children.prevalue: Rosa s speech seemed to have brought a certain conviction into the heart of Van Systens and he was going to answer her in a gentler tone when at once a great noise was heard in the street and loud cheers shook the house

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: What is this? cried the burgomaster; what is this? Is it possible? have I heard aright?
children.prevalue: What is this cried the burgomaster what is this Is it possible have I heard aright

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: And he rushed towards his anteroom, without any longer heeding Rosa, whom he left in his cabinet.
children.prevalue: And he rushed towards his anteroom without any longer heeding Rosa whom he left in his cabinet

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Scarcely had he reached his anteroom when he cried out aloud on seeing his staircase invaded, up to the very landingplace, by the multitude, which was accompanying, or rather following, a young man, simply clad in a violetcoloured velvet, embroidered with silver; who, with a certain aristocratic slowness, ascended the white stone steps of the house.
children.prevalue: Scarcely had he reached his anteroom when he cried out aloud on seeing his staircase invaded up to the very landingplace by the multitude which was accompanying or rather following a young man simply clad in a violetcoloured velvet embroidered with silver who with a certain aristocratic slowness ascended the white stone steps of the house

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: In his wake followed two officers, one of the navy, and the other of the cavalry.
children.prevalue: In his wake followed two officers one of the navy and the other of the cavalry

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Van Systens, having found his way through the frightened domestics, began to bow, almost to prostrate himself before his visitor, who had been the cause of all this stir.
children.prevalue: Van Systens having found his way through the frightened domestics began to bow almost to prostrate himself before his visitor who had been the cause of all this stir

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Monseigneur, he called out, Monseigneur! What distinguished honour is your Highness bestowing for ever on my humble house by your visit?
children.prevalue: Monseigneur he called out Monseigneur What distinguished honour is your Highness bestowing for ever on my humble house by your visit

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Dear Mynheer van Systens, said William of Orange, with a serenity which, with him, took the place of a smile, I am a true Hollander, I am fond of the water, of beer, and of flowers, sometimes even of that cheese the flavour of which seems so grateful to the French; the flower which I prefer to all others is, of course, the tulip. I heard at Leyden that the city of Haarlem at last possessed the black tulip; and, after having satisfied myself of the truth of news which seemed so incredible, I have come to know all about it from the President of the Horticultural Society.
children.prevalue: Dear Mynheer van Systens said William of Orange with a serenity which with him took the place of a smile I am a true Hollander I am fond of the water of beer and of flowers sometimes even of that cheese the flavour of which seems so grateful to the French the flower which I prefer to all others is of course the tulip I heard at Leyden that the city of Haarlem at last possessed the black tulip and after having satisfied myself of the truth of news which seemed so incredible I have come to know all about it from the President of the Horticultural Society

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Oh, Monseigneur, Monseigneur! said Van Systens, what glory to the society if its endeavours are pleasing to your Highness!
children.prevalue: Oh Monseigneur Monseigneur said Van Systens what glory to the society if its endeavours are pleasing to your Highness

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Have you got the flower here? said the Prince, who, very likely, already regretted having made such a long speech.
children.prevalue: Have you got the flower here said the Prince who very likely already regretted having made such a long speech

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I am sorry to say we have not.
children.prevalue: I am sorry to say we have not

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: And where is it?
children.prevalue: And where is it

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: With its owner.
children.prevalue: With its owner

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Who is he?
children.prevalue: Who is he

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: An honest tulipgrower of Dort.
children.prevalue: An honest tulipgrower of Dort

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: His name?
children.prevalue: His name

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Boxtel.
children.prevalue: Boxtel

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: His quarters?
children.prevalue: His quarters

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: At the White Swan; I shall send for him, and if in the meanwhile your Highness will do me the honour of stepping into my drawingroom, he will be sureknowing that your Highness is hereto lose no time in bringing his tulip.
children.prevalue: At the White Swan I shall send for him and if in the meanwhile your Highness will do me the honour of stepping into my drawingroom he will be sureknowing that your Highness is hereto lose no time in bringing his tulip

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Very well, send for him.
children.prevalue: Very well send for him

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Yes, your Highness, but
children.prevalue: Yes your Highness but

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: What is it?
children.prevalue: What is it

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Oh, nothing of any consequence, Monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Oh nothing of any consequence Monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Everything is of consequence, Mynheer van Systens.
children.prevalue: Everything is of consequence Mynheer van Systens

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Well, then, Monseigneur, if it must be said, a little difficulty has presented itself.
children.prevalue: Well then Monseigneur if it must be said a little difficulty has presented itself

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: What difficulty?
children.prevalue: What difficulty

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: This tulip has already been claimed by usurpers. It's true that it is worth a hundred thousand guilders.
children.prevalue: This tulip has already been claimed by usurpers It s true that it is worth a hundred thousand guilders

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Indeed!
children.prevalue: Indeed

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Yes, Monseigneur, by usurpers, by forgers.
children.prevalue: Yes Monseigneur by usurpers by forgers

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: This is a crime, Mynheer van Systens.
children.prevalue: This is a crime Mynheer van Systens

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: So it is, your Highness.
children.prevalue: So it is your Highness

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: And have you any proofs of their guilt?
children.prevalue: And have you any proofs of their guilt

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: No, Monseigneur, the guilty woman
children.prevalue: No Monseigneur the guilty woman

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: The guilty woman, Sir?
children.prevalue: The guilty woman Sir

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: I ought to say, the woman who claims the tulip, Monseigneur, is here in the room close by.
children.prevalue: I ought to say the woman who claims the tulip Monseigneur is here in the room close by

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: And what do you think of her?
children.prevalue: And what do you think of her

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: I think, Monseigneur, that the bait of a hundred thousand guilders may have tempted her.
children.prevalue: I think Monseigneur that the bait of a hundred thousand guilders may have tempted her

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: And so she claims the tulip?
children.prevalue: And so she claims the tulip

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Yes Monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes Monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: And what proof does she offer?
children.prevalue: And what proof does she offer

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: I was just going to question her when your Highness came in.
children.prevalue: I was just going to question her when your Highness came in

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Question her, Mynheer van Systens, question her. I am the first magistrate of the country; I will hear the case and administer justice.
children.prevalue: Question her Mynheer van Systens question her I am the first magistrate of the country I will hear the case and administer justice

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: I have found my King Solomon, said Van Systens, bowing, and showing the way to the Prince.
children.prevalue: I have found my King Solomon said Van Systens bowing and showing the way to the Prince

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: His Highness was just going to walk ahead, but, suddenly recollecting himself he said
children.prevalue: His Highness was just going to walk ahead but suddenly recollecting himself he said

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Go before me, and call me plain Mynheer.
children.prevalue: Go before me and call me plain Mynheer

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: The two then entered the cabinet.
children.prevalue: The two then entered the cabinet

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Rosa was still standing at the same place, leaning on the window, and looking through the panes into the garden.
children.prevalue: Rosa was still standing at the same place leaning on the window and looking through the panes into the garden

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Ah! a Frisian girl, said the Prince, as he observed Rosa's gold brocade headdress and red petticoat.
children.prevalue: Ah a Frisian girl said the Prince as he observed Rosa s gold brocade headdress and red petticoat

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: At the noise of their footsteps she turned round, but scarcely saw the Prince, who seated himself in the darkest corner of the apartment.
children.prevalue: At the noise of their footsteps she turned round but scarcely saw the Prince who seated himself in the darkest corner of the apartment

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: All her attention, as may be easily imagined, was fixed on that important person who was called Van Systens, so that she had no time to notice the humble stranger who was following the master of the house, and who, for aught she knew, might be somebody or nobody.
children.prevalue: All her attention as may be easily imagined was fixed on that important person who was called Van Systens so that she had no time to notice the humble stranger who was following the master of the house and who for aught she knew might be somebody or nobody

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: The humble stranger took a book down from the shelf, and made Van Systens a sign to commence the examination forthwith.
children.prevalue: The humble stranger took a book down from the shelf and made Van Systens a sign to commence the examination forthwith

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Van Systens, likewise at the invitation of the young man in the violet coat, sat down in his turn, and, quite happy and proud of the importance thus cast upon him, began,
children.prevalue: Van Systens likewise at the invitation of the young man in the violet coat sat down in his turn and quite happy and proud of the importance thus cast upon him began

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: My child, you promise to tell me the truth and the entire truth concerning this tulip?
children.prevalue: My child you promise to tell me the truth and the entire truth concerning this tulip

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: I promise.
children.prevalue: I promise

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Well, then, speak before this gentleman; this gentleman is one of the members of the Horticultural Society.
children.prevalue: Well then speak before this gentleman this gentleman is one of the members of the Horticultural Society

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: What am I to tell you, sir, said Rosa, beside that which I have told you already.
children.prevalue: What am I to tell you sir said Rosa beside that which I have told you already

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Well, then, what is it?
children.prevalue: Well then what is it

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: I repeat the question I have addressed to you before.
children.prevalue: I repeat the question I have addressed to you before

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Which?
children.prevalue: Which

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: That you will order Mynheer Boxtel to come here with his tulip. If I do not recognise it as mine I will frankly tell it; but if I do recognise it I will reclaim it, even if I go before his Highness the Stadtholder himself, with my proofs in my hands.
children.prevalue: That you will order Mynheer Boxtel to come here with his tulip If I do not recognise it as mine I will frankly tell it but if I do recognise it I will reclaim it even if I go before his Highness the Stadtholder himself with my proofs in my hands

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: You have, then, some proofs, my child?
children.prevalue: You have then some proofs my child

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: God, who knows my good right, will assist me to some.
children.prevalue: God who knows my good right will assist me to some

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Van Systens exchanged a look with the Prince, who, since the first words of Rosa, seemed to try to remember her, as if it were not for the first time that this sweet voice rang in his ears.
children.prevalue: Van Systens exchanged a look with the Prince who since the first words of Rosa seemed to try to remember her as if it were not for the first time that this sweet voice rang in his ears

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: An officer went off to fetch Boxtel, and Van Systens in the meanwhile continued his examination.
children.prevalue: An officer went off to fetch Boxtel and Van Systens in the meanwhile continued his examination

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: And with what do you support your assertion that you are the real owner of the black tulip?
children.prevalue: And with what do you support your assertion that you are the real owner of the black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: With the very simple fact of my having planted and grown it in my own chamber.
children.prevalue: With the very simple fact of my having planted and grown it in my own chamber

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: In your chamber? Where was your chamber?
children.prevalue: In your chamber Where was your chamber

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: At Loewestein.
children.prevalue: At Loewestein

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: You are from Loewestein?
children.prevalue: You are from Loewestein

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: I am the daughter of the jailer of the fortress.
children.prevalue: I am the daughter of the jailer of the fortress

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: The Prince made a little movement, as much as to say, Well, that's it, I remember now.
children.prevalue: The Prince made a little movement as much as to say Well that s it I remember now

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: And, all the while feigning to be engaged with his book, he watched Rosa with even more attention than he had before.
children.prevalue: And all the while feigning to be engaged with his book he watched Rosa with even more attention than he had before

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: And you are fond of flowers? continued Mynheer van Systens.
children.prevalue: And you are fond of flowers continued Mynheer van Systens

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Yes, sir.
children.prevalue: Yes sir

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Then you are an experienced florist, I dare say?
children.prevalue: Then you are an experienced florist I dare say

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Rosa hesitated a moment; then with a tone which came from the depth of her heart, she said,
children.prevalue: Rosa hesitated a moment then with a tone which came from the depth of her heart she said

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Gentlemen, I am speaking to men of honor.
children.prevalue: Gentlemen I am speaking to men of honor

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: There was such an expression of truth in the tone of her voice, that Van Systens and the Prince answered simultaneously by an affirmative movement of their heads.
children.prevalue: There was such an expression of truth in the tone of her voice that Van Systens and the Prince answered simultaneously by an affirmative movement of their heads

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Well, then, I am not an experienced florist; I am only a poor girl, one of the people, who, three months ago, knew neither how to read nor how to write. No, the black tulip has not been found by myself.
children.prevalue: Well then I am not an experienced florist I am only a poor girl one of the people who three months ago knew neither how to read nor how to write No the black tulip has not been found by myself

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: But by whom else?
children.prevalue: But by whom else

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: By a poor prisoner of Loewestein.
children.prevalue: By a poor prisoner of Loewestein

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: By a prisoner of Loewestein? repeated the Prince.
children.prevalue: By a prisoner of Loewestein repeated the Prince

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: The tone of his voice startled Rosa, who was sure she had heard it before.
children.prevalue: The tone of his voice startled Rosa who was sure she had heard it before

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: By a prisoner of state, then, continued the Prince, as there are none else there.
children.prevalue: By a prisoner of state then continued the Prince as there are none else there

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Having said this he began to read again, at least in appearance.
children.prevalue: Having said this he began to read again at least in appearance

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Yes, said Rosa, with a faltering voice, yes, by a prisoner of state.
children.prevalue: Yes said Rosa with a faltering voice yes by a prisoner of state

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Van Systens trembled as he heard such a confession made in the presence of such a witness.
children.prevalue: Van Systens trembled as he heard such a confession made in the presence of such a witness

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Continue, said William dryly, to the President of the Horticultural Society.
children.prevalue: Continue said William dryly to the President of the Horticultural Society

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Ah, sir, said Rosa, addressing the person whom she thought to be her real judge, I am going to incriminate myself very seriously.
children.prevalue: Ah sir said Rosa addressing the person whom she thought to be her real judge I am going to incriminate myself very seriously

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Certainly, said Van Systens, the prisoner of state ought to be kept in close confinement at Loewestein.
children.prevalue: Certainly said Van Systens the prisoner of state ought to be kept in close confinement at Loewestein

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Alas! sir.
children.prevalue: Alas sir

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: And from what you tell me you took advantage of your position, as daughter of the jailer, to communicate with a prisoner of state about the cultivation of flowers.
children.prevalue: And from what you tell me you took advantage of your position as daughter of the jailer to communicate with a prisoner of state about the cultivation of flowers

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: So it is, sir, Rosa murmured in dismay; yes, I am bound to confess, I saw him every day.
children.prevalue: So it is sir Rosa murmured in dismay yes I am bound to confess I saw him every day

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Unfortunate girl! exclaimed Van Systens.
children.prevalue: Unfortunate girl exclaimed Van Systens

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: The Prince, observing the fright of Rosa and the pallor of the President, raised his head, and said, in his clear and decided tone,
children.prevalue: The Prince observing the fright of Rosa and the pallor of the President raised his head and said in his clear and decided tone

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: This cannot signify anything to the members of the Horticultural Society; they have to judge on the black tulip, and have no cognizance to take of political offences. Go on, young woman, go on.
children.prevalue: This cannot signify anything to the members of the Horticultural Society they have to judge on the black tulip and have no cognizance to take of political offences Go on young woman go on

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Van Systens, by means of an eloquent glance, offered, in the name of the tulip, his thanks to the new member of the Horticultural Society.
children.prevalue: Van Systens by means of an eloquent glance offered in the name of the tulip his thanks to the new member of the Horticultural Society

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Rosa, reassured by this sort of encouragement which the stranger was giving her, related all that had happened for the last three months, all that she had done, and all that she had suffered. She described the cruelty of Gryphus; the destruction of the first bulb; the grief of the prisoner; the precautions taken to insure the success of the second bulb; the patience of the prisoner and his anxiety during their separation; how he was about to starve himself because he had no longer any news of his tulip; his joy when she went to see him again; and, lastly, their despair when they found that the tulip which had come into flower was stolen just one hour after it had opened.
children.prevalue: Rosa reassured by this sort of encouragement which the stranger was giving her related all that had happened for the last three months all that she had done and all that she had suffered She described the cruelty of Gryphus the destruction of the first bulb the grief of the prisoner the precautions taken to insure the success of the second bulb the patience of the prisoner and his anxiety during their separation how he was about to starve himself because he had no longer any news of his tulip his joy when she went to see him again and lastly their despair when they found that the tulip which had come into flower was stolen just one hour after it had opened

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: All this was detailed with an accent of truth which, although producing no change in the impassible mien of the Prince, did not fail to take effect on Van Systens.
children.prevalue: All this was detailed with an accent of truth which although producing no change in the impassible mien of the Prince did not fail to take effect on Van Systens

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: But, said the Prince, it cannot be long since you knew the prisoner.
children.prevalue: But said the Prince it cannot be long since you knew the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: Rosa opened her large eyes and looked at the stranger, who drew back into the dark corner, as if he wished to escape her observation.
children.prevalue: Rosa opened her large eyes and looked at the stranger who drew back into the dark corner as if he wished to escape her observation

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: Why, sir? she asked him.
children.prevalue: Why sir she asked him

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Because it is not yet four months since the jailer Gryphus and his daughter were removed to Loewestein.
children.prevalue: Because it is not yet four months since the jailer Gryphus and his daughter were removed to Loewestein

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: That is true, sir.
children.prevalue: That is true sir

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: Otherwise, you must have solicited the transfer of your father, in order to be able to follow some prisoner who may have been transported from the Hague to Loewestein.
children.prevalue: Otherwise you must have solicited the transfer of your father in order to be able to follow some prisoner who may have been transported from the Hague to Loewestein

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Sir, said Rosa, blushing.
children.prevalue: Sir said Rosa blushing

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: Finish what you have to say, said William.
children.prevalue: Finish what you have to say said William

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: I confess I knew the prisoner at the Hague.
children.prevalue: I confess I knew the prisoner at the Hague

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Happy prisoner! said William, smiling.
children.prevalue: Happy prisoner said William smiling

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: At this moment the officer who had been sent for Boxtel returned, and announced to the Prince that the person whom he had been to fetch was following on his heels with his tulip.
children.prevalue: At this moment the officer who had been sent for Boxtel returned and announced to the Prince that the person whom he had been to fetch was following on his heels with his tulip

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Boxtel's return was scarcely announced, when he entered in person the drawingroom of Mynheer van Systens, followed by two men, who carried in a box their precious burden and deposited it on a table.
children.prevalue: Boxtel s return was scarcely announced when he entered in person the drawingroom of Mynheer van Systens followed by two men who carried in a box their precious burden and deposited it on a table

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The Prince, on being informed, left the cabinet, passed into the drawingroom, admired the flower, and silently resumed his seat in the dark corner, where he had himself placed his chair.
children.prevalue: The Prince on being informed left the cabinet passed into the drawingroom admired the flower and silently resumed his seat in the dark corner where he had himself placed his chair

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Rosa, trembling, pale and terrified, expected to be invited in her turn to see the tulip.
children.prevalue: Rosa trembling pale and terrified expected to be invited in her turn to see the tulip

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: She now heard the voice of Boxtel.
children.prevalue: She now heard the voice of Boxtel

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: It is he! she exclaimed.
children.prevalue: It is he she exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The Prince made her a sign to go and look through the open door into the drawingroom.
children.prevalue: The Prince made her a sign to go and look through the open door into the drawingroom

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: It is my tulip, cried Rosa, I recognise it. Oh, my poor Cornelius!
children.prevalue: It is my tulip cried Rosa I recognise it Oh my poor Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: And saying this she burst into tears.
children.prevalue: And saying this she burst into tears

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The Prince rose from his seat, went to the door, where he stood for some time with the full light falling upon his figure.
children.prevalue: The Prince rose from his seat went to the door where he stood for some time with the full light falling upon his figure

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: As Rosa's eyes now rested upon him, she felt more than ever convinced that this was not the first time she had seen the stranger.
children.prevalue: As Rosa s eyes now rested upon him she felt more than ever convinced that this was not the first time she had seen the stranger

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Master Boxtel, said the Prince, come in here, if you please.
children.prevalue: Master Boxtel said the Prince come in here if you please

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Boxtel eagerly approached, and, finding himself face to face with William of Orange, started back.
children.prevalue: Boxtel eagerly approached and finding himself face to face with William of Orange started back

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: His Highness! he called out.
children.prevalue: His Highness he called out

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: His Highness! Rosa repeated in dismay.
children.prevalue: His Highness Rosa repeated in dismay

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Hearing this exclamation on his left, Boxtel turned round, and perceived Rosa.
children.prevalue: Hearing this exclamation on his left Boxtel turned round and perceived Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: At this sight the whole frame of the thief shook as if under the influence of a galvanic shock.
children.prevalue: At this sight the whole frame of the thief shook as if under the influence of a galvanic shock

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Ah! muttered the Prince to himself, he is confused.
children.prevalue: Ah muttered the Prince to himself he is confused

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: But Boxtel, making a violent effort to control his feelings, was already himself again.
children.prevalue: But Boxtel making a violent effort to control his feelings was already himself again

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Master Boxtel, said William, you seem to have discovered the secret of growing the black tulip?
children.prevalue: Master Boxtel said William you seem to have discovered the secret of growing the black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Yes, your Highness, answered Boxtel, in a voice which still betrayed some confusion.
children.prevalue: Yes your Highness answered Boxtel in a voice which still betrayed some confusion

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: It is true his agitation might have been attributable to the emotion which the man must have felt on suddenly recognising the Prince.
children.prevalue: It is true his agitation might have been attributable to the emotion which the man must have felt on suddenly recognising the Prince

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: But, continued the Stadtholder, here is a young damsel who also pretends to have found it.
children.prevalue: But continued the Stadtholder here is a young damsel who also pretends to have found it

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Boxtel, with a disdainful smile, shrugged his shoulders.
children.prevalue: Boxtel with a disdainful smile shrugged his shoulders

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: William watched all his movements with evident interest and curiosity.
children.prevalue: William watched all his movements with evident interest and curiosity

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Then you don't know this young girl? said the Prince.
children.prevalue: Then you don t know this young girl said the Prince

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: No, your Highness!
children.prevalue: No your Highness

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: And you, child, do you know Master Boxtel?
children.prevalue: And you child do you know Master Boxtel

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: No, I don't know Master Boxtel, but I know Master Jacob.
children.prevalue: No I don t know Master Boxtel but I know Master Jacob

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: I mean to say that at Loewestein the man who here calls himself Isaac Boxtel went by the name of Master Jacob.
children.prevalue: I mean to say that at Loewestein the man who here calls himself Isaac Boxtel went by the name of Master Jacob

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: What do you say to that, Master Boxtel?
children.prevalue: What do you say to that Master Boxtel

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: I say that this damsel lies, your Highness.
children.prevalue: I say that this damsel lies your Highness

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: You deny, therefore, having ever been at Loewestein?
children.prevalue: You deny therefore having ever been at Loewestein

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Boxtel hesitated; the fixed and searching glance of the proud eye of the Prince prevented him from lying.
children.prevalue: Boxtel hesitated the fixed and searching glance of the proud eye of the Prince prevented him from lying

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: I cannot deny having been at Loewestein, your Highness, but I deny having stolen the tulip.
children.prevalue: I cannot deny having been at Loewestein your Highness but I deny having stolen the tulip

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: You have stolen it, and that from my room, cried Rosa, with indignation.
children.prevalue: You have stolen it and that from my room cried Rosa with indignation

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I deny it.
children.prevalue: I deny it

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Now listen to me. Do you deny having followed me into the garden, on the day when I prepared the border where I was to plant it? Do you deny having followed me into the garden when I pretended to plant it? Do you deny that, on that evening, you rushed after my departure to the spot where you hoped to find the bulb? Do you deny having dug in the ground with your handsbut, thank God! in vain, as it was a stratagem to discover your intentions. Say, do you deny all this?
children.prevalue: Now listen to me Do you deny having followed me into the garden on the day when I prepared the border where I was to plant it Do you deny having followed me into the garden when I pretended to plant it Do you deny that on that evening you rushed after my departure to the spot where you hoped to find the bulb Do you deny having dug in the ground with your handsbut thank God in vain as it was a stratagem to discover your intentions Say do you deny all this

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Boxtel did not deem it fit to answer these several charges, but, turning to the Prince, continued,
children.prevalue: Boxtel did not deem it fit to answer these several charges but turning to the Prince continued

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I have now for twenty years grown tulips at Dort. I have even acquired some reputation in this art; one of my hybrids is entered in the catalogue under the name of an illustrious personage. I have dedicated it to the King of Portugal. The truth in the matter is as I shall now tell your Highness. This damsel knew that I had produced the black tulip, and, in concert with a lover of hers in the fortress of Loewestein, she formed the plan of ruining me by appropriating to herself the prize of a hundred thousand guilders, which, with the help of your Highness's justice, I hope to gain.
children.prevalue: I have now for twenty years grown tulips at Dort I have even acquired some reputation in this art one of my hybrids is entered in the catalogue under the name of an illustrious personage I have dedicated it to the King of Portugal The truth in the matter is as I shall now tell your Highness This damsel knew that I had produced the black tulip and in concert with a lover of hers in the fortress of Loewestein she formed the plan of ruining me by appropriating to herself the prize of a hundred thousand guilders which with the help of your Highness s justice I hope to gain

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Yah! cried Rosa, beyond herself with anger.
children.prevalue: Yah cried Rosa beyond herself with anger

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Silence! said the Prince.
children.prevalue: Silence said the Prince

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Then, turning to Boxtel, he said,
children.prevalue: Then turning to Boxtel he said

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: And who is that prisoner to whom you allude as the lover of this young woman?
children.prevalue: And who is that prisoner to whom you allude as the lover of this young woman

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Rosa nearly swooned, for Cornelius was designated as a dangerous prisoner, and recommended by the Prince to the especial surveillance of the jailer.
children.prevalue: Rosa nearly swooned for Cornelius was designated as a dangerous prisoner and recommended by the Prince to the especial surveillance of the jailer

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Nothing could have been more agreeable to Boxtel than this question.
children.prevalue: Nothing could have been more agreeable to Boxtel than this question

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: This prisoner, he said, is a man whose name in itself will prove to your Highness what trust you may place in his probity. He is a prisoner of state, who was once condemned to death.
children.prevalue: This prisoner he said is a man whose name in itself will prove to your Highness what trust you may place in his probity He is a prisoner of state who was once condemned to death

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: And his name?
children.prevalue: And his name

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Rosa hid her face in her hands with a movement of despair.
children.prevalue: Rosa hid her face in her hands with a movement of despair

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: His name is Cornelius van Baerle, said Boxtel, and he is godson of that villain Cornelius de Witt.
children.prevalue: His name is Cornelius van Baerle said Boxtel and he is godson of that villain Cornelius de Witt

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: The Prince gave a start, his generally quiet eye flashed, and a deathlike paleness spread over his impassible features.
children.prevalue: The Prince gave a start his generally quiet eye flashed and a deathlike paleness spread over his impassible features

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: He went up to Rosa, and with his finger, gave her a sign to remove her hands from her face.
children.prevalue: He went up to Rosa and with his finger gave her a sign to remove her hands from her face

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Rosa obeyed, as if under mesmeric influence, without having seen the sign.
children.prevalue: Rosa obeyed as if under mesmeric influence without having seen the sign

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: It was, then to follow this man that you came to me at Leyden to solicit for the transfer of your father?
children.prevalue: It was then to follow this man that you came to me at Leyden to solicit for the transfer of your father

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Rosa hung down her head, and, nearly choking, said,
children.prevalue: Rosa hung down her head and nearly choking said

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Yes, your Highness.
children.prevalue: Yes your Highness

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Go on, said the Prince to Boxtel.
children.prevalue: Go on said the Prince to Boxtel

children.name: Paragraph_58
