children.value: I have nothing more to say, Isaac continued. Your Highness knows all. But there is one thing which I did not intend to say, because I did not wish to make this girl blush for her ingratitude. I came to Loewestein because I had business there. On this occasion I made the acquaintance of old Gryphus, and, falling in love with his daughter, made an offer of marriage to her; and, not being rich, I committed the imprudence of mentioning to them my prospect of gaining a hundred thousand guilders, in proof of which I showed to them the black tulip. Her lover having himself made a show at Dort of cultivating tulips to hide his political intrigues, they now plotted together for my ruin. On the eve of the day when the flower was expected to open, the tulip was taken away by this young woman. She carried it to her room, from which I had the good luck to recover it at the very moment when she had the impudence to despatch a messenger to announce to the members of the Horticultural Society that she had produced the grand black tulip. But she did not stop there. There is no doubt that, during the few hours which she kept the flower in her room, she showed it to some persons whom she may now call as witnesses. But, fortunately, your Highness has now been warned against this impostor and her witnesses.
children.prevalue: I have nothing more to say Isaac continued Your Highness knows all But there is one thing which I did not intend to say because I did not wish to make this girl blush for her ingratitude I came to Loewestein because I had business there On this occasion I made the acquaintance of old Gryphus and falling in love with his daughter made an offer of marriage to her and not being rich I committed the imprudence of mentioning to them my prospect of gaining a hundred thousand guilders in proof of which I showed to them the black tulip Her lover having himself made a show at Dort of cultivating tulips to hide his political intrigues they now plotted together for my ruin On the eve of the day when the flower was expected to open the tulip was taken away by this young woman She carried it to her room from which I had the good luck to recover it at the very moment when she had the impudence to despatch a messenger to announce to the members of the Horticultural Society that she had produced the grand black tulip But she did not stop there There is no doubt that during the few hours which she kept the flower in her room she showed it to some persons whom she may now call as witnesses But fortunately your Highness has now been warned against this impostor and her witnesses

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Oh, my God, my God! what infamous falsehoods! said Rosa, bursting into tears, and throwing herself at the feet of the Stadtholder, who, although thinking her guilty, felt pity for her dreadful agony.
children.prevalue: Oh my God my God what infamous falsehoods said Rosa bursting into tears and throwing herself at the feet of the Stadtholder who although thinking her guilty felt pity for her dreadful agony

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: You have done very wrong, my child, he said, and your lover shall be punished for having thus badly advised you. For you are so young, and have such an honest look, that I am inclined to believe the mischief to have been his doing, and not yours.
children.prevalue: You have done very wrong my child he said and your lover shall be punished for having thus badly advised you For you are so young and have such an honest look that I am inclined to believe the mischief to have been his doing and not yours

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Monseigneur! Monseigneur! cried Rosa, Cornelius is not guilty.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur Monseigneur cried Rosa Cornelius is not guilty

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: William started.
children.prevalue: William started

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Not guilty of having advised you? that's what you want to say, is it not?
children.prevalue: Not guilty of having advised you that s what you want to say is it not

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: What I wish to say, your Highness, is that Cornelius is as little guilty of the second crime imputed to him as he was of the first.
children.prevalue: What I wish to say your Highness is that Cornelius is as little guilty of the second crime imputed to him as he was of the first

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Of the first? And do you know what was his first crime? Do you know of what he was accused and convicted? Of having, as an accomplice of Cornelius de Witt, concealed the correspondence of the Grand Pensionary and the Marquis de Louvois.
children.prevalue: Of the first And do you know what was his first crime Do you know of what he was accused and convicted Of having as an accomplice of Cornelius de Witt concealed the correspondence of the Grand Pensionary and the Marquis de Louvois

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Well, sir, he was ignorant of this correspondence being deposited with him; completely ignorant. I am as certain as of my life, that, if it were not so, he would have told me; for how could that pure mind have harboured a secret without revealing it to me? No, no, your Highness, I repeat it, and even at the risk of incurring your displeasure, Cornelius is no more guilty of the first crime than of the second; and of the second no more than of the first. Oh, would to Heaven that you knew my Cornelius; Monseigneur!
children.prevalue: Well sir he was ignorant of this correspondence being deposited with him completely ignorant I am as certain as of my life that if it were not so he would have told me for how could that pure mind have harboured a secret without revealing it to me No no your Highness I repeat it and even at the risk of incurring your displeasure Cornelius is no more guilty of the first crime than of the second and of the second no more than of the first Oh would to Heaven that you knew my Cornelius Monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: He is a De Witt! cried Boxtel. His Highness knows only too much of him, having once granted him his life.
children.prevalue: He is a De Witt cried Boxtel His Highness knows only too much of him having once granted him his life

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Silence! said the Prince; all these affairs of state, as I have already said, are completely out of the province of the Horticultural Society of Haarlem.
children.prevalue: Silence said the Prince all these affairs of state as I have already said are completely out of the province of the Horticultural Society of Haarlem

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Then, knitting his brow, he added,
children.prevalue: Then knitting his brow he added

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: As to the tulip, make yourself easy, Master Boxtel, you shall have justice done to you.
children.prevalue: As to the tulip make yourself easy Master Boxtel you shall have justice done to you

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Boxtel bowed with a heart full of joy, and received the congratulations of the President.
children.prevalue: Boxtel bowed with a heart full of joy and received the congratulations of the President

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: You, my child, William of Orange continued, you were going to commit a crime. I will not punish you; but the real evildoer shall pay the penalty for both. A man of his name may be a conspirator, and even a traitor, but he ought not to be a thief.
children.prevalue: You my child William of Orange continued you were going to commit a crime I will not punish you but the real evildoer shall pay the penalty for both A man of his name may be a conspirator and even a traitor but he ought not to be a thief

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: A thief! cried Rosa. Cornelius a thief? Pray, your Highness, do not say such a word, it would kill him, if he knew it. If theft there has been, I swear to you, Sir, no one else but this man has committed it.
children.prevalue: A thief cried Rosa Cornelius a thief Pray your Highness do not say such a word it would kill him if he knew it If theft there has been I swear to you Sir no one else but this man has committed it

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Prove it, Boxtel coolly remarked.
children.prevalue: Prove it Boxtel coolly remarked

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: I shall prove it. With God's help I shall.
children.prevalue: I shall prove it With God s help I shall

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Then, turning towards Boxtel, she asked,
children.prevalue: Then turning towards Boxtel she asked

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: The tulip is yours?
children.prevalue: The tulip is yours

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: It is.
children.prevalue: It is

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: How many bulbs were there of it?
children.prevalue: How many bulbs were there of it

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Boxtel hesitated for a moment, but after a short consideration he came to the conclusion that she would not ask this question if there were none besides the two bulbs of which he had known already. He therefore answered,
children.prevalue: Boxtel hesitated for a moment but after a short consideration he came to the conclusion that she would not ask this question if there were none besides the two bulbs of which he had known already He therefore answered

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Three.
children.prevalue: Three

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: What has become of these bulbs?
children.prevalue: What has become of these bulbs

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Oh! what has become of them? Well, one has failed; the second has produced the black tulip.
children.prevalue: Oh what has become of them Well one has failed the second has produced the black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: And the third?
children.prevalue: And the third

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: The third!
children.prevalue: The third

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: The third,where is it?
children.prevalue: The third where is it

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: I have it at home, said Boxtel, quite confused.
children.prevalue: I have it at home said Boxtel quite confused

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: At home? Where? At Loewestein, or at Dort?
children.prevalue: At home Where At Loewestein or at Dort

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: At Dort, said Boxtel.
children.prevalue: At Dort said Boxtel

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: You lie! cried Rosa. Monseigneur, she continued, whilst turning round to the Prince, I will tell you the true story of these three bulbs. The first was crushed by my father in the prisoner's cell, and this man is quite aware of it, for he himself wanted to get hold of it, and, being balked in his hope, he very nearly fell out with my father, who had been the cause of his disappointment. The second bulb, planted by me, has produced the black tulip, and the third and lastsaying this, she drew it from her bosomhere it is, in the very same paper in which it was wrapped up together with the two others. When about to be led to the scaffold, Cornelius van Baerle gave me all the three. Take it, Monseigneur, take it.
children.prevalue: You lie cried Rosa Monseigneur she continued whilst turning round to the Prince I will tell you the true story of these three bulbs The first was crushed by my father in the prisoner s cell and this man is quite aware of it for he himself wanted to get hold of it and being balked in his hope he very nearly fell out with my father who had been the cause of his disappointment The second bulb planted by me has produced the black tulip and the third and lastsaying this she drew it from her bosomhere it is in the very same paper in which it was wrapped up together with the two others When about to be led to the scaffold Cornelius van Baerle gave me all the three Take it Monseigneur take it

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: And Rosa, unfolding the paper, offered the bulb to the Prince, who took it from her hands and examined it.
children.prevalue: And Rosa unfolding the paper offered the bulb to the Prince who took it from her hands and examined it

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: But, Monseigneur, this young woman may have stolen the bulb, as she did the tulip, Boxtel said, with a faltering voice, and evidently alarmed at the attention with which the Prince examined the bulb; and even more at the movements of Rosa, who was reading some lines written on the paper which remained in her hands.
children.prevalue: But Monseigneur this young woman may have stolen the bulb as she did the tulip Boxtel said with a faltering voice and evidently alarmed at the attention with which the Prince examined the bulb and even more at the movements of Rosa who was reading some lines written on the paper which remained in her hands

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Her eyes suddenly lighted up; she read, with breathless anxiety, the mysterious paper over and over again; and at last, uttering a cry, held it out to the Prince and said, Read, Monseigneur, for Heaven's sake, read!
children.prevalue: Her eyes suddenly lighted up she read with breathless anxiety the mysterious paper over and over again and at last uttering a cry held it out to the Prince and said Read Monseigneur for Heaven s sake read

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: William handed the third bulb to Van Systens, took the paper, and read.
children.prevalue: William handed the third bulb to Van Systens took the paper and read

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: No sooner had he looked at it than he began to stagger; his hand trembled, and very nearly let the paper fall to the ground; and the expression of pain and compassion in his features was really frightful to see.
children.prevalue: No sooner had he looked at it than he began to stagger his hand trembled and very nearly let the paper fall to the ground and the expression of pain and compassion in his features was really frightful to see

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: It was that flyleaf, taken from the Bible, which Cornelius de Witt had sent to Dort by Craeke, the servant of his brother John, to request Van Baerle to burn the correspondence of the Grand Pensionary with the Marquis de Louvois.
children.prevalue: It was that flyleaf taken from the Bible which Cornelius de Witt had sent to Dort by Craeke the servant of his brother John to request Van Baerle to burn the correspondence of the Grand Pensionary with the Marquis de Louvois

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: This request, as the reader may remember, was couched in the following terms:
children.prevalue: This request as the reader may remember was couched in the following terms

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: My Dear Godson,
children.prevalue: My Dear Godson

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Burn the parcel which I have intrusted to you. Burn it without looking at it, and without opening it, so that its contents may for ever remain unknown to yourself. Secrets of this description are death to those with whom they are deposited. Burn it, and you will have saved John and Cornelius de Witt.
children.prevalue: Burn the parcel which I have intrusted to you Burn it without looking at it and without opening it so that its contents may for ever remain unknown to yourself Secrets of this description are death to those with whom they are deposited Burn it and you will have saved John and Cornelius de Witt

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Farewell, and love me.
children.prevalue: Farewell and love me

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Cornelius de Witt.
children.prevalue: Cornelius de Witt

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: August 20, 1672.
children.prevalue: August 20 1672

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: This slip of paper offered the proofs both of Van Baerle's innocence and of his claim to the property of the tulip.
children.prevalue: This slip of paper offered the proofs both of Van Baerle s innocence and of his claim to the property of the tulip

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Rosa and the Stadtholder exchanged one look only.
children.prevalue: Rosa and the Stadtholder exchanged one look only

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: That of Rosa was meant to express, Here, you see yourself.
children.prevalue: That of Rosa was meant to express Here you see yourself

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: That of the Stadtholder signified, Be quiet, and wait.
children.prevalue: That of the Stadtholder signified Be quiet and wait

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: The Prince wiped the cold sweat from his forehead, and slowly folded up the paper, whilst his thoughts were wandering in that labyrinth without a goal and without a guide, which is called remorse and shame for the past.
children.prevalue: The Prince wiped the cold sweat from his forehead and slowly folded up the paper whilst his thoughts were wandering in that labyrinth without a goal and without a guide which is called remorse and shame for the past

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Soon, however, raising his head with an effort, he said, in his usual voice,
children.prevalue: Soon however raising his head with an effort he said in his usual voice

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Go, Mr. Boxtel; justice shall be done, I promise you.
children.prevalue: Go Mr Boxtel justice shall be done I promise you

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Then, turning to the President, he added,
children.prevalue: Then turning to the President he added

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: You, my dear Mynheer van Systens, take charge of this young woman and of the tulip. Goodbye.
children.prevalue: You my dear Mynheer van Systens take charge of this young woman and of the tulip Goodbye

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: All bowed, and the Prince left, among the deafening cheers of the crowd outside.
children.prevalue: All bowed and the Prince left among the deafening cheers of the crowd outside

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Boxtel returned to his inn, rather puzzled and uneasy, tormented by misgivings about that paper which William had received from the hand of Rosa, and which his Highness had read, folded up, and so carefully put in his pocket. What was the meaning of all this?
children.prevalue: Boxtel returned to his inn rather puzzled and uneasy tormented by misgivings about that paper which William had received from the hand of Rosa and which his Highness had read folded up and so carefully put in his pocket What was the meaning of all this

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Rosa went up to the tulip, tenderly kissed its leaves and, with a heart full of happiness and confidence in the ways of God, broke out in the words,
children.prevalue: Rosa went up to the tulip tenderly kissed its leaves and with a heart full of happiness and confidence in the ways of God broke out in the words

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Thou knowest best for what end Thou madest my good Cornelius teach me to read.
children.prevalue: Thou knowest best for what end Thou madest my good Cornelius teach me to read

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Whilst the events we have described in our last chapter were taking place, the unfortunate Van Baerle, forgotten in his cell in the fortress of Loewestein, suffered at the hands of Gryphus all that a prisoner can suffer when his jailer has formed the determination of playing the part of hangman.
children.prevalue: Whilst the events we have described in our last chapter were taking place the unfortunate Van Baerle forgotten in his cell in the fortress of Loewestein suffered at the hands of Gryphus all that a prisoner can suffer when his jailer has formed the determination of playing the part of hangman

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Gryphus, not having received any tidings of Rosa or of Jacob, persuaded himself that all that had happened was the devil's work, and that Dr. Cornelius van Baerle had been sent on earth by Satan.
children.prevalue: Gryphus not having received any tidings of Rosa or of Jacob persuaded himself that all that had happened was the devil s work and that Dr Cornelius van Baerle had been sent on earth by Satan

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The result of it was, that, one fine morning, the third after the disappearance of Jacob and Rosa, he went up to the cell of Cornelius in even a greater rage than usual.
children.prevalue: The result of it was that one fine morning the third after the disappearance of Jacob and Rosa he went up to the cell of Cornelius in even a greater rage than usual

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The latter, leaning with his elbows on the windowsill and supporting his head with his two hands, whilst his eyes wandered over the distant hazy horizon where the windmills of Dort were turning their sails, was breathing the fresh air, in order to be able to keep down his tears and to fortify himself in his philosophy.
children.prevalue: The latter leaning with his elbows on the windowsill and supporting his head with his two hands whilst his eyes wandered over the distant hazy horizon where the windmills of Dort were turning their sails was breathing the fresh air in order to be able to keep down his tears and to fortify himself in his philosophy

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The pigeons were still there, but hope was not there; there was no future to look forward to.
children.prevalue: The pigeons were still there but hope was not there there was no future to look forward to

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Alas! Rosa, being watched, was no longer able to come. Could she not write? and if so, could she convey her letters to him?
children.prevalue: Alas Rosa being watched was no longer able to come Could she not write and if so could she convey her letters to him

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: No, no. He had seen during the two preceding days too much fury and malignity in the eyes of old Gryphus to expect that his vigilance would relax, even for one moment. Moreover, had not she to suffer even worse torments than those of seclusion and separation? Did this brutal, blaspheming, drunken bully take revenge on his daughter, like the ruthless fathers of the Greek drama? And when the Genievre had heated his brain, would it not give to his arm, which had been only too well set by Cornelius, even double force?
children.prevalue: No no He had seen during the two preceding days too much fury and malignity in the eyes of old Gryphus to expect that his vigilance would relax even for one moment Moreover had not she to suffer even worse torments than those of seclusion and separation Did this brutal blaspheming drunken bully take revenge on his daughter like the ruthless fathers of the Greek drama And when the Genievre had heated his brain would it not give to his arm which had been only too well set by Cornelius even double force

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The idea that Rosa might perhaps be illtreated nearly drove Cornelius mad.
children.prevalue: The idea that Rosa might perhaps be illtreated nearly drove Cornelius mad

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: He then felt his own powerlessness. He asked himself whether God was just in inflicting so much tribulation on two innocent creatures. And certainly in these moments he began to doubt the wisdom of Providence. It is one of the curses of misfortune that it thus begets doubt.
children.prevalue: He then felt his own powerlessness He asked himself whether God was just in inflicting so much tribulation on two innocent creatures And certainly in these moments he began to doubt the wisdom of Providence It is one of the curses of misfortune that it thus begets doubt

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Van Baerle had proposed to write to Rosa, but where was she?
children.prevalue: Van Baerle had proposed to write to Rosa but where was she

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: He also would have wished to write to the Hague to be beforehand with Gryphus, who, he had no doubt, would by denouncing him do his best to bring new storms on his head.
children.prevalue: He also would have wished to write to the Hague to be beforehand with Gryphus who he had no doubt would by denouncing him do his best to bring new storms on his head

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: But how should he write? Gryphus had taken the paper and pencil from him, and even if he had both, he could hardly expect Gryphus to despatch his letter.
children.prevalue: But how should he write Gryphus had taken the paper and pencil from him and even if he had both he could hardly expect Gryphus to despatch his letter

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Then Cornelius revolved in his mind all those stratagems resorted to by unfortunate prisoners.
children.prevalue: Then Cornelius revolved in his mind all those stratagems resorted to by unfortunate prisoners

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: He had thought of an attempt to escape, a thing which never entered his head whilst he could see Rosa every day; but the more he thought of it, the more clearly he saw the impracticability of such an attempt. He was one of those choice spirits who abhor everything that is common, and who often lose a good chance through not taking the way of the vulgar, that high road of mediocrity which leads to everything.
children.prevalue: He had thought of an attempt to escape a thing which never entered his head whilst he could see Rosa every day but the more he thought of it the more clearly he saw the impracticability of such an attempt He was one of those choice spirits who abhor everything that is common and who often lose a good chance through not taking the way of the vulgar that high road of mediocrity which leads to everything

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: How is it possible, said Cornelius to himself, that I should escape from Loewestein, as Grotius has done the same thing before me? Has not every precaution been taken since? Are not the windows barred? Are not the doors of double and even of treble strength, and the sentinels ten times more watchful? And have not I, besides all this, an Argus so much the more dangerous as he has the keen eyes of hatred? Finally, is there not one fact which takes away all my spirit, I mean Rosa's absence? But suppose I should waste ten years of my life in making a file to file off my bars, or in braiding cords to let myself down from the window, or in sticking wings on my shoulders to fly, like Daedalus? But luck is against me now. The file would get dull, the rope would break, or my wings would melt in the sun; I should surely kill myself, I should be picked up maimed and crippled; I should be labelled, and put on exhibition in the museum at the Hague between the bloodstained doublet of William the Taciturn and the female walrus captured at Stavesen, and the only result of my enterprise will have been to procure me a place among the curiosities of Holland.
children.prevalue: How is it possible said Cornelius to himself that I should escape from Loewestein as Grotius has done the same thing before me Has not every precaution been taken since Are not the windows barred Are not the doors of double and even of treble strength and the sentinels ten times more watchful And have not I besides all this an Argus so much the more dangerous as he has the keen eyes of hatred Finally is there not one fact which takes away all my spirit I mean Rosa s absence But suppose I should waste ten years of my life in making a file to file off my bars or in braiding cords to let myself down from the window or in sticking wings on my shoulders to fly like Daedalus But luck is against me now The file would get dull the rope would break or my wings would melt in the sun I should surely kill myself I should be picked up maimed and crippled I should be labelled and put on exhibition in the museum at the Hague between the bloodstained doublet of William the Taciturn and the female walrus captured at Stavesen and the only result of my enterprise will have been to procure me a place among the curiosities of Holland

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: But no; and it is much better so. Some fine day Gryphus will commit some atrocity. I am losing my patience, since I have lost the joy and company of Rosa, and especially since I have lost my tulip. Undoubtedly, some day or other Gryphus will attack me in a manner painful to my selfrespect, or to my love, or even threaten my personal safety. I don't know how it is, but since my imprisonment I feel a strange and almost irresistible pugnacity. Well, I shall get at the throat of that old villain, and strangle him.
children.prevalue: But no and it is much better so Some fine day Gryphus will commit some atrocity I am losing my patience since I have lost the joy and company of Rosa and especially since I have lost my tulip Undoubtedly some day or other Gryphus will attack me in a manner painful to my selfrespect or to my love or even threaten my personal safety I don t know how it is but since my imprisonment I feel a strange and almost irresistible pugnacity Well I shall get at the throat of that old villain and strangle him

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Cornelius at these words stopped for a moment, biting his lips and staring out before him; then, eagerly returning to an idea which seemed to possess a strange fascination for him, he continued,
children.prevalue: Cornelius at these words stopped for a moment biting his lips and staring out before him then eagerly returning to an idea which seemed to possess a strange fascination for him he continued

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Well, and once having strangled him, why should I not take his keys from him, why not go down the stairs as if I had done the most virtuous action, why not go and fetch Rosa from her room, why not tell her all, and jump from her window into the Waal? I am expert enough as a swimmer to save both of us. Rosa,but, oh Heaven, Gryphus is her father! Whatever may be her affection for me, she will never approve of my having strangled her father, brutal and malicious as he has been.

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: I shall have to enter into an argument with her; and in the midst of my speech some wretched turnkey who has found Gryphus with the deathrattle in his throat, or perhaps actually dead, will come along and put his hand on my shoulder. Then I shall see the Buytenhof again, and the gleam of that infernal sword,which will not stop halfway a second time, but will make acquaintance with the nape of my neck.

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: It will not do, Cornelius, my fine fellow,it is a bad plan. But, then, what is to become of me, and how shall I find Rosa again?
children.prevalue: It will not do Cornelius my fine fellow it is a bad plan But then what is to become of me and how shall I find Rosa again

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Such were the cogitations of Cornelius three days after the sad scene of separation from Rosa, at the moment when we find him standing at the window.
children.prevalue: Such were the cogitations of Cornelius three days after the sad scene of separation from Rosa at the moment when we find him standing at the window

children.prevalue: And at that very moment Gryphus entered

children.prevalue: Umph umph

children.value: We are the daughters of the secret fire Of the fire which runs through the veins of the earth; We are the daughters of Aurora and of the dew; We are the daughters of the air; We are the daughters of the water; But we are, above all, the daughters of heaven.

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Cornelius turned round, merely saying, Good morning, and then began his song again:
children.prevalue: Cornelius turned round merely saying Good morning and then began his song again

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Men defile us and kill us while loving us, We hang to the earth by a thread; This thread is our root, that is to say, our life, But we raise on high our arms towards heaven.
children.prevalue: Men defile us and kill us while loving us We hang to the earth by a thread This thread is our root that is to say our life But we raise on high our arms towards heaven

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Ah, you accursed sorcerer! you are making game of me, I believe, roared Gryphus.
children.prevalue: Ah you accursed sorcerer you are making game of me I believe roared Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Cornelius continued:
children.prevalue: Cornelius continued

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: For heaven is our home, Our true home, as from thence comes our soul, As thither our soul returns,Our soul, that is to say, our perfume.
children.prevalue: For heaven is our home Our true home as from thence comes our soul As thither our soul returns Our soul that is to say our perfume

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Gryphus went up to the prisoner and said,
children.prevalue: Gryphus went up to the prisoner and said

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: But you don't see that I have taken means to get you under, and to force you to confess your crimes.
children.prevalue: But you don t see that I have taken means to get you under and to force you to confess your crimes

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Are you mad, my dear Master Gryphus? asked Cornelius.
children.prevalue: Are you mad my dear Master Gryphus asked Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: And, as he now for the first time observed the frenzied features, the flashing eyes, and foaming mouth of the old jailer, he said,
children.prevalue: And as he now for the first time observed the frenzied features the flashing eyes and foaming mouth of the old jailer he said

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Bless the man, he is more than mad, he is furious.
children.prevalue: Bless the man he is more than mad he is furious

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Gryphus flourished his stick above his head, but Van Baerle moved not, and remained standing with his arms akimbo.
children.prevalue: Gryphus flourished his stick above his head but Van Baerle moved not and remained standing with his arms akimbo

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: It seems your intention to threaten me, Master Gryphus.
children.prevalue: It seems your intention to threaten me Master Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Yes, indeed, I threaten you, cried the jailer.
children.prevalue: Yes indeed I threaten you cried the jailer

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: And with what?
children.prevalue: And with what

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: First of all, look at what I have in my hand.
children.prevalue: First of all look at what I have in my hand

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: I think that's a stick, said Cornelius calmly, but I don't suppose you will threaten me with that.
children.prevalue: I think that s a stick said Cornelius calmly but I don t suppose you will threaten me with that

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Oh, you don't suppose! why not?
children.prevalue: Oh you don t suppose why not

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Because any jailer who strikes a prisoner is liable to two penalties,the first laid down in Article 9 of the regulations at Loewestein:
children.prevalue: Because any jailer who strikes a prisoner is liable to two penalties the first laid down in Article 9 of the regulations at Loewestein

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: 'Any jailer, inspector, or turnkey who lays hands upon any prisoner of State will be dismissed.'
children.prevalue: Any jailer inspector or turnkey who lays hands upon any prisoner of State will be dismissed

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Yes, who lays hands, said Gryphus, mad with rage, but there is not a word about a stick in the regulation.
children.prevalue: Yes who lays hands said Gryphus mad with rage but there is not a word about a stick in the regulation

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: And the second, continued Cornelius, which is not written in the regulation, but which is to be found elsewhere:
children.prevalue: And the second continued Cornelius which is not written in the regulation but which is to be found elsewhere

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: 'Whosoever takes up the stick will be thrashed by the stick.'
children.prevalue: Whosoever takes up the stick will be thrashed by the stick

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Gryphus, growing more and more exasperated by the calm and sententious tone of Cornelius, brandished his cudgel, but at the moment when he raised it Cornelius rushed at him, snatched it from his hands, and put it under his own arm.
children.prevalue: Gryphus growing more and more exasperated by the calm and sententious tone of Cornelius brandished his cudgel but at the moment when he raised it Cornelius rushed at him snatched it from his hands and put it under his own arm

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Gryphus fairly bellowed with rage.
children.prevalue: Gryphus fairly bellowed with rage

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Hush, hush, my good man, said Cornelius, don't do anything to lose your place.
children.prevalue: Hush hush my good man said Cornelius don t do anything to lose your place

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Ah, you sorcerer! I'll pinch you worse, roared Gryphus.
children.prevalue: Ah you sorcerer I ll pinch you worse roared Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: I wish you may.
children.prevalue: I wish you may

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Don't you see my hand is empty?
children.prevalue: Don t you see my hand is empty

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Yes, I see it, and I am glad of it.
children.prevalue: Yes I see it and I am glad of it

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: You know that it is not generally so when I come upstairs in the morning.
children.prevalue: You know that it is not generally so when I come upstairs in the morning

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: It's true, you generally bring me the worst soup, and the most miserable rations one can imagine. But that's not a punishment to me; I eat only bread, and the worse the bread is to your taste, the better it is to mine.
children.prevalue: It s true you generally bring me the worst soup and the most miserable rations one can imagine But that s not a punishment to me I eat only bread and the worse the bread is to your taste the better it is to mine

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: How so?
children.prevalue: How so

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Oh, it's a very simple thing.
children.prevalue: Oh it s a very simple thing

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Well, tell it me, said Gryphus.
children.prevalue: Well tell it me said Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Very willingly. I know that in giving me bad bread you think you do me harm.
children.prevalue: Very willingly I know that in giving me bad bread you think you do me harm

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Certainly; I don't give it you to please you, you brigand.
children.prevalue: Certainly I don t give it you to please you you brigand

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Well, then, I, who am a sorcerer, as you know, change your bad into excellent bread, which I relish more than the best cake; and then I have the double pleasure of eating something that gratifies my palate, and of doing something that puts you in a rage.
children.prevalue: Well then I who am a sorcerer as you know change your bad into excellent bread which I relish more than the best cake and then I have the double pleasure of eating something that gratifies my palate and of doing something that puts you in a rage

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Gryphus answered with a growl.
children.prevalue: Gryphus answered with a growl

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Oh! you confess, then, that you are a sorcerer.
children.prevalue: Oh you confess then that you are a sorcerer

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Indeed, I am one. I don't say it before all the world, because they might burn me for it, but as we are alone, I don't mind telling you.
children.prevalue: Indeed I am one I don t say it before all the world because they might burn me for it but as we are alone I don t mind telling you

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Well, well, well, answered Gryphus. But if a sorcerer can change black bread into white, won't he die of hunger if he has no bread at all?
children.prevalue: Well well well answered Gryphus But if a sorcerer can change black bread into white won t he die of hunger if he has no bread at all

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: What's that? said Cornelius.
children.prevalue: What s that said Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Consequently, I shall not bring you any bread at all, and we shall see how it will be after eight days.
children.prevalue: Consequently I shall not bring you any bread at all and we shall see how it will be after eight days

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Cornelius grew pale.
children.prevalue: Cornelius grew pale

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: And, continued Gryphus, we'll begin this very day. As you are such a clever sorcerer, why, you had better change the furniture of your room into bread; as to myself, I shall pocket the eighteen sous which are paid to me for your board.
children.prevalue: And continued Gryphus we ll begin this very day As you are such a clever sorcerer why you had better change the furniture of your room into bread as to myself I shall pocket the eighteen sous which are paid to me for your board

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: But that's murder, cried Cornelius, carried away by the first impulse of the very natural terror with which this horrible mode of death inspired him.
children.prevalue: But that s murder cried Cornelius carried away by the first impulse of the very natural terror with which this horrible mode of death inspired him

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Well, Gryphus went on, in his jeering way, as you are a sorcerer, you will live, notwithstanding.
children.prevalue: Well Gryphus went on in his jeering way as you are a sorcerer you will live notwithstanding

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Cornelius put on a smiling face again, and said,
children.prevalue: Cornelius put on a smiling face again and said

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Have you not seen me make the pigeons come here from Dort?
children.prevalue: Have you not seen me make the pigeons come here from Dort

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Well? said Gryphus.
children.prevalue: Well said Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Well, a pigeon is a very dainty morsel, and a man who eats one every day would not starve, I think.
children.prevalue: Well a pigeon is a very dainty morsel and a man who eats one every day would not starve I think

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: And how about the fire? said Gryphus.
children.prevalue: And how about the fire said Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Fire! but you know that I'm in league with the devil. Do you think the devil will leave me without fire? Why, fire is his proper element.
children.prevalue: Fire but you know that I m in league with the devil Do you think the devil will leave me without fire Why fire is his proper element

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: A man, however healthy his appetite may be, would not eat a pigeon every day. Wagers have been laid to do so, and those who made them gave them up.
children.prevalue: A man however healthy his appetite may be would not eat a pigeon every day Wagers have been laid to do so and those who made them gave them up

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Well, but when I am tired of pigeons, I shall make the fish of the Waal and of the Meuse come up to me.
children.prevalue: Well but when I am tired of pigeons I shall make the fish of the Waal and of the Meuse come up to me

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Gryphus opened his large eyes, quite bewildered.
children.prevalue: Gryphus opened his large eyes quite bewildered

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: I am rather fond of fish, continued Cornelius; you never let me have any. Well, I shall turn your starving me to advantage, and regale myself with fish.
children.prevalue: I am rather fond of fish continued Cornelius you never let me have any Well I shall turn your starving me to advantage and regale myself with fish

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Gryphus nearly fainted with anger and with fright, but he soon rallied, and said, putting his hand in his pocket,
children.prevalue: Gryphus nearly fainted with anger and with fright but he soon rallied and said putting his hand in his pocket

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Well, as you force me to it, and with these words he drew forth a claspknife and opened it.
children.prevalue: Well as you force me to it and with these words he drew forth a claspknife and opened it

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Halloa! a knife? said Cornelius, preparing to defend himself with his stick.
children.prevalue: Halloa a knife said Cornelius preparing to defend himself with his stick

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The two remained silent for some minutes, Gryphus on the offensive, and Van Baerle on the defensive.
children.prevalue: The two remained silent for some minutes Gryphus on the offensive and Van Baerle on the defensive

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Then, as the situation might be prolonged to an indefinite length, Cornelius, anxious to know something more of the causes which had so fiercely exasperated his jailer, spoke first by putting the question,
children.prevalue: Then as the situation might be prolonged to an indefinite length Cornelius anxious to know something more of the causes which had so fiercely exasperated his jailer spoke first by putting the question

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Well, what do you want, after all?
children.prevalue: Well what do you want after all

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I'll tell you what I want, answered Gryphus; I want you to restore to me my daughter Rosa.
children.prevalue: I ll tell you what I want answered Gryphus I want you to restore to me my daughter Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Your daughter? cried Van Baerle.
children.prevalue: Your daughter cried Van Baerle

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Yes, my daughter Rosa, whom you have taken from me by your devilish magic. Now, will you tell me where she is?
children.prevalue: Yes my daughter Rosa whom you have taken from me by your devilish magic Now will you tell me where she is

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: And the attitude of Gryphus became more and more threatening.
children.prevalue: And the attitude of Gryphus became more and more threatening

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Rosa is not at Loewestein? cried Cornelius.
children.prevalue: Rosa is not at Loewestein cried Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: You know well she is not. Once more, will you restore her to me?
children.prevalue: You know well she is not Once more will you restore her to me

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I see, said Cornelius, this is a trap you are laying for me.
children.prevalue: I see said Cornelius this is a trap you are laying for me

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Now, for the last time, will you tell me where my daughter is?
children.prevalue: Now for the last time will you tell me where my daughter is

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Guess it, you rogue, if you don't know it.
children.prevalue: Guess it you rogue if you don t know it

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Only wait, only wait, growled Gryphus, white with rage, and with quivering lips, as his brain began to turn. Ah, you will not tell me anything? Well, I'll unlock your teeth!
children.prevalue: Only wait only wait growled Gryphus white with rage and with quivering lips as his brain began to turn Ah you will not tell me anything Well I ll unlock your teeth

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: He advanced a step towards Cornelius, and said, showing him the weapon which he held in his hands,
children.prevalue: He advanced a step towards Cornelius and said showing him the weapon which he held in his hands

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Do you see this knife? Well, I have killed more than fifty black cocks with it, and I vow I'll kill their master, the devil, as well as them.
children.prevalue: Do you see this knife Well I have killed more than fifty black cocks with it and I vow I ll kill their master the devil as well as them

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: But, you blockhead, said Cornelius, will you really kill me?
children.prevalue: But you blockhead said Cornelius will you really kill me

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: I shall open your heart to see in it the place where you hide my daughter.
children.prevalue: I shall open your heart to see in it the place where you hide my daughter

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Saying this, Gryphus in his frenzy rushed towards Cornelius, who had barely time to retreat behind his table to avoid the first thrust; but as Gryphus continued, with horrid threats, to brandish his huge knife, and as, although out of the reach of his weapon, yet, as long as it remained in the madman's hand, the ruffian might fling it at him, Cornelius lost no time, and availing himself of the stick, which he held tight under his arm, dealt the jailer a vigorous blow on the wrist of that hand which held the knife.
children.prevalue: Saying this Gryphus in his frenzy rushed towards Cornelius who had barely time to retreat behind his table to avoid the first thrust but as Gryphus continued with horrid threats to brandish his huge knife and as although out of the reach of his weapon yet as long as it remained in the madman s hand the ruffian might fling it at him Cornelius lost no time and availing himself of the stick which he held tight under his arm dealt the jailer a vigorous blow on the wrist of that hand which held the knife

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The knife fell to the ground, and Cornelius put his foot on it.
children.prevalue: The knife fell to the ground and Cornelius put his foot on it

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Then, as Gryphus seemed bent upon engaging in a struggle which the pain in his wrist, and shame for having allowed himself to be disarmed, would have made desperate, Cornelius took a decisive step, belaboring his jailer with the most heroic selfpossession, and selecting the exact spot for every blow of the terrible cudgel.
children.prevalue: Then as Gryphus seemed bent upon engaging in a struggle which the pain in his wrist and shame for having allowed himself to be disarmed would have made desperate Cornelius took a decisive step belaboring his jailer with the most heroic selfpossession and selecting the exact spot for every blow of the terrible cudgel

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: It was not long before Gryphus begged for mercy. But before begging for mercy, he had lustily roared for help, and his cries had roused all the functionaries of the prison. Two turnkeys, an inspector, and three or four guards, made their appearance all at once, and found Cornelius still using the stick, with the knife under his foot.
children.prevalue: It was not long before Gryphus begged for mercy But before begging for mercy he had lustily roared for help and his cries had roused all the functionaries of the prison Two turnkeys an inspector and three or four guards made their appearance all at once and found Cornelius still using the stick with the knife under his foot

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: At the sight of these witnesses, who could not know all the circumstances which had provoked and might justify his offence, Cornelius felt that he was irretrievably lost.
children.prevalue: At the sight of these witnesses who could not know all the circumstances which had provoked and might justify his offence Cornelius felt that he was irretrievably lost

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: In fact, appearances were sadly against him.
children.prevalue: In fact appearances were sadly against him

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: In one moment Cornelius was disarmed, and Gryphus raised and supported; and, bellowing with rage and pain, he was able to count on his back and shoulders the bruises which were beginning to swell like the hills dotting the slopes of a mountain ridge.
children.prevalue: In one moment Cornelius was disarmed and Gryphus raised and supported and bellowing with rage and pain he was able to count on his back and shoulders the bruises which were beginning to swell like the hills dotting the slopes of a mountain ridge

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: A protocol of the violence practiced by the prisoner against his jailer was immediately drawn up, and as it was made on the depositions of Gryphus, it certainly could not be said to be too tame; the prisoner being charged with neither more nor less than with an attempt to murder, for a long time premeditated, with open rebellion.
children.prevalue: A protocol of the violence practiced by the prisoner against his jailer was immediately drawn up and as it was made on the depositions of Gryphus it certainly could not be said to be too tame the prisoner being charged with neither more nor less than with an attempt to murder for a long time premeditated with open rebellion

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Whilst the charge was made out against Cornelius, Gryphus, whose presence was no longer necessary after having made his depositions, was taken down by his turnkeys to his lodge, groaning and covered with bruises.
children.prevalue: Whilst the charge was made out against Cornelius Gryphus whose presence was no longer necessary after having made his depositions was taken down by his turnkeys to his lodge groaning and covered with bruises

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: During this time, the guards who had seized Cornelius busied themselves in charitably informing their prisoner of the usages and customs of Loewestein, which however he knew as well as they did. The regulations had been read to him at the moment of his entering the prison, and certain articles in them remained fixed in his memory.
children.prevalue: During this time the guards who had seized Cornelius busied themselves in charitably informing their prisoner of the usages and customs of Loewestein which however he knew as well as they did The regulations had been read to him at the moment of his entering the prison and certain articles in them remained fixed in his memory

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Among other things they told him that this regulation had been carried out to its full extent in the case of a prisoner named Mathias, who in 1668, that is to say, five years before, had committed a much less violent act of rebellion than that of which Cornelius was guilty. He had found his soup too hot, and thrown it at the head of the chief turnkey, who in consequence of this ablution had been put to the inconvenience of having his skin come off as he wiped his face.
children.prevalue: Among other things they told him that this regulation had been carried out to its full extent in the case of a prisoner named Mathias who in 1668 that is to say five years before had committed a much less violent act of rebellion than that of which Cornelius was guilty He had found his soup too hot and thrown it at the head of the chief turnkey who in consequence of this ablution had been put to the inconvenience of having his skin come off as he wiped his face

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Mathias was taken within twelve hours from his cell, then led to the jailer's lodge, where he was registered as leaving Loewestein, then taken to the Esplanade, from which there is a very fine prospect over a wide expanse of country. There they fettered his hands, bandaged his eyes, and let him say his prayers.
children.prevalue: Mathias was taken within twelve hours from his cell then led to the jailer s lodge where he was registered as leaving Loewestein then taken to the Esplanade from which there is a very fine prospect over a wide expanse of country There they fettered his hands bandaged his eyes and let him say his prayers

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Hereupon he was invited to go down on his knees, and the guards of Loewestein, twelve in number, at a sign from a sergeant, very cleverly lodged a musketball each in his body.
children.prevalue: Hereupon he was invited to go down on his knees and the guards of Loewestein twelve in number at a sign from a sergeant very cleverly lodged a musketball each in his body

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: In consequence of this proceeding, Mathias incontinently did then and there die.
children.prevalue: In consequence of this proceeding Mathias incontinently did then and there die

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Cornelius listened with the greatest attention to this delightful recital, and then said,
children.prevalue: Cornelius listened with the greatest attention to this delightful recital and then said

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Ah! ah! within twelve hours, you say?
children.prevalue: Ah ah within twelve hours you say

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Yes, the twelfth hour had not even struck, if I remember right, said the guard who had told him the story.
children.prevalue: Yes the twelfth hour had not even struck if I remember right said the guard who had told him the story

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Thank you, said Cornelius.
children.prevalue: Thank you said Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The guard still had the smile on his face with which he accompanied and as it were accentuated his tale, when footsteps and a jingling of spurs were heard ascending the staircase.
children.prevalue: The guard still had the smile on his face with which he accompanied and as it were accentuated his tale when footsteps and a jingling of spurs were heard ascending the staircase

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The guards fell back to allow an officer to pass, who entered the cell of Cornelius at the moment when the clerk of Loewestein was still making out his report.
children.prevalue: The guards fell back to allow an officer to pass who entered the cell of Cornelius at the moment when the clerk of Loewestein was still making out his report

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Is this No. 11? he asked.
children.prevalue: Is this No 11 he asked

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Yes, Captain, answered a noncommissioned officer.
children.prevalue: Yes Captain answered a noncommissioned officer

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Then this is the cell of the prisoner Cornelius van Baerle?
children.prevalue: Then this is the cell of the prisoner Cornelius van Baerle

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Exactly, Captain.
children.prevalue: Exactly Captain

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Where is the prisoner?
children.prevalue: Where is the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Here I am, sir, answered Cornelius, growing rather pale, notwithstanding all his courage.
children.prevalue: Here I am sir answered Cornelius growing rather pale notwithstanding all his courage

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: You are Dr. Cornelius van Baerle? asked he, this time addressing the prisoner himself.
children.prevalue: You are Dr Cornelius van Baerle asked he this time addressing the prisoner himself

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Yes, sir.
children.prevalue: Yes sir

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Then follow me.
children.prevalue: Then follow me

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Oh! oh! said Cornelius, whose heart felt oppressed by the first dread of death. What quick work they make here in the fortress of Loewestein. And the rascal talked to me of twelve hours!
children.prevalue: Oh oh said Cornelius whose heart felt oppressed by the first dread of death What quick work they make here in the fortress of Loewestein And the rascal talked to me of twelve hours

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Ah! what did I tell you? whispered the communicative guard in the ear of the culprit.
children.prevalue: Ah what did I tell you whispered the communicative guard in the ear of the culprit

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: A lie.
children.prevalue: A lie

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: How so?
children.prevalue: How so

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: You promised me twelve hours.
children.prevalue: You promised me twelve hours

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Ah, yes, but here comes to you an aidedecamp of his Highness, even one of his most intimate companions Van Deken. Zounds! they did not grant such an honour to poor Mathias.
children.prevalue: Ah yes but here comes to you an aidedecamp of his Highness even one of his most intimate companions Van Deken Zounds they did not grant such an honour to poor Mathias

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Come, come! said Cornelius, drawing a long breath. Come, I'll show to these people that an honest burgher, godson of Cornelius de Witt, can without flinching receive as many musketballs as that Mathias.
children.prevalue: Come come said Cornelius drawing a long breath Come I ll show to these people that an honest burgher godson of Cornelius de Witt can without flinching receive as many musketballs as that Mathias

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Saying this, he passed proudly before the clerk, who, being interrupted in his work, ventured to say to the officer,
children.prevalue: Saying this he passed proudly before the clerk who being interrupted in his work ventured to say to the officer

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: But, Captain van Deken, the protocol is not yet finished.
children.prevalue: But Captain van Deken the protocol is not yet finished

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: It is not worth while finishing it, answered the officer.
children.prevalue: It is not worth while finishing it answered the officer

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: All right, replied the clerk, philosophically putting up his paper and pen into a greasy and wellworn writingcase.
children.prevalue: All right replied the clerk philosophically putting up his paper and pen into a greasy and wellworn writingcase

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: It was written, thought poor Cornelius, that I should not in this world give my name either to a child to a flower, or to a book,the three things by which a man's memory is perpetuated.
children.prevalue: It was written thought poor Cornelius that I should not in this world give my name either to a child to a flower or to a book the three things by which a man s memory is perpetuated

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Repressing his melancholy thoughts, he followed the officer with a resolute heart, and carrying his head erect.
children.prevalue: Repressing his melancholy thoughts he followed the officer with a resolute heart and carrying his head erect

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Cornelius counted the steps which led to the Esplanade, regretting that he had not asked the guard how many there were of them, which the man, in his official complaisance, would not have failed to tell him.
children.prevalue: Cornelius counted the steps which led to the Esplanade regretting that he had not asked the guard how many there were of them which the man in his official complaisance would not have failed to tell him

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: What the poor prisoner was most afraid of during this walk, which he considered as leading him to the end of the journey of life, was to see Gryphus and not to see Rosa. What savage satisfaction would glisten in the eyes of the father, and what sorrow dim those of the daughter!
children.prevalue: What the poor prisoner was most afraid of during this walk which he considered as leading him to the end of the journey of life was to see Gryphus and not to see Rosa What savage satisfaction would glisten in the eyes of the father and what sorrow dim those of the daughter

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: How Gryphus would glory in his punishment! Punishment? Rather savage vengeance for an eminently righteous deed, which Cornelius had the satisfaction of having performed as a bounden duty.
children.prevalue: How Gryphus would glory in his punishment Punishment Rather savage vengeance for an eminently righteous deed which Cornelius had the satisfaction of having performed as a bounden duty

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: But Rosa, poor girl! must he die without a glimpse of her, without an opportunity to give her one last kiss, or even to say one last word of farewell?
children.prevalue: But Rosa poor girl must he die without a glimpse of her without an opportunity to give her one last kiss or even to say one last word of farewell

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: And, worst of all, must he die without any intelligence of the black tulip, and regain his consciousness in heaven with no idea in what direction he should look to find it?
children.prevalue: And worst of all must he die without any intelligence of the black tulip and regain his consciousness in heaven with no idea in what direction he should look to find it

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: In truth, to restrain his tears at such a crisis the poor wretch's heart must have been encased in more of the aes triplexthe triple brassthan Horace bestows upon the sailor who first visited the terrifying Acroceraunian shoals.
children.prevalue: In truth to restrain his tears at such a crisis the poor wretch s heart must have been encased in more of the aes triplexthe triple brassthan Horace bestows upon the sailor who first visited the terrifying Acroceraunian shoals

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: In vain did Cornelius look to the right and to the left; he saw no sign either of Rosa or Gryphus.
children.prevalue: In vain did Cornelius look to the right and to the left he saw no sign either of Rosa or Gryphus

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: On reaching the Esplanade, he bravely looked about for the guards who were to be his executioners, and in reality saw a dozen soldiers assembled. But they were not standing in line, or carrying muskets, but talking together so gayly that Cornelius felt almost shocked.
children.prevalue: On reaching the Esplanade he bravely looked about for the guards who were to be his executioners and in reality saw a dozen soldiers assembled But they were not standing in line or carrying muskets but talking together so gayly that Cornelius felt almost shocked

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: All at once, Gryphus, limping, staggering, and supporting himself on a crooked stick, came forth from the jailer's lodge; his old eyes, gray as those of a cat, were lit up by a gleam in which all his hatred was concentrated. He then began to pour forth such a torrent of disgusting imprecations against Cornelius, that the latter, addressing the officer, said,
children.prevalue: All at once Gryphus limping staggering and supporting himself on a crooked stick came forth from the jailer s lodge his old eyes gray as those of a cat were lit up by a gleam in which all his hatred was concentrated He then began to pour forth such a torrent of disgusting imprecations against Cornelius that the latter addressing the officer said

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: I do not think it very becoming sir, that I should be thus insulted by this man, especially at a moment like this.
children.prevalue: I do not think it very becoming sir that I should be thus insulted by this man especially at a moment like this

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Well! hear me, said the officer, laughing, it is quite natural that this worthy fellow should bear you a grudge,you seem to have given it him very soundly.
children.prevalue: Well hear me said the officer laughing it is quite natural that this worthy fellow should bear you a grudge you seem to have given it him very soundly

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: But, sir, it was only in selfdefence.
children.prevalue: But sir it was only in selfdefence

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Never mind, said the Captain, shrugging his shoulders like a true philosopher, let him talk; what does it matter to you now?
children.prevalue: Never mind said the Captain shrugging his shoulders like a true philosopher let him talk what does it matter to you now

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: The cold sweat stood on the brow of Cornelius at this answer, which he looked upon somewhat in the light of brutal irony, especially as coming from an officer of whom he had heard it said that he was attached to the person of the Prince.
children.prevalue: The cold sweat stood on the brow of Cornelius at this answer which he looked upon somewhat in the light of brutal irony especially as coming from an officer of whom he had heard it said that he was attached to the person of the Prince

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: The unfortunate tulipfancier then felt that he had no more resources, and no more friends, and resigned himself to his fate.
children.prevalue: The unfortunate tulipfancier then felt that he had no more resources and no more friends and resigned himself to his fate

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: God's will be done, he muttered, bowing his head; then, turning towards the officer, who seemed complacently to wait until he had finished his meditations he asked,
children.prevalue: God s will be done he muttered bowing his head then turning towards the officer who seemed complacently to wait until he had finished his meditations he asked

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Please, sir, tell me now, where am I to go?
children.prevalue: Please sir tell me now where am I to go

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: The officer pointed to a carriage, drawn by four horses, which reminded him very strongly of that which, under similar circumstances, had before attracted his attention at Buytenhof.
children.prevalue: The officer pointed to a carriage drawn by four horses which reminded him very strongly of that which under similar circumstances had before attracted his attention at Buytenhof

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Enter, said the officer.
children.prevalue: Enter said the officer

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Ah! muttered Cornelius to himself, it seems they are not going to treat me to the honours of the Esplanade.
children.prevalue: Ah muttered Cornelius to himself it seems they are not going to treat me to the honours of the Esplanade

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: He uttered these words loud enough for the chatty guard, who was at his heels, to overhear him.
children.prevalue: He uttered these words loud enough for the chatty guard who was at his heels to overhear him

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: That kind soul very likely thought it his duty to give Cornelius some new information; for, approaching the door of the carriage, whilst the officer, with one foot on the step, was still giving some orders, he whispered to Van Baerle,
children.prevalue: That kind soul very likely thought it his duty to give Cornelius some new information for approaching the door of the carriage whilst the officer with one foot on the step was still giving some orders he whispered to Van Baerle

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Condemned prisoners have sometimes been taken to their own town to be made an example of, and have then been executed before the door of their own house. It's all according to circumstances.
children.prevalue: Condemned prisoners have sometimes been taken to their own town to be made an example of and have then been executed before the door of their own house It s all according to circumstances

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Cornelius thanked him by signs, and then said to himself,
children.prevalue: Cornelius thanked him by signs and then said to himself

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Well, here is a fellow who never misses giving consolation whenever an opportunity presents itself. In truth, my friend, I'm very much obliged to you. Goodbye.
children.prevalue: Well here is a fellow who never misses giving consolation whenever an opportunity presents itself In truth my friend I m very much obliged to you Goodbye

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: The carriage drove away.
children.prevalue: The carriage drove away

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Ah! you villain, you brigand, roared Gryphus, clinching his fists at the victim who was escaping from his clutches, is it not a shame that this fellow gets off without having restored my daughter to me?
children.prevalue: Ah you villain you brigand roared Gryphus clinching his fists at the victim who was escaping from his clutches is it not a shame that this fellow gets off without having restored my daughter to me

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: If they take me to Dort, thought Cornelius, I shall see, in passing my house, whether my poor borders have been much spoiled.
children.prevalue: If they take me to Dort thought Cornelius I shall see in passing my house whether my poor borders have been much spoiled

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The carriage rolled on during the whole day; it passed on the right of Dort, went through Rotterdam, and reached Delft. At five o'clock in the evening, at least twenty leagues had been travelled.
children.prevalue: The carriage rolled on during the whole day it passed on the right of Dort went through Rotterdam and reached Delft At five o clock in the evening at least twenty leagues had been travelled

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Cornelius addressed some questions to the officer, who was at the same time his guard and his companion; but, cautious as were his inquiries, he had the disappointment of receiving no answer.
children.prevalue: Cornelius addressed some questions to the officer who was at the same time his guard and his companion but cautious as were his inquiries he had the disappointment of receiving no answer

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Cornelius regretted that he had no longer by his side the chatty soldier, who would talk without being questioned.
children.prevalue: Cornelius regretted that he had no longer by his side the chatty soldier who would talk without being questioned

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: That obliging person would undoubtedly have given him as pleasant details and exact explanations concerning this third strange part of his adventures as he had done concerning the first two.
children.prevalue: That obliging person would undoubtedly have given him as pleasant details and exact explanations concerning this third strange part of his adventures as he had done concerning the first two

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The travellers passed the night in the carriage. On the following morning at dawn Cornelius found himself beyond Leyden, having the North Sea on his left, and the Zuyder Zee on his right.
children.prevalue: The travellers passed the night in the carriage On the following morning at dawn Cornelius found himself beyond Leyden having the North Sea on his left and the Zuyder Zee on his right

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Three hours after, he entered Haarlem.
children.prevalue: Three hours after he entered Haarlem

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Cornelius was not aware of what had passed at Haarlem, and we shall leave him in ignorance of it until the course of events enlightens him.
children.prevalue: Cornelius was not aware of what had passed at Haarlem and we shall leave him in ignorance of it until the course of events enlightens him

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: But the reader has a right to know all about it even before our hero, and therefore we shall not make him wait.
children.prevalue: But the reader has a right to know all about it even before our hero and therefore we shall not make him wait

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: We have seen that Rosa and the tulip, like two orphan sisters, had been left by Prince William of Orange at the house of the President van Systens.
children.prevalue: We have seen that Rosa and the tulip like two orphan sisters had been left by Prince William of Orange at the house of the President van Systens

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Rosa did not hear again from the Stadtholder until the evening of that day on which she had seen him face to face.
children.prevalue: Rosa did not hear again from the Stadtholder until the evening of that day on which she had seen him face to face

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Toward evening, an officer called at Van Systen's house. He came from his Highness, with a request for Rosa to appear at the Town Hall.
children.prevalue: Toward evening an officer called at Van Systen s house He came from his Highness with a request for Rosa to appear at the Town Hall

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: There, in the large Council Room into which she was ushered, she found the Prince writing.
children.prevalue: There in the large Council Room into which she was ushered she found the Prince writing

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: He was alone, with a large Frisian greyhound at his feet, which looked at him with a steady glance, as if the faithful animal were wishing to do what no man could do,read the thoughts of his master in his face.
children.prevalue: He was alone with a large Frisian greyhound at his feet which looked at him with a steady glance as if the faithful animal were wishing to do what no man could do read the thoughts of his master in his face

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: William continued his writing for a moment; then, raising his eyes, and seeing Rosa standing near the door, he said, without laying down his pen,
children.prevalue: William continued his writing for a moment then raising his eyes and seeing Rosa standing near the door he said without laying down his pen

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Come here, my child.
