children.prevalue: Come here my child

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Rosa advanced a few steps towards the table.
children.prevalue: Rosa advanced a few steps towards the table

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Sit down, he said.
children.prevalue: Sit down he said

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Rosa obeyed, for the Prince was fixing his eyes upon her, but he had scarcely turned them again to his paper when she bashfully retired to the door.
children.prevalue: Rosa obeyed for the Prince was fixing his eyes upon her but he had scarcely turned them again to his paper when she bashfully retired to the door

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The Prince finished his letter.
children.prevalue: The Prince finished his letter

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: During this time, the greyhound went up to Rosa, surveyed her and began to caress her.
children.prevalue: During this time the greyhound went up to Rosa surveyed her and began to caress her

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Ah, ah! said William to his dog, it's easy to see that she is a countrywoman of yours, and that you recognise her.
children.prevalue: Ah ah said William to his dog it s easy to see that she is a countrywoman of yours and that you recognise her

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Then, turning towards Rosa, and fixing on her his scrutinising, and at the same time impenetrable glance, he said,
children.prevalue: Then turning towards Rosa and fixing on her his scrutinising and at the same time impenetrable glance he said

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Now, my child.
children.prevalue: Now my child

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The Prince was scarcely twentythree, and Rosa eighteen or twenty. He might therefore perhaps better have said, My sister.
children.prevalue: The Prince was scarcely twentythree and Rosa eighteen or twenty He might therefore perhaps better have said My sister

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: My child, he said, with that strangely commanding accent which chilled all those who approached him, we are alone; let us speak together.
children.prevalue: My child he said with that strangely commanding accent which chilled all those who approached him we are alone let us speak together

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Rosa began to tremble, and yet there was nothing but kindness in the expression of the Prince's face.
children.prevalue: Rosa began to tremble and yet there was nothing but kindness in the expression of the Prince s face

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Monseigneur, she stammered.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur she stammered

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: You have a father at Loewestein?
children.prevalue: You have a father at Loewestein

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Yes, your Highness.
children.prevalue: Yes your Highness

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: You do not love him?
children.prevalue: You do not love him

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: I do not; at least, not as a daughter ought to do, Monseigneur.
children.prevalue: I do not at least not as a daughter ought to do Monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: It is not right not to love one's father, but it is right not to tell a falsehood.
children.prevalue: It is not right not to love one s father but it is right not to tell a falsehood

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Rosa cast her eyes to the ground.
children.prevalue: Rosa cast her eyes to the ground

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: What is the reason of your not loving your father?
children.prevalue: What is the reason of your not loving your father

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: He is wicked.
children.prevalue: He is wicked

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: In what way does he show his wickedness?
children.prevalue: In what way does he show his wickedness

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: He illtreats the prisoners.
children.prevalue: He illtreats the prisoners

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: All of them?
children.prevalue: All of them

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: All.
children.prevalue: All

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: But don't you bear him a grudge for illtreating some one in particular?
children.prevalue: But don t you bear him a grudge for illtreating some one in particular

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: My father illtreats in particular Mynheer van Baerle, who
children.prevalue: My father illtreats in particular Mynheer van Baerle who

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Who is your lover?
children.prevalue: Who is your lover

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Rosa started back a step.
children.prevalue: Rosa started back a step

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Whom I love, Monseigneur, she answered proudly.
children.prevalue: Whom I love Monseigneur she answered proudly

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Since when? asked the Prince.
children.prevalue: Since when asked the Prince

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Since the day when I first saw him.
children.prevalue: Since the day when I first saw him

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: And when was that?
children.prevalue: And when was that

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The day after that on which the Grand Pensionary John and his brother Cornelius met with such an awful death.
children.prevalue: The day after that on which the Grand Pensionary John and his brother Cornelius met with such an awful death

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: The Prince compressed his lips, and knit his brow and his eyelids dropped so as to hide his eyes for an instant. After a momentary silence, he resumed the conversation.
children.prevalue: The Prince compressed his lips and knit his brow and his eyelids dropped so as to hide his eyes for an instant After a momentary silence he resumed the conversation

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: But to what can it lead to love a man who is doomed to live and die in prison?
children.prevalue: But to what can it lead to love a man who is doomed to live and die in prison

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: It will lead, if he lives and dies in prison, to my aiding him in life and in death.
children.prevalue: It will lead if he lives and dies in prison to my aiding him in life and in death

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: And would you accept the lot of being the wife of a prisoner?
children.prevalue: And would you accept the lot of being the wife of a prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: As the wife of Mynheer van Baerle, I should, under any circumstances, be the proudest and happiest woman in the world; but
children.prevalue: As the wife of Mynheer van Baerle I should under any circumstances be the proudest and happiest woman in the world but

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: But what?
children.prevalue: But what

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: I dare not say, Monseigneur.
children.prevalue: I dare not say Monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: There is something like hope in your tone; what do you hope?
children.prevalue: There is something like hope in your tone what do you hope

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: She raised her moist and beautiful eyes, and looked at William with a glance full of meaning, which was calculated to stir up in the recesses of his heart the clemency which was slumbering there.
children.prevalue: She raised her moist and beautiful eyes and looked at William with a glance full of meaning which was calculated to stir up in the recesses of his heart the clemency which was slumbering there

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Ah, I understand you, he said.
children.prevalue: Ah I understand you he said

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Rosa, with a smile, clasped her hands.
children.prevalue: Rosa with a smile clasped her hands

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: You hope in me? said the Prince.
children.prevalue: You hope in me said the Prince

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Yes, Monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes Monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Umph!
children.prevalue: Umph

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: The Prince sealed the letter which he had just written, and summoned one of his officers, to whom he said,
children.prevalue: The Prince sealed the letter which he had just written and summoned one of his officers to whom he said

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Captain van Deken, carry this despatch to Loewestein; you will read the orders which I give to the Governor, and execute them as far as they regard you.
children.prevalue: Captain van Deken carry this despatch to Loewestein you will read the orders which I give to the Governor and execute them as far as they regard you

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: The officer bowed, and a few minutes afterwards the gallop of a horse was heard resounding in the vaulted archway.
children.prevalue: The officer bowed and a few minutes afterwards the gallop of a horse was heard resounding in the vaulted archway

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: My child, continued the Prince, the feast of the tulip will be on Sunday next, that is to say, the day after tomorrow. Make yourself smart with these five hundred guilders, as I wish that day to be a great day for you.
children.prevalue: My child continued the Prince the feast of the tulip will be on Sunday next that is to say the day after tomorrow Make yourself smart with these five hundred guilders as I wish that day to be a great day for you

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: How does your Highness wish me to be dressed? faltered Rosa.
children.prevalue: How does your Highness wish me to be dressed faltered Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Take the costume of a Frisian bride. said William; it will suit you very well indeed.
children.prevalue: Take the costume of a Frisian bride said William it will suit you very well indeed

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Haarlem, whither, three days ago, we conducted our gentle reader, and whither we request him to follow us once more in the footsteps of the prisoner, is a pleasant city, which justly prides itself on being one of the most shady in all the Netherlands.
children.prevalue: Haarlem whither three days ago we conducted our gentle reader and whither we request him to follow us once more in the footsteps of the prisoner is a pleasant city which justly prides itself on being one of the most shady in all the Netherlands

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: While other towns boast of the magnificence of their arsenals and dockyards, and the splendour of their shops and markets, Haarlem's claims to fame rest upon her superiority to all other provincial cities in the number and beauty of her spreading elms, graceful poplars, and, more than all, upon her pleasant walks, shaded by the lovely arches of magnificent oaks, lindens, and chestnuts.
children.prevalue: While other towns boast of the magnificence of their arsenals and dockyards and the splendour of their shops and markets Haarlem s claims to fame rest upon her superiority to all other provincial cities in the number and beauty of her spreading elms graceful poplars and more than all upon her pleasant walks shaded by the lovely arches of magnificent oaks lindens and chestnuts

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Haarlem,just as her neighbour, Leyden, became the centre of science, and her queen, Amsterdam, that of commerce,Haarlem preferred to be the agricultural, or, more strictly speaking, the horticultural metropolis.
children.prevalue: Haarlem just as her neighbour Leyden became the centre of science and her queen Amsterdam that of commerce Haarlem preferred to be the agricultural or more strictly speaking the horticultural metropolis

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: In fact, girt about as she was, breezy and exposed to the sun's hot rays, she seemed to offer to gardeners so many more guarantees of success than other places, with their heavy sea air, and their scorching heat.
children.prevalue: In fact girt about as she was breezy and exposed to the sun s hot rays she seemed to offer to gardeners so many more guarantees of success than other places with their heavy sea air and their scorching heat

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: On this account all the serene souls who loved the earth and its fruits had gradually gathered together at Haarlem, just as all the nervous, uneasy spirits, whose ambition was for travel and commerce, had settled in Rotterdam and Amsterdam, and all the politicians and selfish worldlings at the Hague.
children.prevalue: On this account all the serene souls who loved the earth and its fruits had gradually gathered together at Haarlem just as all the nervous uneasy spirits whose ambition was for travel and commerce had settled in Rotterdam and Amsterdam and all the politicians and selfish worldlings at the Hague

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: We have observed that Leyden overflowed with scholars. In like manner Haarlem was devoted to the gentle pursuits of peace,to music and painting, orchards and avenues, groves and parks. Haarlem went wild about flowers, and tulips received their full share of worship.
children.prevalue: We have observed that Leyden overflowed with scholars In like manner Haarlem was devoted to the gentle pursuits of peace to music and painting orchards and avenues groves and parks Haarlem went wild about flowers and tulips received their full share of worship

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Haarlem offered prizes for tulipgrowing; and this fact brings us in the most natural manner to that celebration which the city intended to hold on May 15th, 1673 in honour of the great black tulip, immaculate and perfect, which should gain for its discoverer one hundred thousand guilders!
children.prevalue: Haarlem offered prizes for tulipgrowing and this fact brings us in the most natural manner to that celebration which the city intended to hold on May 15th 1673 in honour of the great black tulip immaculate and perfect which should gain for its discoverer one hundred thousand guilders

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Haarlem, having placed on exhibition its favourite, having advertised its love of flowers in general and of tulips in particular, at a period when the souls of men were filled with war and sedition,Haarlem, having enjoyed the exquisite pleasure of admiring the very purest ideal of tulips in full bloom,Haarlem, this tiny town, full of trees and of sunshine, of light and shade, had determined that the ceremony of bestowing the prize should be a fete which should live for ever in the memory of men.
children.prevalue: Haarlem having placed on exhibition its favourite having advertised its love of flowers in general and of tulips in particular at a period when the souls of men were filled with war and sedition Haarlem having enjoyed the exquisite pleasure of admiring the very purest ideal of tulips in full bloom Haarlem this tiny town full of trees and of sunshine of light and shade had determined that the ceremony of bestowing the prize should be a fete which should live for ever in the memory of men

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: So much the more reason was there, too, in her determination, in that Holland is the home of fetes; never did sluggish natures manifest more eager energy of the singing and dancing sort than those of the good republicans of the Seven Provinces when amusement was the order of the day.
children.prevalue: So much the more reason was there too in her determination in that Holland is the home of fetes never did sluggish natures manifest more eager energy of the singing and dancing sort than those of the good republicans of the Seven Provinces when amusement was the order of the day

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Study the pictures of the two Teniers.
children.prevalue: Study the pictures of the two Teniers

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: It is certain that sluggish folk are of all men the most earnest in tiring themselves, not when they are at work, but at play.
children.prevalue: It is certain that sluggish folk are of all men the most earnest in tiring themselves not when they are at work but at play

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Thus Haarlem was thrice given over to rejoicing, for a threefold celebration was to take place.
children.prevalue: Thus Haarlem was thrice given over to rejoicing for a threefold celebration was to take place

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: In the first place, the black tulip had been produced; secondly, the Prince William of Orange, as a true Hollander, had promised to be present at the ceremony of its inauguration; and, thirdly, it was a point of honour with the States to show to the French, at the conclusion of such a disastrous war as that of 1672, that the flooring of the Batavian Republic was solid enough for its people to dance on it, with the accompaniment of the cannon of their fleets.
children.prevalue: In the first place the black tulip had been produced secondly the Prince William of Orange as a true Hollander had promised to be present at the ceremony of its inauguration and thirdly it was a point of honour with the States to show to the French at the conclusion of such a disastrous war as that of 1672 that the flooring of the Batavian Republic was solid enough for its people to dance on it with the accompaniment of the cannon of their fleets

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The Horticultural Society of Haarlem had shown itself worthy of its fame by giving a hundred thousand guilders for the bulb of a tulip. The town, which did not wish to be outdone, voted a like sum, which was placed in the hands of that notable body to solemnise the auspicious event.
children.prevalue: The Horticultural Society of Haarlem had shown itself worthy of its fame by giving a hundred thousand guilders for the bulb of a tulip The town which did not wish to be outdone voted a like sum which was placed in the hands of that notable body to solemnise the auspicious event

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: And indeed on the Sunday fixed for this ceremony there was such a stir among the people, and such an enthusiasm among the townsfolk, that even a Frenchman, who laughs at everything at all times, could not have helped admiring the character of those honest Hollanders, who were equally ready to spend their money for the construction of a manofwarthat is to say, for the support of national honouras they were to reward the growth of a new flower, destined to bloom for one day, and to serve during that day to divert the ladies, the learned, and the curious.
children.prevalue: And indeed on the Sunday fixed for this ceremony there was such a stir among the people and such an enthusiasm among the townsfolk that even a Frenchman who laughs at everything at all times could not have helped admiring the character of those honest Hollanders who were equally ready to spend their money for the construction of a manofwarthat is to say for the support of national honouras they were to reward the growth of a new flower destined to bloom for one day and to serve during that day to divert the ladies the learned and the curious

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: At the head of the notables and of the Horticultural Committee shone Mynheer van Systens, dressed in his richest habiliments.
children.prevalue: At the head of the notables and of the Horticultural Committee shone Mynheer van Systens dressed in his richest habiliments

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: The worthy man had done his best to imitate his favourite flower in the sombre and stern elegance of his garments; and we are bound to record, to his honour, that he had perfectly succeeded in his object.
children.prevalue: The worthy man had done his best to imitate his favourite flower in the sombre and stern elegance of his garments and we are bound to record to his honour that he had perfectly succeeded in his object

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Dark crimson velvet, dark purple silk, and jetblack cloth, with linen of dazzling whiteness, composed the festive dress of the President, who marched at the head of his Committee carrying an enormous nosegay, like that which a hundred and twentyone years later, Monsieur de Robespierre displayed at the festival of The Supreme Being.
children.prevalue: Dark crimson velvet dark purple silk and jetblack cloth with linen of dazzling whiteness composed the festive dress of the President who marched at the head of his Committee carrying an enormous nosegay like that which a hundred and twentyone years later Monsieur de Robespierre displayed at the festival of The Supreme Being

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: There was, however, a little difference between the two; very different from the French tribune, whose heart was so full of hatred and ambitious vindictiveness, was the honest President, who carried in his bosom a heart as innocent as the flowers which he held in his hand.
children.prevalue: There was however a little difference between the two very different from the French tribune whose heart was so full of hatred and ambitious vindictiveness was the honest President who carried in his bosom a heart as innocent as the flowers which he held in his hand

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Behind the Committee, who were as gay as a meadow, and as fragrant as a garden in spring, marched the learned societies of the town, the magistrates, the military, the nobles and the boors.
children.prevalue: Behind the Committee who were as gay as a meadow and as fragrant as a garden in spring marched the learned societies of the town the magistrates the military the nobles and the boors

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: The people, even among the respected republicans of the Seven Provinces, had no place assigned to them in the procession; they merely lined the streets.
children.prevalue: The people even among the respected republicans of the Seven Provinces had no place assigned to them in the procession they merely lined the streets

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: This is the place for the multitude, which with true philosophic spirit, waits until the triumphal pageants have passed, to know what to say of them, and sometimes also to know what to do.
children.prevalue: This is the place for the multitude which with true philosophic spirit waits until the triumphal pageants have passed to know what to say of them and sometimes also to know what to do

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: This time, however, there was no question either of the triumph of Pompey or of Caesar; neither of the defeat of Mithridates, nor of the conquest of Gaul. The procession was as placid as the passing of a flock of lambs, and as inoffensive as a flight of birds sweeping through the air.
children.prevalue: This time however there was no question either of the triumph of Pompey or of Caesar neither of the defeat of Mithridates nor of the conquest of Gaul The procession was as placid as the passing of a flock of lambs and as inoffensive as a flight of birds sweeping through the air

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Haarlem had no other triumphers, except its gardeners. Worshipping flowers, Haarlem idolised the florist.
children.prevalue: Haarlem had no other triumphers except its gardeners Worshipping flowers Haarlem idolised the florist

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: In the centre of this pacific and fragrant cortege the black tulip was seen, carried on a litter, which was covered with white velvet and fringed with gold.
children.prevalue: In the centre of this pacific and fragrant cortege the black tulip was seen carried on a litter which was covered with white velvet and fringed with gold

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The handles of the litter were supported by four men, who were from time to time relieved by fresh relays,even as the bearers of Mother Cybele used to take turn and turn about at Rome in the ancient days, when she was brought from Etruria to the Eternal City, amid the blare of trumpets and the worship of a whole nation.
children.prevalue: The handles of the litter were supported by four men who were from time to time relieved by fresh relays even as the bearers of Mother Cybele used to take turn and turn about at Rome in the ancient days when she was brought from Etruria to the Eternal City amid the blare of trumpets and the worship of a whole nation

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: This public exhibition of the tulip was an act of adoration rendered by an entire nation, unlettered and unrefined, to the refinement and culture of its illustrious and devout leaders, whose blood had stained the foul pavement of the Buytenhof, reserving the right at a future day to inscribe the names of its victims upon the highest stone of the Dutch Pantheon.
children.prevalue: This public exhibition of the tulip was an act of adoration rendered by an entire nation unlettered and unrefined to the refinement and culture of its illustrious and devout leaders whose blood had stained the foul pavement of the Buytenhof reserving the right at a future day to inscribe the names of its victims upon the highest stone of the Dutch Pantheon

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: It was arranged that the Prince Stadtholder himself should give the prize of a hundred thousand guilders, which interested the people at large, and it was thought that perhaps he would make a speech which interested more particularly his friends and enemies.
children.prevalue: It was arranged that the Prince Stadtholder himself should give the prize of a hundred thousand guilders which interested the people at large and it was thought that perhaps he would make a speech which interested more particularly his friends and enemies

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: For in the most insignificant words of men of political importance their friends and their opponents always endeavour to detect, and hence think they can interpret, something of their true thoughts.
children.prevalue: For in the most insignificant words of men of political importance their friends and their opponents always endeavour to detect and hence think they can interpret something of their true thoughts

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: As if your true politician's hat were not a bushel under which he always hides his light!
children.prevalue: As if your true politician s hat were not a bushel under which he always hides his light

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: At length the great and longexpected dayMay 15, 1673arrived; and all Haarlem, swelled by her neighbours, was gathered in the beautiful treelined streets, determined on this occasion not to waste its applause upon military heroes, or those who had won notable victories in the field of science, but to reserve their applause for those who had overcome Nature, and had forced the inexhaustible mother to be delivered of what had theretofore been regarded as impossible,a completely black tulip.
children.prevalue: At length the great and longexpected dayMay 15 1673arrived and all Haarlem swelled by her neighbours was gathered in the beautiful treelined streets determined on this occasion not to waste its applause upon military heroes or those who had won notable victories in the field of science but to reserve their applause for those who had overcome Nature and had forced the inexhaustible mother to be delivered of what had theretofore been regarded as impossible a completely black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Nothing however, is more fickle than such a resolution of the people. When a crowd is once in the humour to cheer, it is just the same as when it begins to hiss. It never knows when to stop.
children.prevalue: Nothing however is more fickle than such a resolution of the people When a crowd is once in the humour to cheer it is just the same as when it begins to hiss It never knows when to stop

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: It therefore, in the first place, cheered Van Systens and his nosegay, then the corporation, then followed a cheer for the people; and, at last, and for once with great justice, there was one for the excellent music with which the gentlemen of the town councils generously treated the assemblage at every halt.
children.prevalue: It therefore in the first place cheered Van Systens and his nosegay then the corporation then followed a cheer for the people and at last and for once with great justice there was one for the excellent music with which the gentlemen of the town councils generously treated the assemblage at every halt

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Every eye was looking eagerly for the heroine of the festival,that is to say, the black tulip,and for its hero in the person of the one who had grown it.
children.prevalue: Every eye was looking eagerly for the heroine of the festival that is to say the black tulip and for its hero in the person of the one who had grown it

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: In case this hero should make his appearance after the address we have seen worthy Van Systens at work on so conscientiously, he would not fail to make as much of a sensation as the Stadtholder himself.
children.prevalue: In case this hero should make his appearance after the address we have seen worthy Van Systens at work on so conscientiously he would not fail to make as much of a sensation as the Stadtholder himself

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: But the interest of the day's proceedings for us is centred neither in the learned discourse of our friend Van Systens, however eloquent it might be, nor in the young dandies, resplendent in their Sunday clothes, and munching their heavy cakes; nor in the poor young peasants, gnawing smoked eels as if they were sticks of vanilla sweetmeat; neither is our interest in the lovely Dutch girls, with red cheeks and ivory bosoms; nor in the fat, round mynheers, who had never left their homes before; nor in the sallow, thin travellers from Ceylon or Java; nor in the thirsty crowds, who quenched their thirst with pickled cucumbers;no, so far as we are concerned, the real interest of the situation, the fascinating, dramatic interest, is not to be found here.
children.prevalue: But the interest of the day s proceedings for us is centred neither in the learned discourse of our friend Van Systens however eloquent it might be nor in the young dandies resplendent in their Sunday clothes and munching their heavy cakes nor in the poor young peasants gnawing smoked eels as if they were sticks of vanilla sweetmeat neither is our interest in the lovely Dutch girls with red cheeks and ivory bosoms nor in the fat round mynheers who had never left their homes before nor in the sallow thin travellers from Ceylon or Java nor in the thirsty crowds who quenched their thirst with pickled cucumbers no so far as we are concerned the real interest of the situation the fascinating dramatic interest is not to be found here

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Our interest is in a smiling, sparkling face to be seen amid the members of the Horticultural Committee; in the person with a flower in his belt, combed and brushed, and all clad in scarlet,a colour which makes his black hair and yellow skin stand out in violent contrast.
children.prevalue: Our interest is in a smiling sparkling face to be seen amid the members of the Horticultural Committee in the person with a flower in his belt combed and brushed and all clad in scarlet a colour which makes his black hair and yellow skin stand out in violent contrast

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: This hero, radiant with rapturous joy, who had the distinguished honour of making the people forget the speech of Van Systens, and even the presence of the Stadtholder, was Isaac Boxtel, who saw, carried on his right before him, the black tulip, his pretended daughter; and on his left, in a large purse, the hundred thousand guilders in glittering gold pieces, towards which he was constantly squinting, fearful of losing sight of them for one moment.
children.prevalue: This hero radiant with rapturous joy who had the distinguished honour of making the people forget the speech of Van Systens and even the presence of the Stadtholder was Isaac Boxtel who saw carried on his right before him the black tulip his pretended daughter and on his left in a large purse the hundred thousand guilders in glittering gold pieces towards which he was constantly squinting fearful of losing sight of them for one moment

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Now and then Boxtel quickened his step to rub elbows for a moment with Van Systens. He borrowed a little importance from everybody to make a kind of false importance for himself, as he had stolen Rosa's tulip to effect his own glory, and thereby make his fortune.
children.prevalue: Now and then Boxtel quickened his step to rub elbows for a moment with Van Systens He borrowed a little importance from everybody to make a kind of false importance for himself as he had stolen Rosa s tulip to effect his own glory and thereby make his fortune

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Another quarter of an hour and the Prince will arrive and the procession will halt for the last time; after the tulip is placed on its throne, the Prince, yielding precedence to this rival for the popular adoration, will take a magnificently emblazoned parchment, on which is written the name of the grower; and his Highness, in a loud and audible tone, will proclaim him to be the discoverer of a wonder; that Holland, by the instrumentality of him, Boxtel, has forced Nature to produce a black flower, which shall henceforth be called Tulipa nigra Boxtellea.
children.prevalue: Another quarter of an hour and the Prince will arrive and the procession will halt for the last time after the tulip is placed on its throne the Prince yielding precedence to this rival for the popular adoration will take a magnificently emblazoned parchment on which is written the name of the grower and his Highness in a loud and audible tone will proclaim him to be the discoverer of a wonder that Holland by the instrumentality of him Boxtel has forced Nature to produce a black flower which shall henceforth be called Tulipa nigra Boxtellea

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: From time to time, however, Boxtel withdrew his eyes for a moment from the tulip and the purse, timidly looking among the crowd, for more than anything he dreaded to descry there the pale face of the pretty Frisian girl.
children.prevalue: From time to time however Boxtel withdrew his eyes for a moment from the tulip and the purse timidly looking among the crowd for more than anything he dreaded to descry there the pale face of the pretty Frisian girl

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: She would have been a spectre spoiling the joy of the festival for him, just as Banquo's ghost did that of Macbeth.
children.prevalue: She would have been a spectre spoiling the joy of the festival for him just as Banquo s ghost did that of Macbeth

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: And yet, if the truth must be told, this wretch, who had stolen what was the boast of man, and the dowry of a woman, did not consider himself as a thief. He had so intently watched this tulip, followed it so eagerly from the drawer in Cornelius's dryroom to the scaffold of the Buytenhof, and from the scaffold to the fortress of Loewestein; he had seen it bud and grow in Rosa's window, and so often warmed the air round it with his breath, that he felt as if no one had a better right to call himself its producer than he had; and any one who would now take the black tulip from him would have appeared to him as a thief.
children.prevalue: And yet if the truth must be told this wretch who had stolen what was the boast of man and the dowry of a woman did not consider himself as a thief He had so intently watched this tulip followed it so eagerly from the drawer in Cornelius s dryroom to the scaffold of the Buytenhof and from the scaffold to the fortress of Loewestein he had seen it bud and grow in Rosa s window and so often warmed the air round it with his breath that he felt as if no one had a better right to call himself its producer than he had and any one who would now take the black tulip from him would have appeared to him as a thief

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Yet he did not perceive Rosa; his joy therefore was not spoiled.
children.prevalue: Yet he did not perceive Rosa his joy therefore was not spoiled

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: In the centre of a circle of magnificent trees, which were decorated with garlands and inscriptions, the procession halted, amidst the sounds of lively music, and the young damsels of Haarlem made their appearance to escort the tulip to the raised seat which it was to occupy on the platform, by the side of the gilded chair of his Highness the Stadtholder.
children.prevalue: In the centre of a circle of magnificent trees which were decorated with garlands and inscriptions the procession halted amidst the sounds of lively music and the young damsels of Haarlem made their appearance to escort the tulip to the raised seat which it was to occupy on the platform by the side of the gilded chair of his Highness the Stadtholder

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: And the proud tulip, raised on its pedestal, soon overlooked the assembled crowd of people, who clapped their hands, and made the old town of Haarlem reecho with their tremendous cheers.
children.prevalue: And the proud tulip raised on its pedestal soon overlooked the assembled crowd of people who clapped their hands and made the old town of Haarlem reecho with their tremendous cheers

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: At this solemn moment, and whilst the cheers still resounded, a carriage was driving along the road on the outskirts of the green on which the scene occurred; it pursued its way slowly, on account of the flocks of children who were pushed out of the avenue by the crowd of men and women.
children.prevalue: At this solemn moment and whilst the cheers still resounded a carriage was driving along the road on the outskirts of the green on which the scene occurred it pursued its way slowly on account of the flocks of children who were pushed out of the avenue by the crowd of men and women

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: This carriage, covered with dust, and creaking on its axles, the result of a long journey, enclosed the unfortunate Van Baerle, who was just beginning to get a glimpse through the open window of the scene which we have triedwith poor success, no doubtto present to the eyes of the reader.
children.prevalue: This carriage covered with dust and creaking on its axles the result of a long journey enclosed the unfortunate Van Baerle who was just beginning to get a glimpse through the open window of the scene which we have triedwith poor success no doubtto present to the eyes of the reader

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The crowd and the noise and the display of artificial and natural magnificence were as dazzling to the prisoner as a ray of light flashing suddenly into his dungeon.
children.prevalue: The crowd and the noise and the display of artificial and natural magnificence were as dazzling to the prisoner as a ray of light flashing suddenly into his dungeon

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Notwithstanding the little readiness which his companion had shown in answering his questions concerning his fate, he ventured once more to ask the meaning of all this bustle, which at first sight seemed to be utterly disconnected with his own affairs.
children.prevalue: Notwithstanding the little readiness which his companion had shown in answering his questions concerning his fate he ventured once more to ask the meaning of all this bustle which at first sight seemed to be utterly disconnected with his own affairs

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: What is all this, pray, Mynheer Lieutenant? he asked of his conductor.
children.prevalue: What is all this pray Mynheer Lieutenant he asked of his conductor

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: As you may see, sir, replied the officer, it is a feast.
children.prevalue: As you may see sir replied the officer it is a feast

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Ah, a feast, said Cornelius, in the sad tone of indifference of a man to whom no joy remains in this world.
children.prevalue: Ah a feast said Cornelius in the sad tone of indifference of a man to whom no joy remains in this world

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Then, after some moments, silence, during which the carriage had proceeded a few yards, he asked once more,
children.prevalue: Then after some moments silence during which the carriage had proceeded a few yards he asked once more

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The feast of the patron saint of Haarlem? as I see so many flowers.
children.prevalue: The feast of the patron saint of Haarlem as I see so many flowers

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: It is, indeed, a feast in which flowers play a principal part.
children.prevalue: It is indeed a feast in which flowers play a principal part

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Oh, the sweet scents! oh, the beautiful colours! cried Cornelius.
children.prevalue: Oh the sweet scents oh the beautiful colours cried Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Stop, that the gentleman may see, said the officer, with that frank kindliness which is peculiar to military men, to the soldier who was acting as postilion.
children.prevalue: Stop that the gentleman may see said the officer with that frank kindliness which is peculiar to military men to the soldier who was acting as postilion

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Oh, thank you, Sir, for your kindness, replied Van Baerle, in a melancholy tone; the joy of others pains me; please spare me this pang.
children.prevalue: Oh thank you Sir for your kindness replied Van Baerle in a melancholy tone the joy of others pains me please spare me this pang

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Just as you wish. Drive on! I ordered the driver to stop because I thought it would please you, as you are said to love flowers, and especially that the feast of which is celebrated today.
children.prevalue: Just as you wish Drive on I ordered the driver to stop because I thought it would please you as you are said to love flowers and especially that the feast of which is celebrated today

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: And what flower is that?
children.prevalue: And what flower is that

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: The tulip.
children.prevalue: The tulip

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: The tulip! cried Van Baerle, is today the feast of tulips?
children.prevalue: The tulip cried Van Baerle is today the feast of tulips

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Yes, sir; but as this spectacle displeases you, let us drive on.
children.prevalue: Yes sir but as this spectacle displeases you let us drive on

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The officer was about to give the order to proceed, but Cornelius stopped him, a painful thought having struck him. He asked, with faltering voice,
children.prevalue: The officer was about to give the order to proceed but Cornelius stopped him a painful thought having struck him He asked with faltering voice

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Is the prize given today, sir?
children.prevalue: Is the prize given today sir

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Yes, the prize for the black tulip.
children.prevalue: Yes the prize for the black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Cornelius's cheek flushed, his whole frame trembled, and the cold sweat stood on his brow.
children.prevalue: Cornelius s cheek flushed his whole frame trembled and the cold sweat stood on his brow

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Alas! sir, he said, all these good people will be as unfortunate as myself, for they will not see the solemnity which they have come to witness, or at least they will see it incompletely.
children.prevalue: Alas sir he said all these good people will be as unfortunate as myself for they will not see the solemnity which they have come to witness or at least they will see it incompletely

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: What is it you mean to say?
children.prevalue: What is it you mean to say

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I mean to say. replied Cornelius, throwing himself back in the carriage, that the black tulip will not be found, except by one whom I know.
children.prevalue: I mean to say replied Cornelius throwing himself back in the carriage that the black tulip will not be found except by one whom I know

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: In this case, said the officer, the person whom you know has found it, for the thing which the whole of Haarlem is looking at at this moment is neither more nor less than the black tulip.
children.prevalue: In this case said the officer the person whom you know has found it for the thing which the whole of Haarlem is looking at at this moment is neither more nor less than the black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The black tulip! replied Van Baerle, thrusting half his body out of the carriage window. Where is it? where is it?
children.prevalue: The black tulip replied Van Baerle thrusting half his body out of the carriage window Where is it where is it

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Down there on the throne,don't you see?
children.prevalue: Down there on the throne don t you see

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I do see it.
children.prevalue: I do see it

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Come along, sir, said the officer. Now we must drive off.
children.prevalue: Come along sir said the officer Now we must drive off

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Oh, have pity, have mercy, sir! said Van Baerle, don't take me away! Let me look once more! Is what I see down there the black tulip? Quite black? Is it possible? Oh, sir, have you seen it? It must have specks, it must be imperfect, it must only be dyed black. Ah! if I were there, I should see it at once. Let me alight, let me see it close, I beg of you.
children.prevalue: Oh have pity have mercy sir said Van Baerle don t take me away Let me look once more Is what I see down there the black tulip Quite black Is it possible Oh sir have you seen it It must have specks it must be imperfect it must only be dyed black Ah if I were there I should see it at once Let me alight let me see it close I beg of you

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Are you mad, Sir? How could I allow such a thing?
children.prevalue: Are you mad Sir How could I allow such a thing

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I implore you.
children.prevalue: I implore you

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: But you forget that you are a prisoner.
children.prevalue: But you forget that you are a prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: It is true I am a prisoner, but I am a man of honour, and I promise you on my word that I will not run away, I will not attempt to escape,only let me see the flower.
children.prevalue: It is true I am a prisoner but I am a man of honour and I promise you on my word that I will not run away I will not attempt to escape only let me see the flower

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: But my orders, Sir, my orders. And the officer again made the driver a sign to proceed.
children.prevalue: But my orders Sir my orders And the officer again made the driver a sign to proceed

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Cornelius stopped him once more.
children.prevalue: Cornelius stopped him once more

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Oh, be forbearing, be generous! my whole life depends upon your pity. Alas! perhaps it will not be much longer. You don't know, sir, what I suffer. You don't know the struggle going on in my heart and mind. For after all, Cornelius cried in despair, if this were my tulip, if it were the one which has been stolen from Rosa! Oh, I must alight, sir! I must see the flower! You may kill me afterwards if you like, but I will see it, I must see it.
children.prevalue: Oh be forbearing be generous my whole life depends upon your pity Alas perhaps it will not be much longer You don t know sir what I suffer You don t know the struggle going on in my heart and mind For after all Cornelius cried in despair if this were my tulip if it were the one which has been stolen from Rosa Oh I must alight sir I must see the flower You may kill me afterwards if you like but I will see it I must see it

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Be quiet, unfortunate man, and come quickly back into the carriage, for here is the escort of his Highness the Stadtholder, and if the Prince observed any disturbance, or heard any noise, it would be ruin to me, as well as to you.
children.prevalue: Be quiet unfortunate man and come quickly back into the carriage for here is the escort of his Highness the Stadtholder and if the Prince observed any disturbance or heard any noise it would be ruin to me as well as to you

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Van Baerle, more afraid for his companion than himself, threw himself back into the carriage, but he could only keep quiet for half a minute, and the first twenty horsemen had scarcely passed when he again leaned out of the carriage window, gesticulating imploringly towards the Stadtholder at the very moment when he passed.
children.prevalue: Van Baerle more afraid for his companion than himself threw himself back into the carriage but he could only keep quiet for half a minute and the first twenty horsemen had scarcely passed when he again leaned out of the carriage window gesticulating imploringly towards the Stadtholder at the very moment when he passed

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: William, impassible and quiet as usual, was proceeding to the green to fulfil his duty as chairman. He held in his hand the roll of parchment, which, on this festive day, had become his baton.
children.prevalue: William impassible and quiet as usual was proceeding to the green to fulfil his duty as chairman He held in his hand the roll of parchment which on this festive day had become his baton

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Seeing the man gesticulate with imploring mien, and perhaps also recognising the officer who accompanied him, his Highness ordered his carriage to stop.
children.prevalue: Seeing the man gesticulate with imploring mien and perhaps also recognising the officer who accompanied him his Highness ordered his carriage to stop

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: In an instant his snorting steeds stood still, at a distance of about six yards from the carriage in which Van Baerle was caged.
children.prevalue: In an instant his snorting steeds stood still at a distance of about six yards from the carriage in which Van Baerle was caged

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: What is this? the Prince asked the officer, who at the first order of the Stadtholder had jumped out of the carriage, and was respectfully approaching him.
children.prevalue: What is this the Prince asked the officer who at the first order of the Stadtholder had jumped out of the carriage and was respectfully approaching him

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Monseigneur, he cried, this is the prisoner of state whom I have fetched from Loewestein, and whom I have brought to Haarlem according to your Highness's command.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur he cried this is the prisoner of state whom I have fetched from Loewestein and whom I have brought to Haarlem according to your Highness s command

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: What does he want?
children.prevalue: What does he want

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: He entreats for permission to stop here for minute.
children.prevalue: He entreats for permission to stop here for minute

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: To see the black tulip, Monseigneur, said Van Baerle, clasping his hands, and when I have seen it, when I have seen what I desire to know, I am quite ready to die, if die I must; but in dying I shall bless your Highness's mercy for having allowed me to witness the glorification of my work.
children.prevalue: To see the black tulip Monseigneur said Van Baerle clasping his hands and when I have seen it when I have seen what I desire to know I am quite ready to die if die I must but in dying I shall bless your Highness s mercy for having allowed me to witness the glorification of my work

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: It was, indeed, a curious spectacle to see these two men at the windows of their several carriages; the one surrounded by his guards, and all powerful, the other a prisoner and miserable; the one going to mount a throne, the other believing himself to be on his way to the scaffold.
children.prevalue: It was indeed a curious spectacle to see these two men at the windows of their several carriages the one surrounded by his guards and all powerful the other a prisoner and miserable the one going to mount a throne the other believing himself to be on his way to the scaffold

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: William, looking with his cold glance on Cornelius, listened to his anxious and urgent request.
children.prevalue: William looking with his cold glance on Cornelius listened to his anxious and urgent request

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Then addressing himself to the officer, he said,
children.prevalue: Then addressing himself to the officer he said

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Is this person the mutinous prisoner who has attempted to kill his jailer at Loewestein?
children.prevalue: Is this person the mutinous prisoner who has attempted to kill his jailer at Loewestein

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Cornelius heaved a sigh and hung his head. His goodtempered honest face turned pale and red at the same instant. These words of the allpowerful Prince, who by some secret messenger unavailable to other mortals had already been apprised of his crime, seemed to him to forebode not only his doom, but also the refusal of his last request.
children.prevalue: Cornelius heaved a sigh and hung his head His goodtempered honest face turned pale and red at the same instant These words of the allpowerful Prince who by some secret messenger unavailable to other mortals had already been apprised of his crime seemed to him to forebode not only his doom but also the refusal of his last request

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: He did not try to make a struggle, or to defend himself; and he presented to the Prince the affecting spectacle of despairing innocence, like that of a child,a spectacle which was fully understood and felt by the great mind and the great heart of him who observed it.
children.prevalue: He did not try to make a struggle or to defend himself and he presented to the Prince the affecting spectacle of despairing innocence like that of a child a spectacle which was fully understood and felt by the great mind and the great heart of him who observed it

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Allow the prisoner to alight, and let him see the black tulip; it is well worth being seen once.
children.prevalue: Allow the prisoner to alight and let him see the black tulip it is well worth being seen once

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Thank you, Monseigneur, thank you, said Cornelius, nearly swooning with joy, and staggering on the steps of his carriage; had not the officer supported him, our poor friend would have made his thanks to his Highness prostrate on his knees with his forehead in the dust.
children.prevalue: Thank you Monseigneur thank you said Cornelius nearly swooning with joy and staggering on the steps of his carriage had not the officer supported him our poor friend would have made his thanks to his Highness prostrate on his knees with his forehead in the dust

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: After having granted this permission, the Prince proceeded on his way over the green amidst the most enthusiastic acclamations.
children.prevalue: After having granted this permission the Prince proceeded on his way over the green amidst the most enthusiastic acclamations

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: He soon arrived at the platform, and the thunder of cannon shook the air.
children.prevalue: He soon arrived at the platform and the thunder of cannon shook the air

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Van Baerle, led by four guards, who pushed their way through the crowd, sidled up to the black tulip, towards which his gaze was attracted with increasing interest the nearer he approached to it.
children.prevalue: Van Baerle led by four guards who pushed their way through the crowd sidled up to the black tulip towards which his gaze was attracted with increasing interest the nearer he approached to it

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: He saw it at last, that unique flower, which he was to see once and no more. He saw it at the distance of six paces, and was delighted with its perfection and gracefulness; he saw it surrounded by young and beautiful girls, who formed, as it were, a guard of honour for this queen of excellence and purity. And yet, the more he ascertained with his own eyes the perfection of the flower, the more wretched and miserable he felt. He looked all around for some one to whom he might address only one question, but his eyes everywhere met strange faces, and the attention of all was directed towards the chair of state, on which the Stadtholder had seated himself.
children.prevalue: He saw it at last that unique flower which he was to see once and no more He saw it at the distance of six paces and was delighted with its perfection and gracefulness he saw it surrounded by young and beautiful girls who formed as it were a guard of honour for this queen of excellence and purity And yet the more he ascertained with his own eyes the perfection of the flower the more wretched and miserable he felt He looked all around for some one to whom he might address only one question but his eyes everywhere met strange faces and the attention of all was directed towards the chair of state on which the Stadtholder had seated himself

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: William rose, casting a tranquil glance over the enthusiastic crowd, and his keen eyes rested by turns on the three extremities of a triangle formed opposite to him by three persons of very different interests and feelings.
children.prevalue: William rose casting a tranquil glance over the enthusiastic crowd and his keen eyes rested by turns on the three extremities of a triangle formed opposite to him by three persons of very different interests and feelings

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: At one of the angles, Boxtel, trembling with impatience, and quite absorbed in watching the Prince, the guilders, the black tulip, and the crowd.
children.prevalue: At one of the angles Boxtel trembling with impatience and quite absorbed in watching the Prince the guilders the black tulip and the crowd

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: At the other, Cornelius, panting for breath, silent, and his attention, his eyes, his life, his heart, his love, quite concentrated on the black tulip.
children.prevalue: At the other Cornelius panting for breath silent and his attention his eyes his life his heart his love quite concentrated on the black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: And thirdly, standing on a raised step among the maidens of Haarlem, a beautiful Frisian girl, dressed in fine scarlet woollen cloth, embroidered with silver, and covered with a lace veil, which fell in rich folds from her headdress of gold brocade; in one word, Rosa, who, faint and with swimming eyes, was leaning on the arm of one of the officers of William.
children.prevalue: And thirdly standing on a raised step among the maidens of Haarlem a beautiful Frisian girl dressed in fine scarlet woollen cloth embroidered with silver and covered with a lace veil which fell in rich folds from her headdress of gold brocade in one word Rosa who faint and with swimming eyes was leaning on the arm of one of the officers of William

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The Prince then slowly unfolded the parchment, and said, with a calm clear voice, which, although low, made itself perfectly heard amidst the respectful silence, which all at once arrested the breath of fifty thousand spectators.
children.prevalue: The Prince then slowly unfolded the parchment and said with a calm clear voice which although low made itself perfectly heard amidst the respectful silence which all at once arrested the breath of fifty thousand spectators

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: You know what has brought us here?
children.prevalue: You know what has brought us here

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: A prize of one hundred thousand guilders has been promised to whosoever should grow the black tulip.
children.prevalue: A prize of one hundred thousand guilders has been promised to whosoever should grow the black tulip

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: The black tulip has been grown; here it is before your eyes, coming up to all the conditions required by the programme of the Horticultural Society of Haarlem.
children.prevalue: The black tulip has been grown here it is before your eyes coming up to all the conditions required by the programme of the Horticultural Society of Haarlem

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The history of its production, and the name of its grower, will be inscribed in the book of honour of the city.
children.prevalue: The history of its production and the name of its grower will be inscribed in the book of honour of the city

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Let the person approach to whom the black tulip belongs.
children.prevalue: Let the person approach to whom the black tulip belongs

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: In pronouncing these words, the Prince, to judge of the effect they produced, surveyed with his eagle eye the three extremities of the triangle.
children.prevalue: In pronouncing these words the Prince to judge of the effect they produced surveyed with his eagle eye the three extremities of the triangle

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: He saw Boxtel rushing forward. He saw Cornelius make an involuntary movement; and lastly he saw the officer who was taking care of Rosa lead, or rather push her forward towards him.
children.prevalue: He saw Boxtel rushing forward He saw Cornelius make an involuntary movement and lastly he saw the officer who was taking care of Rosa lead or rather push her forward towards him

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: At the sight of Rosa, a double cry arose on the right and left of the Prince.
children.prevalue: At the sight of Rosa a double cry arose on the right and left of the Prince

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Boxtel, thunderstruck, and Cornelius, in joyful amazement, both exclaimed,
children.prevalue: Boxtel thunderstruck and Cornelius in joyful amazement both exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Rosa! Rosa!
children.prevalue: Rosa Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: This tulip is yours, is it not, my child? said the Prince.
children.prevalue: This tulip is yours is it not my child said the Prince

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Yes, Monseigneur, stammered Rosa, whose striking beauty excited a general murmur of applause.
children.prevalue: Yes Monseigneur stammered Rosa whose striking beauty excited a general murmur of applause

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Oh! muttered Cornelius, she has then belied me, when she said this flower was stolen from her. Oh! that's why she left Loewestein. Alas! am I then forgotten, betrayed by her whom I thought my best friend on earth?
children.prevalue: Oh muttered Cornelius she has then belied me when she said this flower was stolen from her Oh that s why she left Loewestein Alas am I then forgotten betrayed by her whom I thought my best friend on earth

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Oh! sighed Boxtel, I am lost.
children.prevalue: Oh sighed Boxtel I am lost

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: This tulip, continued the Prince, will therefore bear the name of its producer, and figure in the catalogue under the title, Tulipa nigra Rosa Barlaensis, because of the name Van Baerle, which will henceforth be the name of this damsel.
children.prevalue: This tulip continued the Prince will therefore bear the name of its producer and figure in the catalogue under the title Tulipa nigra Rosa Barlaensis because of the name Van Baerle which will henceforth be the name of this damsel

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: And at the same time William took Rosa's hand, and placed it in that of a young man, who rushed forth, pale and beyond himself with joy, to the foot of the throne saluting alternately the Prince and his bride; and who with a grateful look to heaven, returned his thanks to the Giver of all this happiness.
children.prevalue: And at the same time William took Rosa s hand and placed it in that of a young man who rushed forth pale and beyond himself with joy to the foot of the throne saluting alternately the Prince and his bride and who with a grateful look to heaven returned his thanks to the Giver of all this happiness

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: At the same moment there fell at the feet of the President van Systens another man, struck down by a very different emotion.
children.prevalue: At the same moment there fell at the feet of the President van Systens another man struck down by a very different emotion

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Boxtel, crushed by the failure of his hopes, lay senseless on the ground.
children.prevalue: Boxtel crushed by the failure of his hopes lay senseless on the ground

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: When they raised him, and examined his pulse and his heart, he was quite dead.
children.prevalue: When they raised him and examined his pulse and his heart he was quite dead

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: This incident did not much disturb the festival, as neither the Prince nor the President seemed to mind it much.
children.prevalue: This incident did not much disturb the festival as neither the Prince nor the President seemed to mind it much

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Cornelius started back in dismay, when in the thief, in the pretended Jacob, he recognised his neighbour, Isaac Boxtel, whom, in the innocence of his heart, he had not for one instant suspected of such a wicked action.
children.prevalue: Cornelius started back in dismay when in the thief in the pretended Jacob he recognised his neighbour Isaac Boxtel whom in the innocence of his heart he had not for one instant suspected of such a wicked action

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Then, to the sound of trumpets, the procession marched back without any change in its order, except that Boxtel was now dead, and that Cornelius and Rosa were walking triumphantly side by side and hand in hand.
children.prevalue: Then to the sound of trumpets the procession marched back without any change in its order except that Boxtel was now dead and that Cornelius and Rosa were walking triumphantly side by side and hand in hand

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: On their arriving at the Hotel de Ville, the Prince, pointing with his finger to the purse with the hundred thousand guilders, said to Cornelius,
children.prevalue: On their arriving at the Hotel de Ville the Prince pointing with his finger to the purse with the hundred thousand guilders said to Cornelius

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: It is difficult to say by whom this money is gained, by you or by Rosa; for if you have found the black tulip, she has nursed it and brought it into flower. It would therefore be unjust to consider it as her dowry; it is the gift of the town of Haarlem to the tulip.
children.prevalue: It is difficult to say by whom this money is gained by you or by Rosa for if you have found the black tulip she has nursed it and brought it into flower It would therefore be unjust to consider it as her dowry it is the gift of the town of Haarlem to the tulip

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Cornelius wondered what the Prince was driving at. The latter continued,
children.prevalue: Cornelius wondered what the Prince was driving at The latter continued

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I give to Rosa the sum of a hundred thousand guilders, which she has fairly earned, and which she can offer to you. They are the reward of her love, her courage, and her honesty. As to you, Sirthanks to Rosa again, who has furnished the proofs of your innocence
children.prevalue: I give to Rosa the sum of a hundred thousand guilders which she has fairly earned and which she can offer to you They are the reward of her love her courage and her honesty As to you Sirthanks to Rosa again who has furnished the proofs of your innocence

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: And, saying these words, the Prince handed to Cornelius that flyleaf of the Bible on which was written the letter of Cornelius de Witt, and in which the third bulb had been wrapped,
children.prevalue: And saying these words the Prince handed to Cornelius that flyleaf of the Bible on which was written the letter of Cornelius de Witt and in which the third bulb had been wrapped

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: As to you, it has come to light that you were imprisoned for a crime which you had not committed. This means, that you are not only free, but that your property will be restored to you; as the property of an innocent man cannot be confiscated. Cornelius van Baerle, you are the godson of Cornelius de Witt and the friend of his brother John. Remain worthy of the name you have received from one of them, and of the friendship you have enjoyed with the other. The two De Witts, wrongly judged and wrongly punished in a moment of popular error, were two great citizens, of whom Holland is now proud.
children.prevalue: As to you it has come to light that you were imprisoned for a crime which you had not committed This means that you are not only free but that your property will be restored to you as the property of an innocent man cannot be confiscated Cornelius van Baerle you are the godson of Cornelius de Witt and the friend of his brother John Remain worthy of the name you have received from one of them and of the friendship you have enjoyed with the other The two De Witts wrongly judged and wrongly punished in a moment of popular error were two great citizens of whom Holland is now proud

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The Prince, after these last words, which contrary to his custom, he pronounced with a voice full of emotion, gave his hands to the lovers to kiss, whilst they were kneeling before him.
children.prevalue: The Prince after these last words which contrary to his custom he pronounced with a voice full of emotion gave his hands to the lovers to kiss whilst they were kneeling before him

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Then heaving a sigh, he said,
children.prevalue: Then heaving a sigh he said

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Alas! you are very happy, who, dreaming only of what perhaps is the true glory of Holland, and forms especially her true happiness, do not attempt to acquire for her anything beyond new colours of tulips.
children.prevalue: Alas you are very happy who dreaming only of what perhaps is the true glory of Holland and forms especially her true happiness do not attempt to acquire for her anything beyond new colours of tulips

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: And, casting a glance towards that point of the compass where France lay, as if he saw new clouds gathering there, he entered his carriage and drove off.
children.prevalue: And casting a glance towards that point of the compass where France lay as if he saw new clouds gathering there he entered his carriage and drove off

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Cornelius started on the same day for Dort with Rosa, who sent her lover's old housekeeper as a messenger to her father, to apprise him of all that had taken place.
children.prevalue: Cornelius started on the same day for Dort with Rosa who sent her lover s old housekeeper as a messenger to her father to apprise him of all that had taken place

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Those who, thanks to our description, have learned the character of old Gryphus, will comprehend that it was hard for him to become reconciled to his soninlaw. He had not yet forgotten the blows which he had received in that famous encounter. To judge from the weals which he counted, their number, he said, amounted to fortyone; but at last, in order, as he declared, not to be less generous than his Highness the Stadtholder, he consented to make his peace.
children.prevalue: Those who thanks to our description have learned the character of old Gryphus will comprehend that it was hard for him to become reconciled to his soninlaw He had not yet forgotten the blows which he had received in that famous encounter To judge from the weals which he counted their number he said amounted to fortyone but at last in order as he declared not to be less generous than his Highness the Stadtholder he consented to make his peace

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Appointed to watch over the tulips, the old man made the rudest keeper of flowers in the whole of the Seven Provinces.
children.prevalue: Appointed to watch over the tulips the old man made the rudest keeper of flowers in the whole of the Seven Provinces

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: It was indeed a sight to see him watching the obnoxious moths and butterflies, killing slugs, and driving away the hungry bees.
children.prevalue: It was indeed a sight to see him watching the obnoxious moths and butterflies killing slugs and driving away the hungry bees

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: As he had heard Boxtel's story, and was furious at having been the dupe of the pretended Jacob, he destroyed the sycamore behind which the envious Isaac had spied into the garden; for the plot of ground belonging to him had been bought by Cornelius, and taken into his own garden.
children.prevalue: As he had heard Boxtel s story and was furious at having been the dupe of the pretended Jacob he destroyed the sycamore behind which the envious Isaac had spied into the garden for the plot of ground belonging to him had been bought by Cornelius and taken into his own garden

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Rosa, growing not only in beauty, but in wisdom also, after two years of her married life, could read and write so well that she was able to undertake by herself the education of two beautiful children which she had borne in 1674 and 1675, both in May, the month of flowers.
children.prevalue: Rosa growing not only in beauty but in wisdom also after two years of her married life could read and write so well that she was able to undertake by herself the education of two beautiful children which she had borne in 1674 and 1675 both in May the month of flowers

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: As a matter of course, one was a boy, the other a girl, the former being called Cornelius, the other Rosa.
children.prevalue: As a matter of course one was a boy the other a girl the former being called Cornelius the other Rosa

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Van Baerle remained faithfully attached to Rosa and to his tulips. The whole of his life was devoted to the happiness of his wife and the culture of flowers, in the latter of which occupations he was so successful that a great number of his varieties found a place in the catalogue of Holland.
children.prevalue: Van Baerle remained faithfully attached to Rosa and to his tulips The whole of his life was devoted to the happiness of his wife and the culture of flowers in the latter of which occupations he was so successful that a great number of his varieties found a place in the catalogue of Holland

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The two principal ornaments of his drawingroom were those two leaves from the Bible of Cornelius de Witt, in large golden frames; one of them containing the letter in which his godfather enjoined him to burn the correspondence of the Marquis de Louvois, and the other his own will, in which he bequeathed to Rosa his bulbs under condition that she should marry a young man of from twentysix to twentyeight years, who loved her and whom she loved, a condition which was scrupulously fulfilled, although, or rather because, Cornelius did not die.
children.prevalue: The two principal ornaments of his drawingroom were those two leaves from the Bible of Cornelius de Witt in large golden frames one of them containing the letter in which his godfather enjoined him to burn the correspondence of the Marquis de Louvois and the other his own will in which he bequeathed to Rosa his bulbs under condition that she should marry a young man of from twentysix to twentyeight years who loved her and whom she loved a condition which was scrupulously fulfilled although or rather because Cornelius did not die

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: And to ward off any envious attempts of another Isaac Boxtel, he wrote over his door the lines which Grotius had, on the day of his flight, scratched on the walls of his prison:
children.prevalue: And to ward off any envious attempts of another Isaac Boxtel he wrote over his door the lines which Grotius had on the day of his flight scratched on the walls of his prison

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Sometimes one has suffered so much that he has the right never to be able to say, 'I am too happy.'
children.prevalue: Sometimes one has suffered so much that he has the right never to be able to say I am too happy
